sentences.text: In a twist, judges overturned a 2013 ruling, though they didn't shut down the program, urging Congress to take charge instead.
The NSA's surveillance activities—exposed by Edward Snowden, who's now in Russia—involved collecting details like phone numbers and call times, but not the conversations themselves.
They reportedly also spied on European entities, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel.
Germany has drastically cut back on NSA-related internet surveillance, citing a lack of clear justification for those searches.
Gordon Adams from American University mentioned that Congress might uphold the court's decision soon.
The House will vote on the USA Freedom Act, aimed at ending the NSA's bulk data collection.
Yet, some senators prefer to extend Section 215 of the USA Patriot Act, allowing the data collection to continue.
This section, set to expire in June, is the key for the NSA’s operations to carry on.

Recently, the 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals in New York weighed in after New York District Judge William Pauley dismissed a challenge from the ACLU, which claimed the NSA's call tracking violated the Constitution.
According to the 97-page ruling, a part of the USA Patriot Act that lets the FBI collect business records for counterterrorism cannot justifiably be used to collect domestic call records in bulk.
However, the court didn’t address the program's constitutionality, originally launched post-9/11.
The Snowden leaks of June 2013 ignited global outrage, even as US officials insisted the program was legal.
These practices, okayed secretly by a national security court since 2006, are set to expire on June 1.
House leaders are leaning towards passing a bill to stop bulk phone record collection and introduce laws aimed at better protecting civil liberties.
But Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell wants to extend the Patriot Act, thus keeping the bulk collection going.

The White House is on board with finding an "alternative mechanism" to retain the program's essential features without the government holding onto all the bulk data, says Ned Price from the White House National Security Council.
What's this bank levy all about, what's the big deal, and why are they hiking it now?
Basically, it's a yearly tax on the debt of UK banks, which covers things like deposited funds, but there are some exceptions.
Originally, the plan was to set the levy rate at 0.05% in 2011. However, in February, the Treasury decided to bump it up to a standard rate of 0.075% starting in May.
They then nudged it to 0.078% in March and are planning another increase to 0.088% from January.

So, what's the deal with this levy? It's got a two-part purpose: one, to discourage banks from relying on risky borrowing practices—which was a huge factor in the 2008 crisis—and two, to rake in a hefty amount of cash.
Can it help chip away at the budget deficit? Well, the Treasury figures this levy will pull in about £2.6 billion a year.
That's about 2.1% of the budget deficit forecasted by the Office for Budget Responsibility for this year.
And it's roughly 19% of the pre-tax profits made by the five big UK banks over the 12 months up to September, though, more banks are taxed under this levy than just those five.
Now, about the borrowing they're looking to curb: Banks traditionally lend out money from deposits made by people and businesses.
But in the past decade, they've been getting creative, hitting up global markets to borrow trillions through new, tricky methods.
Unlike regular deposits, this kind of money doesn't have a natural limit because it can come from all over and get recycled among banks.
A lot of this borrowing was on a short leash, meaning banks had to go back to the market for refinancing super frequently.
When the financial crisis hit, investors got jittery about possible bank defaults, and this led to a panic where they just stopped lending.
Even profitable banks faced collapse because they couldn't refinance. Why let retail deposits off the hook with this levy?
The image of a bank run, with folks queuing down the street to pull their money out—think Northern Rock—is daunting.
Since the 1930s, governments have been insuring most people's deposits to stop these kinds of runs among depositors.
You know, it was pretty unexpected. The commodities markets, and I didn't see it coming when OPEC decided to cut production at their meeting in Algiers.
They're still facing a tough road to actually make a lasting dent in oil prices, though.
The market wasn't betting on this—they were gearing up for more chaos like at the Doha meeting last April, where OPEC and other oil exporters struggled to agree.
But this time, they made some headway. The backdrop here is the significant drop in crude oil prices, now less than half of what they were in June 2014.
This slump has hit OPEC countries hard in the wallet and their economies. Take Saudi Arabia, for example.
Back in 2012, their government had a nice surplus of 12% of GDP. Last year? A 16% deficit. Angola, too, went from a 7% economic growth in 2013 down to 3% last year.
And don't even get started on Venezuela—their woes go beyond just oil prices, worsened by a political crisis.
For nearly a couple of years now, OPEC countries have been feeling the squeeze financially.
While OPEC doesn't cover the entire market—big players like the US, Russia, China, and Canada aren't members—they do control about 40% of the global market.
Historically, their move has been to cut production when prices drop, often led by Saudi Arabia, the biggest player in the group.
This year's been tricky, though. With Iran bouncing back from sanctions due to its nuclear program, they're eager to grab more market share.
Saudi Arabia wasn't too keen on cutting its production unless Iran did too—a bit of a deadlock fueled by longstanding geopolitical tensions between these Gulf giants.
That was what torpedoed the talks in Doha back in April. But now, things have shifted.
Iran has already ramped up production and could push it further, though it's not as easy as it was post-sanctions. Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia seems to have eased up on its position somewhat.
Picture this: you’ve landed in Monaco, ready to catch all the thrills of Formula 1 racing, and you can choose your own adventure.
How would you dive in? Maybe you see yourself on a neoclassical balcony in Monte Carlo, looking over Casino Square with a glass of champagne in hand.
Or perhaps you're at a circuit-side restaurant, indulging in lobster and exquisite wine as the cars whiz past.
You might be drawn to the Paddock Club, where a grandstand view awaits along with a spot at the Monaco Yacht Club.
On the other hand, imagine being down in the thick of it, bent over a roaring Formula 1 car's exhaust, decked out in a race suit, sweating through a toasty 80 degrees.

Chris Rea, who isn't just a Jordan mechanic but also a singer-songwriter with millions of albums sold, reminisces about his own experience: “I even got to wear my own suit and helmet in the garage. Skipping the VIP stuff, I ended up managing Eddie Irvine's right-rear tire.
Did it a few times, but Monaco was the toughest.” Cue 1995, the Monaco Grand Prix.

Eddie Irvine hits the pits, right-rear tire acting up, and Rea’s on the job. “The wheel was hot as anything, and working up a sweat in that gear was exhausting, especially with the awful hangover I had.
Thanks, Eddie Jordan, for the chance—and the hangover too.” Monaco wasn't just about mingling for Rea; his fascination started at home, glued to the TV.
“It was a lazy Sunday afternoon, watching the race from Monte Carlo. Stirling Moss was leading, miles ahead.
Watching him fly down the hill, I turned to my dad and asked about these quirky things, and he said, ‘Squale—sharks.’ I was just a kid, around eight.
Wanted to know about the bold color, and he called it ‘blood red.’ Curious about the driver, I learned he was like a kinder Darth Vader with a modern helmet.
His name was Wolfgang Alexander von Trips, and he lived in a castle. That moment, that was the beginning for me.”
For 70 years, my dad's been carrying the weight of what happened with his ship, HMS Hebe, back in June 1940.
He was the chief engine room artificer during the Dunkirk evacuation. The Hebe was stationed in Dover as a control vessel, making three trips to Dunkirk from May 27 to June 4.
"It was scorching, dangerous, and downright terrifying with those constant German air raids," Harold Biles remembered, who turned 28 amid the chaos.
"We were about 200 meters off Dunkirk's beach, surrounded by a sea of soldiers.
There we were on the water, and there they were on the beach, desperately trying to reach us."
The bombing and shellfire never seemed to let up, though night offered a bit of a break—some much-needed rest.

Just after midnight on May 29, 1940, the captain of HMS Hebe decided to send a small boat to Dunkirk’s beach to fetch Lord John Gort, the commander-in-chief of the British Expeditionary Force, and bring him back to England.
"As we bolted back to Dover, I can still picture Lord Gort standing by the guardrail, bracing himself against the wild waves.
He was quite a sight in his red-trimmed uniform, but he looked defeated, his head hanging low."
There were no cheers for the evacuation of 330,000 men away from Nazi POW camps.
To him, it was a loss. He'd lost an army. The German assaults, along with the sheer trauma and exhaustion, took a toll on the crew of the Hebe and others involved in the evacuation.
My father recalls seeing early symptoms of what we'd now call post-traumatic stress—back then, dismissed as "lack of moral fiber."
"While we were loading supplies in Dover, a low-flying RAF plane sent the whole dock into panic.
One seaman looked up, screamed, and just crumpled right there. Three or four others followed suit."
Later, an ill-thought-out order directed anyone feeling too stressed from the previous week's events to leave the ship and report to the dockside for hospitalization.
Roughly 20 men stepped off, and Dad still remembers their relieved smiles as they crossed the gangway.
The Department for Transport has announced plans to buy up to 60 new trains, each capable of cruising at 225 mph.
They aim to award the contract, which also includes maintenance, by 2019. These trains are earmarked for the first phase of the HS2 project, which plans to link London and Birmingham by 2026.
Construction is set to kick off later this year, slashing rail travel between the two cities by 32 minutes.
The project’s second phase, shaped like a Y, will have two parts. First, the Birmingham to Crewe line is expected to start running in 2027.
The final stretch to a new station at Manchester Airport will wrap up six years after that.
This second phase requires separate contracts for train supply. Transport Secretary Chris Grayling emphasized that the new railway would handle over 300,000 travelers a day.
He mentioned, "Building and maintaining these trains will create hundreds of jobs and offer significant opportunities for British businesses and suppliers."
Grayling also noted the broader impact of HS2’s construction, predicting 25,000 jobs and 2,000 apprenticeships, with efforts to involve UK suppliers to boost their contract-winning chances.
The formal process begins in spring 2017, preceded by a launch on Friday, allowing interested companies to dive into the bidding details.
Invitations to tender are slated for 2018. Hitachi Rail Europe intends to bid for the HS2 train contract.
Based in London, they manufacture trains at their Newton Aycliffe site in County Durham.
Nick Hughes, their sales director, commented, "Our HS2 trains will be British-built for Britain, blending Japanese Shinkansen technology with local manufacturing know-how."
Gordon Wakeford from Siemens Mobility called this large-scale manufacturing contract "exciting news" for the rail industry, with potential UK supply chain benefits.
Siemens recently ramped up its focus on HS2 by appointing two executives to lead its rolling stock bid team.
However, HS2 isn’t without its critics, who argue it poses threats to large swathes of the English countryside.

This year has been incredibly tough for any commissioner, as the NFL edges close to an annual revenue of £16 billion ($25 billion) and pushes ahead with expansion aims in Europe, especially in London.
Meanwhile, Commissioner Goodell pulls in around £26 million ($40 million) a year, while American Football's professional scene grows both in fame and controversy.

Back in 2014, fifty NFL players were arrested for various offenses, ranging from Tennessee's Shonn Greene's illegal parking in a disabled spot to Minnesota's Adrian Peterson being charged with child abuse.
Included in these were five domestic violence cases, most notably involving Baltimore's Ray Rice, who was caught on camera assaulting his fiancée in an elevator.
Goodell took a lot of heat for how the NFL handled the Rice incident, which led to a major report by former FBI director Robert Mueller, slamming the league's management.
These issues have lingered into 2015, with four new player arrests, covering charges like domestic violence and rape.

Yet, amid all this chaos, the NFL's business is booming. Scandals like those with Rice and Peterson eventually faded into the background, and stadium attendance skyrocketed, with over 17 million fans showing up for the 256 regular-season games—the highest since 2008.
TV viewership hit record highs, too. Although youth football participation is dipping due to concussion worries, NFL fandom keeps growing stronger than ever, both at home and abroad.
The annual Harris Report still ranks the NFL as America's favorite sport by a wide margin, far outpacing Major League Baseball and college football combined.
New figures from sports market research group Repucom reveal TV networks airing the NFL saw audience boosts compared to 2013, with significant jumps for both Thursday and Monday Night Football.
Plus, more than 47 million people tuned in for the NFL’s College Draft, sparking 9.6 million tweets, all without a single pass or tackle in sight.
In tourism-dependent Antigua, a nasty disease has decimated nearly half of the island's majestic coconut palms, leaving behind a rather eerie sight of headless trunks.
Lethal yellowing, which wreaked havoc on coconut trees in Florida and Jamaica, has landed here, threatening Antigua's culture and economy.
With coconut products forming a staple in local cuisine, beauty routines, and traditional remedies, the impact is widespread.
Barbara Japal, president of the island's Horticultural Society, estimates about 45% of Antigua's coconut palms have vanished.
Street vendor Julian Rose, who’s been selling coconut water for $3.70 (£2.40) a bottle for the past four years, feels the pinch.
His supply—and his earnings—have been slashed in half over the last year. "I've kept my prices the same—people aren't willing to pay more," he says.
The official advice is to swiftly cut down and burn any palm showing symptoms like premature fruit drop and yellowing fronds that eventually fall off.
But with stretched resources, the government couldn’t control the disease since its detection in 2012.
"It hits tourism because, as we say, the 'palm is the charm,' and it really mars the seascape," Mrs. Japal explains to the BBC.
"They look like beheaded soldiers—it's shocking and almost feels disrespectful.
Coconuts are vital here; they're used in cooking, and the oil is applied to skin and hair.
While not mainstream medicine, the coconut oil is cherished for healing skin and cleansing the body."
Lethal yellowing spreads through an insect that hops from plant to plant, which Mrs. Japal suspects came with imported trees.
Since 2012, importing palms has been banned. "We had lots of plants brought in years ago," Mrs. Japal points out.
"There's a plant protection unit, but who checks every container of 3,000 trees?"
She mentions that underfunding has left the staff unable to cope. "Affected palms aren't properly disposed of unless private individuals step in."

Although there's no cure for lethal yellowing, trees can be treated with quarterly injections of the antibiotic oxytetracycline (OTC). "Local folks don't use OTC; it's just too pricey," Mrs. Japal notes.
Earlier today, George Osborne mentioned that he currently has no plans to cut the top income tax rate further, though he didn’t slam the door shut on the idea either.
Back in 2013, the coalition government had already knocked the rate down from 50% to 45%.
Ed Balls, Labour's shadow chancellor, didn't hold back, criticizing Osborne for not flat-out rejecting further cuts.
During an interview on Sky News's Murnaghan show, Osborne was asked if he planned to drop the tax rate by another 5% for those making over £150,000.
His reply was straightforward: “That’s not our plan.” Yet, when urged to completely rule it out, he dodged a bit, saying, “You can judge us by what we say we want to do.
Our aim is to lift the tax-free personal allowance to £12,500, ensuring that full-time workers on the minimum wage won’t pay income tax, thus helping millions.
And for higher-earners, our priority is to push the higher rate threshold up to £50,000.
Those are our big tax promises for the next Parliament.” Later, Prime Minister David Cameron backed him up, stating, “It’s not our policy.

We want to increase the basic threshold to £12,500, which will take another million people out of income tax and cut taxes for 30 million.” However, Ed Balls fired back, saying, "When George Osborne cut the top rate from 50p to 45p, we figured he and Cameron aimed to slash it to 40p eventually.
If they go ahead, it's just more tax breaks for the richest.” He urged them to clear the air and rule out further reductions.
These talks aren’t just about income tax, though; they touch on national insurance and business taxes too.
Meanwhile, Liberal Democrat minister David Laws chimed in, accusing the Conservatives of claiming more credit than they deserved for the raises in personal allowance.
Laws, who once served as the chief secretary to the Treasury, pointed out that neither the prime minister nor the chancellor was eager about it in their discussions with the Lib Dems.
He made it clear that his party aims to “go further and faster” in boosting the allowance soon.

Osborne, for his part, has marked raising the allowance as one of his “major tax commitments.” Looking at the numbers, the tax-free personal allowance is set to rise from £10,600 in 2015-16 to £10,800 in 2016-17, and then to £11,000 in 2017-18.
Laws also told Pienaar’s Politics on BBC Radio 5 live that these moves are largely credited to his party’s efforts.
Yoan Gouffran kicked things off by netting the first goal from close range. Then, a messy scene around the goal led to Henri Lansbury accidentally scoring for Newcastle with an own goal.
Despite Newcastle’s win, the celebration was tempered by a setback: Dwight Gayle, their top scorer, had to leave the game after 33 minutes due to an injury.
Things didn’t look great for Aston Villa either; Scott Hogan was stretchered off after a late-game incident, marking their ninth straight league match without a win.
Hogan, who they brought in from Brentford for £12 million back in January, took a nasty fall during a header attempt when Villa was pushing forward.
For Gayle, leading the Championship with 20 goals, it seemed like that pesky hamstring issue—which had already sidelined him for six matches—had flared up again.
Villa managed to hang on initially, sitting six points clear of the relegation zone despite only snagging one point in 2017.

They were neck and neck with Newcastle until they slipped behind. Birkir Bjarnason, the Icelandic midfielder, gave it his best shot for Villa but couldn’t capitalize on Hogan’s flick-on, nor get past Karl Darlow’s solid save.
Newcastle seized the opportunity after Gayle’s exit: a Matt Ritchie cross went unhandled by Villa, paving the way for Gouffran to hit his mark.
From there, Newcastle seemed on the brink of widening their lead, although destiny lent a hand in the form of a second goal that nudged them above Brighton in the standings.
Jamaal Lascelles got hold of a Jonjo Shelvey corner, and his shot bounced off Lansbury into the net from near the post.
Afterwards, Newcastle's manager Rafael Benitez shared his thoughts with BBC Radio Newcastle: "The league's incredibly trying.
Each game poses its own hurdles, and today was no different against a side packed with talented players. They pressed hard early, making it tricky for us to execute our play.
Finding the net was key to opening things up, and after the second goal, spaces started to appear.
We got more opportunities and took control. Dwight was uncomfortable from the get-go, saying he felt something in his hamstring.

We'll need to evaluate how serious it is." On the flip side, Villa manager Steve Bruce spoke to BBC WM: "Scott's injury really capped off a rough night for us, and we're naturally anxious about what we'll find.
He's damaged his ankle, but only X-rays and scans will tell us how bad it is. Losing him would be a real blow.
We just hope it’s not as severe as my gut says it might be. I thought in the first half, we performed well.
Newcastle hadn't really challenged our goal, and yet we let a soft one in. Then we handed them another early in the second half, and that was just unlucky."
The commission's taking a close look at the tax setups given to U.S. companies that have their HQs in Europe.
Next month, the EU will announce its verdict on Apple, which might end up with a massive tax bill running into billions.
The commission assured that there’s "no bias against U.S. companies" in these probes.
A Wednesday report from the U.S. regulator, though, warned that Brussels could end up acting like a "supra-national tax authority," possibly overhauling member states' tax rules.
Critically, the report claims that Brussels uses different standards when dealing with U.S. companies, calling the possible fines "deeply troubling."
Apple supposedly dodged billions in taxes by tucking away profits in Ireland thanks to a deal with Irish officials.
JP Morgan, working as Apple's investment banker, hinted that in a worst-case scenario, the bill might skyrocket to $19 billion (£14.3 billion).
Beyond Apple, several companies like Amazon and Starbucks are also under the European Commission's microscope for alleged tax dodging.
Just last year, it was found that Starbucks and Fiat received sweet tax deals from the Netherlands.
Now, the EU's executive body is looking into whether Apple scored some exclusive tax perks in Ireland, contrary to EU state aid regulations.
The U.S. government earlier voiced its disapproval of Brussels’ probe, claiming it specifically targets U.S. firms.
Recently, the Treasury Department asked Brussels to rethink its actions against U.S. companies such as Apple, Starbucks, and Amazon, warning of hefty cross-border tax impacts.

Robert Stack, a deputy from the Treasury, expressed in a blog post that these investigations are a big deal for the global tax system and the G20's tax avoidance fight, alongside attempts to boost tax clarity for growth and investment.
He suggested that any charge from the European Commission might count as a foreign tax credit in the U.S., which could dial down these companies' tax bills back home.
The Treasury's mulling over what to do if the commission keeps on its current course.
The commission insists it plays fair, applying EU laws equally to all companies in Europe.
Apple, on its side, has said there’s no "special tax deal with the Irish government."
"We have received no preferential treatment from Irish authorities," the company claimed.
In September 2014, the tragic discovery of 14-year-old Alice Gross's body in the River Brent in West London shocked the community.
Not long after, authorities found the body of Arnis Zalkalns, a builder from Latvia, nearby.
An inquest is now digging into whether government and police missteps played a role in this tragedy, particularly questioning why Zalkalns, with his history, lived in the UK without scrutiny.
During the inquest at the Royal Courts of Justice, Alice's mother, Rosalind Hodgkiss, delivered a heartfelt statement.
Her family, she said, is eager to find out if the systems meant to monitor foreign offenders and facilitate cross-border information sharing are actually working.
"While we know these systems might have evolved," she said, "it's shocking that someone with a murder conviction could slip through the cracks without any monitoring.
It's left us doubting our country's ability to keep its citizens safe. The Home Office and police must ensure this kind of oversight never happens again."
Rosalind talked about Alice, painting a picture of a vibrant, popular girl who was sharp and witty, with a passion for songwriting.
She also shared the "immeasurable devastation" that Alice's death has brought to their family, admitting that there are many questions they'll never have answers to.

Alice disappeared on August 28, 2014, after taking a walk by the canal. Her body was found a month later, after what the Metropolitan Police dubbed their most extensive investigation since the 7/7 bombings in 2005.
Pathologist Dr. Ashley Fegan-Earl testified that Alice was found in the River Brent, her body tied in a fetal position, weighed down with heavy objects like bricks, logs, and a bicycle wheel.
The conclusion was harrowing: she had been sexually assaulted and asphyxiated, likely by someone larger exerting pressure on her torso.
Zalkalns, the prime suspect in Alice's murder, would have faced charges if he hadn't died.
It was revealed he had a previous conviction for killing his wife in Latvia back in 1998.
Lisa Passey, 28, and her ex-partner Wayne Dale, 45, are facing trial after leaving their two-year-old son, Kian, and another child unsupervised while they spent time with a friend.
Appearing at Worcester Crown Court, Ms. Passey admitted, "It was down to me and Wayne... it's our fault."
Both have denied charges of gross negligence manslaughter as the case unfolds. We'll share updates as they emerge from Hereford and Worcester.
In her testimony, Ms. Passey broke down more than once while recounting the events surrounding Kian's death at their home in Kyreside, Tenbury Wells.
Speaking through tears, she said, "I don't want any pity. I was stupid for not going upstairs."
The court was told that on the day of the incident, Kian had been left in the bath while Ms. Passey was outside in the garden with a friend, smoking and drinking coffee.
Mr. Dale joined them briefly to smoke and to "burn" a CD for the same friend. Kian was later discovered unresponsive in an overflowing bathtub by Mr. Dale.
The cause of death was determined to be drowning, with soap bubbles reportedly found in the toddler's lungs.
Evidence presented in court suggested he may have accidentally turned on the taps while left alone upstairs.
Ms. Passey faced scrutiny over inconsistencies in her accounts, including telling a doctor the bath had been empty at the time.
"I was all over the place," she admitted when questioned by prosecution barrister Jonas Hankin QC.
"If you'd gone through something like this—losing a child—you’d understand. You’re still trying to grieve."
She added that Mr. Dale often left Kian alone in the bath, claiming it was normally "just for a few minutes." The trial continues.
Parliament's just given the green light to send over a formal invite, and the prince needs to say "yes" before he can take the throne.
King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who was beloved by many, passed away on October 13, throwing Thailand into deep mourning.
Even though the prince was next in line, he reportedly wants to hold off for about a year, giving folks time to grieve.
Some commentators point out this leaves Thailand in a bit of a constitutional limbo, as normally the heir would step up right away.
There have been concerns voiced by high-ranking officials about whether the crown prince can measure up to his father’s legacy—a reign that spanned 70 years.
The monarchy isn't just symbolic; it plays a key political role. Particularly during turbulent times, like the 2014 military coup, King Bhumibol was a pillar of unity.
The head of parliament, the National Legislative Assembly, is expected to touch base with the prince soon to formally invite him.
Once he accepts, they'll make the succession public, though when exactly remains up in the air.

Prem Tinsulanonda, a former Prime Minister, is acting as regent for now. Royal successions aren't exactly routine in Thailand—the last one was seven decades ago following the mysterious death of the young King Ananda.
His brother Bhumibol was declared king during an emergency parliamentary session that night.
Despite growing curiosity about his sister, Princess Sirindhorn, Crown Prince Vajiralongkorn has held his claim to the throne since 1972.
Thai tradition mainly follows primogeniture, where the eldest son becomes king, but the monarch can pick an heir.
King Bhumibol backed his son unwaveringly. The prince's choice to postpone his ascension adds yet another wrinkle to this unfolding saga.
His actual reasons remain a mystery, as assuming the throne wouldn't have collided with the national mourning period.
Sgt. Brian Wood, who served in the 2004 Iraq conflict, recently shared with the BBC just how damaging the allegations against him and his team have been.
After all, IHAT was shut down following a scandal involving a key lawyer tied to many abuse cases.
Veterans Minister Mark Lancaster commented that although IHAT started with the best intentions, it ended up "completely abused" by some lawyers. Sgt.
Wood, a member of the 1st Princess of Wales' Royal Regiment, told BBC Breakfast that even the Ministry of Defence recognizes the government has "important lessons to learn."
He was particularly critical of the Al-Sweady Inquiry, slamming the serious and unfounded allegations of unlawful killing, mutilation, and mistreatment of prisoners of war.
"Those events simply did not occur, and I don't understand where these claims came from," he said, calling the closure of IHAT "good news."
He pointed out how systemic weaknesses had been exploited and remarked that a more careful vetting of allegations before making them public would have been wiser.
The personal impact on his team has been immense, with careers affected, marriages ended, and PTSD worsened from their battlefield experiences.
On the flip side, former Army Captain Rachel Webster, who was arrested in a raid back in January 2014, wasn't as optimistic about the IHAT shutdown.
She labeled it "too little, too late," telling ITV News, "I hadn’t done anything wrong.
The humiliation was unforgettable, affecting myself and other soldiers and veterans.
It has destroyed lives, including mine." Meanwhile, Mark Lancaster, speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today program, stressed that the government still has to investigate any abuse claims responsibly.
"We cannot simply ignore them," he noted, explaining that without IHAT, UK troops could have faced scrutiny from the International Criminal Court.

He did, however, praise the closure as a "positive" move. IHAT, which began in 2010 to look into allegations from Iraqi civilians against UK service members, had been criticized by the Commons defence committee for being an "unstoppable, self-perpetuating machine" that didn't really consider the military's perspective.
On Friday, the Ministry of Defence announced IHAT would wrap up by summer, handing off any remaining cases to the Royal Navy Police.
In the heart of Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley, a young Syrian boy proudly shows off his creation: a model house made from cardboard.
It has a shiny red roof, bright blue walls, and tiny windows that open and close.
This little house brings out mixed feelings, a nod to the homes they once knew, with such thoughtful details—quite unlike the bleak camp that surrounds him, where windows are a rare luxury.
Here, the schoolroom stands alongside roughly 40 other structures, all fashioned from wooden frames on bare concrete, covered with plastic sheets.
Sometimes the sheeting has random ads printed on them, featuring black-and-white images of men in sunglasses and with trendy stubble.
In the realm of politics, UK Prime Minister David Cameron has suggested taking in refugees directly from camps like these, aiming to discourage hazardous attempts to cross the Mediterranean.
It makes sense in theory, but might be too little, too late. The plan would welcome about 4,000 refugees annually until 2020—not nearly enough to make a big difference.
Just a stone's throw away, over the rolling hills, you can still hear echoes of the conflict—bombings ordered by President Bashar al-Assad on besieged Syrian towns.

Here in Lebanon, they're safer, but comfort is another story. Rats are everywhere, the water’s not safe to drink, and while now the September sun scorches, the winters are harsh, with snow piling up to three feet and freezing temperatures.

These tough conditions push many to consider leaving Lebanon. One man, Mzead al-Ali, is thinking about joining others who've risked everything to move on, hoping to earn money and send it back to his wife and children, including their seven-month-old twins.
Just three days ago, his brother set off for Turkey, and so far, they haven't heard from him.
His mother, fighting back tears, wishes she could talk about it, but instead she keeps her hands over her face.
Technically, this place is designated a temporary settlement, not a refugee camp, but just about everyone calls it one.
There's around a million refugees from Syria in Lebanon now, a staggering number for a country of just four million people.
Nearly a third of them live in camps like this; even those with proper homes face constant hardships.
A government minister mentioned that the burden on Lebanon is almost more than it can bear, and tensions just keep on rising.
Over the years, many Haitians have made their way to the Dominican Republic, often without proper paperwork, hoping to escape the grinding poverty and unemployment back home.
Things took a turn in 2013 when the Dominican Republic’s top court ruled that children born to undocumented immigrants weren’t automatically given Dominican citizenship.
After that, undocumented folks had 18 months to sort out their status—with many who missed the deadline opting to leave, claiming they were pushed out by the authorities.
The BBC’s Will Grant sheds some light on the Catholic Church's role in this migration saga.
In the mix, you've got some priests speaking up for those returning to Haiti and others who’ve been called out for backing divisive policies.
Weekly Mass at Parc Cadeau—held in a humble hut crafted from wicker and palm leaves, with congregants on simple wooden benches—is quite the modest affair.
When you take a look around this camp—just one of several along the Haiti-Dominican Republic border—you see it’s a place where gratitude is scarce.

It’s undeniably one of the most impoverished spots in Latin America. A year ago, thousands of Haitians found themselves at Parc Cadeau—whether forced out or leaving under the threat of clashes with Dominican authorities.
Today, there are still hundreds of families stuck on this dusty patch of land, living in makeshift shelters made of plastic, cardboard, and rope. Many are caught in a sort of limbo, nearly stateless.
Take Soinicier Giles, for instance—just like countless others here, he spent 22 years farming in the Dominican Republic before being deported last year.
He shows me the rundown hut where his wife Eleny and six of their eight kids are staying.
The other two were left behind during his deportation. The conditions are dire, especially for the youngest ones.
"We sleep right on the floor, and it gets soaked inside when it rains," Eleny explains.
All her children were born in the Dominican Republic, but since coming to the camp, they’ve suffered from malnutrition and have developed skin issues.
"They're always hungry, we're all struggling because we can only manage one meal a day," she shares, her Spanish colored with a Creole accent.
Among the few lending a hand to these returnees is Father Luc Leandre, the parish priest.
With support from the International Organization for Migration, he’s managed to resettle some of the most desperate families into nearby Haitian communities.
"It's a dire crisis, really bad," Father Leandre says to me. "The Church is like a mother to everyone, and my role is to help."

The advertisement, funded by the government for an anti-violence initiative, holds crucial significance as concerns grow about Mexico's drug violence spilling over into this tiny Central American nation.
President Mauricio Funes raised the alarm last April. "We've got intel that the cartels are exploring El Salvador for potential operations," he announced.
This, President Funes explained, is partly because of the "effectiveness" of Mexican President Felipe Calderon's policies, pushing the cartels to seek new bases elsewhere.
Since then, the security forces have ramped up their vigilance, keeping an eye out for criminal groups like the Zetas—known for their brutality in Mexico—possibly setting up shop in El Salvador.
They're also wary of any alliances or turf wars between these cartels and the local gangs.
According to Douglas Garcia Funes of the Salvadoran national police, intelligence reports suggest gang members are already knee-deep in trafficking drugs and money to the U.S. via Mexico.
In a country plagued with one of the highest murder rates globally, this casts a dark shadow on its future.
Many Salvadorans warn that it might crank up the violence in their already struggling nation, while the government braces for the worst.
Hugo Martinez, El Salvador's foreign minister, told BBC News, "We are indeed worried, which is why we're focusing on preventive measures."
Take a look inside the jails of El Salvador: The gangs known as "maras," which sprang up among Salvadoran migrants in Los Angeles during the 1980s, play a huge role in the climbing crime statistics.
Some estimates show that about 15,000 young people are tangled up in these gangs, and some families have now witnessed a third generation involved.

These maras have a tight hold on certain territories, claiming they're doing "social cleansing" by wiping out petty crime while simultaneously extorting money for protection and engaging in widespread criminal antics.
A former gang member, choosing to stay anonymous, reveals that being part of a "mara" gives young, impoverished Salvadorans a sense of strength against the rest of society.
"People are scared of what a gang member might do, whether it's robbing or killing," he says.
"That's what being in a 'mara' is all about." Although maras aren't new to El Salvador, a striking incident in June marked a turning point.
Gang members torched a small bus in the capital, leading to the deaths of 17 people, and the government swiftly labeled it a "terrorist act."
During Sunday's match against Roma, there was a brief two-minute pause in play, and the 22-year-old striker found himself one of three AC Milan players targeted.
"If this happens again, I'm walking off because it's just ridiculous," the Italy international remarked.
"I almost did leave, but I figured people would think it was because we were struggling with the game."
At that point, AC Milan was down a player when the Serie A match at San Siro was temporarily halted.

The game continued only once Roma's traveling fans were told to cut it out. For this incident, Roma ended up with a 50,000 euro (£42,400) fine from the Italian Football League, and they put out a statement on Monday slamming their fans' behavior and vowing to "deal with this issue directly."
Fifa president Sepp Blatter wasn't impressed by the penalty and told the governing body's website: "They haven't really looked into what happened.

Just giving a monetary punishment doesn't cut it and it's unacceptable." Balotelli, who has knocked in 11 goals in just 12 games since moving from Manchester City in January, opened up about how the incident has shifted his approach to dealing with such problems.
Talking to CNN, he admitted: "I used to say if it happened in the stadium, I'd shrug it off and not let it bother me, but now I think I've changed my mind a bit."
This season’s been tough on AC Milan players with several episodes of racial abuse.
Back in January, a friendly against Pro Patria got stopped because of racist chants directed at Kevin-Prince Boateng.
Then in February, Inter Milan was slapped with a 50,000 euro fine after their fans racially targeted Balotelli, who played for them before, during the Milan derby.
And come April, Juventus was fined 30,000 euros (£25,000) for their supporters racially abusing AC Milan players.
The first international anti-corruption summit is set to tackle, expose, and hopefully eliminate corruption on a global scale.
Scheduled for Thursday at Lancaster House, it's drawing in political leaders, businesses, sports groups, and charities alike.
Prime Minister Cameron has pointed out that corruption is "the root of so many of the world's problems" and labels it as "an enemy of progress."
According to him, "It destroys jobs, hinders economic growth, traps the poorest in desperate poverty, and undermines our security by driving people towards extremist groups."
He didn't sugarcoat the challenge, though, acknowledging, "the battle against corruption will not be won overnight.
It'll take time, courage, and determination to push through the needed changes.
But honestly, we can't hope to tackle big global issues without facing the exploitation, fraud, and dishonesty that lie at their core.
Tackling the issue directly has been a taboo for far too long. This summit aims to shift that by putting the fight against corruption squarely on the international agenda."
World leaders expected to attend include Afghan President Ashraf Ghani, Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos, Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari, and Erna Solberg, the Prime Minister of Norway.
Russia will have Deputy Foreign Minister Oleg Syromolotov there. Speakers will likely feature World Bank President Jim Yong Kim and IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde.
The prime minister is pushing for summit leaders to pledge to reveal corruption and go after those involved or supportive of it.

Campaigners are pushing for action against UK-linked tax havens too. The Panama Papers leak revealed how some wealthy folks use offshore firms to dodge taxes and sidestep sanctions, putting this issue front and center.

A representative from Downing Street noted, "We're talking with the Overseas Territories and Crown Dependencies that have major financial centers about attending, and we expect a good number to join the summit."
Transparency International's Robert Barrington commented, "The prime minister is crafting a stage for dedicated governments to implement real change and shape the agenda for the future.
What's crucial now is persuading other governments to aim high and ensuring the UK government stands firm against any last-minute attempts by less committed countries to dilute the summit's goals."
The Chiefs snagged a bonus point before halftime, thanks to two tries from Thomas Waldrom, plus Jack Nowell and Mitch Lees crossing the line.
Just before the half-time break, Frank Halai managed a try for the Wasps, and then Ashley Johnson and Lorenzo Cittadini scored post-halftime, pulling the hosts back level.
Waldrom completed his hat-trick, and Moray Low's late try sealed a solid win for the visitors.
Exeter came out blazing, knocking in four tries within the first 34 minutes to lead 27-6.

Meanwhile, Jimmy Gopperth scored two penalties for Wasps. George Smith set up Halai with a neat grubber just as the whistle blew for halftime, and Gopperth’s conversion put the score at 27-13 at the break.
After the half, Johnson and Cittadini barged over for Wasps, tying it up 52 minutes in, but then Waldrom clinched his third try to snatch back Exeter's lead.
Even with Henry Slade sidelined by a knee injury later on, Exeter regained their groove, with Low landing their sixth try.
There's a chance the Chiefs could lose their top spot if the undefeated Saracens beat Newcastle Falcons on Sunday.
Wasps’ director of rugby, Dai Young, reflected, "Today really brought us back down to earth.
Exeter dominated in every area. Our line-out was lackluster, despite normally excelling at it.
Exeter made it seem effortless, which deserves credit, but we need improvement.
Complacency can sneak in when you’re praised, and it’s something to watch out for."
Rob Baxter, Exeter's director of rugby, said, "The performance today was superb.
Wasps made a surprising comeback. They've faced intense games recently, which can be tiring and affect consistency.
We aimed to keep the pressure on Wasps with line speed and scoreboard pressure, exploiting any weariness from those past matches."
Wasps lineup: Piutau; Tagicakibau, Daly, Jacobs, Halai; Gopperth, Simpson; Mullan, Johnson, Cittadini, Davies, Gaskell, Jones, Smith, Thompson.
Replacements: Shervington, McIntyre, Cooper-Wooley, Myall, Hughes, Simpson, Jackson, Leiua.
Exeter lineup: Dollman; Nowell, Slade, Hill, Short; Steenson, Chudley; Moon, Yeandle (capt), Francis, Lees, Parling, Johnson, Salvi, Waldrom.
This case is thought to be the first time someone has allegedly broken the Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures, known as TPims.
The suspect, referred to only as BM for legal reasons, made an appearance at the Old Bailey.
He's been charged with not contacting a monitoring company and failing to report to a police station twice last January. The Home Office hasn't commented on the situation.
TPims took over from control orders back in January 2012. As of March, BM was one of nine UK citizens under these measures.
So far, the BBC hasn't heard of anyone else being charged in court for violating a TPim.
According to the Home Office, "We don’t comment on individual cases. The police investigate all breaches of TPims and will prosecute when feasible."
Those with a TPim might have to stay overnight at a specified location and report daily to the police.
Other restrictions could restrict communication with certain people, visiting specific areas, or traveling abroad.
The Labour Party has argued that TPims have "weakened" public protection against terrorism.
In March, David Anderson, who reviews terror laws independently, mentioned that TPims might not be as effective as the old control orders, mainly because they can only last for up to two years.
The court heard that BM faces two charges of breaching Section 23 of a TPim order.
According to the charges, he didn’t contact a monitoring company on January 16 and didn’t report to a police station on January 27.
BM, sporting a grey beard and wearing a white shirt at his hearing, can't have his name or address published due to legal reasons.
Prosecutor Louise Gray asked for a provisional plea and case management hearing on July 2.
BM was given unconditional bail but still has to follow his TPim restrictions. A trial date hasn't been set yet.
Problems crop up because the six-digit codes used by booking systems to identify travelers are pretty easy to guess.
Two researchers showed just how vulnerable these codes are by changing a flight booking and seat assignment for a reporter.
They shared their work at the Chaos Communication Congress over in Germany. Karsten Nohl and Nemanja Nikodijevic from Security Research Labs (SRL) laid it all out in a blog.
They pointed out that the computer systems behind airline bookings hail from the 1970s and 80s.
Even though they've been updated with web services, these systems still lack the security needed to block misuse.
Notably, they don't have a way of verifying who’s actually accessing flight details.
Plus, most reservation systems let you try as many times as you want to get at booking information.
The researchers said hackers can exploit these gaps since the codes use a limited set of characters.
This allows them to bombard the servers with queries and dig out someone’s details.
“With just passengers’ last names, booking codes can be easily found online,” they noted.
This kind of access means attackers could steal personal data, redirect flyer miles, or up their phishing game.
More extreme attacks might even let someone change flight details entirely, maybe even scoring free rides.
SRL teamed up with German TV station ARD to prove it, altering a reporter’s flight to park him next to a German politician.
They urged airlines and travel agents to act fast to lock down traveler data. For starters, they suggested limiting possible queries per booking.

It turns out most flight bookings run through Amadeus, Sabre, and Travelport. Amadeus said it was “assessing” the findings and planned to “address” the security issues, working with partners to close these gaps. They also mentioned limiting booking query attempts.
Sabre insisted it has “numerous layers” of security for its systems but didn’t want to discuss these publicly so as not to compromise safety. Travelport hasn’t yet responded to SRL’s findings.
Stadium safety expert Paul Scott finds himself right in the thick of things, as highlighted in a revealing Cabinet Office report pointing to "broken" relations lurking behind the scenes.
This report suggests it’s going to take at least another year to roll out a fresh planning application.
Still, the authors are confident that building a new stadium is "achievable," and they describe the business case as "sound."

Commissioned following Mr. Scott's April testimony to a Stormont committee about flaws in the emergency-exiting plans for the proposed 38,000-seat stadium, the report advises replacing him as chair of the Safety Technical Group supervising the Casement project.
Personnel changes are part of the recommendation, and Sports Minister Carál Ní Chuilín is on board with implementing these changes.
She welcomed the report’s finding that the stadium project remains viable, saying it brings clarity to the situation.
The report also points out "broken" relationships among key players, suggesting that an independent mediator might be needed to smooth things over.
Although construction was supposed to kick off this year, that plan got derailed when planning permission was overturned back in December 2014.
According to the report, "The Casement Park project is behind schedule," and it needs to tackle two main issues: fixing the flawed emergency-exiting plans and reapplying for planning permission.
A "delivery confidence assessment" in the report rates Casement at "amber/red."
While the report recommends removing Mr. Scott as chair of the Safety Technical Group, there’s a chance he could still stay on the team.
Whoever takes over should be equipped with mediation and facilitation skills rather than just technical expertise.
The chairman of the Stormont committee, which has been looking into Mr. Scott’s claims, noted that the Cabinet Office report is only "part of the resolution."
Democratic Unionist Party MLA Nelson McCausland mentioned there are still questions aimed at the minister and other officials.
"We'll hold a special committee session at Stormont next week and ask the minister and permanent secretary to come forward with answers," he stated.
Talha Asmal, a 17-year-old from Dewsbury, has been identified as one of the four suicide bombers who attacked security forces near an oil refinery south of Baiji.
The Guardian reports Isis social media claimed that Asmal, also known as Abu Yusuf al-Britani, took part in the attack.
His family is utterly devastated by the news, sharing that Talha might be Britain's youngest known suicide bomber.
Before this, another young man from West Yorkshire, Hasib Hussein, was only 18 when he set off a bomb on a London bus during the 7 July 2005 attacks.
In a heartfelt statement, Asmal's family described him as a loving and kind teenager, one who never displayed any violent or radical behavior.
They believe he was targeted and manipulated online by individuals who exploited his youth and naivety, ultimately leading to his tragic end.
They said, "Talha was influenced by people who took advantage of his innocence, guiding him to his death under the orders of cowardly Isis handlers."

The family is understandably heartbroken and shattered by what has happened. West Yorkshire Police released a comment, stating, "We are aware of media reports concerning the death of a British national in Iraq.
The identity isn't confirmed, so we can't provide further comment." Talha had traveled to Syria with Hassan Munshi, another teen from Dewsbury.

To add to this complex web, Munshi's brother, Hammaad Munshi, was previously arrested at 16 in 2006 after a napalm-making guide was found on his computer, making him the youngest to be convicted under the Terrorism Act.
British police estimate that at least 700 people from the UK have traveled to support or fight for jihadist groups in Syria and Iraq.
A BBC News database is tracking those who have died, been convicted of related offenses, or are still in the region.
Spotting graffiti in the Netherlands? You might be surprised to see it's often in impeccably correct English.
But what's really catching attention these days is the rising number of UK students choosing to study in the Netherlands—it's been on a steady climb.
With UK students visiting Dutch universities as part of their open day tours, it's clear these institutions are pitching themselves as alternatives to top-tier UK universities.
Since tuition fees shot up to £9,000 in England, predictions about students heading abroad for more affordable education are proving true.
This term alone, Dutch universities welcomed 2,600 UK students—a whopping 33% jump from last year.
Independent school headteachers are encouraging students to consider Dutch universities, even pushing for them to be included on the UCAS application form.
Take the University of Groningen, for example: it saw a similar 33% increase in UK enrolments, now reaching about 300 students, prompting special open day events.
This 400-year-old university not only ranks in the world’s top 100 but is also the second oldest in the Netherlands.
It has more English-taught degrees than Dutch ones, drawing students from places as diverse as Germany, China, the UK, and the Netherlands.
For UK families visiting Groningen, tuition fees are definitely on their minds. Phoebe Watkinson and her dad, Phil, traveled all the way from the Wirral.
Phoebe thinks an affordable European degree could give her a leg up in the job market, adding a touch of daring to her resume.
Plus, getting back home from the Netherlands is no harder than returning from within the UK.
Phil, remembering the days of free higher education, finds the cost of degrees today unsettling.
"I'd be thrilled if she studied here," he said, citing not just the financial aspect, but the academic and social benefits too.
"Sure, most people focus on lower fees," he adds, "but there's a lot more to consider."
Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford finds the idea of Universal Basic Income (UBI) quite appealing, suggesting it could effectively tackle poverty and inequality.
Supporters think it might help those who've been unemployed but are wary of taking up a job because they might lose their benefits.
While there's interest, criticism isn't far off—Patrick Minford from Cardiff University's Business School argues it’s “not a workable scheme.” So, what’s the deal with UBI?
It’s about everyone getting a set amount of money, regardless of whether they're employed, and without the need to prove they're looking for work.
Up in Scotland, the policy has garnered backing from numerous political parties, with studies underway to see if pilot programs might kick off in Glasgow and Fife.
Jamie Cooke from the RSA think tank filled in the BBC's Sunday Politics Wales program: “UBI lets folks transition to work without penalties.
You'll keep getting payments, giving you the freedom to choose work, training, or even start your own business without losing your safety net.” Professor Minford has reservations, though.
As a former adviser to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, he thinks the idea is flawed by its hefty cost.
"It’s bound to impose high taxes," he warns, "putting off the more affluent who end up footing the bill."
Back in January, Drakeford spoke to the assembly about being drawn to UBI, imagining it could simplify life for those struggling with the tricky balance of part-time work and navigating benefits.
Still, he’s aware that selling the idea to the public is a whole other challenge for political leaders.
As for Minford, when quizzed about Drakeford’s enthusiasm for UBI, he couldn't hide his worries for Wales: “It’s concerning.
I hope Wales doesn’t follow suit with Scotland on this pricey socialist experiment.”
During the Falklands War on May 25, 1982, a Type 42 destroyer was hit, resulting in the tragic loss of 19 sailors' lives and injuring 30 others.
The ship sank in just 20 minutes and carried with it various documents and equipment considered vital to the UK's security, as Clive Gale explained.
Gale was part of a 39-member Royal Navy team that undertook dives on sunken ships like the HMS Coventry, spanning four months starting in autumn 1982.
Reflecting on these dives, Gale said, "We were deeply aware that we were diving on a war grave, with all the lives that were lost with the ship.
Visiting such a place leaves an indelible mark on you." Operation Blackleg, as it was called, was a tough and risky mission, with some dives lasting up to eight hours.
"We were 8,000 miles away from any rescue facilities, and Argentina was still a threat, plus there was a 500lb (227kg) unexploded bomb lying somewhere wrecked," Gale pointed out.
"The mission was full of close calls. Cutting into steel underwater traps oxygen, and even a tiny spark can lead to massive explosions.
One diver lost the front of his helmet and nearly drowned. I got knocked out and had to be saved by a fellow diver."
The mission, 300ft (91m) under the sea, was to "recover or destroy specific items," he mentioned. Yet, some items brought back weren't on any official list.
"I took off this big brass plaque while someone else got the ship's bell, and then we found the cross of nails," Gale said.
"These personal items from the crew were later given to Coventry Cathedral after we completed our mission."

Gotabhaya Rajapaksa, the former defense secretary, is facing accusations tied to his approval for a private company to establish a floating armory, which supposedly cost the state more than $75 million (£57m).

He’s standing firm against these claims, insisting on his innocence. These charges came down from a special anti-corruption commission at a Colombo magistrates court, shedding light on the complex aftermath of Mahinda Rajapaksa’s presidency, which wrapped up last year.
Right after Mahinda Rajapaksa's electoral defeat, the authorities found the floating armory near southern Sri Lanka, along with another weapons stash in the capital.
This discovery is just part of the broader investigations that have engulfed the Rajapaksa family since their unexpected fall from power.

Avant-Garde Security Service, the private firm implicated in this debacle, argued that the arsenal was meant to protect commercial vessels, but the authorities received complaints alleging these weapons were used for intimidation instead.
Additionally, Gotabhaya Rajapaksa is facing separate allegations—though again, he denies them—regarding human rights violations during the 2009 crackdown on Tamil Tiger militants.
Other Rajapaksa family members are also facing intense scrutiny due to various corruption allegations.
Not too long ago, Namal Rajapaksa, Mahinda’s eldest son, got arrested on suspicions of money laundering, a charge he disputes as well.

Namal’s brother, Yoshitha, and Mahinda's other brother, Basil, have had their brushes with the law for similar offenses; Basil, who once served as the economic development minister, has been detained three times related to fund mismanagement and money laundering, but he’s out on bail now.
President Maithripala Sirisena is leading efforts to probe whether the Rajapaksa family siphoned billions from public coffers during Mahinda’s nearly ten years at the helm.
Meanwhile, Mahinda, now part of the opposition, faces harsh criticism over alleged human rights abuses committed by the Sri Lankan military during their protracted battle against Tamil separatists.
Some schools might soon switch from council control to academies following the "Trojan Horse" investigations, which deal with claims that hardline Muslim groups are trying to infiltrate city schools.
At present, four separate investigations are underway. A government insider mentioned that they're keeping all options open.
Park View, a school named in these allegations, put out a statement on Thursday refuting any extremist ties.
Reports from Ofsted and the Department for Education are expected in June, detailing the potential measures for these schools.

There’s word that government ministers are in talks with successful schools and academy trusts about taking over schools facing these concerns, possibly shifting them away from local council oversight to become government-funded academies led by experienced headteachers.
Influential school groups, like Birmingham's Perry Beeches chain, might get involved.
Since some implicated schools are already academies, they might just change hands within different academy trusts.
Birmingham City Council isn't commenting on any action plans until after the Ofsted reports are released.
However, a council spokesperson stated, "We maintain regular contact with the DfE, though this matter hasn't come up for discussion."
The GMB union expressed outrage, criticizing the government for seemingly planning the schools' transfer to allied academy chains before investigations have even concluded.
Before these Trojan Horse allegations surfaced, Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw hinted that restructuring the local authority might be necessary.
As the largest local authority in England, Birmingham has previously been a subject of private discussions hinting it would be a challenge for any private entity to handle its vast services.

An alternative could be peeling off some or all of its education and children's services into an independent trust—a model tested in Hackney, London, after a government-declared need for radical intervention.

At a recent meeting with school reps, Birmingham City Council's chief executive, Mark Rogers, spoke of an impending "firestorm" once the Ofsted reports are out, advising everyone to brace for "significant structural changes" in the education sector.
Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr meticulously examines Daisy the sheep, on the lookout for any signs of heat, swelling, crepitus, or lameness that might hint at diseases like osteoarthritis.
But Daisy's no ordinary sheep—she's one of 13 clones living at a University of Nottingham farm.
Along with Daisy, there are her fellow clones Debbie, Denise, and Diane, all sharing the same genetic blueprint as Dolly, the first cloned mammal born back in 1996.

Despite the years that have passed in sheep generations, Kevin Sinclair, a developmental biology professor at Nottingham and the study's lead author, points out they're basically Dolly's quadruplets and identical to their original donor ewe.
"We went from one Dolly to five," he jokes. We catch this scene in a straw-covered pen at the university's Sutton Bonington Campus, where each of the 13 sheep gets the same careful check-up.
They’ve grown used to these tests—accepted, if not exactly embraced. They're some of the world's most closely observed animals, which likely explains their calm demeanors.
Sinclair talks about the bigger picture here, noting, "The future of cloning might hinge on these findings.
A key question since Dolly's debut is whether these animals age like their naturally born peers and how healthy they really are."

The heart of the research is grappling with a persistent cloning query: since the DNA is taken from adult cells with a history of divisions, could there be some sort of "age-memory" passed on that affects these clones?
"The idea is the clone might be biologically older than it looks," Sinclair says.
"So, while a newborn clone might outwardly seem like any lamb, it might end up battling age-linked issues sooner."
This wasn't an unfounded concern—Dolly herself died relatively young at six-and-a-half years old.
A virus that led to lung problems forced her—including some of her cohort—to be euthanized.
Allan Whittern ran the grocery store on Suffolk Parade from 1932 until he passed away in 1982, an impressive 50-year span.
When the store finally shut its doors in 1991, his son donated a painted door featuring Allan's likeness to the Wilson Art Gallery and Museum in town.
The gallery, managed by the Cheltenham Trust, plans to restore this unique piece for an upcoming exhibit.
Thelma Whittern, Allan’s daughter-in-law, shared the backstory of how the portrait came to be.
Apparently, after Allan turned down a Whitbread rep's offer to place an ad on the warehouse door, he jokingly told the guy to paint his portrait instead—and that's just what happened!

Thelma noted that people have often asked about the door since it vanished. In the old days, folks would walk past in the evening, spot the portrait, and call out “goodnight Mr. Whittern" as if he were actually leaving the store.
With the door gone, there've been plenty of questions like, "What happened to it?
You didn't get rid of it, did you?" A crowdfunding initiative has already pulled in over half of the £3,000 needed for the door's restoration, but around £1,400 is still needed by Friday.
Chloe Moorhead from the trust emphasized how important it is to preserve Cheltenham’s rich history, not just for the trust, but for the town itself.
She encouraged folks to contribute, calling it a fantastic opportunity to protect a vital piece of Cheltenham’s art history for the future.
Security forces are still on the hunt for the students abducted by Boko Haram militants back on April 14.
The situation was initially muddled when the military mistakenly announced that most of the girls had been rescued.
Parents and some girls who managed to escape say that more than 200 students were taken from their school in Chibok, a town in Borno state, by armed men under the cover of night.
A local government official backs this up, estimating the number of missing at around 100.
On the other hand, Nigeria's military claims that most of the girls have either escaped or been freed, saying only eight remain missing.
However, locals are skeptical, insisting many are still unaccounted for, which has led parents to search the Sambisa forest, near the Cameroon border, only to find no Nigerian soldiers in sight.
Major General Chris Olukolade admits the erroneous report about the girls' release, explaining it wasn’t meant to mislead anyone.
Parents hold firm that over 200 girls are still missing. So far, no military rescues have taken place.
Asabe Kwambura, the headmistress of the school in Chibok, is urging the government to step up their rescue efforts.
She also makes an emotional plea to the kidnappers, believed to be Boko Haram members, to "have mercy on the students."
In a conversation with the BBC, Kwambura says that at least 190 girls are still missing, which contradicts a local state governor’s claim that about 80 are unaccounted for.
Video footage from the aftermath of the attack shows classrooms set on fire by the gunmen.

A government source tried to clarify the mix-up, saying initially it was thought only the science students were taken before their exam, but later it became clear that 105 art students were also in the hostels.
Across social media, Nigerians are venting their frustration at the government's response.
Lawyer Ibrahim M. Abdullahi was the first to tweet the #BringBackOurGirls hashtag.
Angry crowds have marched in Abuja, condemning what they see as government indifference to the mass kidnapping.

A leader from the Chibok community warns that the girls might have been taken to nearby states and possibly forced into marriages with militants, reporting 230 girls missing, an increase from earlier figures.
Desperate, the parents in Chibok have protested, demanding the government intensify the search, with similar protests popping up in towns and cities across Nigeria.

The Beyond Caravaggio exhibition is bringing something exciting to Edinburgh, featuring works by the famed Italian artist Caravaggio along with pieces from 30 other European artists who were inspired by his style.
Thanks to a partnership with the National Galleries in London and Dublin, these works have made their way to Scotland for the first time, wrapping up their tour here.
Caravaggio, real name Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio, certainly lived up to his “bad boy” reputation in the early 17th century, known for his reckless behavior.
He died at 39 in 1610, after years on the run for killing a man in a tennis-related feud.
Christopher Baker, who's currently the acting director at the Scottish National Gallery, called Caravaggio a “revolutionary artist” in a chat with BBC Scotland.
He said, “Caravaggio is your classic bad boy artist with a life full of drama—court cases, even murder in his past—but his artistic genius was undeniable.
His works were so extraordinary that artists across Europe, particularly in Rome and Naples, were drawn to his style and wanted to mimic him.
This exhibition tells that story.” One of the highlights is *The Taking of Christ* (1602) from the National Gallery of Ireland, on indefinite loan from the Dublin Jesuit Community.
This piece had quite an adventure itself, having been rediscovered in a Jesuit house in Dublin in 1990.
Aidan Weston-Lewis, a curator at the Scottish National Gallery, shared a bit of a missed opportunity—it was actually offered to the gallery in 1921 at no cost, but they turned it down.

Surprisingly, it was the only Caravaggio piece in a private Scottish collection and was picked up by William Hamilton Nisbet when he was in Rome in 1802. The Mattei family had originally commissioned it 200 years prior.

For 120 years, it was displayed at Biel House in East Lothian. Weston-Lewis pointed out, “His descendants left a large collection to the Scottish National Gallery, but due to tight space, only certain works were selected for inclusion. Unfortunately, this one didn’t make the cut back then.”
The doctors' union is raising concerns that patient care might suffer when GPs are stuck seeing up to 60 patients each day.
They’re pushing for more funding so doctors can dedicate at least 15 minutes to each patient.
Now, NHS England has said that the length of consultations is up to the doctors themselves, and they haven’t set any national rule for them to be capped at 10 minutes.
Yet, if you check the NHS Choices website, it says GPs usually spend about 8 to 10 minutes with each patient and advises folks to plan ahead to get everything discussed.

Just this month, the BMA came out with a report on "safe working in general practice," aiming to shake things up and start a conversation about how GPs are under "unsustainable pressure" from their rising workload and lack of staff.
This report floats ideas for restructuring that could be rolled out across the UK.
Dr. Nicola Hulme, a GP from Cheshire, called NHS England’s comments about endless appointment times "insulting."
She noted the heavy demand forces them into using these 10-minute windows to wrap up their over 12-hour days.
Often running late, she doesn’t tackle paperwork until after 7 pm and typically gets home no earlier than 8 pm after starting her day at 7:30 am.
"Nobody enters medicine expecting it to be easy," she said. "We're hard workers, but the level of demand and intensity at the moment isn’t safe."
Dr. Ali Alibhai, working in central London, pointed out that handling many chronic conditions, like diabetes, makes those short eight-minute slots inadequate for providing safe care.
Dr. Brian Balmer from the BMA’s GPs' committee highlighted that given an aging population, more patients have complex issues needing more time.
He stressed that GPs find themselves shortening care, juggling an "unsafe number of consultations."
He suggested setting a limit of 25 consultations a day, which aligns with recommendations in other parts of Europe.
Dr. Balmer added, "We need to rethink how patients get care from their GPs. Consultation times should be boosted to 15 minutes, with the support of government funding, as promised."
The King's Fund, a health think tank, reported that GPs are under "huge pressure," with workloads rising, but no matching increase in funding or staff.
Not too long ago, trainee doctors had to bide their time—sometimes up to four years—before they got a real taste of consultations.

Enter GP Live, a game-changing software cooked up by Aberdeen University. This tool streams consultations right to the students, aiming to draw more of them into general practice and tackle the ongoing recruitment headaches.
Consultations are broadcast shortly after they happen, offering students a peek into what a day in the life of a GP looks like.
GP Live makes use of the University's Digitally Enhanced Learning Spaces (DELS).
Here, students dive into interactive sessions using big 55-inch displays and top-notch web conferencing tech.
The mastermind behind this initiative is Dr. John McKeown, a senior clinical lecturer and GP at Cults Medical Group in Aberdeen.

He noted: “The real pull for students is seeing consultations almost live. It’s got an immediacy that clicks with those familiar with digital interactive learning.” Dr. McKeown is big on engaging sessions.
He delves into how GPs communicate, steer consultations, and decide on next steps.
One standout perk of the system? It sparks discussions about different practices and brings various issues to light.
Dr. McKeown added that students get some real-world insights into the hurdles GPs face, whether they’re working in tough spots or far-flung rural areas.
The system lets students work through a string of consultations, mimicking a typical GP morning.
They get to see all kinds of skills—like interpersonal and diagnostic ones—in action during a regular workday.
Dr. McKeown also pointed out the rising demand for new GPs in Scotland by the time today’s first-year students finish their studies.
Berlusconi, in a chat with an Italian newspaper, remarked that since Americans chose Mr. Trump, it’s best to let him get on with his job.
Both Berlusconi, a media powerhouse, and Trump, a real estate mogul, made the leap from business to politics.
While Trump has faced legal trouble, he hasn’t been convicted of any crimes, unlike Berlusconi.
At 70, Trump, who bested Hillary Clinton in the recent election, stands out as one of America’s most well-known billionaires.
Forbes pegs his net worth at around $3.7 billion (€3.4 billion, £2.9 billion). Berlusconi, now 80, served as Italy’s prime minister four times before facing criminal convictions in 2013 and 2015.

Forbes estimates his family's worth at $5.9 billion. When asked about their similarities, Berlusconi told Corriere della Sera that while some parallels exist, their entrepreneurial paths are quite different; he’s never met Trump.
He didn’t give more details, but he might've meant their distinct hair or larger-than-life images.
Italians quickly noticed resemblances between the U.S. president and their ex-PM, even coming up with the nickname "Trumpusconi" on social media.
In the interview, Berlusconi stopped short of celebrating Trump’s win but discussed why he thought Clinton lost.

According to him, Trump appealed to Americans fed up with the same old political scene, pointing out a mistake common among left-leaning groups worldwide: mixing up "political correctness" with meeting people’s real needs.
Italy’s facing a constitutional reform referendum on December 4, which is seen as a test of current Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's leadership.
Renzi has promised to step down if the vote doesn’t go his way, something that polls say is a narrow possibility.

This could bolster Italy’s anti-establishment Five Star Movement. Its founder, Beppe Grillo, once a comedian, called Trump’s election a game-changer for media and intellectual elites. So, could a Trump-style shake-up spread to Europe?
Fr Alec Reid, a respected 82-year-old member of the Redemptorist order, passed away early Friday morning at a hospital in Dublin.

Over his long and impactful life, Fr Reid played a quietly pivotal role as a go-between for the republican movement and the SDLP, and he was among the witnesses who confirmed the decommissioning of IRA weapons.
In recent times, he also participated in discussions with Basque nationalists aiming for independence from Spain.
Back in 1988, one of the most unforgettable images from the Northern Ireland Troubles was of Fr Reid praying over the bodies of soldiers Derek Wood and David Howes, both Army corporals.
Tragically, they were dragged from their car, beaten, and shot by the IRA after mistakenly driving into a republican funeral in Belfast.
The photo of Fr Reid, stained with blood as he administered last rites, stood as a testament to his profound faith and convictions, according to a Ministry of Defence spokesperson.
Gerry Adams, leader of Sinn Féin, regarded Clonard monastery in west Belfast—where Fr Reid served during the Troubles—as "the cradle of the peace process."
Adams recalled visiting with Fr Reid at St Vincent's Hospital in Dublin the night before his passing and planned to stop by again that Friday.
He remarked, "Fr Reid lived the gospel message, endorsing dialogue even when unpopular, and relentlessly pursued peace."
Northern Ireland Secretary of State Theresa Villiers offered her sympathies, underscoring the debt of gratitude owed for Fr Reid's vital contributions to peace and reconciliation in Northern Ireland.
Former SDLP leader John Hume described Fr Reid as "more than a mediator," emphasizing how his courage, determination, and selflessness significantly eased and shortened the road to peace.
Hume encouraged everyone to honor Fr Reid’s legacy by continuing the quest for reconciliation.
Michael D. Higgins, President of Ireland, pointed out that Fr Reid’s compassionate delivery of last rites to the two corporals amidst brutality in 1988 provided a powerful image of humanity.
As news of Fr Alec Reid's passing reached west Belfast, it was met with tears and tributes.
The choice to call off the event came after weather forecasts signaled more nasty weather was on the way.
On Saturday, the performances had to be stopped because of relentless thunderstorms, making many of the 92,000 folks at the outdoor venue seek refuge in their cars and tents.
By Sunday morning, local authorities had pulled the festival’s license, leaving organizers no choice but to cancel.
They took to Facebook (posting in German) to express their regret, stating it was necessary because keeping fans safe mattered most.

Some on Facebook criticized the organizers for not canceling sooner. Rock am Ring, hosted at an airport in Mendig—about 100 km (roughly 62 miles) west of Frankfurt—required attendees to clear the festival grounds by noon on Sunday.
A lightning strike early Saturday morning seriously injured at least eight people.
