Central Europe has been dealing with heavy storms and rainfall lately, which sadly led to 11 deaths in Germany.
This isn’t the first time Rock am Ring faced lightning issues—last year, 33 attendees were sent to the hospital.
On their website, the festival organizers frequently cautioned fans about possible heavy rains and thunderstorms.
Initially, they had planned to continue through Sunday evening, featuring popular bands like Red Hot Chili Peppers, Black Sabbath, Foals, Deftones, and We Are Scientists.
Just last weekend, a lightning incident at a football match in southwest Germany injured 35 people, with three sustaining serious injuries.
Similarly, in Paris, a lightning strike at a park during a kids' birthday party hurt another 11 people.
A study out of the UK, featured in *Nature*, has discovered that rebuilding the nerves responsible for transmitting sound in gerbils led to partial hearing improvement.
If we could achieve similar results in humans, it might dramatically change their hearing capabilities—from being unable to detect traffic to following conversations.

Yet, this kind of treatment is still quite a ways off. For activities like tuning into the radio or chatting with a friend, our ears need to turn sound waves into electrical signals that our brains can interpret.
This happens deep in the inner ear, where tiny hairs transform those vibrations into electrical impulses.
Unfortunately, in about 10% of people with significant hearing loss, damaged nerve cells disrupt this signal transfer—similar to a relay race where the baton gets dropped early on.
The team at the University of Sheffield focused on replacing these compromised nerve cells, called spiral ganglion neurons, with new ones.

There's a lot of excitement around using stem cells to restore these ear nerves, though this approach won't help most individuals with hearing loss, which usually results from damage to those delicate hairs.

The researchers have been working on turning embryonic stem cells into the initial forms of these hair cells, but injecting them successfully into the ear is tricky. They need to be positioned just right.
As Prof. Dave Moore put it, repairing hair cells with stem cells is "almost an impossible task," suggesting it might be easier to grow and transplant a whole new ear.
The team used stem cells from a human embryo, which can potentially become any cell type—from nerves and skin to muscles and kidneys.
By using specific chemicals, they turned these stem cells into cells similar to spiral ganglion neurons, which they then carefully injected into the inner ears of 18 deaf gerbils.
After about ten weeks, these gerbils showed an average improvement of 45% in their hearing range.
Dr. Marcelo Rivolta clarified: "This could mean moving from profound deafness, where even the sound of a truck is inaudible, to being able to converse."
After a grueling four-day trek covering 129 kilometers (about 80 miles), Kai finally reached a camp in Bentiu, a town up north.
He had fled Leer, a small town in Unity State, caught in the turmoil of violent conflict.
Rival forces battling it out forced him to abandon his family, driven by sheer fear.
"At night, they'd start shooting, and we'd run," Kai recalls. "We'd dive into the swamp, keeping only our heads above water."
As the days blurred together, he lost all sense of time, hiding out in those murky waters.
The clashes left his family's cattle stolen, his brother—who helped with the livestock—killed, and their home destroyed.

Though he's found temporary safety, anxiety for his family's fate lingers. "I have no idea if they're okay; they might be alive or dead with the fighting still raging. Now, I'm stuck choosing between going to school or going back for my parents."
Former President of Botswana, Festus Mogae, who leads a commission monitoring the 2015 peace deal, warns that the simmering conflict might spiral into an "uncontrolled escalation of violence."

The situation has intensified around Yei in the southeast, Leer in the north, and Nasir in the northeast, driving security concerns sky-high and crippling road transport. Commodity prices have skyrocketed, leading to inflation rates hitting 700%.
With roadways perilous, humanitarian efforts now heavily depend on costly airlifts.
Every day, planes from Juba or Gambella in Ethiopia fly in, carrying loads of grain, pulses, and vegetable oil for drop-offs near camps.
Even fuel for vehicles and generators gets airlifted. Mahimbo Mdoe, Unicef's representative in South Sudan, points out that the crisis demands more supplies, personnel, and security.

"Malnutrition in Northern Bahr al-Ghazal has tripled, which means we need three times the former supply levels for children," Mdoe explains, labeling the situation as "dire" with up to six million children impacted.
Without intervention, he warns, conditions could worsen for civilians, especially women and children, making life tougher for humanitarian workers.

To help secure Juba amid the ongoing power tussle between President Salva Kiir and ousted Vice-President Riek Machar, the UN Security Council set up the Regional Protection Force (RPF) back in August.
Greater Manchester Police has issued an apology for racial stereotyping after a mock terror attack featured a pretend terrorist shouting "Allahu Akbar."
Folks at Longsight Saath Saath are calling for an investigation into the matter.
GMP stated they won’t be releasing further statements about the training exercise that happened at Trafford Centre.
The scenario, depicting a suicide bombing, involved an extremist group similar to Daesh, though GMP emphasized the event wasn’t tied to any specific terror threat.
Syed Azhar Shah, who led a meeting with about 30 people, said that the apology from GMP's assistant chief constable Garry Shewan fell short.

He mentioned they'd only accept it if the responsible parties resigned. While he saw the importance of the training, he found it "shocking to portray Muslims as terrorists," suggesting it unfairly singles out one group as being capable of such acts.
Mr. Shah voiced concern over how this portrayal affects children and the community, who might struggle with their identities as either terrorists or British citizens.
He announced more events to "condemn this" and ensure it isn’t repeated, stressing that a single apology "won't fix all the pain."
One participant pointed out that showing a Muslim as a terrorist sends "the totally wrong message," straining relations between the community and GMP.
"We’re all British citizens. Islam does not permit any killing," the participant remarked.

Tony Lloyd, Greater Manchester's police and crime commissioner, expressed frustration over the operation, claiming it was "marred by the ill-judged... and unacceptable decision" to have the terrorist shout "Allahu Akbar" before the fake bombs went off.
Other spots included in the three-day counter-terror exercise were Redbank Community Home in Newton-le-Willows.
Monitor has stepped in to review the financial health of Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust "on behalf of patients," as stated by the NHS regulator.
This action comes after the hospital's expected £7.8 million deficit ballooned with no clear plans for recovery.
According to the hospital, the widened gap is due to an uptick in demand and efforts to bring on more staff.

Alan Tobias OBE, who chairs the hospital, explained: "The overspend is a result of necessary investments in services and staffing to keep up with high patient care standards and an increase in attendance.
We're open to this review as it gives us the chance to show Monitor, patients, and others that our financial strategies are reliable and sustainable."
The hospital is set to tackle the deficit while maintaining "high quality care for local people," aiming for a surplus within three years.

Monitor's investigation will dig into the hospital's financial status, scrutinizing its financial management skills and looking into ways to bolster sustainability, all for the good of patients in the area.
The review will also check how the trust works with local health and care organizations to address its financial hurdles.

Katherine Cawley, Monitor's regional director, stated: "Southend is a lifeline for quality healthcare, now and in the future, and we're worried that the trust's shaky financial performance could put this at risk.
We've launched this investigation to gain a deeper understanding of the trust's financial situation and to find solutions for improvement."
The wild weather hitting Norfolk and Lincolnshire caused quite a stir, prompting evacuations and even shutting down an air display.
In Cambridgeshire, the BBC Weather reported a whopping 50mm of rain dumped in just an hour, leading to the banks of the River Nene in March taking a serious hit.
I mean, imagine being in a Tesco when water starts streaming through the ceiling near the fresh fish counter—one shopper did just that.
Richard Mayer, 32, found himself in a sticky situation, stuck in his car over at Bar Hill.
He was in town house-hunting when he was trapped by floodwaters. "It's lapping over the curb," he shared from inside his vehicle.
"Sure, people can walk through it, but driving? Forget it. I'm parked on the pavement, trying to stay above it all, right by the Bar Hill roundabout near Tesco.
Cars are scattered everywhere, and as folks try to plow through, engines are conking out and causing jams."
Over in March, Doddington, and Wisbech St Mary, fire service group commander Ryan Stacey reported that seven crews were busy assisting with evacuations, rescuing belongings, and pumping out homes.
While he couldn’t pin down exact numbers, Stacey knew they were helping at least 60 properties.
He had a warning for drivers: "Steer clear of standing water—it can wreck your car and hide nasty surprises."
They set up a rest center at St John the Evangelist Parish Hall on Queens Street to help affected residents.
West Norfolk didn't get off easy either with flash flooding reports pouring in.
The Norfolk Fire and Rescue Service was swamped, dealing with about 40 flood-related calls.

They were scrambled across Swaffham, Necton, Outwell, and Downham Market. With the downpours continuing, Cambridgeshire police were strongly urging folks to stay off the roads unless absolutely necessary.

Chief Inspector Nick Knight explained they're teaming up with the Highways Agency, Fire and Rescue Service, Fenland District Council, and Cambridgeshire County Council to manage road closures, evacuate residents, and fish out vehicles caught in floodwater.

“No point calling 999 for sandbags—don't have 'em,” he added pointedly. As for the power situation, UK Power Network crews were hustling to get electricity back on, with roughly 400 homes still in the dark by 9 p.m. Friday night.
In a fiery speech aimed squarely at Donald Trump, Mrs. Clinton made it known she's gunning for voters in the political center as the general election approaches.
Though her talk was branded as a national security speech, it didn't bring any fresh proposals to the table.
Instead, it was a bold and often mocking critique of the Republican frontrunner, wrapped in patriotic language that might strike a chord with Republicans too.
Mrs. Clinton cast herself as the genuine defender of American values, a level-headed commander-in-chief who views America as an exceptional nation.
In stark contrast, she argued that Trump sees the country as "weak" and "an embarrassment," citing his comments about the military being a "disaster" and calling the nation a "third-world country."
Delivering her speech in San Diego, home to 95,000 military personnel, she was introduced by an active-duty naval officer's spouse with 20 American flags proudly displayed behind her.

Despite not being done with the primary race, Mrs. Clinton is clearly reaching out to independents and Republicans concerned about Trump's unpredictable stance on foreign policy and his controversial remarks on women, Mexican immigrants, and Muslims.
On Thursday, Ruth Guerra, who led Hispanic media relations for the Republican National Committee, stepped down from her role.

Mrs. Clinton has the potential to draw in moderate Republicans disappointed by their party's hardline positions on social issues like gay marriage, abortion, and gun rights, yet who find her foreign policy firm and reassuring.
After winning the Pennsylvania primary back in late April, Mrs. Clinton encouraged all "thoughtful" Republicans, independents, and Democrats to unite against the divisive Republican candidates.
Even though House Speaker Paul Ryan finally threw his support behind Trump on Thursday after weeks of hesitation, many top Republicans remain cautious.

Several Republican governors and senators intend to skip the party's convention in July, and some lifelong Republicans are publicly saying they'll cast their votes for a Democrat for the first time this November.

While Mrs. Clinton's focus on America's role in global leadership might not sit well with the increasingly isolationist GOP base, it's definitely appealing to a lot of moderates and foreign policy buffs.

For a bit there on Twitter, #RepublicansforHillary was trending after Doug Elmets, who served in the Reagan administration, commented on US cable TV that "four years of Hillary Clinton is better than one day with Donald Trump as president."
Situated smack dab in the bustling heart of the city, yet wedged between fast-food joints, this place doesn’t exactly scream prime real estate.
It's at the scruffy end of Nemanjina Street, near the main railway station, giving off the vibe of a transient haven.
Here, signs scribbled in Arabic hint at a steady flow of newcomers from the Middle East who are trickling into Serbia's capital. Walking inside, it's almost like stepping into a controlled whirlwind.
On the ground floor, you’ll find young men perched lamely on stiff chairs, eyeing the computers lining one wall, waiting for their turn.
The lucky ones at the computers are chatting away in animated Skype conversations, headsets on, immersed in their digital lifeline.
Head upstairs, and the vibe does a quick flip. Bewildered families are packed into a barely roomy "safe space," coordinated by Save The Children.
Parents try to coax their kids towards a heap of toys, though one small child is crying his heart out.
There's that unmistakable scent of the refugee journey—damp clothes, the kind that haven't seen a wash recently—that begins to fill the air.
Translator Marjan, struggling to bridge the communication gap, sheds some light: "They're Yazidi people from Iraq."
With more than two dozen in this family group, they bypassed the usual route through Greece and Macedonia, opting instead to enter Serbia via its eastern border with Bulgaria.
In the rather sterile, windowless meeting room, the scene is peppered with overflowing ashtrays and half-drunk mugs of Turkish coffee, evidencing a rough morning.
Vladimir Sjekloca, the center's manager, takes a moment to break down the scenario: "There are always people in Belgrade," he remarks, estimating about 400-500 daily.

Despite ramped-up border measures and the proclaimed shutdown of the Balkan route—even as hundreds slip through the fence from Greece to Macedonia—refugees are just finding new ways to connect the dots on their way to Western Europe.
"There's this old smuggling route entering through Bulgaria that's getting popular again.
Afghans even tell us, 'It's cheaper than crossing the sea from Turkey to Greece, plus we can’t swim.'"

Before the route clamped down, nations along the path worked together to shepherd refugees from Macedonia to near Slovenia's border with Austria via official trains and buses, making it relatively streamlined and reducing the chance they’d fall victim to smugglers.
Now, those aiming for Western Europe are tangled up with shady operatives once more.
"The journey through Bulgaria is riddled with abuse," Vladimir points out. "People suffer at the hands of the mafia and smugglers—and the system leaves them unprotected."
Terence Brannigan, chairman of the Maze/Long Kesh Development Corporation, recently shared his thoughts after traffic bottlenecked around the old prison site on the first day of the event.
He pointed out that these rural roads were never meant to handle such heavy traffic, but assured everyone that work is underway to improve the infrastructure.
"In about a year, you'll see some real changes," he promised, albeit with a touch of realism.
"Sure, in 12 months we won't have two direct roads to the motorway network ready just yet.
We're working on creating two motorway connections—one from the east, one from the west.
First, we need to complete environmental studies, get those cleared, then move on to planning approvals before we can start building."
The three-day event's new location, after moving from the King's Hall in Belfast, is expected to draw around 80,000 people.
First Minister Peter Robinson chimed in on Wednesday, hoping the access complications would soon be sorted.
Mr. Brannigan stressed that fixing these infrastructure issues has always been a top priority, but acknowledged the lengthy "rigorous process" involved.
He commented, "Long queues can really take away from an otherwise fantastic show, a brilliant event, and a real chance to highlight Northern Ireland."
Thankfully, funding is secured, so it's not a matter of lacking resources or support.
"We've got to follow due process, which, let's be honest, can be a bit frustrating."
This year, show-goers are encouraged to take public transport, with the Balmoral Show website offering details on getting there by car or public transit.
At 33, Fay is just one match away from earning her 185th cap for Scotland as they gear up to face Slovenia in their opening Euro 2017 qualifier this Tuesday.
Ever since she made her debut in 1998 against the Czech Republic, Fay has been a vital part of the national team.
Looking back at earlier matches, like those against Holland, she's often wondered if it was time to hang up her boots.
After Scotland lost both legs of the World Cup play-off against the Netherlands, just short of Canada, she found herself at a crossroads.
The big question on her mind? Whether she’d still get a shot at a major championship.
"Qualifying for Euro 2017 would probably be the peak of my career," she admitted.
With Anna Signeul at the helm, Scotland's got a golden chance. The draw looks good—Belarus, Macedonia, and Iceland as top seeds.
Plus, with the tournament set for the Netherlands in two years and more slots available, expectations are through the roof.
"There's pressure from outside to qualify, but we can’t take any team lightly," Fay warned.
"We're not so full of ourselves to assume we’ll qualify automatically. We'll play to our strengths and put in the hard work game by game.

If we respect our opponents, I'm sure we'll do well in this group." The team is based in Nova Gorica, close to the Italian border, although their match will be held in Ajdovščina, about a half-hour drive away.
"The place is gorgeous," Fay remarked about the venue, tucked in a valley with mountains all around.
"The pitch suits our style, and fingers crossed they’ll give it a good watering before the game. It's the perfect spot to kick off our campaign."
MP Brendan O'Hara is throwing a reception to lay out plans for turning the old NATO base at Machrihanish into the UK's hub for space tourism.
Out of the five spots proposed across the UK—including a trio in Scotland—Machrihanish is in the running to become a spaceport.
The UK government had hoped to set up a spaceport by the end of 2018, kicking off consultations in 2014 and eventually whittling down candidate sites.
Prestwick in South Ayrshire, Stornoway in the Western Isles, Newquay airport in Cornwall, and Llanbedr airport in Snowdonia National Park were all considered.
Fast forward to May last year, when spaceport licensing made it into the Queen's Speech, bringing in an airport-style licensing system wherever suitable.

According to the Department for Transport, this move could make "viable business models" possible at various places, encouraging Prestwick and Campbeltown to chase investment to showcase their suitability as prime spaceport locations.
Officials suggest that a spaceport would cater not just to space tourism but also satellite launches.
Machrihanish, near Campbeltown, has previously been approved for space flights twice and even served as an emergency landing site for NASA's Space Shuttle way back in 1981.
Tom Millar, who's at the helm of DiscoverSpace UK and the Machrihanish Airbase Community Company, highlighted strong local backing for the bid and the economic perks it could bring.
He pointed out, "Our site has great promise—boasting a runway over 3,000 meters long, plenty of room for growth, and the green light for planning from Argyll and Bute Council.
The safety case is solid, with a sparsely populated area perfect for sea launches."

Brendan O'Hara, SNP MP, called placing the spaceport in Kintyre a "no-brainer," and said, "A spaceport would be a huge economic boost for Argyll and Bute, giving Scotland a shot to lead the UK's space adventure. The sky's not the limit!"
After another 24 shops were shut down, police have arrested 186 people they suspect of breaking the law.
The Home Office seems pretty pleased that many retailers can't rake in profits from selling these dangerous substances anymore.
But according to DrugWise, a charity that keeps tabs on this stuff, the ban's just pushed the trade into the shadows.
Legal highs, which mimic drugs like cocaine, cannabis, and ecstasy, popped onto the scene around 2008 with names like Spice and Black Mamba.
Then in late May, the Psychoactive Substances Act rolled out, making it illegal to produce, sell, or supply such drugs.
Commander Simon Bray from the National Police Chiefs Council noted that since the law took effect, London's Metropolitan Police have seized almost 14,000 nitrous oxide canisters.
While it's tough to say exactly how this affects drug use, Mr. Bray suggested that it’s probably had some impact, particularly on newbie users.
There was a big misconception that these substances were legal and therefore safe.
The Angelus Foundation, which raises awareness about the risks of legal highs, mentioned that several online sellers have packed up shop too.
Jeremy Sare, the charity's communication head, said to the BBC, "The ban seems to have made a significant difference, and we back it. We've been surprised online sales haven’t spiked.
It seems traders have just stopped. It’s early days, and this could shift over the next year, but it looks like many have shut down.
They complied with the law until now, and with new rules, they’ve ceased.” He pointed out that homeless people and prisoners are the main consumers of these substances.
Greg, who relocated from Essex to west Wales, recounted his run-in with a legal high called Holy Smoke on BBC Radio 5 live.
"I just tried a little," he said, "and my head started spinning. I got paranoid, wanting to run home and hide, but I couldn’t walk right.
I genuinely thought I might die. I hear it's still fairly easy to get, with quite a few people under the impression it’s still legal."
Meanwhile, "Alison," someone who's recovering from drug use, also had her share of experiences with legal highs.
The amount under scrutiny is more than double what was first thought during the investigation into FN staff finances.
Parliament suspects funds were allocated to FN assistants who weren’t doing MEP work but were rather involved with FN activities back in France.
Though the FN denies these claims, they’ve been sent to French investigators. Ms. Le Pen, meanwhile, is busy campaigning for the presidential runoff on May 7th.
She’s up against Emmanuel Macron, a liberal centrist who’s currently leading the polls.
Allegations of improper payments, dating back to 2012, implicate Ms. Le Pen along with several other FN MEPs.
Critical of the EU, the FN rejects its liberal and market-focused policies. Ms.
Le Pen argues that she’s the victim of a politically driven attack. Wondering why Marine Le Pen is labeled far-right? Look into: Le Pen and the Rise of the National Front.
The European Parliament has decided to hold back half of Ms. Le Pen’s salary and expenses to recover the funds they say she owes.
The FN holds 24 MEP seats, making them France’s biggest delegation. Ms. Le Pen hasn’t responded to a summons on this matter in France, citing her immunity as an MEP.
BBC's Hugh Schofield in Paris mentions that FN supporters are often pretty skeptical about the EU and might not find the alleged fraud particularly upsetting.
On Tuesday, Ms. Le Pen stepped down as FN leader, claiming she needed to set aside party interests during the presidential campaign.

Jean-François Jalkh, who’s temporarily taken over, faced immediate backlash for comments he made in 2000, questioning the Nazis’ use of Zyklon B gas for mass killings, saying, "I consider it technically impossible—again, impossible—to use it...in mass murders," Le Monde quoted him.
When asked by Le Monde, Jalkh brushed this off as "utter rubbish" and claimed he didn’t remember the interview.

Meanwhile, a year ago, FN founder Jean-Marie Le Pen was slapped with a €30,000 (£25,278; $32,600) fine for calling the Nazi gas chambers a "minor detail" of World War Two—a conviction for denying crimes against humanity.
He faced another conviction in 2012 for asserting the Nazi occupation of France was "not particularly inhumane."
Marine Le Pen, his daughter, drew heavy criticism on April 9th after suggesting France wasn’t responsible for the 1942 deportation of 13,000 Jews to Nazi death camps.
Mr. Haldane expressed concern that increasing interest rates might "unnecessarily raise the risk of the economy falling below critical speed."
Known as the most cautious when it comes to interest rate hikes, he noted the intricate balance required in such decisions.
Since the financial crisis back in 2009, interest rates have been stuck at 0.5%.
While there was talk of the first increase happening towards the end of 2016, the Bank of England's latest inflation report, hinting at a gloomier global growth outlook, caused some wavering.
In his address to the TUC, Mr. Haldane highlighted an important possibility: the next move in interest rates could just as much be a cut as a rise.
"Policy in the UK needs to be ready to shift in either direction based on how the data unfolds," he emphasized, pointing out the uncertain terrain.
Wage growth, he noted, might not be as robust as previously thought, and this could lead inflation to undercut the Bank's November forecasts, which anticipated breaching the 2% target in two years.
As it stands, the Consumer Price Index is hovering at 0.1%. "Looking at the current scenario," he noted, "I'm not convinced there's a solid case to raise interest rates just yet.
It's like the economic plane is struggling to gain speed on the runway, making it a risky moment to consider take-off.
Plus, inflation trends don't give me confidence we'll meet the target, even two years out."
On top of that, he remarked on the complications of the UK's increasingly expensive housing market.
"The UK housing market is in chaos," he said to the TUC. "We're seeing a chronic and growing gap between demand and supply, which is sending house prices through the roof."
When a baby takes its first breath, a whole network of neural pathways is already in place, playing a big part in how they see the world.
These early connections might even influence the risk of developing conditions like autism.
Despite their importance, figuring out how this intricate brain network forms during pregnancy is still mostly a mystery.
Teams from Guy's and St Thomas' Hospital, King's College London, Imperial College, and Oxford University are on a mission to craft a dynamic map of how the brain grows.
This endeavor could give us invaluable insights into developmental issues that crop up when things don't go according to plan.

Prof. David Edwards, who heads the Centre for the Developing Brain, emphasizes the critical nature of prenatal scans: "Too many kids face developmental challenges from issues around birth or just before.
Scanning the brain while it's still developing is crucial since many problems seem to start appearing then."
The Developing Human Connectome Project is geared up to look at more than 1,500 babies, diving into their neurological development.
These studies will include babies in the womb, those born prematurely, and full-term infants to set benchmarks for normal development and examine the impact of birth complications.

And they’re sharing their discoveries with the wider research world. At the heart of their work are cutting-edge MRI technologies, now capable of capturing brain details that were out of reach until now.

Even though fetuses are known for wriggling around in their amniotic sacs, making it tough to get a clear scan, researchers at the Centre for the Developing Brain have come up with ways to counteract these movements, allowing them to build complete 3D images despite the fetal gymnastics.
The attack on December 19 resulted in the deaths of twelve people. Anis Amri managed to escape all the way to Italy, where police in Milan eventually shot him dead.
Authorities suspect that 26-year-old Bilel A. might have been involved in plotting the attack or at least knew something about it.
Although he was taken into custody on suspicion of benefit fraud, there wasn't enough evidence to link him directly to the attack itself.
Frauke Koehler, a spokesperson for the federal prosecutors, mentioned on Wednesday that Bilel had known Amri since late 2015.
They reportedly had intense conversations at a restaurant just the night before the attack.
Authorities searched Bilel's home, which was within an asylum shelter, and seized his communication devices for further analysis.
Apparently, Bilel used at least two fake identities across several German cities between April and November 2015.
Investigators are also looking into another person, a former roommate of Amri, as a potential witness.
Amri tried reaching out to this individual twice on the day of the attack, though it’s still unclear if they actually communicated.
A little over two weeks after the attack, German prosecutors confirmed without a doubt that Amri, who was 24 at the time, was responsible for the attack.
Investigators throughout Europe have been piecing together more details about the attack and Amri's escape to Italy.
On Wednesday, Italian police confirmed that the gun used by Amri to kill Polish driver Lukasz Urban was the same one he fired in Milan four days later.

Just before launching the attack, Amri allegedly visited Friedrich-Krause-Ufer, where he shot Urban, then stopped by a mosque before returning to the truck to carry out the attack at Breitscheidplatz, just a few miles away.
Surveillance footage later caught him near Zoo station, making an index finger gesture that is often associated with the jihadist group Islamic State.
Although some details are fuzzy, it seems Amri fled to the North Rhine-Westphalia area in western Germany.
From there, his final journey wound through the Netherlands, Belgium, France, and onto Italy, using the open borders of the Schengen zone to his advantage.
Not all pieces of Amri's story have come to light yet. Swiss police have announced they're investigating the Berlin attack after receiving a tip from another law enforcement agency.
Casper Read, a 15-year-old on his solo journey to visit his grandparents in France, found himself unexpectedly kicked off a flight after a seat mix-up.

His mom, Stephanie Portal, who hails from Worthing, West Sussex, shared that Casper felt both “kicked off and cheated.” EasyJet has since apologized, offered compensation, and is looking into what went wrong.
"There was an adult claiming the seat, and Casper was the one who had to leave.
I can't tell if it was just bad luck or if they figured it was easier to ask him to go, but it wasn’t right," said Ms. Portal.
Initially, Casper was sent up to the cockpit thinking they’d give him a new seat, but soon, he was led off the plane and ended up at the information desk.
With no help, he navigated the airport himself, unfortunately missing three earlier flights and enduring a frustrating 10-hour wait before he finally got on the last flight of the day.
Ms. Portal mentioned that an EasyJet manager told her they overbook flights by as much as five seats because sometimes people just don’t show up.
It's not about when you buy the ticket; it's about when you check in that determines if you might lose your spot.
"This system is seriously flawed, and the way the attendants handled that situation was irresponsible," she remarked.
"No kid should be bumped off a plane, and those who lose seats should get first dibs on the next available flight.
Airlines shouldn’t be playing the odds with passenger no-shows." Although usually laidback, Casper felt “kicked off and cheated,” his mom reiterated.
An EasyJet spokesperson commented: "EasyJet regrets that Casper Read's flight from London Gatwick to Toulouse was overbooked on July 20.
We're looking into how he managed to board without being told at the gate. EasyJet has specific procedures in place for unaccompanied minors, which unfortunately weren't followed here."
Back in February, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics) pointed out that the rise in potential buyers was at its lowest in nearly a year.
They mentioned that better mortgage deals are taking care of some of the pent-up demand, though prices are still likely to climb.
Meanwhile, data from mortgage lenders show the government's new Help to Buy scheme is making it easier for first-time buyers with a reduced average deposit.
The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) noted that in January, the average deposit for first-time buyers dropped to 18% from December's 20%.
However, there was a dip in loans to both first-time buyers and existing homeowners, which is typical for the season.
In January, mortgages issued to buyers fell by 16% compared to December, but they were up 30% from the same time last year, indicating a year-long growth in sales.
Simon Rubinsohn, the chief economist at Rics, suggested this slow patch might stick around for a bit.
"In February, the growth in buyer numbers we've seen over months started slowing as last summer's interest boom stabilized," he said.
"It seems like the pent-up demand from the downturn is gradually being met." Rubinsohn also hinted that bad weather, including floods, might've kept people from viewing properties.
Rics pointed out a shortage in new properties hitting the market, which is likely to push prices higher.
Though house prices across the UK did go up in February, it wasn't as rapid as before.
Rics found that 45% more surveyors observed rising prices rather than falling ones in February.
Their surveys have shown that home prices have been on the rise nationwide for 11 straight months.

According to the latest numbers from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) in February, the average home price in the UK broke the £250,000 barrier for the first time, with a 5.5% increase last year.

However, other reports suggest lower figures. The Nationwide Building Society, one of the UK's biggest mortgage lenders, says the average UK home is valued at £177,846, with annual price growth over 9%.
A massive review of 5,000 studies on golf and health uncovered that the physical perks of playing golf tend to grow as players age.

This deep dive is part of the Golf and Health Project spearheaded by the World Golf Foundation, with a mission to plug the research gaps on how golf affects aspects like mental health and muscle strengthening.
Dr. Roger Hawkes, who helms the project, mentioned that the aim is to bring "scientific rigour" to the health claims linked to golf.
He added, "We’ve had this feeling for years that we’ve been underestimating the potential health impact of golf.

We've pulled together a preliminary review of what's already known and now we’re going to zero in on this research and flag knowledge gaps so that, in five years, we’ve got solid evidence to lean on."
Firming up all this data through detailed research will really up the game in terms of providing useful resources.

Dr. Andrew Murray, one of the lead researchers, pointed out, "Evidence suggests golfers tend to outlive non-golfers, enjoying boosts in cholesterol levels, body composition, overall wellness, self-esteem, and self-worth.
Since it’s a sport that anyone can pick up regardless of age, golf shows off a ton of health benefits across different age groups."
The study also highlighted how playing golf helps folks hit and exceed government guidelines for moderate to vigorous exercise.
Golfers covering 18 holes on foot can walk between four to eight miles, while those opting for electric carts cover about four miles, burning a minimum of 500 calories in the process.
Steve Mona, CEO of the World Golf Foundation, stressed the significance of the Golf and Health Project for the sport’s progress.

"It's a universal truth that golf is good for you," Mona said. "Academic backing achieved through thorough research will provide solid resources for everyone from governments, politicians, and professional tours, to golf businesses, PGA Professionals, and beyond, all to the sport’s benefit."
The research was released to tie in with the Alfred Dunhill Links Championship happening in St Andrews this week.
If you’re interested in getting into golf, have a look at the Get Inspired activity guide for the sport.
Katie Milby, a spirited 13-year-old from the UK, is coping with Morquio A syndrome—a tough degenerative disease impacting about 105 individuals across the country.
This condition gradually chips away at mobility, health, and stamina. Her buddy, Kyle Pirrie, kickstarted a petition to push for the drug Vimizim to be available through the NHS.
While Morquio syndrome can't be cured, Vimizim offers a significant boost to the quality of life for those affected.
The drug acts by replacing a missing enzyme, helping kids grow better, boosting their energy and ability to walk, and easing pain.
However, the drug manufacturer, who has been footing the bill, plans to stop unless the NHS in England and Scotland steps up to fund it.
For Katie, who attends Stranraer Academy, losing access to the drug would be life-changing: "I wouldn't be able to move; I'd just be in so much pain," she expressed.
"And I probably wouldn't be able to go to school." This predicament inspired Kyle to launch a petition, which has already garnered nearly 2,000 signatures.
Kyle shared, "Watching a friend face possibly losing treatment made me feel terrible.
She's got a fantastic outlook—funny and friendly. It's heartbreaking to think she could be in constant pain."
Alex Fergusson, MSP for Galloway and West Dumfries, backs the initiative, too: "This medication isn't cheap, but Katie put it best—how do you value a human life?"
Fergusson remarked. "Just over a hundred patients in the UK, only five in Scotland, and those using Vimizim report significant relief from pain and symptoms."
Without treatment, most with the condition don't live past their mid-20s, but Vimizim can substantially change that.
Fergusson lauds Katie and her friends for spearheading the petition to secure treatment access.
The Scottish Medicines Consortium is currently evaluating the drug, with a decision expected by early September.
The government’s putting forward a new deal for prison officers that includes a pay raise and an earlier retirement age.

Members of the union will have their say on it via a vote. Just last month, up to 10,000 prison officers across England and Wales staged a 24-hour protest, frustrated by the increase in jail violence.

They returned to work after a High Court order demanded they end the walkout. Under the proposed deal, officers can retire at 65—three years sooner than the state pension age—without any financial penalty and still receive full pension benefits.
Uniformed staff are set to see annual pay raises ranging from 0.5% to 1% over the next three years, alongside performance-based increases.

Plus, there's a "recognition and retention" bonus of £1,000 in the works. Sam Gyimah, the prisons minister, mentioned that the government and the Prison Officers' Association (POA) reached significant agreements on health and safety improvements, and they'll be giving governors new powers over staffing in prisons.
The POA's recent actions were fueled by failed negotiations with the government on health and safety issues, especially after some serious incidents in English prisons.
In October, tragic news hit when Jamal Mahmoud, a prisoner at HMP Pentonville, was killed in a stabbing that injured two others.

Around the same time, a riot at Bedford prison caused nearly £1m in damages. Shortly after, another distressing event occurred when an officer at HMP Isle of Wight was attacked by an inmate wielding a razor blade.
To tackle these safety challenges, Justice Secretary Liz Truss announced a £1.3bn investment towards building new prisons over the next five years.
This plan includes hiring 2,100 additional prison officers, introducing drug tests for inmates both as they enter and leave prison, and providing governors more control.
Speaking about the new pay arrangement, she remarked, "This agreement is a fair offer that duly recognizes the hard work and dedication of officers nationwide, who are doing a tough job."
The network's rollout will start with 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to more than 2,000, all aimed at providing global broadband from orbit.
A key priority? Connecting schools. To pull this off, satellite manufacturing must evolve, especially for Airbus.
Typically, Europe's top space firm takes months and quite a budget to create specialized platforms.
But the OneWeb project flips that script, demanding high-volume, budget-friendly production.
They're looking at assembly line methods borrowed from car and airplane factories, planning to crank out three units per shift, each costing under a million bucks.
At first, Airbus CEO Tom Enders thought the OneWeb idea was a bit of a pipe dream.
"In space, everything's usually 'gold-plated.' It has to work perfectly, using the priciest materials," he told BBC News.
"We've had to rethink things to be commercial and cost-effective, which is key for the OneWeb model."
Airbus and OneWeb kicked off their first assembly line in Toulouse, France, and they're gearing up for two more in a new Florida factory.
Unlike traditional satellite cleanrooms, the new lines use trolley robots to move satellites around workstations.
But it's not just about automation; suppliers and parts are also adapting to this new production scale.
The first batch of 10 satellites from Toulouse is set to launch by next April, with more launches following in November.

After that, the pace picks up significantly. Building the OneWeb constellation involves a historic rocket campaign, including over 20 Soyuz launches to send groups of 32-36 satellites up to 1,200 km above Earth.
By the end of 2020, about 300 satellites should be operational, climbing to over 600 the following year and surpassing 800 by mid-decade.
OneWeb and Airbus face competition from SpaceX, Boeing, ViaSat, and other companies aiming to set up similar mega-constellations.
Not all will snag the billions needed in funding, though, and Airbus believes OneWeb has the first-mover advantage.
Kelly, who's 25, got back late after a trip to Australia and ended up benched for Saturday's loss to Leigh in the Qualifiers.
Peacock mentioned that they're still having talks about Kelly's disciplinary situation and whether he'll play in Sunday's game against London.
When asked about Kelly's future with the club next season, Peacock told the BBC's Super League Show: "It depends on Albert. Right now, we're in a bit of limbo."
Since joining Hull KR at the beginning of 2015, Kelly has been a key player, even leading the Robins to last season's Challenge Cup final.
If they'd beaten Leigh, Rovers could've climbed to second in the Qualifiers table, but the 25-18 defeat at home left them stuck in fourth and fighting to keep their Super League spot for next season.
Former England skipper Peacock explained, "It was a tough call, especially given Albert's performance this year and the game's stakes.
But when you grant someone time at home, and they extend their stay, messing up prep for maybe our biggest game, you've got to draw a line.
It's a letdown because he put personal choices above the club, the other players, and the fans."
On another note, stand-off Maurice Blair will miss the game against London, as he's been granted leave to attend his brother's funeral in Australia.
The public is set to head to the polls on Thursday, June 23, 2016, for a referendum—basically a nationwide vote.

Let’s dig into what’s been happening with the UK and the European Union. Back in 2013, then British Prime Minister, David Cameron, promised that if the Conservative Party won the next general election, he'd let the people decide if the UK should stick around in the EU or not.
Fast forward to now: the Conservatives won, so here comes the promised referendum.
A referendum’s a straightforward vote where all adults get a say, usually answering a simple "Yes" or "No" question.
The side with more than half the votes takes the win. To give a bit of context, the European Union (EU) is essentially a coalition of 28 countries in Europe where governments work together.
It was born after World War Two, with an eye towards preventing further conflicts through closer cooperation.
Think of it like joining a club: you gotta play by the rules, but you also get perks.
Member countries contribute funds, mostly through taxes, that the EU uses to influence how folks live and do business across Europe.
There’s an EU parliament too, made up of Members of the European Parliament, who are selected by the citizens of EU countries.
The parliament’s job? Tweaking, approving, or throwing out laws that affect all member nations.

Here’s who joined when: in 1957, Belgium, France, Netherlands, Germany, Italy, and Luxembourg were the first in; the UK tagged along in 1973 with Denmark and Ireland; Greece hopped on board in 1981, followed by Portugal and Spain in 1986.

Austria, Finland, and Sweden joined in 1995; 2004 saw a big wave with Hungary, Poland, Czech Republic, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, and Cyprus; then there was Bulgaria and Romania in 2007, and finally, Croatia in 2013.
The EU was largely set up to make trade smoother, cutting through the red tape when buying and selling between countries.
It’s also loosened immigration rules, letting folks move more freely within its borders.
EU laws touch on a boatload of things, like work hours, safety standards, and even fishing quotas.
Throughout the UK's 40-ish years in the EU, there’s been this ongoing debate about the whole arrangement.
Some folks say the EU boosts the UK’s wealth and standing, while others worry it chips away at British sovereignty.

Media playback isn't supported on this device. At the Great City Games, the 30-year-old gold medalist from London 2012 pulled off a win with a final jump of 8.18m, leaving Uruguay's Emiliano Lasa behind with 7.96m.
Meanwhile, Holly Bradshaw set a new British record in the women's pole vault at 4.80m.

The event kicked off with a minute of silence, honoring the victims of Monday's horrific attack in Manchester, where a suicide bomber killed 22 and injured 116 as concert-goers were leaving an Ariana Grande performance at the Manchester Arena.

Both the council and police gave the green light for the Great City Games to continue in the city center, alongside the Great Manchester Run scheduled for Sunday and set to air on BBC One from 12:30 to 14:30 BST.
It marked the first big event since the attack, drawing in massive crowds under the sunny skies of Deansgate and Albert Square, which had hosted a earlier vigil for those affected by the tragedy.
Rutherford put on a stellar show in the square, securing first place with an 8.08m jump on his second attempt, before stretching his lead with the final jump.
"It's been amazing to see everyone out here supporting us," Rutherford commented.
"It's been a rough week, and I'm overjoyed to give people a reason to smile. Manchester's always been a favorite for me, not just because of the football, but due to the amazing support for sports.
It's something special." Media playback isn't supported on this device. Bradshaw really shined, not only surpassing her personal best but also smashing her previous British pole vault record.

She started off at 4.50m and cleared it on her third attempt, outdoing her opponents, including fellow Britons Rachel Gibbons and Sally Peake, as well as Belgium's Chloe Henry, who couldn't get past the 4m mark.
Bradshaw then bettered her 2012 record of 4.71m, nailing 4.80m on her first go.
"It was nerve-wracking at the start," Bradshaw shared with BBC Sport, having finished sixth in London 2012 and fifth in Rio.
"But the conditions were spot-on. Once I got focused, I was thrilled to jump 4.72 and then 4.80. My training's been amazing, and I'm in the best shape I’ve ever been."
The central bank decided, with everyone in agreement, to bump up the key interest rate to somewhere between 0.5% and 0.75%.
They pointed to stronger economic growth and rising employment as the main reasons.
Still, they emphasized that any further rate increases would be "gradual" in the near future.
Fed Chair Janet Yellen called the economic outlook "highly uncertain" and saw the rate hike as just a "modest shift."
She mentioned that with the new Trump administration coming in, rates might have to go up faster next year.
President-elect Trump has promised to spur growth with tax cuts, more spending, and deregulation.
During a press conference after the announcement, Yellen remarked it was too early to predict Trump's economic plans without more details.

However, she did say that some Federal Open Market Committee members have already factored in potential increased spending into their forecasts, which is leading them to anticipate three rate hikes next year, as opposed to the two they predicted back in September.

While talking to the press, Yellen acknowledged, "We are operating under a cloud of uncertainty... All the FOMC members recognize the considerable uncertainty about possible changes in economic policy and their effects on the economy."
She also avoided addressing Trump's public remarks about the Fed or his habit of tweeting about policy and criticizing companies.
"I strongly believe in the independence of the Fed," she stated, adding, "I won't offer the incoming president advice."
The rate increase was expected, marking the first hike since the last one over a year ago.

Rates have been extremely low since the global financial crisis, but the U.S. economy is showing signs of bouncing back, with recent data on consumer confidence, job growth, housing prices, and growth in manufacturing and services supporting that view.
Yellen described the rate hike as a sign of confidence in the economy's progress and the expectation that it will keep moving forward.
Even though inflation isn't quite at the Fed's 2% goal, they expect it will pick up gradually over the medium term.

The Fed’s statement noted that "Economic conditions will warrant only gradual increases in the federal funds rate," and they added that the rate will probably stay below long-term levels for a while. The Fed also released its economic forecasts for the next three years.
Lexi Brown, whose full name was Alexys, sadly passed away at her home on Emmadale Close in Weymouth last Thursday.
Right now, authorities are digging into how she ended up trapped. A post-mortem is on the schedule for this week.
Initially, the goal for the fundraising campaign was to bring in £2,000. Alison Record, the person who set up the Just Giving page, shared her deep sadness over Lexi's passing.
The fundraising page says: "Everyone now knows about the heartbreaking loss the Brown family is facing with the death of their beloved daughter, Lexi.
It's an unimaginable sorrow, and they should be able to grieve without worrying about the financial strain."

Record explained, "This tragedy has hit them hard; they need time together, and every penny raised will help make that happen." There are loads of comments on the page, offering support and solidarity.
Steph Harris wrote, "Our thoughts are with you during this painful time, fly high beautiful princess.
Love Steph and family xxx" Lesley Andrews added: "Money won't ease the hurt, but every penny comes with a lot of love.
Take care. xx" Aster Group, the housing association managing the property, is working alongside the police in their investigation.
The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) is also looking into the incident. Dorset County Council mentioned that they weren't responsible for installing the disabled lift in the home.
Back in March 2012, Nottingham embarked on a hefty £570 million project to extend the Chilwell and Clifton tram lines.

Fast forward, and public services are now rolling out from 6 a.m. sharp. Yes, there were bumps along the way—businesses and commuters voiced their woes about the chaos, but Nottingham City Council stands by the belief that this venture will give the local economy a much-needed boost.
The initial hiccups were due to surprise pipe and cable relocations, followed by some necessary track bed updates.
The overhaul brought a budget of £570 million and introduced 28 new stations, stretching 11 miles of fresh track with 22 new trams, all set to transport up to 20 million passengers.
Contractor Vinci took quite a hit, reporting a whopping £165 million loss in its civil engineering branch, thanks to these setbacks.
Jane Urquhart, who oversees NET at Nottingham City Council, called it a "really great day" for Nottingham.
"Trams every seven minutes mean better access to key city spots," she commented.
She emphasized that the tram system is crucial in easing congestion, improving the environment, and making Nottingham a better place all around.
While NET and the council held back on firm opening dates, recent weeks saw them wrap up final tests.
Steve Barber from the Light Rail Transit Association, once a Broxtowe borough councillor, was relieved to see the project finally done, hoping it would benefit Beeston and the wider city.
Down in Clifton, Stephen Knight, a butcher, shared his optimism despite past trade dips of a third due to disruptions.
"Workers have been supportive, and we hope the public returns, even with parking challenges," he said.
Meanwhile, Lisa Withers, a local florist, was ecstatic to be aboard the first tram from Clifton, confident it marks a new chapter for Nottingham.
"Today's fantastic for the city," she noted, "and I'm sure the tram will push forward progress for everyone—residents, workers, and visitors alike."
Alexander Wotherspoon, an 83-year-old man, stood before the Paisley Sheriff Court facing charges tied to the tragic death of 17-year-old Eilish Herron.
The case revolves around an incident back in September 2014 when Eilish was hit by Mr. Wotherspoon's car at an Asda petrol station located in Linwood.

The charges claim he lost control while reversing. Wotherspoon, a Houston, Renfrewshire resident who relies on a zimmer frame to get around, insists he didn't start the engine and reverse with the door open, as alleged, leading to the mishap.

The charge states his vehicle accidentally rammed into the Renault Clio that Eilish was refueling, which caused her to fall, shift her car, and ultimately the vehicle reversed over her, dragging her underneath and delivering fatal injuries.
This heart-wrenching incident took place at the Asda petrol station within Phoenix Retail Park, Linwood, on September 10, 2014.
The case, presided over by Sheriff Susan Sinclair, has been deferred for trial in August, and Mr. Wotherspoon remains out on bail.
In the past, Eilish's mother, Shanneal, aged 47, said, "Eilish was a wonderful girl, a typical teenager who treasured her life, family, and sports.
She was my best friend, and we shared countless laughs. Her absence leaves an indescribable void in our family, which is very close-knit."
Eilish had a deep passion for netball, playing with Paisley Juniors and also volunteering as a junior coach.
In memory of her, Netball Scotland launched the Eilish Herron Young Coach of the Year Award, celebrating young coaches annually.
Jason Alexander, 39 years old and from Griffithstown, Torfaen, found himself in hot water after he misused a company credit card to buy around £91,000 worth of iPads, phones, and computers.
After pleading guilty to fraud, he was handed a two-year prison sentence back in January.
Now, things have taken another turn as Cardiff Crown Court has ordered him to pay back £115,000 to his former employers.
During the proceedings, Judge Stephen Hopkins QC commented on Alexander's actions, hinting they might have been driven by a kind of misguided generosity.
"You spent up to £5,000 on these gadgets, only to sell them off to employees for as little as £180, letting them think they were getting a great deal," the judge said.
Alexander's got six months to cough up £115,867 or he’s looking at another 18 months behind bars.
According to the judge, the fallout of Alexander's scheme stretched far and wide.
"Your actions have left a mark on many unsuspecting folks," the judge noted. "Those who bought from you now feel duped and stressed.
The impact on your workmates was substantial, sinking morale all around. You breached their trust over several years," he continued.

As the purchasing manager at Northern Automotive Systems, a car parts company situated in Gilwern near Abergavenny, Monmouthshire, Alexander pulled off 287 online purchases through platforms like Amazon, eBay, and Argos.
Typically, the company's credit card bill only ran a few hundred pounds a month, but with Alexander, it skyrocketed to nearly £10,000 monthly.
His shady dealings got busted when dubious company managers grilled employees about snagging cheap electronics.
Trying to cover his tracks, Alexander went to lengths—wiping emails, faking invoices, receipts, and card statements.
During his 14-year stint, he also took advantage of company funds to fuel up his white Land Rover, a red Mini, and even his partner’s Ford Fiesta.
At 39, the cyclist who snagged a silver medal in Beijing back in 2008 found herself sidelined with a back injury during training.
As she bid farewell to the sport, she had some sharp words about how she was treated.
Now, she's turning back to dentistry, where she expects to be on equal footing, saying, "As a woman in my thirties, I will be treated as an equal."
She didn't hide her frustration with her Great Britain teammates and coach Shane Sutton for leaving her out of the team pursuit events at the London Olympics two years ago.
"The past decade of my life has been all about professional cycling, and overall, it's been incredibly fulfilling," she reflected.
"I've always given my all as a professional athlete, and I'm truly proud of everything I've achieved."

Originally hailing from County Londonderry, she won an Olympic silver in the individual pursuit for Great Britain in Beijing and snagged team pursuit golds at the World Championships in 2008, 2009, and 2011.
Living in Cornwall, she raced for England at the 2006 Commonwealth Games, then grabbed a silver for Northern Ireland in Delhi four years later.
She had hoped her final track appearance would be a podium finish in Glasgow, but her injury got in the way.
"Deciding to end one's sporting career is never easy," she admitted. "It's disappointing not to compete at the Commonwealth Games, but I wish my Northern Irish teammates all the best in Glasgow.
Looking ahead, I do hope to give back to the sport, but right now, I'm eager to focus on my dentistry career."
When it comes to her comments about sexism in cycling, former Team GB track cyclist Victoria Pendleton backed her up, acknowledging that women do face different treatment.
The Olympic gold medalist and former world champion told BBC Radio 5 live: "Sport is still largely a man's world, and navigating it can be tough."

Pendleton, who retired after the 2012 Olympics at 31, shared: "I often felt less supported as a woman and had to take on a more male-oriented approach. I can see how she could have thrived with another kind of support."
Bello Abba Mohammed and his father are facing accusations of misappropriating $1.5 million (£1 million) meant for buying arms for the troops fighting against Boko Haram militants.

They’ve both pleaded not guilty to the charges. After taking office in May, President Muhammadu Buhari started digging into military gear procurement, which led to the discovery of fake contracts tallying up to $2 billion.

Just last month, Sambu Dasuki, the former national security adviser, found himself behind bars dealing with 19 charges, including fraud, money laundering, and criminal breach of trust tied to this mess.
As expected, Dasuki, who had spearheaded operations against Boko Haram during President Goodluck Jonathan’s leadership, has denied any wrongdoing.

Bello Haliru Mohammed, who ran the defense ministry for Jonathan between 2011 and 2012—and who's now high up in the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP)—made his court appearance in Abuja in a wheelchair.
He ended up in the hospital after the hearing was postponed, according to Nigeria's Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC).

Meanwhile, his son is sitting in jail, waiting for a bail hearing on Thursday. Boko Haram's pursuit to create an Islamic state in northeastern Nigeria has been devastating, taking countless lives over the past six years.
Though soldiers had long complained about lacking proper gear despite the military's hefty budget, they’re saying things have improved since Buhari took over.

However, backers of the previous president insist that this uptick in equipment is all thanks to orders placed during Jonathan’s time in office, as pointed out by the BBC's Abuja editor, Bashir Sa’ad Abdullahi.

In an impressive showing, the Lions clinched a stunning victory over Sri Lanka A, thanks to a record-smashing 367-run partnership that propelled them to an eye-popping 425-1 total—the second-highest ever in List A matches.
Duckett was on fire, racking up an unbeaten 220 from just 131 balls, which is the ninth-highest score in List A history. Bell-Drummond chipped in with a brilliant 171 off 139 balls.
Coach Flower, who now guides the Lions, remarked, "These guys are more than ready for international cricket."
The tri-series played out beautifully for Flower's squad. They managed wins twice against both Pakistan A and Sri Lanka A, with their batsmen scoring over 150 in every game.
Duckett's form was unstoppable; he hammered another 163 not out, leading the team to a seven-wicket triumph against Pakistan A on July 19, and kept the pace up in Monday’s 140-run win.
Dawid Malan, the 28-year-old from Middlesex, who recently got the call for England's T20 matches against Sri Lanka, knocked up 185 in an 88-run Duckworth-Lewis victory over Sri Lanka on July 21.
Meanwhile, seasoned international player Sam Billings, who's had five ODIs and seven T20s under his belt, smashed 175 in the second win against Pakistan on Sunday.
Flower had this to say on the Tuffers and Vaughan Cricket Show on BBC Radio 5 live: "These young lads are set to elevate English cricket as they vie for their spots on the team.
Their stellar innings and partnerships haven’t gone unnoticed; the selectors must be watching closely."
Flower, who previously coached England's national side from 2009 to 2014, particularly hailed Northants' 21-year-old opener Duckett as "a very talented young man."
He added, "We can't tell what’s ahead, but there’s no reason Duckett shouldn’t enjoy a successful international career."
Katharine of Aragon died in 1536 at Kimbolton Castle and was given quite the grand send-off at her funeral held at a cathedral.
Every year, there's a festival in her memory, featuring a Catholic mass—something you don't see every day in an Anglican cathedral.
It's part of the BBC's People's Passion series, which dives into how cathedrals function in today's world.
Katharine’s marriage to Henry VIII took a hit because she couldn't produce a male heir for the Tudors.
Stuart Orme from Vivacity Heritage, which helps put together the Katharine of Aragon Festival, mentioned, "She was admired for her piety and dignity."
Many people felt for Katharine after Henry divorced her, thinking she'd been wronged.

Though she lived modestly after their split, her funeral on January 29, 1536, was anything but; it brought in four bishops and six abbots. Her tomb was adorned with black marble, gold inscriptions, and decorations.
Orme also explained that when Oliver Cromwell's troops ransacked the cathedral in 1643, they made off with the gold.
Then, in the 1700s, a dean thought the marble would look good in his summerhouse floor.
Fast forward to the late 1800s—Katharine Clayton, the wife of a cathedral canon, rallied English Katharines to chip in for the marble slab we see today.
The Katharine of Aragon Festival takes place on the Friday and Saturday closest to January 29.
A Spanish embassy rep is invited to the service on Friday, and a Catholic mass follows on Saturday.
Hundreds of kids in Tudor getups learn about life in the 16th century through reenactments.
Flowers and her symbol, the pomegranate, are placed on her tomb. She picked the pomegranate as a princess in Spain because it symbolized fertility back in medieval times.
Last month in Harlow, Essex, 39-year-old Arek Jozwik was attacked. Just a few days after that tragic event, two more Polish men were assaulted during a vigil held for him.
In response, Essex Police brought in Polish officers to help reassure the community.
Roger Hirst, the Essex Police and Crime Commissioner, mentioned that since the Brexit vote, there's been an uptick in derogatory remarks aimed at non-British individuals.
Speaking to the BBC, he said: "There's a change in public sentiment... something that wasn’t obvious a few months back.

It seems to line up with the Brexit decision." To keep the community informed and reassured, the local engagement team, including 2nd Lieutenant Bartosz Czernicki and Chief Sergeant Dariusz Tybura, will be mingling with residents over the next week.
Chief Inspector Alan Ray noted some locals shared their reluctance to trust police based on experiences in Poland, though others were glad to have the Polish officers around.
Sadly, Mr. Jozwik passed away from head injuries on August 29, two days after allegedly being punched and knocked to the ground at The Stow, Harlow.

Inspector Ray highlighted that the idea behind bringing in Polish officers was to offer reassurance to the entire community, acknowledging that both Polish and English police are met with mixed feelings.
"Some folks trust us, and others don’t," he said. Six teenagers have been arrested and are currently out on police bail in connection with Mr. Jozwik's death.
Portugal, sitting comfortably at the top of their Euro 2016 qualifying group, decided to give Cristiano Ronaldo a breather in their match against Cape Verde, who are ranked 38th worldwide.
The match kicked off with Cape Verde hitting the ground running—Odair Fortes drew first blood, and after halftime, Admilson Gege upped the ante with another goal.
Things went south for Portugal’s crew when defender Andre Pinto received a red card about an hour into the game.
Even though Cape Verde didn't make it far in this year's Africa Cup of Nations, they find themselves ranked between Wales and Scotland on FIFA’s list.
Nestled about 400 miles off the coast of Senegal in the Atlantic, they pulled off a tidy 2-0 win against the host team.
Despite Portugal's relentless grinding—the highlight being Ukra's right-footed rocket that just missed, set up nicely by André Almeida—their effort came up short.
Portugal nabbed numerous free kicks thanks to fouls from Cape Verde’s players like Jeffry Fortes and Nuno Rocha, but it didn't shift the game’s tides.
Both teams shuffled their lineups a bit, with Portugal swapping André Almeida for André Gomes, and Cape Verde sending in Ricardo for Júlio Tavares.
André André almost got on the board with a header from Vitorino Antunes’ cross, but Cape Verde's defense stood firm.
Sérgio Semedo picked up a yellow card late in the showdown, showcasing their defensive grit. When the final whistle blew, Portugal couldn’t crack Cape Verde’s lead.

Amid tough competition in the market, Sainsbury's, which ranks as the UK’s second-largest supermarket, noted a 1.1% drop in like-for-like sales, excluding fuel, over the 16 weeks leading up to September 24th.
Total sales also saw a dip, slipping by 0.4%. Despite these setbacks, Chief Executive Mike Coupe remains optimistic, believing their strategy will outshine major rivals.
To tackle challenges from fast-growing German discount stores Aldi and Lidl, Sainsbury's has shifted towards lowering prices on everyday products rather than sticking to promotions.
Recent price cuts include staples like broccoli, onions, Margherita pizza, and their own-brand nappies.

Coupe’s take? He thinks customers still pick Sainsbury's over the competition. In a big move, Sainsbury's wrapped up a £1.4 billion acquisition of Home Retail Group, the owner of Argos, to broaden shopping choices for customers.
With this, they're planning to set up 200 digital collection points in their stores by year’s end.
Before the acquisition, Home Retail Group reported a 2.3% rise in like-for-like sales for the quarter ending August 27th.
Plus, facing competition from Amazon's grocery delivery, Sainsbury's is pushing its "Chop Chop" one-hour delivery in London, using bikes to add a twist to customer convenience.
Now, Sainsbury's isn't new to challenges. They've seen profits dwindle for two years straight, and analysts foresee another dip for the 2016-17 fiscal year.
Profits for the year ending March 12 dropped from £681 million to £587 million.

Their shares have dipped by 9% over the last six months. John Ibbotson, of Retail Vision, didn't mince words, calling Sainsbury's simpler pricing strategy and scrapping multi-buy promotions "distinctly underwhelming" given the market's tough conditions.
On the upside, he thinks Argos could boost Sainsbury's finances and enhance its online services and logistics.
Still, he warned, blending these two companies won't be a walk in the park, and stressed the need to keep their eye on the main prize: the grocery business.
Meanwhile, Aldi, too, chimed in, revealing that the constant price battle has been squeezing its profit margins—not immune to the market's pressures either.
Lord Advocate James Wolffe has raised concerns about the potential impact on Scots' safety and security if the UK pulls out of Europol.
In a recent online article, he backed the Scottish government's push for the UK to adopt the new rules of the EU police agency.
If the Home Office doesn't opt into these regulations, the UK is set to lose its membership by May 2017. Wolffe has plans to meet with MEPs and top lawyers in Brussels on Wednesday.
In a piece for EurActiv, he stated, "I firmly believe it’s not in the interests of Scotland, the UK, or Europe to walk away from criminal justice cooperation mechanisms following the referendum.
Staying fully engaged is key to maximizing our influence and input in their evolution."
The UK has a deadline of December 2016 to decide whether to sign up for the new Europol regulations.
Scotland’s Justice Secretary Michael Matheson also pressed the UK government for a confirmation of their participation.
Wolffe echoed this sentiment, underscoring the importance of being part of Europol and Eurojust for Scotland.

"Without these, our citizens’ safety will, in my opinion, be compromised. The danger posed by transnational crime is too significant to back off from police and judicial cooperation in Europe," he remarked.

Brandon Lewis, the UK’s policing and fire minister, responded by saying, "The prime minister has assured that our law enforcement collaboration will carry on post-EU, and we will work to ensure our citizens’ safety.
A decision on the new Europol regulation opt-in will be made soon. For now, the UK remains a full member, with the option to opt into the new framework as long as we are in the EU."
Since 2011, the European Arrest Warrant (EAW), facilitated through Europol, has been involved in 541 cases in Scottish courts, leading to 367 extraditions from Scotland.
The Crown Office has also issued 45 EAWs to swiftly bring people back to Scotland for trials on serious charges.
Over the past year, the UK has strengthened the EAW system with access to the Schengen Information System.
After their 2-0 win against Romania in Falkirk last Friday, the players opted to skip media interactions.
This choice comes as Anna Signeul and her squad gear up for Euro 2017 in the Netherlands next month.
The Scottish FA didn't hide its disappointment in a statement, pointing out the players' decision to dodge media duties.
Still, they’re hopeful for a solution before the upcoming Tuesday friendly in Vaxjo against Sweden.
"We confirm we're discussing terms and conditions with the Scotland Women's national team as they prep for the Euros in the Netherlands," the statement mentioned.

"Our goal is to resolve this quickly through talks with their advisors." To ensure optimal preparation for the finals—where they’ll face England, Portugal, and Spain—the Scottish players based locally are getting financial assistance to go full-time.
The funding comes courtesy of the Scottish Football Partnership, Sport Scotland, and energy company SSE, and it'll cover their needs until the tournament ends.

Around half the team is expected to benefit from this arrangement. Coach Signeul is steering clear of the contract discussions, mentioning that it's out of her hands and up to the players and the SFA.
"I'm not involved at all in that process," she remarked, adding that the same approach is taken with men’s head coach Gordon Strachan.
"Men's teams also handle their contracts separately, and I doubt Gordon is involved with those; it’s a coach-free zone." Signeul plans to reveal her Euro 2017 lineup on June 20.

Research teams recently found that some common devices—like smart doorbells, connected cameras, a child's toy, and a child tracking locator—were vulnerable to hacking due to weak default passwords and poor security measures.
These weaknesses could have exposed user data, but thankfully, all four companies reacted promptly.
After being alerted, they worked to strengthen their security and patch these vulnerabilities.
Tod Beardsley, who heads security research at Rapid7, pointed out a big issue with the Internet of Things (IoT): almost everyone is unknowingly drawn into tech-related issues.
While these companies churn out their smart devices confidently, they often overlook key design steps to ensure security.

During his review, Beardsley identified that a toy bear with internet capabilities had lousy web configurations, potentially leaking sensitive info about children, their families, and their home networks.
The HereO watch faced similar risks—hackers could have sneaked into a family's watch network.

Eli Shemesh, the chief tech officer at HereO, shared that they resolved these concerns within hours of being notified and appreciated Rapid7's insights and the wider IoT community's commitment to user safety.
He reassured that since their GPS watches weren't yet on the market, no children were ever in harm's way.
Elsewhere, researchers at Context IS found that a Motorola Focus outdoor camera could be hijacked remotely to gain access to a connected network.
At the same time, Pentest Partners discovered that the Ring smart doorbell, known for streaming footage to a phone app, had its own issues.
By removing its cover and hitting the setup button, an attacker could nab the Wi-Fi network key.
Fortunately, all these security flaws were reported and fixed by the manufacturers.
Era Home Security, in particular, acted quickly to address their bug, as noted by Ken Munro from Pentest Partners.
Not long after Germany's Lufthansa revealed it would stop flying to Venezuela, they explained that the government owed them millions in ticket sales.
Venezuela's economy, which leans heavily on oil, has been hit hard by the drop in global oil prices.

This has led to soaring inflation and constant shortages of basic necessities. Many airlines are struggling to convert their earnings into dollars due to Venezuela's strict currency controls, making it tough to send money out of the country.
Latam Airlines also said it's suspending flights to Caracas Airport, without saying when they’ll resume.
The first flights to go will be from Sao Paulo to Caracas, happening in just days, and routes from Lima and Santiago will be cut by the end of July.
Venezuela's currency controls, put in place back in 2003 by the late President Hugo Chavez, have only gotten stricter over the last couple of years.
This has pushed many airlines to scale back operations because they can't get billions in revenue out of the country, stuck in bolivars.

Now, some airlines are only accepting dollars for ticket payments. Meanwhile, the Venezuelan government insists it’s using its shrinking foreign reserves to buy essential goods like medicine and industrial gear.
To add to the mess, Coca-Cola has stopped making some drinks due to a lack of sugar, and Bridgestone has pulled out entirely after more than 60 years in Venezuela.
Teams huddled around F1's commercial chief Bernie Ecclestone and FIA president Jean Todt to hash out the mess with the new elimination qualifying format.
Despite most teams wanting to go back to the 2015 system, Mercedes F1 boss Toto Wolff pointed out that Todt and Ecclestone weren't on board.
Instead, the FIA pitched a fresh aggregate system to be discussed next week. Come qualifying at Sunday's race in Bahrain, Lewis Hamilton clocked the quickest time.
The twist? By the end of the first and second sessions, the track practically emptied out with no cars in sight.
Red Bull's team principal, Christian Horner, voiced that everyone agreed this new format, booting the slowest car every 90 seconds through three sessions, isn’t cutting it.
He said, "There's a hang-up from the promoter and FIA about not reverting to 2015. The teams are ready to roll back.
A compromise is up for debate—let's mull over what's on the table. Without agreeing to a middle ground, we're stuck with this flawed setup."

Both Horner and Wolff admitted they were scratching their heads over why Ecclestone and Todt were against the 2015 format, where cars stayed in the session, gradually reducing in numbers over three rounds.
Todt, during Saturday's briefing, shared that race promotors were pushing for change, worried the 2015 approach lacked thrill.
Ecclestone chimed in, saying he wanted a shake-up in grid configurations so speed wasn't the only factor putting cars in front.
Horner added there's chatter about returning to the old system but using drivers' two fastest laps for grid spots instead of just one.
He hinted, "This plan needs deeper examination—maybe aggregate times of two laps rather than one. It’s crucial to closely consider this before bringing it to a vote."
