According to an informal rotational system, the ninth Secretary-General ought to hail from Eastern Europe.
Still, this opportunity might slip away because regional candidates aren't getting strong backing at home or a unified push from neighboring countries.
Although the process has seen more transparency with open hearings, this has led to a crowded field of 11 candidates; eight are from Eastern Europe.
Among them are seasoned figures like former or current foreign ministers from Moldova, Macedonia, Montenegro, Croatia, Serbia, and Slovakia.
Slovenia's ex-president is also a contender. Plus, Bulgaria has put forward Irina Bokova, currently helming UNESCO, the UN's cultural and educational division.

Yet, there's a downside. Some worry these Eastern European candidates could cancel each other out, making it easier for heavy-hitters like Argentina's Susana Malcorra, New Zealand's Helen Clark, or Portugal's former head of UNHCR, Antonio Guterres, to take the lead.
A straw poll by the Security Council in July should give a clearer picture of where each candidate stands.
There's chatter about more entrants, too; Kristalena Georgieva from Bulgaria is contemplating a run.
In her words to the BBC, "I'm watching the race closely. A lot of people want me to jump in.

Let's see how it unfolds." She's already lining up some international support. Initially, Ms. Bokova seemed in a strong position with backing from Russia, but her prospects have dimmed amid a critical UNESCO investigation and her views on Palestinian statehood, which the U.S. isn't too thrilled about.

For context, almost half of UNESCO's budget goes to staff salaries. On the flip side, Georgieva boasts a strong track record at the World Bank and she served as an EU commissioner for humanitarian affairs and is currently a commissioner for budgetary affairs.
She spearheaded an initiative aimed at saving $1 billion annually by directly aiding those in need.
For more on the candidates and how the selection process unfolds, you can check out the details on the UN's website.
Richard Gowan from the European Council on Foreign Relations commented, "Insiders say that either Kristalena Georgieva or Antonio Guterres could give the UN the kind of change it needs."
There's a consensus that the next UN leader should have solid managerial chops and experience in the international realm.
Jenny Rathbone and Mike Hedges are both hoping to snag a spot in a ballot that could let them propose a bill to outlaw agency fees.
Hedges calls these fees a "tax" that hits some of the most vulnerable folks in society, particularly students.
On the flip side, a letting agent warns that banning fees might throw a wrench in efforts to amp up professionalism in the sector.
Meanwhile, the Welsh Government is open to looking at how such a law might roll out.
Scotland already said goodbye to these charges, and the UK government is mulling over kicking them out in England too.
In Wales, there's no official plan yet, but the government is "actively considering" taking action—despite some flak for not moving quicker.
All opposition party assembly members (AMs) seem on board with the idea. New laws can pop up through a random ballot that AMs enter.
Hedges mentions that fees are a huge headache in university cities and places where housing demand is through the roof.
He figures about 20 AMs might throw their hats in for the ballot, with him and Rathbone as the known frontrunners pushing for the ban.
Jenny Rathbone, an AM from Cardiff Council, pointed out that their dual effort "doubles the chances of one of us being picked."

Catherine Iannucci, a 21-year-old history and politics student at Cardiff University, shared that she and her six co-tenants shelled out £80 each just to get their place, adding up to a hefty £560 in fees.
A member of Labour Students who's delved into agency fees research for Rathbone, Iannucci said, "It's a significant amount of money.
We don't really know what they're for or what they cover." Plus, she forked over a month's rent as a deposit and another £50.
"When we start hunting around February, smack in the middle of the term, spare cash is scarce.
It adds pressure for the rest of the term," she explained. She's all for a ban—as long as it doesn't trigger rent hikes.
The latest cement material is pretty impressive: it's designed to develop mineral phases that trap radioactive isotopes trying to sneak through.
Studies done at the atomic level indicate this cement could retain its trapping abilities for at least 2,000 years.
Guys at Sheffield University claim their mix is up to 50% more effective than the barriers we've seen so far.
Sooner or later, the government has to pick a spot for a massive underground facility to store hundreds of thousands of cubic meters of nuclear waste gathered over the last 60 years.
A lot of this waste will get immobilized and encased in cement, which has to stop radioisotopes from spreading for a long, long time.
The Sheffield researchers did their experiments at the Diamond Light Source over in Oxfordshire.
It’s the UK’s top synchrotron, using X-rays to take a super close look at samples.
Diamond now has a dedicated space, a beamline, for really long-term research. This setup let Dr. Claire Corkhill and her team study various cement mixes for the past year and a half.

"We've gathered high-resolution data, which helps us build predictive models to understand how phases form and when, reaching up to the 2,000-year mark—right when we anticipate water will start interacting with a geological disposal site," Dr. Corkhill from the Sheffield NucleUS research group said.
The top-performing cement they've come up with, temporarily named No7, contains blast-furnace slag.
The sulphides from slag react with water to create sulphate mineral phases, which are super at soaking up technetium-99.
"Technetium-99 is a common fission product—you'll find it only in nuclear reactors—and it's known for being very mobile in the environment.
But our cement grabs hold of it, keeping it from moving around," Dr. Corkhill noted.
Findings indicate No7 has a big edge over the currently proposed Nirex Reference Vault Backfill cement barrier.
But they're not stopping there; research continues on other mixes to uncover even more effective solutions.
The cement research was presented at the AAAS annual meeting, alongside the Diamond facility's capabilities for extended experiments.
This unique facility lets scientists check out how materials behave over time, with samples set up on a robotic bench, getting monitored without hands-on interference.
England is gearing up for their first competitive match since that disappointing World Cup exit, and it’s a pretty critical moment.
Hodgson’s pretty upfront about the stakes here, saying, “We need to do well. If the result isn't great, it's a lesson learned for our long-term goals.

Winning one game doesn’t guarantee us greatness for 2016, and losing it doesn't mean we're no good.” This game sets off England's attempt to qualify for the tournament in France, where, for the first time ever, we’ll see 24 teams in the European Championships.
They've got a face-off with Switzerland, and that's just the beginning—Hodgson's lads have nine more games in Group E over the next 13 months as they push for a spot in the finals.
The top two teams in each group will automatically qualify, plus the best of the third-placed teams.

The rest will have to fight it out in the play-offs. The last time England played a major competitive match, they ended up with a 0-0 draw against Costa Rica in Brazil last June, which saw them knocked out after losses to Italy and Uruguay.
Hodgson, who's been in charge since 2012 and steered England to the Euro quarter-finals that year, admits the World Cup's failure still weighs heavy.
But he’s clear that this Euro 2016 qualifying run isn't about starting from scratch.
"We're not at the beginning of development," he stated. "We're moving forward despite the World Cup hiccup.
This isn't a brand-new team. We've got players like Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, Ross Barkley, and Raheem Sterling who've been around.

Still, we need to make sure we’re much stronger in the next two years." As they prep for Switzerland, England just scraped a 1-0 win over Norway in a friendly at Wembley, where Hodgson was visibly peeved when reminded that his squad only managed two shots on target, including Wayne Rooney's penalty.
When asked about handling criticism since the World Cup, Hodgson said, "There's no nasty edge here.
I love my job. It's a fantastic chance. Coaching your country is the height of a coaching career.
Am I aware of the popularity dip after the World Cup? I'd have been surprised if there hadn't been one."
Forty-nine children tragically lost their lives and over 70 others suffered severe injuries when a fire tore through the ABC nursery, a facility without an emergency exit.
Families of the victims have been fighting for justice, insisting the nursery didn't meet safety standards.
Yet, a lawyer representing these families stated that the arrest warrants went after the wrong people.
Prosecutors had called for the nursery's director, some managers, and teachers to be arrested.
Gabriel Alvarado, from Hands United for Our Children, criticized this move as misguided, saying the blame was misdirected.
He pointed out that some of those now facing arrest had even endangered themselves while trying to rescue the kids.
Alvarado highlighted a teacher about to be arrested, whose daughter had burns covering 95% of her body from the fire. "Imagine this girl seeing her own mother go to prison," he said.
The blaze broke out in a warehouse in Hermosillo on June 5, 2009, swiftly spreading across the roof to the nursery where the little ones were napping.
The nursery, lacking essentials like sprinklers, fire extinguishers, and reliable smoke alarms, relied on poorly trained staff.
The families insist the disaster was preventable if proper safety measures were in place.
They also argue a nursery should never have been close to a building packed with tires and flammable stuff.
They've grown increasingly frustrated since, while many officials have faced trial, only the government official responsible for the nursery’s last safety inspection has spent time behind bars.

Their frustration intensified following a media report last year hinting that the warehouse fire might have been a deliberate act to eliminate sensitive local government documents. The official investigation, however, blamed it on an electrical short circuit.
The Markit/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index just reported the biggest month-to-month jump ever seen in UK services.
Initially, the pound shot up to $1.3372 against the dollar before settling down to $1.3312, nudging up by 0.13%.

This news has some analysts thinking the UK might dodge a recession this year. Ranko Berich from Monex Europe remarked, "Sterling might be headed up thanks to today's PMI figures, hinting that the post-EU referendum slump might just be a blip."
He added, "It changes the bleak outlook for the third quarter we thought was a given."
Still, a few experts urged caution. Neil Wilson, a markets analyst at ETX Capital, pointed out, "These PMIs are still just surveys.
We'll need solid economic numbers in the coming months. It’s easy to read too much into one month’s results.
We're not out of the woods yet." Meanwhile, the FTSE 100 barely budged, dipping 15 points to 6,879.
Banks were a drag, with Royal Bank of Scotland tumbling 3.5% and Lloyds Banking Group down 2.1% following some unkind words from Deutsche Bank.
On the upside, mining stocks shone a bit, with BHP Billiton and Randgold Resources climbing 1.3% and 1.6%, respectively.
Marks and Spencer took a hit, with shares dropping 1.4% after announcing they'd cut over 500 jobs at their head office. Over in the US, financial markets took a breather for Labor Day.
The Private Infrastructure Development Group (PIDG) finds itself with a £27 million surplus, courtesy of boosted donations from the British government.
This has prompted the National Audit Office (NAO) to suggest that ministers keep a closer eye on PIDG's spending habits.
Recently, PIDG has backed projects like a steel foundry in Nigeria and a hydropower venture in Uganda.
They've also tweaked their travel policy, which used to let board members book pricey flexible business class flights.
Margaret Hodge, who chairs the Commons Public Accounts Committee, didn't hold back in chastising the Department for International Development (DfID) for its lax oversight.
She exclaimed, "It's shocking that since 2011, 15 flights were booked, each over £5,000.
It's only now that PIDG has changed its travel policy. DfID must tighten up its handling of these administrative expenses."

Launched in 2002 by the UK, Switzerland, Holland, and Sweden, PIDG's mission is to stimulate private sector investment in infrastructure across developing countries, tackling projects from roads to power and housing.
The UK shoulders a whopping 70% of PIDG's funding and is set to chip in £700 million by 2015.
In 2011, UK funding for PIDG surged fivefold, in line with the government's push to boost private investment in the developing world.
Still, the NAO observed that a hefty chunk of these funds stays parked, with the PIDG Trust holding onto £27 million.
Amyas Morse, head honcho at the NAO, noted, "Sure, PIDG helps poor communities in tough spots, but DfID isn't exactly swimming in proof that pouring cash into PIDG is the best move.
Their financial oversight hasn't cut the mustard, letting PIDG Trust hang onto nearly £27 million of DfID funding since 2012.
There's been some progress on these issues lately, but really, DfID should've been more on the ball after deciding to pump up PIDG's funding back in 2011."

The report also takes aim at two PIDG subsidiaries, GuarantCo and the Emerging Africa Infrastructure Fund (EAIF)—brainchildren of UK Prime Minister Tony Blair back in 2002—which are set up in the tax haven of Mauritius.

The charity War on Want slammed this arrangement, saying it goes against Prime Minister David Cameron's vow for tax fairness for poorer countries. As the NAO put it, this setup "raises reputational risks" for DfID.
The chief operating officer of the region announced that they're going to review the claims made by head coach Sean Holley and forwards coach Jonathan Humphreys.
Hore, a former fitness coach for Wales and a New Zealander, said, "We're definitely looking into both cases."
Meanwhile, Johnson is gearing up to take on the role of senior assistant coach under Scotland's head coach Andy Robinson. Hore mentioned, "We've been weighing our next steps for a while now.
We need to revisit the framework we set up four years ago when we hired Johnson to help develop our coaching staff and build effective systems.
Are we happy with how things stand? It's time to evaluate this and decide whether we should bring in someone new or stick with our current crew.

If we choose to keep it internal, we have to decide who'll take the lead." Hore admitted that the holiday season has made it tough for the Ospreys' decision-makers, like joint managing directors Roger Blyth and Mike Cuddy, to meet up about this situation.
"Some directors were out over the holidays, and we heard about Johnson leaving sooner than expected," Hore remarked.
"So there's still a bit of work left to do." Despite all this, the Ospreys snapped their three-game losing streak with a 17-12 win over Cardiff Blues on New Year's Day at the Liberty Stadium.
Fabian Picardo, the chief minister of Gibraltar, mentioned to the BBC that he's chatting with Scotland's First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, about exploring different possibilities.
One intriguing idea on the table is for Gibraltar and Scotland to hang onto the UK's EU membership since both regions had voted to remain in the EU.
Sturgeon confirmed she's in talks with Gibraltar, and Northern Ireland might also come into play in these discussions.
In a chat with Newsnight, Picardo said, "Some parts of what is currently the UK could stay in the EU while others leave."
The idea is that areas that choose to stay would maintain their current EU access, while those deciding to exit would negotiate separate arrangements.
This might not be handled under Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, which is the usual exit route for EU member states. There’s a precedent for this kind of split.
Denmark joined the EEC, the EU’s predecessor, in 1973 along with the UK and Ireland.
However, Greenland, which is part of Denmark, got its autonomy in 1979 and opted out of the EU in 1985 after a referendum.
Nicola Sturgeon has also mentioned that another Scottish independence referendum seems "highly likely" after the recent EU leaving vote.
Over 95% of voters in Gibraltar chose to remain, and they also largely want to remain part of the UK.
Back in 2002, Gibraltar strongly rejected shared sovereignty with Spain in a referendum.
Picardo highlighted Gibraltar’s status as a British Overseas Territory, insisting it shouldn’t result in an automatic EU exit.
He stated, "Gibraltar has clearly expressed, perhaps even more than Scotland, our desire to continue accessing the EU single market.
My duty is to protect Gibraltar's interests and find partners in the UK who will do the same."
Post-referendum, Spain again expressed a desire for shared control over Gibraltar.
Spain's acting Foreign Minister, Jose Manuel Garcia-Margallo, claimed, "The Spanish flag on the Rock is closer than before."
But in his first interview since the referendum, Picardo dismissed any Spanish claims, firmly declaring that Gibraltar wouldn't give up any sovereign advantages.
In prison, inmates have the option to read books, catch some TV shows, and play computer games.
They’ve got a kettle, sink, a safe, and usually a toilet in their cells. Residential officer Kerry Payne points out that the real punishment is the loss of freedom.
She says, "Prison isn't for punishment anymore; it’s about giving offenders the chance to hit pause and turn things around, something they often don’t get to do outside.
Unchecked, problems just spiral.” Some inmates are willing to talk about their lives inside.
Take James, for instance—he’s 27 now and has been in and out of various Scottish prisons like Polmont, Barlinnie, Kilmarnock, and Dumfries since he was 18.

When he’s out, he works as a joiner. Inside, he’s the "hall passman," responsible for cleaning parts of the prison, earning about £10 a week. His cell is pretty cramped, just enough space for a bed, sink, and toilet.
They have safes that can be unlocked by staff when they do checks. James has brightened up his tiny space with posters, a stereo, and a TV, which sets him back £1 a week.
"It's tiny, but it's mine," he says with a shrug. Then there's Jason, who's halfway through his 13-month stint at HMP Dumfries.
He's 38 and hasn’t kept count of how many times he’s been behind bars since he was first locked up at 14.
"It's like a revolving door for me," he confesses. Asked if prison helps him, he responds, "No, I have to help myself.
Prison doesn’t do that. Over the years, I’ve started reflecting more, maybe because I’m older and I'm considering change to stop repeating old mistakes—but it’s a slow process."
Is this his last prison stint? "That’s my intention," he says. Jason participates in art classes and enjoys them, but isn’t sure he’ll keep it up once he's out.
"I've got other issues to tackle first," he admits. Does he enjoy prison life? "Absolutely not," he replies.
Would he prefer to be free? "Definitely." Ryan, once a police officer, has about 12 weeks left of his sentence.
He began serving his time at HMP Addiewell in West Lothian, which isn’t far from his home in Lanarkshire.
It's no surprise that even a seasoned gardener like him might seem a bit unsettled.
Honestly, who wouldn’t be a little unsure when given a giant vegetable with a crowd of photographers clicking away?
Chances are, this moment is going to make the rounds in the newspapers and stick in people’s minds.

It highlights that before Mr. Corbyn dives into the challenges awaiting him—be it nuclear talks, economic balancing acts, or internal Labour party decisions—his team’s top priority should be steering through the week without a hitch.
These party conferences have this intense vibe where meticulously crafted speeches can suddenly be upstaged by unexpected events, even the seemingly trivial ones.
Such moments can shift perceptions or bring to light uncomfortable truths that political parties would rather not face, sometimes causing top politicians to lose their grip.
Take 2003, for example. I remember watching Conservative aides squirm as their leader, Iain Duncan Smith, declared that the "quiet man" would "turn up the volume."
That whole week, Conservatives were having secret huddles, pondering how to oust him, with his awkward speech adding to his downfall.

Fast forward to 2006: Cherie Blair’s off-the-cuff and later denied comment, "It's a lie," in response to Gordon Brown praising her husband, spread like wildfire through the conference center and laid bare the intense and bitter rivalry between their camps.

Then in 2008, the story wasn't just David Miliband posing with a banana—his remark about avoiding a “Heseltine moment” made his leadership intentions clear, turning the banana photo into headline material.
The year before, Sir Menzies Campbell was already under pressure for his less-than-dynamic leadership of the Liberal Democrats.
I can still picture that painfully awkward media stop at an eco-friendly house near Bournemouth, where aides let him be snapped checking out an organic toilet.
That instance perfectly illustrated the weaknesses of his team, and a few weeks later, he stepped down. For Labour this week, Jeremy Corbyn’s "marrow moment" may soon be forgotten.
But to push his agenda forward, Team Corbyn’s main objective should probably be avoiding any blunders.
In the charged atmosphere of a conference, even the most seasoned political teams find it tough to keep everything in line.

Looks like media playback won't work on this device. Over in Barcelona, a 16-year-old from Plymouth just broke a record with a blistering time of 1:04.30, shaving off 0.15 seconds from Jessica Hardy’s 2009 record.
And before this, Meilutyte had clocked a 1:04.52 during the qualifiers, snagging the second-fastest time ever and setting a new European record.
Jumping to the 200m individual medley final, Sophie Allen came in seventh place, while her fellow Brit, Siobhan-Marie O'Connor, landed in eighth.
The reigning London 2012 Olympic champ, Meilutyte, has her sights set on bagging Lithuania's first-ever gold at the World Championships in Tuesday’s final.
Media playback still isn't cooperating. "I’m planning to relax tomorrow, keep energy levels high for the big event," she mentioned casually.
"I've hit my major goal, so it's all in for the final now. Snatching gold would really be the cherry on top."
Her coach, Jon Rudd, chimed in with, "This feels almost unreal, like winning Olympic gold.
We wanted that world record tonight and will zero in on medals tomorrow." Yuliya Efimova from Russia is set to give her a run for her money, keeping Meilutyte on her toes, though Rudd is optimistic.
Switching gears, Brit O'Connor moved into the medley final after Australian Emily Seebohm pulled out to focus on her preferred 100m backstroke event.
O'Connor was second halfway through but couldn’t hold steady, ending up eighth as Hungary's Katinka Hosszu came out victorious.
To everyone's surprise, Olympic gold medalist Ye Shiwen finished fourth. "I’ve got to figure out how to pace these better," admitted O'Connor.
"I start too fast and let excitement get the best of me in that final." Meanwhile, Allen, at 21, shared her thoughts: "I’m a bit bummed about not hitting a personal best like in the semi-final."
She added, "It’s just electrifying to see how much youthful spirit this sport brings out."
After winning the toss and deciding to bat with the pink ball, the home team started their opening session without a hitch.
Things took a turn when Craig Overton, who finished with figures of 2 for 35, stepped in to dismiss Jimmy Adams for 47 and Rilee Rossouw in quick succession.
Jack Leach with 2 for 54 and Tim Groenewald with 2 for 27 soon sped up Hampshire's batting collapse.
Hampshire then sent Somerset to bat for a short six-over spell, which wrapped up at 18 without loss.
Overton, despite sitting out England's recent T20 series against South Africa, delivered a spell that really swung the momentum.

Liam Dawson with 53 and Adams had set up a solid opening stand, but Overton managed to edge out Adams and have Rossouw caught by Steven Davies—marking Rossouw's fifth duck in eight County Championship innings.
Dawson was out lbw to Lewis Gregory, who claimed a solid 3 for 51, and though James Vince tried to hold things together with his 47, Hampshire's lineup folded under Leach's precise left-arm spin.

Hampshire's skipper George Bailey decided to declare after the team secured a batting point, leaving Marcus Trescothick not out on 10 and newcomer Eddie Byrom unbeaten on one as they reached stumps under the floodlights with ease.
Liam Dawson shared his thoughts with BBC Solent, saying, "Crowd numbers are the same so far.
It's still in the early stages, and maybe it'll catch on. From what I see, they really need to reconsider the ball choice.

These ones go soft too quick, and it could lead to dull cricket." Somerset's Craig Overton also chipped in his perspective to BBC Radio Bristol, commenting, "The ball behaves strangely—it swings but then softens fast.
It doesn’t offer much to bowlers and makes scoring difficult because of how soft it gets.
We knew it would be tricky to bat after lights, so ending nought down with Tres and Eddie is spot on.
Being with the England squad was a learning curve, and I'm hoping to get some game time next series."
You can’t help but feel for the families affected by the tragic loss of these flights, both those who lost loved ones and those who narrowly survived.
It doesn’t seem to stop—two Malaysian airplanes disappeared within a year, taking 537 passengers with them.
Then there was the AirAsia accident on the way to Singapore in December, claiming 162 lives.
It's not just the incidents themselves; what’s terrifying is that entire planes can suddenly drop from the sky without warning.
You’d think air travel’s getting riskier, right? Wrong. Despite these tragedies, air travel is incredibly safe these days.

Last year alone, 3.2 billion passengers took to the skies. According to Ascend’s safety analysts, 2014 was almost the safest year on record, with only one fatal accident for every 2.38 million flights, better than 2013’s one in 1.91 million flights.
The figures don’t even count the Malaysian plane shot down in Ukraine, costing 298 lives—that’s classified as a war loss, not an accident.
But even if you factor that in, historically, air travel in 2014 was safer. The Aviation Safety Network noted 21 fatal crashes that year (Ukraine included), down from 29 in 2013 and 23 in 2012.

Nearly 1,000 lives were lost in 2014, which is 700 more than the previous year, but still far below the 2,370 who perished in 1972, even though four times fewer people were flying back then. So, why has flying become much safer?
Mostly, it’s down to technology. David Learmount from Flightglobal says something like, "Think of 1970s cars—poor brakes, iffy handling, barely any safety features.
Aircraft were in the same boat." Sure, they got the basics of flying by the 1940s, but the tech leaps since then are what made all the difference.
Each new plane model gets safer thanks to improved computers, better designs, and superior materials.

Plus, we learn from each catastrophe. A couple of decades ago, Controlled Flight Into Terrain (CFIT) was the biggest killer—a bland term for deadly accidents where planes unknowingly crash into terrain, usually during landing near hills.
The Enhanced Ground Proximity Warning System changed the game. David compares it to a sat nav for airplanes, steering them clear of hills and mountains, even when visibility's poor.
Matthew Todd Miller, a 24-year-old from the US, found himself sentenced to six years of hard labor in North Korea on September 14, 2014.
The charges? "Hostile acts," according to the North Korean state media. His troubles started back in April when reports surfaced that he'd torn up his tourist visa and sought asylum in the country.
Hailing from Bakersfield, California, Miller is the youngest of four brothers, raised by parents who worked as oil engineers.
Friends from school remember him as "quiet but super smart." His interest in Korea began four years earlier when visiting a brother stationed in South Korea with the US Air Force.
Apparently, he liked the country so much he decided to stick around, or so says a neighbor from California.
Court documents included notes supposedly penned by Miller, linking him to Wikileaks, the infamous organization known for publishing US state secrets.
But as BBC's Stephen Evans pointed out from Seoul, it was murky whether those notes were genuine or done under pressure.
In a CNN interview—with North Korean officials in attendance—Miller confessed, "I will say that I prepared to violate the law of the DPRK before coming here."
He admitted to deliberately breaking the law but kept mum about specifics. What exactly he was charged with remained unspecified.
Around the same time, Korean-American Pae Jun-ho, known in the States as Kenneth Bae, ended up in a similar bind.
He was nabbed in November 2012 while entering Rason, a northeastern port city near the North Korean-China border.

North Korean authorities accused him, both a tour operator and Christian missionary, of using his business as a front to create groups aiming to topple the government. For this, he received a 15-year hard labor sentence in May 2013.
Bae's ordeal came amid heightened US-North Korea tensions following North Korea’s third nuclear test, and attempts to free him have run aground.

His family says he's dealing with diabetes and liver issues. Meanwhile, Jeffrey Edward Fowle, a 56-year-old from Miamisburg, Ohio, waded into North Korea on April 29, 2014, but was detained while trying to leave around May to June.
A father of three and city worker, he entered as a tourist but got into hot water after allegedly leaving a Bible in his hotel room—a decidedly provocative act in North Korea's eyes.
Though he was tried on unspecified charges, negotiations secured his release, and Fowle made it back to the US in October 2014.
The team's dreams today are all about snagging a spot on the fourth row of the grid—or maybe the third if everything falls perfectly into place—and racking up some decent points.

It's quite a step back from their glory days, though. This is a team with a staggering 182 Grand Prix wins, a 23.18% victory rate, 12 drivers' world titles, and eight constructors' championships under their belt.
Even now, with results that are anything but stellar, they've got two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, who many would argue remains the best driver out there.
The slide began in 2013, when McLaren started to lose its touch with chassis design, even while running the top engine of the time.
Nowadays, they may have gotten the car part sorted out, but the Honda power unit is still a headache.

It's a far cry from their golden age with Honda—when they ruled F1. Back in 1988, legends Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost led McLaren to win 15 out of 16 races, a level of dominance that even put Mercedes to shame later on.
They kept that dominance for another four years but hit a slump not unlike today's, only to bounce back in 1998-99 with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes.
Interestingly, the last time they took the constructors' title was at the start of Hakkinen’s wins.
In 2007, there was a hint of redemption with Alonso and Lewis Hamilton as teammates.
They ended the season neck and neck, one point shy of catching Ferrari's Kimi Raikkonen.
But the dream was dashed when McLaren was caught with Ferrari's secrets, resulting in disqualification from the constructors' championship and a $100 million fine.
Then there was the 'lie-gate' scandal in 2009, when Hamilton and sporting director Dave Ryan misled race stewards.

That one ended with Hamilton apologizing and Ryan getting the boot. Victories flowed until about 2012—with Hamilton and Jenson Button bagging seven wins—but aside from Hamilton's 2008 championship, titles slipped through their fingers.

These days, even wins are hard to come by. Given the ups and downs of McLaren's F1 saga, their current woes aren't entirely shocking. Like many seasoned teams, they've had their cycles of highs and lows.
Bolivians recently weighed in on a potential change to their constitution. Right now, the president and vice president are capped at two consecutive five-year terms.
President Evo Morales, who’s been in charge since 2006, was pushing to run again.
As the vote counting neared completion, the "No" camp held onto a slender yet clear lead, effectively blocking Morales’s hopes of extending his tenure beyond two consecutive terms.
Even with this limit, Morales was allowed to run for a third stint in 2014 because the constitutional court decided his first term didn’t count, it predated the current constitution.
So, in the 2019 elections, Morales won’t be eligible, though he’ll finish his term set to end in 2020.
Following the preliminary result favouring "No", Morales assured the nation that his administration's agenda would persist, stating "the fight will continue."
In his own party, some want him to prepare a successor, while rivals see a chance to shake up the ruling parties.
Morales conceded he’d "lost a battle, but not the war." Santa Cruz, where opposition runs strong, became the scene of celebrations.
Both opposition figures and members of Morales's party hailed the result as a win for democracy.

Ex-President Carlos Mesa commented that it proved "no one is indispensable," while Samuel Doria Medina, a three-time opponent of Morales, tweeted Bolivia’s win, saying "the people told them 'no'" after the government pushed for the referendum.
Morales secured 61% of the vote in the last election, but many deemed the planned constitutional revision to be too much.
Critics, even within his ranks, thought it was time for a new generation of leaders to step up.

Adding to the mix, allegations have surfaced; rumors have it that Morales swayed decisions to help a Chinese company tied to his former girlfriend—claims he denies, promising to look into how contracts were awarded.
Investigators have found parts that might belong to a Buk surface-to-air missile system and are pretty intrigued by them.
These parts could be key to figuring out who’s responsible for the crash, but right now, there's no confirmed connection to the disaster.
Back in July 2014, Flight MH17 crashed in an area held by Russian-backed rebels, killing all 298 people aboard—283 passengers, including 80 kids, and 15 crew from Malaysian Airlines.
Of the victims, about two-thirds were Dutch, and there were also many Malaysians and Australians among them.
Ukraine and several Western countries blame pro-Russian rebels for shooting down the plane, possibly using a Buk system supplied by Russia.

Meanwhile, Russia and the rebels point fingers at the Ukrainian military. The Joint Investigation Team (JIT), working alongside the Dutch Safety Board, has reported that these intriguing parts were "secured during a previous recovery mission in eastern Ukraine."
They stated, "The parts are of particular interest to the criminal investigation as they could reveal more details about those involved in the MH17 crash.

Therefore, the JIT is further investigating the origin of these parts." Fred Westerbeke from the Dutch Prosecutor’s Office mentioned they discovered seven fragments—not part of the aircraft—and analysis points to them originating from a missile system.
He noted, "Additional investigation is needed to determine what these fragments precisely are and if they belong to the system that brought down MH17.
Confirming this could signify a breakthrough." However, the Dutch Safety Board is being cautious, saying there’s no proven link yet between these parts and the crash.

The prevailing thought is that the jet was downed by a surface-to-air missile, which the preliminary report last September supports by highlighting that the damage to the plane's fuselage and cockpit matched impacts from several high-energy objects.
A Buk missile strike seems likely. Still, the big question remains: Who fired the shot—Russian-backed separatists, the Russian military, or maybe even the Ukrainian forces, who also have Buk systems?
While these missile parts could shed light on things, satellite data might also offer crucial insights.
The new series takes on a darker, more serious tone, reminiscent of Doctor Who's recent season.
Not everyone loved the change, but the Atlantis team is bracing themselves for any critiques.
"We've designed the show to fit a pre-watershed slot," says Johnny Capps, the executive producer and co-creator of Atlantis.
"I think today's audiences are much more sophisticated. Kids are exposed to more complex and intriguing content than ever, so we have to match that level."
With its new 8:30 pm airtime, they hope to draw in both kids and adults. This shift to a darker narrative isn't necessarily a bad thing.
"Exploring life's complexities and emotional stories can be really enriching," Capps adds.
"These stories give families a chance to see life’s highs and lows, and understand the impact of emotional experiences." Jack Donnelly, who plays Jason, shared his initial worries about the changes.
"It's quite different from the first season," he tells Newsbeat. "I chatted with Mark (Addy) and Rob (Emms) about it recently, and honestly, it feels more like a reboot than a continuation.
The show's now serialized, with each episode building on the last, a big departure from our standalone stories."
Are they ready for any backlash? "To a degree," Jack admits. "Rob, Mark, and I had our doubts at first because we had found our groove last season, balancing humor with seriousness.
But we pivoted under the producers' guidance for this new direction." After catching rough cuts of some episodes, Jack observes, "It might not be as kid-friendly as last year.
Still, I think the show has improved overall. This fresh direction adds depth and intrigue to the series."
A team at King's College London has found that smokers might be more prone to developing schizophrenia, and it could happen at an earlier age than non-smokers.
Their research, published in Lancet Psychiatry, reviewed 61 different studies and suggests that nicotine from cigarettes might affect the brain in some way.
Some experts are calling this evidence a "pretty strong case," but they still stress the need for more research.

For quite a while, people have thought smoking was tied to psychosis, but the usual belief has been that people with schizophrenia smoke to self-medicate, dealing with symptoms like hearing voices or experiencing hallucinations.
The King's team dug into data from 14,555 smokers and 273,162 non-smokers. They found that a higher smoking rate before a schizophrenia diagnosis suggests it might not just be about self-medication.

Dr. James MacCabe of King's Institute of Psychiatry, Psychology and Neuroscience said, "It's very difficult to establish causation with this study type, but we hope this reveals the potential role of tobacco as a causative factor in psychosis, leading to more research and clinical trials for clearer evidence."
While most smokers don't end up with schizophrenia, researchers believe lighting up still ups the risk.
On average, one out of 100 people will develop schizophrenia, but for smokers, this could increase to two out of 100.
The research points out that nicotine can change the levels of dopamine in the brain—a known player in psychosis.
Professor Michael Owen from Cardiff University recognized the "pretty strong case" made here for smoking increasing the risk of schizophrenia.
He said, "Proving causation is challenging without randomized trials, but there are already many reasons to target public health initiatives toward those with mental illnesses."
The charity Rethink Mental Illness chimed in, noting that "42% of cigarettes in England are smoked by individuals with mental health issues."
They find any link between smoking and psychosis quite concerning and stress the need for longer-term studies to really get to the bottom of this potential connection.
Ethiopia, despite being one of the world's poorest countries, is riding a wave of rapid economic growth.
A third of its population gets by on less than a buck a day, but the country’s economy is among the globe's fastest-expanding.
There's a bit of debate on whether investing here is a smart move, though. Since 2004, Ethiopia's economy has been growing by about 10% each year.
The government expects this double-digit growth to stick around, but the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has a more cautious prediction of a 6.5% increase for 2013.
Even so, considering the global economic situation and Ethiopia's limited natural resources, that's still pretty remarkable.
Coffee stands as one of Ethiopia’s biggest exports, and in Addis Ababa, coffee exporter Michael Girma recounts his start-up challenges.
"You need your own cash to kick things off in the export game, but once that's set, you can go to the banks," he shares.
Girma also runs a café, bar, and pizzeria, employing 140 people, and despite growing competition, his businesses pull in a solid 20-30% profit each year.
"Things have really shifted over the past seven years," he remarks. "You've got to be aggressive, not arrogant."
While foreign investors are invited, certain industries are held exclusively for locals.
"Sectors catering to domestic needs are restricted, but for export-focused projects, foreigners have free rein," he points out.
"Otherwise, it’d be quite the competition." Despite stubborn high inflation, some investors feel that the potential of Africa's next most populous nation is undervalued.
Earlier this year, Shultze Global Investments launched a $100 million equity fund aimed at Ethiopian businesses.
Working from a modest office in Addis Ababa, Berhane Demissie handles this fund's allocation.
"Ethiopia holds tremendous opportunities for investors," she asserts, with agriculture being a particularly promising field.
"Anything can thrive here with our various climates and soils, especially when it comes to value-added agriculture and exports," says Ms. Demissie.

With 85% of Ethiopians depending on agriculture, she highlights government initiatives helping farmers gain access to financing and fertilizers to boost their productivity. This, she hopes, will eventually lead to reducing poverty.

It might take a while for India's triumph to truly sink in. Girisha Hosanagara Nagarajegowda pulled off something really special, snagging a silver in the Men's High Jump F42 category, which is for athletes dealing with arm or leg impairments.
This was a big moment for India, where medals in the Paralympics aren't exactly common.
But there are still lingering doubts: can this triumph spark better awareness around disability rights?
Generally speaking, India hasn’t been very accommodating to its disabled citizens, as loads of public spaces still lack basic facilities.
Even before Girisha’s shining moment, the spotlight was on some troubling issues at the Athletes' Village.
A bunch of athletes said the Paralympics Committee of India dropped the ball on getting accommodation for escorts and coaches, which threw off their routines.
Like Farman Basha, a weightlifter, told CNN-IBN about how his training took a hit without proper access to his escort.
“I was all set to snag a medal, but now my training’s gone to waste,” he vented.
On a special show, Rajdeep Sardesai, CNN-IBN’s editor, raised the awkward question: does India treat its Paralympians as second-class citizens?
Other media outlets quickly joined in, pointing out how the controversy scooped up more attention than the Games themselves.
While there was just one medal in the end, the event sparked loads of inspiring stories which didn’t quite make it to the headlines.

During the CNN-IBN program, Olympic silver medallist Rajyawardhan Singh Rathod was pretty unsurprised at how Paralympians were treated, calling for big changes to secure equal rights for disabled folks in India. “Our country needs a serious attitude makeover,” he said.
Another topic lost on Indian media was the lack of female athletes in the Paralympic lineup.

Officials chalked it up to tough qualifications, but there’s a deeper issue at play—most schools don’t even offer basic sports facilities for the disabled, and those with resources rarely push for disabled women to join in.
Girisha’s silver, thankfully, remains unstained by all this drama. Despite the challenges, he made sure India left London with some glory.
Coming from Karnataka in the south of India, he's from a regular, middle-class family.
Eric Bikubi, 28, and Magalie Bamu, 29, have been convicted at the Old Bailey for murdering Kristy Bamu, whom they accused of practicing witchcraft.
The couple from Newham were convinced Kristy was somehow controlling and harming a young boy, according to what the jury heard.
Originally from the Democratic Republic of Congo, where witchcraft, called Kindoki, and exorcisms are practiced in some churches, their actions bring to light a disturbing reality.
A 2010 Unicef report showed that 20,000 children accused of witchcraft were living on Kinshasa’s streets, the capital of DR Congo.
Even though DR Congo has laws against accusing children of possession, when I visited Kinshasa in 2008, nothing seemed to have changed.
One evening, I found myself in a slum, knocking on the ramshackle door of a place that served as a church.
Pastor Tsimba greeted me and introduced me to three kids, aged between six and twelve.
He said they were afflicted by Kindoki. These children had been kept there for days without food, forced to work, while their parents paid for this so-called treatment.
The room was dim, lit by flickering candles, as the pastor loudly prayed and brought each child up.
He ordered them to lie down, slapping their stomachs harder each time. Then he dripped hot wax on them, making the kids grimace silently with wide-open eyes.
In a bizarre twist, Pastor Tsimba pressed a pipe to their belly buttons, acting as though he was sucking out a piece of meat, before triumphantly spitting it into a bowl.
He claimed a witch had fed this to them and infected them with Kindoki. The children, now quiet and bewildered, were pronounced "delivered" by him.

I reported their situation to a social worker. A dedicated man, he promised to assist, but faced difficulties since his unit had not paid him for months, leaving him without money for gas or bus fare. Yet, he kept on working, traveling on foot.
There are plenty of big achievements people rack up—think Olympic gold medals, setting world records, or even snagging a seat in Parliament.
Take Sebastian Coe, for example. Back in 1979, when he was just 22, this rising star in middle-distance running smashed three world records in a whirlwind 41 days.
Coe wasn't just fast; he was making history, holding records for the 800m, one mile, and 1,500m all at the same time—a feat that snagged him the Sports Personality of the Year title.
Come 1980 at the Moscow Olympics, Coe really shone. In a gripping showdown with fellow Brit Steve Ovett, he took gold in the 1,500m and snagged silver for the 800m, just a step behind Ovett.
Fast forward to 1984, despite battling illness, Coe returned to the Olympic scene in Los Angeles.
He made a comeback by winning his second consecutive gold in the 1,500m, outperforming another Brit, Steve Cram, while Ovett couldn't finish.
Coe again took silver in the 800m, this time behind Joaquim Cruz. After hanging up his running shoes in 1990, Coe switched lanes to politics.
He was elected to Parliament in 1992 as a Conservative representative for Falmouth and Camborne, beating the Liberal Democrats by more than 3,000 votes.
Though he lost his seat in 1997 amid Tony Blair's Labour wave, he later teamed up as chief of staff for William Hague during his stint as Leader of the Opposition.
In a twist of fate, Coe played a massive role in London snagging the Olympics in 2005.
Initially trailing Paris and Madrid, London came out on top, thanks partly to Coe's killer speech that swayed the final vote.
He reflected that organizing the Olympics was "on a different planet" compared to winning medals.
As Chairman of the London Organising Committee, Coe was instrumental in pulling off the Queen's cameo with James Bond at the opening ceremony.

By 2015, Coe was leading the IAAF, calling it his greatest accomplishment yet. In a heated contest against Sergey Bubka, the former Olympic pole vaulter, Coe came out ahead with 115 votes to Bubka's 92. Not too bad for a guy with such a packed resume.
Back when he was in primary school, the now 22-year-old student was assaulted and robbed by a bunch of kids in a side street.
Even though that was ages ago, he still finds himself crossing the street to avoid big groups.
No surprise there, especially since his whole family has dealt with similar harassment.
Over in France, the ethnic Chinese community has been putting up with casual racism for years, often seen as easy targets.

But now, they've hit their limit. In August, a heartbreaking event took place: Zhang Chaolin, a 49-year-old tailor and father of two, died in a hospital after being attacked by three teenagers in Aubervilliers, a suburb in northern Paris.
During the attack, he was kicked in the chest, causing him to fall and hit his head on the pavement.
It seems the attackers’ aim was to snatch his friend’s bag, but Zhang only had sweets and smokes on him.
This tragedy sparked a massive gathering, with over 15,000 ethnic Chinese rallying at Paris's Place de la Republique on September 4th, expressing their profound fears.
France hosts Europe’s largest Chinese community, which numbers over 600,000 people.
They haven’t been around as long as other migrant groups like those from Africa.

Take David, for example—he was born in Paris to parents who immigrated from China in the early '90s and has been subjected to taunts like being asked if he eats dogs or being called “spring roll head.” He's been told to "go back to his own country" and to "work with his little Chinese hands."
These insults are not unfamiliar to East Asian migrants and their children across the Western world.
Many British and French Chinese folks say these kind of racist remarks seem more acceptable than those hurled at more established migrant groups.
In France, Asian migrants are often seen as targets of especially nasty attacks.
"These assaults come from what they believe about us," says David, who prefers to keep his real name private.
Aubervilliers, a working-class suburb teeming with immigrants, has more than 1,200 mainly Chinese wholesalers, playing a key role in the European textile industry.
Buyers often come from afar to haggle over prices for Italian and Chinese-made garments.
Activists have noted that in just the first seven months of this year, there were at least 100 attacks on Chinese nationals just in that suburb.
Since France doesn’t track statistics by ethnicity, it's tricky to gauge the true scale.
The town's communist mayor, Meriem Derkaoui, has labeled Zhang’s murder as clear "racist targeting."
Six people are facing attempted murder charges for reportedly setting a man’s makeshift newspaper blanket on fire.
Another individual is charged for failing to help the Polish man, who was eventually saved by passersby after the attackers left him.
The disturbing incident, which was caught on CCTV, has raised concern nationwide.
Among those charged, six are from Syria and one is from Libya, with ages ranging from 16 to 21.
According to German media, they arrived in Germany between 2014 and 2016, with some having come as unaccompanied minors.
This shocking event has sparked renewed conversations about the care provided to unaccompanied minors in Germany and reignited debates over the role of CCTV cameras in crime prevention.
The attack took place around 2:00 am local time (1:00 am GMT) on Christmas Day at the Schoenleinstrasse underground station in Berlin's Neukölln district.
The alleged leader, a 21-year-old Syrian, is accused of lighting a handkerchief near the victim's head, leading the fire to catch onto the man’s backpack and a plastic bag before they fled.
A train driver and passersby quickly put out the flames with a fire extinguisher.
After CCTV footage was released, six of the suspects turned themselves in to the authorities. The supposed ringleader was captured near his home.

He claims he was drunk at the time and doesn't remember what happened. Despite this, he will be tried as an adult and, if found guilty, faces at least three years in prison. All suspects have been in custody since December 27.
The five players from SKT snagged a cool $2 million after clenching a tight 3-2 victory against Samsung, the team backed by the phone giant.
With this win, SKT now boasts their third championship title in just four years, adding to their victories from 2015.
The intense final showdown happened at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, stretching on for a full six hours and drawing in almost 20,000 eager League of Legends (LoL) fans.
Lee Sang-hyeok, better known as Faker from SKT, stood out and earned the title of the tournament's MVP.
In total, the tournament dished out $5 million in prizes, with Samsung scoring $750,000 for their impressive second-place finish.
Fans chipped in to swell the prize pot, making it even more lucrative for the competing teams.
Philippa Warr, a gaming journalist from Rock, Paper Shotgun, captured the excitement of the final, calling it simply "breathtaking."
Samsung didn’t go down without a fight, staging an incredible comeback after dropping the first two games.
Their win in the nearly 70-minute-long third game was nothing short of "beautiful," followed by a more straightforward victory in the fourth, setting the stage for the all-important fifth match.
Warr pointed out that SKT's "fluidity" and veteran expertise were key to clinching the win, the prize, and the renowned Summoner's Cup trophy.
As for LoL, it’s a wildly popular game that pits teams of five against each other on a small map.
Each player picks a hero with unique attack and defense skills, aiming to be the first to demolish the opponent’s base.
Riot Games, the creator of LoL, notes that around 100 million people dive into the game each month.
Jack Lopresti has described a letter circulated to party members, calling for a new candidate, as an "attempt to destroy my character and reputation."
The Filton and Bradley Stoke MP had recently left his wife for fellow MP Andrea Jenkyns, who gave birth to their son in March.

During a Friday evening meeting, Lopresti was reselected. Just earlier this month, an anonymous letter reached Conservative Party members in the constituency, arguing that Lopresti hadn't been representing their interests well.
It even suggested that "several excellent people" should be considered to take up the role as parliamentary candidates.
In response, the local party assured that they’d take "appropriate legal action" should they identify the letter's author.
Lopresti first took office in 2010 and earned a strong re-election victory with nearly a 10,000-vote lead five years later.
Last November made news with his engagement to Jenkyns, who successfully contested Ed Balls, former Labour shadow chancellor, to become MP for Morley and Outwood in 2015.
Their son, Clifford George, arrived this March. "My family and I have been grappling with an intense smear campaign that carries racist undertones," Lopresti said.
"Since Clifford's birth, my office has been overrun with fake calls, supposedly from national journalists, and alarming threats of illegally recorded conversations.
It’s really shaken my team. "But I’ve received loads of supportive messages from party members and constituents.
I’m pretty sure this effort to undermine me is the work of a select few. "It seems to stem from personal choices that some folks weren't fond of," he noted.
"I love Andrea and am so proud of my little son Clifford, and nobody’s gonna change that."
Since Friday, Mr. Besigye has been under house arrest, openly labeling Uganda's election a "sham" and a "creeping military coup."
It's hard not to see why he feels this way, given that President Museveni, who's held power for three decades, nabbed almost 61% of the vote while Mr. Besigye managed 35%.
Foreign observers didn't paint a bright picture either, noting that the election unfolded in a climate thick with fear and intimidation.

Eduard Kukan, the EU's chief observer, commended Ugandans for their "remarkable determination" to cast their votes but pointed out that the National Resistance Movement's heavy grip compromised the campaign's fairness.
Sporadic violence and loud opposition cries of fraud, coupled with blocked social media and messaging apps, further marred the election. "Today, I am under house arrest," Mr. Besigye remarked.
"My home is sealed off, and I can't go anywhere. No one's allowed to visit me. Plus, I'm cut off from the internet.
This regime is flexing its harsh power out in the open. It's not an electoral process; it's a creeping military coup."
This election was Mr. Besigye's fourth attempt to unseat Museveni, representing the opposition Forum for Democratic Change.
It's worth noting that these two were once on the same team, with Mr. Besigye even serving as Museveni's personal doctor during their guerrilla warfare days.
Now, he's said to be confined to prevent him from announcing his own vote count.
Museveni, who took power in 1986, is praised for bringing stability to Uganda, although critics argue he's becoming increasingly authoritarian.
Amama Mbabazi, the former Prime Minister and Museveni's closest challenger in this race, is reportedly also under house arrest.
Meanwhile, the National Resistance Movement is celebrating its victory, maintaining that Museveni's opponents "failed to offer any alternative."
Uganda's old guard seems to be employing fresh election strategies this time around.
The packed Monrovia stadium was buzzing, with none other than state president Ellen Johnson Sirleaf watching from the stands, as all the action unfolded in the second half.
In an electrifying match, Mitis Mulbah bagged two goals and Benjamin Sarkoh added another, propelling Liberia to a thrilling victory over Kabylie, a club ranked among Africa's top ten.
Mulbah got things rolling by breaking the deadlock in a goalmouth scramble around the 58th minute.
Later, after a blunder by Algerian goalkeeper Malek Asselah, Sarkoh took full advantage to wrap up the win.
Kabylie’s big loss was another blow for Algerian football, especially after the disappointing exit of the Desert Foxes at the group stage in the recent Africa Cup of Nations.
In another game, Mouloudia Alger didn’t fare much better, losing 2-1 on the road to Ghana's Bechem United.
They did manage to snag an away goal, though, which gives them a fighting chance in the return leg coming up next weekend.
Meanwhile, Rayon Sports from Rwanda seem well poised to advance in Africa's second-tier club competition after thrashing Al Salam Wau of South Sudan 4-0 in Juba.
Savio Nshuti kicked off a goal spree in the second half with a strike at 54 minutes, followed by goals from Pierrot Kwizera, Nova Bayama, and Moussa Camara.
Over in Niger, Bosnian Enes Sipovic netted the critical goal that saw Ittihad Tanger from Morocco, new to continental competitions, come from behind to defeat Douanes 2-1 in Niamey.
Morocco had more to cheer about when second-division MAS Fes, taking full advantage of home turf, secured a solid 3-0 win over CARA of Congo Brazzaville, former African champions.
A mistake by the Congolese keeper allowed Koffi Boua an easy shot, opening up scoring for MAS Fes, the 2011 Confederation Cup winners.
Despite playing on neutral ground in Cairo, Al Hilal Benghazi of Libya emerged victorious against Kenya's Ulinzi Stars with a 1-0 win, thanks to an Ahmed Al Abbar goal just after the break.
The Comoros team Volcan surprised many by holding the Vipers from Uganda to a goalless draw in Kampala, hinting at a potential first continental triumph for the island nation.
Meanwhile, CS Sfaxien of Tunisia, the competition's record three-time winners, are among 12 clubs skipping straight to the round of 32.
This season, the Confederation Cup, much like the Champions League, will introduce a new setup with boosted prize money.
The qualifying rounds have been trimmed to two before playoffs against last-32 Champions League losers, and the group stage now features 16 instead of eight clubs.
A survey conducted with 2,750 youngsters aged 11 to 18 shows that one in ten checks their phone for notifications at least ten times a night.

This research, carried out by Digital Awareness UK along with the Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference, raises concerns about the way late-night phone habits might leave students showing up to school sleepy and less attentive.
The organizations propose a "digital detox," urging kids to stash their devices 90 minutes before they hit the hay or, better yet, keep them out of the bedroom altogether.

Out of the 45% who confessed to phone checking when it's really time to be snoozing, a whopping 94% are tied to social media, and 10% feel all kinds of stressed that they’re missing out if they don’t catch up with their feeds before sleeping.
And in this crew, 75% are jamming to music while over half are engrossed in films.
Surprisingly, 32% of these kids say their parents are clueless about their late-night screen time.
Charlotte Robertson, who co-founded DAUK, chimed in: "The overwhelming use of social media is impacting kids' physical and emotional health.
Many wake up greeted by more than a hundred notifications from conversations that took place overnight.
There's this pressure to reply to messages at 1 AM just to fit in and not miss out on anything."
Mike Buchanan, the HMC chairman, remarked: "The data makes it clear that most kids are driven by FOMO.
Fatigue from staying up on their phones is hurting their focus and grades. Instead of blaming technology, though, we should accept what's going on and seek to promote using it in a positive way."
The transformation of China's Communist Party founder into a pop art icon through portraits echoes Warhol's famous interpretations of Marilyn Monroe and Campbell's soup cans.
This portrait series, derived from a photo in Mao's Little Red Book, has cemented its place as a memorable image of the 20th century.
With the auction around the corner, expectations are running high; it could fetch as much as $15 million (£12.1 million).
Back in 2014, this particular portrait was snapped up in London for £7.6 million ($9.4 million).
The current owner, keeping their identity under wraps, is putting it up for sale again via Sotheby's in Hong Kong on April 2.
Warhol kicked off his silk-screen series of Mao in 1972, right when U.S.-China relations started thawing, thanks to President Nixon’s groundbreaking visit to Beijing.
He used a photo found on the Little Red Book’s inside cover—a powerful emblem of Chinese communism and propaganda.
With over a billion copies in circulation, this book is one of history's most published works.

During Mao's reign, owning a copy was practically mandatory. Warhol created nearly 200 versions in various sizes, echoing the style of his earlier pieces featuring Marilyn Monroe and Elvis Presley from the '60s.
Turning his gaze to Mao marked a departure from his usual subjects of everyday items or glamorous figures.
Chairman Mao, a formidable political figure, became a striking choice for the vibrant colors of Pop Art—a choice that still stirs conversation in China.
In 2013, a significant Warhol exhibit notably skipped over the Mao portraits, which ignited discussions in the Chinese media about whether the portraits were respectful or satirical.
Despite this, Chinese collectors are snapping up Western art at a growing rate, representing about 20% of global art buyers.
Factors like the yuan’s dip and tighter money controls are spurring interest in international art investments.
As a result, Warhol's vision of Mao might eventually land in China through these worldwide markets. Reported by Andreas Illmer for the BBC.
At a garden party at Buckingham Palace, under the relentless rain on Tuesday, the Queen made an unexpectedly candid remark.
"Oh, bad luck," she noted when told that a Metropolitan Police commander had managed the Chinese leader's visit.
This offhand comment was unusual and left many scratching their heads about the visit still shrouded in mystery.
Seriously, there’s a lot we don’t know. The Lord Chamberlain introduced Police Commander Lucy D'Orsi to the Queen and shared that she was "seriously, seriously undermined by the Chinese."
Reflecting on the chaos, Commander D'Orsi admitted it was "quite a testing time," recounting how "they walked out of Lancaster House and told me the trip was off."
The Queen seemed quite knowledgeable about the issue, adding, "They were very rude to the ambassador."
In agreement, Ms. D'Orsi quipped, "They walked out on both of us." Whether the Chinese officials threatened to ditch the entire state visit or just part of it isn’t clear.
Was it security-related pressure on Ms. D'Orsi or something bigger diplomatically?

We just don't know, and the police haven’t provided any details. President Xi and Madame Peng stayed at Buckingham Palace during the visit, so it makes sense the Queen would be in the loop about such details.
Meanwhile, the Metropolitan Police faced criticism from human rights groups for how they handled protests during Mr. Xi's October 2015 visit.
Commander D'Orsi expressed her disappointment over allegations that the Met had "worked to the bidding of the Chinese to suppress protest."

The Queen’s accidental remarks were caught by Peter Wilkinson, her official cameraman, and shared with broadcasters via the usual "pool" system for royal events, which limits multiple news crews at engagements. That's when the Queen’s unusually forthright comments came to light.
Meanwhile, Mr. Xi remarked that he thought his visit would lift UK-China relations to "a new height."
Buckingham Palace didn’t offer a statement on the "private conversation" but assured everyone that the visit went smoothly with cooperative efforts from all involved.
Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Lu Kang later commented that the president’s trip was highly successful, marking "the start of the Golden Era between China and the UK."
Thanks to the Queen’s offhand comments, we've got a glimpse of the tangled and tricky situation faced by both the police commander and the British ambassador behind the scenes.
By halftime, the Warriors were ahead of Leinster 13-6, thanks to Zander Fagerson's try, while Duncan Weir and Leinster's Fergus McFadden each kicked two penalties.

The third quarter saw Luke McGrath and Taqele Naiyaravoro swap tries. Once Naiyaravoro got hit with a yellow card, Leinster took control with a penalty try, and McFadden chipped in with a late penalty.
The visitors were bolstered by the return of six Scottish internationals, eyeing their first away win against Leinster since 2011.
They broke through in the 13th minute after a series of plays culminated in the 19-year-old prop Fagerson bulldozing his way over the line.
Weir easily converted the try, then McFadden made his mark with his first penalty shortly afterward.
By the 21st minute, another penalty from McFadden shrunk the lead, spurred by Aaron Dundon's ruck work and precise line-out delivery.
Weir seized a Leinster error, nailing a fantastic 43-meter penalty post-maul collapse.
He repeated his feat six minutes before halftime, following a penalty against Mike McCarthy at a maul.
Leinster missed a chance for a third penalty when McFadden's attempt went wide; this followed Pat MacArthur's reckless tackle that sidelined Dundon and earned him a yellow card.

As play resumed, Leinster made the most of their numbers advantage; scrum-half McGrath engineered a play where Garry Ringrose sped up the sideline, leading to McGrath's try duly converted by McFadden.
The tie didn’t last long—just six minutes—before the Scots struck back with powerful attacking spells, setting up Naiyaravoro for a strong try.

Leinster reclaimed the lead with a penalty try; substitute Isaac Boss kicked things off with a pass to Isa Nacewa, which Naiyaravoro reportedly knocked over the line on purpose, resulting in his sin-binning after a video review.
McFadden's conversion swung the score in Leinster's favor, cemented further when he landed his third penalty.
Leinster's lineup boasted players like Nacewa, Ringrose, and Te'o, with Boss, Dooley, and others waiting in the wings.
Glasgow Warriors had Lamont, Naiyaravoro, Vernon, and more, with Hart and Yanuyanutawa ready to step in.
Come July, Boro was the club to watch in the Premier League, snapping up eight new players.
Karanka chatted with BBC Tees, saying, "We're taking our time. We've got the team’s core; it’s about keeping the momentum going."
The better the squad, the better the odds of staying in the Premier League, he explained.
Having come close to promotion in the 2015 play-offs, Boro leveled with Brighton on the final day last season.
This earned them promotion by goal difference and brought them back to the top tier after a seven-year hiatus.
They cruised through pre-season without defeat but let one slip just 14 minutes into their 3-1 triumph over Aston Villa last Saturday.
This made Karanka worry about their defense lapses. As he put it, "We need more players, especially in central defense. That's the area that needs beefing up.
Dael Fry is brilliant, with tons of potential, getting better by the day. But he needs space to grow, and we've got to add more players."
While shoring up the defense remains vital, Karanka is focused on making sure the new faces blend in fast.
"What's crucial to me is that the guys fit into the team smoothly," he remarked.
"We're mixing players who battled to stay in the Championship a couple of years back with those who were in the Champions League not long ago.
Still, the team spirit hasn’t budged." Middlesbrough is all set to kick off their Premier League journey at home against Stoke City on Saturday, 13 August.
After Ryan Lochte falsely claimed he was robbed at gunpoint during the Rio Olympics, his sponsors swiftly reacted.
Skin care company Syneron-Candela and Japanese mattress maker Airweave both released statements addressing the incident.
Lochte, a swimmer with 12 Olympic medals and numerous endorsements, felt the repercussions.
Speedo, his biggest sponsor, declared, "We cannot condone behavior that contradicts our brand values."
Lochte acknowledged Speedo's decision with respect and thanked them for their years of support.
Appearing on a U.S. talk show, he admitted, "I made a mistake and learned from it.
My immature, intoxicated behavior tarnished the Games." Ralph Lauren, which had a short-term deal with Lochte for the Rio Olympics, pulled his photos from their website and won't renew his contract.
Nevertheless, both Ralph Lauren and Airweave still back the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic teams.
Syneron-Candela highlighted their high standards for employees and partners. In a notable move, Speedo chose to give $50,000 from Lochte's sponsorship fee to Save the Children's Brazilian program.
While the specifics of Lochte’s Speedo contract remain undisclosed, it is known to conclude this year after lasting a decade.
Back during the 2012 London Olympics, Forbes estimated Lochte raked in around $2 million in endorsements.
Even though his Rio performance didn’t quite match up, Forbes guessed he’d still earn between $1 million and $2 million in sponsorships.
The whole controversy kicked off after Lochte and his teammates returned to the Olympic village one night.
Unable to get into a locked bathroom at a gas station, they relieved themselves outside.
Initially, they claimed they were robbed by impostors posing as police, but Lochte eventually admitted he exaggerated the tale while drunk.
Despite CCTV footage contradicting his story, Lochte insisted he didn’t lie to Brazilian police.
His actions were heavily criticized back home, with media outlets like the New York Post branding him the "Ugly American" and running the headline, "Liar, Liar, Speedo on Fire."
Hamilton called the change "too drastic" and "the worst-looking" modification in Formula 1 history.
Back in 2009, Henry Surtees, son of John Surtees, died in a Formula Two race after getting hit by a loose tire.
John Surtees spoke up, saying, "Losing Henry was a tragedy that something like this could have prevented."
Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel chimed in, saying the device can be as "ugly as possible" if it saves lives; he believes we might've avoided Henry Surtees' death with a system like this in place.
John Surtees, who clinched the drivers' championship with Ferrari back in ’64, commented, "Lewis might consider the 'halo' and his responsibility as a world champ.

Changes come and sometimes they’re just bound to happen. The governing body might have no choice but to push these regulations, considering the direction things are going. Henry got hit by a wheel weighing 28kg—maybe a 'halo' could've helped."

Over at McLaren, Fernando Alonso views the 'halo' as necessary. "This is the future of F1; we can't risk any serious injuries or deaths like those over the past couple years," said the two-time world champ, referring to fatal accidents involving Jules Bianchi and Justin Wilson.

"Alright, the 'halo' might seem a bit much visually—perhaps a canopy or different solution will come along soon—but fingers crossed, next year every car will have a system like this." Dive deeper into the 'halo' here.
The Office for National Statistics has flagged Oldham as the most deprived area in England, with West Bromwich in the West Midlands not far behind.

On the flip side, Guildford in Surrey emerged as the least deprived town. This study took a good look at income, employment, health, education, skills, crime stats, disability access, housing, and the built environment, covering cities and towns in England and Wales.
It found that the northwest boasts five out of the ten most deprived towns, with the West Midlands having three in the top five.
While Oldham claimed the top spot overall, West Bromwich really struggled with employment and income, ranking dead last out of 109 areas in both and coming second-to-last for education.
Meanwhile, Birmingham didn't fare well in the housing category. At the other end of the spectrum, Guildford, Woking, and St Albans topped the list for having the least deprivation.
The study also pointed out that 29 out of 45 towns in southern England have average house prices over £200,000, which is a far cry from just three out of 64 in the North and Midlands.
Since 2010, house prices in Cambridge shot up by 47%, while Swansea saw a 4% dip.

As per ONS data, Burnley in Lancashire stands out as the most affordable place to buy a home, with average prices coming in at £166,000 for detached homes, £120,000 for semi-detached, £69,950 for flats, and £54,498 for terraced houses—rounding out to an average of £78,000.

St Albans, on the other hand, is where housing gets pricey, with averages of £675,000 for detached homes, £529,400 for semi-detached, £400,000 for terraced houses, and £255,000 for flats, pulling the average to £390,000.

Eddie Moores, who’s Oldham Council's cabinet member for health, mentioned they've been putting in the hours over the last five years to boost health, wages, skills, and jobs through programs like Get Oldham Working, the Oldham Education and Skills Commission, and the Warm Homes Oldham project, which has helped over 3,300 people get out of fuel poverty.
He also talked about investments in the borough's biggest post-war regeneration plan to ensure they reap the benefits of a growing economy.
Sandwell Council Leader Darren Cooper commented on how significant cuts from the central government have drained local resources.

A group from Glasgow University has been digging into recordings of Glaswegian speech, stretching from the early 1900s up to today, and they’ve unearthed some intriguing patterns in accent evolution across the UK.

Among these are the swapping of "f" for "th" in words like "think" and dropping the "l" in "people" to pronounce it as "peopo." Even with these shifts, the Scottish accent holds its own distinctiveness.
Professor Jane Stuart-Smith, who heads the university's phonetics lab, led the three-year Sounds of the City project.
She admitted, "We were quite surprised by what we found. There's this common belief that traditional dialects in the UK are fading, some even disappearing completely.
But we've discovered that, in Glasgow at least, Scottish accents aren't just surviving—they're thriving.
Unlike in England, Scottish accents aren’t blending into a more generic, English-like accent but are staying very unique."
Throughout their research, the Glasgow team put together a digital collection of recorded speech sounds.

Their study found two main types of changes. The first includes those common accent tweaks, like swapping "f" and "l," spreading throughout the UK, influenced by dialect interactions and popular London-based TV shows.
The second set of changes is subtler and specific to Scotland, altering vowel sounds in words like "boat," "goat," and "coat," as well as the stop sounds in "pin," "top," and "cat."
They initially thought these sounds would stick around or change in line with Anglo-English accents, but the changes in Scotland are evolving separately, having done so for over a century.
The Glasgow team speculated that some of these changes began around World War I.
The research spotlighted six recordings from 1916, stored in the British Library, of Scottish soldiers held in German POW camps.
These recordings showed that Scot accents were already on the move a hundred years ago, maybe even earlier.
The project’s outcomes will be available online for students and other researchers to access.
Cambridge University Press is diving into the media chatter from the 2014 Brazil World Cup to rate England's 'confidence levels' out of 100.
These scores shift with the language used about the team. After England’s 2-2 draw with Ecuador on June 4, their confidence sat at 38.
It ticked up to 40 following the 0-0 match with Honduras on June 8, then spiked to 77 the day after.
As they gear up for the game in Manaus, the Cambridge Confidence Index places England at a 70.
Over the last couple of weeks, researchers have sifted through millions of words from varied media outlets.
Dr. Claire Dembry from Cambridge University Press noted, "Our wide range of sources gives us unique insights into the mood around the England team.
It's fascinating to see national confidence rise ahead of the Italy match, particularly after uninspiring games against Ecuador and Honduras."
Words like "progress," "strong," and "joy" are increasingly coming up from players, coaches, and fans.
