Adam Lallana, 26, and 18-year-old Luke Shaw, both aiming to leave Southampton, have received more positive mentions than any other England players.
Neymar stole the spotlight, becoming the most talked-about player after netting twice in Brazil's 3-1 victory over Croatia.
The term "controversial" started trending following a debated penalty for Brazil's first goal and anti-World Cup protests in several host cities.
Cambridge plans to keep an eye on the positive and negative trends throughout the tournament to track shifts in perceived confidence in the England squad.
A team of academics from the University of Westminster studied the independence of kids between seven and 15 years old, surveying 18,000 children across 16 countries.
England came in seventh place for child independence, with the study emphasizing how much freedom to explore their own neighborhoods can benefit kids' health and development.
But, it turns out, the biggest reason for parents holding back is the fear of traffic.
The research, which took place between 2010 and 2012, asked children and parents about unsupervised activities possible in their areas.
They found that kids under 11 generally don't get to roam around solo. Even as they grow older and inch closer to having adult privileges like driving, restrictions persist.
Finland led in letting kids explore independently, with Germany right behind. In Finland, most children move freely without adults tagging along.
In England, though, it's a different story. While crossing roads alone is common for primary school kids, only 28% get to make their way home from school by themselves.
Even fewer get the green light for nighttime outings, bus rides, or going places other than school.
For secondary school students, less than a quarter venture out after dark on their own.
Ben Shaw from the Policy Studies Institute pointed out, "Sure, protecting kids is important.

But gaining independence is crucial for their growth. The jump from primary to secondary school is often seen as the time for this change, but holding back can lead to more road accidents around that age."
European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker wants the Brexit process to kick off "immediately," and several EU foreign ministers are echoing this urgency for Britain to get a move on.
But British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond's taking a more cautious approach, saying, "nothing is going to happen at the moment."
He explained that Britain has control over when it formally starts the withdrawal process, and talks won't begin until a replacement for Prime Minister David Cameron is in place.
Hammond's stance got a nod of approval from Peter Altmaier, German Chancellor Angela Merkel's chief of staff.
Altmaier expressed that UK politicians should mull over the repercussions of Brexit deeply—but not necessarily Brexit itself.
"Politicians in London should take the time to reconsider the consequences of the Brexit decision," he told Reuters.
Merkel herself emphasized that the EU shouldn't be "particularly nasty" during negotiations, suggesting the focus shouldn't be on discouraging other nations from leaving.
The ball's in the UK's court here—triggering Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon starts the clock on a two-year negotiation period to iron out the exit terms.
The UK can do this formally, whether by writing or speaking up at a European Council meeting with ministers from all EU member states.
Cameron's plan is to step down by October, letting his successor steer the negotiations ship.
Since last Thursday's vote, questions are swirling about just when and how the UK will formally kick off the talks.
This Brexit vote has really stirred the pot across Europe, with leaders of Eurosceptic parties in France, the Netherlands, and Italy now clamoring for their own referendums.

Some EU leaders are pushing for quick changes to ward off further chaos. French Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron is one of them, pitching the idea of drafting a new mission statement for the EU and putting it to a referendum.
"We've never had the courage to organize a true European referendum in its real sense," Macron said at a conference.
The plan is to first map out this new vision with the peoples of Europe and then have the whole bloc vote on it.
The first EU summit without Britain is teed up for Wednesday, following Cameron's talks with EU members.
The Brexit news hit global stock markets and the pound hard, causing a big slump, and credit rating agency Moody’s downgraded the UK's credit outlook to "negative." So, what comes next for Brexit?
At 25, Williams ended up with an ankle injury during Wales' win against South Africa.

Word is, he’s set to join the European champions for the 2017-18 season. Scarlets’ head coach, Wayne Pivac, has been pretty straightforward about it, saying, "Once that decision is finalized, we won't hide it."
For now, he mentioned, "Liam's taking a breather this week, but nothing new on the contract front. I trust Sanjay [Williams] with what he shares.
Honestly, I haven't been too wrapped up in the future, but we've got [the new Kiwi wing/full-back] Johnny McNicholl now."
Pivac is hopeful that Williams will bounce back in time for the European Champions Cup games against Toulon on December 11 and 18.
Meanwhile, Jonathan Davies, Gareth Davies, Samson Lee, and Jake Ball are gearing up for regional matches again. Scott Williams and Ken Owens, though, are getting some downtime.
Scotland’s flanker John Barclay is undergoing checks following his national team duties, and it looks like South African lock David Bulbring might need surgery on his shoulder.
"Three of our internationals need a breather after all their time on the field during preseason and training," Pivac said.
"We’re being strategic about upcoming games and rest opportunities. Some players got a bit of a break during the Treviso and Dragons matches earlier this season."
On the other hand, Rob Evans, the Wales prop, is eyeing his season debut against Zebre, having bounced back from wrist surgery.
"He's super eager and ready to go, but we need to focus that energy. He's definitely in the mix for the trip," Pivac remarked.
"Rob’s all fired up to earn back his Scarlets and Wales spots. He knows it’s go-time from day one."
As for contracts, Scarlets are in talks with regional captain Owens and his usual deputy, Kiwi center Hadleigh Parkes.

"We’ve held off on Ken because of his time with the national team, but I’ll catch up with him next week to talk about what’s next. As our current captain, we’re hoping he sticks around," Pivac explained.
After a week of nationwide protests over perceived injustices in policing, President Obama asked Congress for more funding.
It all kicked off in Ferguson, Missouri, where riots erupted when a grand jury chose not to indict a white police officer for killing an unarmed Black man.
Protests quickly spread throughout the country, culminating in a mass walkout that Monday.
Students and workers across various cities stepped out for lunchtime demonstrations to spotlight the issue.
"This isn't just a problem isolated to Ferguson, Missouri. It's a national issue," Obama remarked.
"But it's a problem we can fix." He made these comments following a series of meetings at the White House that included mayors, civil rights leaders, and police officials.
The discussions centered around a program that offers surplus U.S. military equipment to local police forces at no cost.
Obama announced he'd asked for recommendations from federal agencies to ensure this program doesn't lead to a "militarized culture" in local policing.
The Ferguson police department had caught flak for its aggressive response to protests after the shooting of Michael Brown back in August.
Obama's funding request, stretching over three years, aims to secure funds for 50,000 body cameras for cops and to support law enforcement reform efforts.
Body cameras could provide vital evidence in interactions between police and civilians, especially in heated situations like what happened in Ferguson.
During a meeting at the White House, young people shared stories of discrimination that, as Obama put it, "contradict my beliefs about America’s potential."
He also announced a new task force on modern policing led by Philadelphia Police Commissioner Charles Ramsey.
On that same Monday, a commission gathered in Ferguson to address issues related to Brown's death.
Formed by Missouri Governor Jay Nixon, this 16-member panel is set to explore changes in how the public engages with law enforcement and to consider community stability measures.

Officer Darren Wilson, who shot Brown, resigned over the weekend. His resignation followed the decision not to charge him, sparking a broader national debate about the tension between Black communities and police.
Wilson claimed he feared for his life, while Brown's supporters insisted the teen was trying to surrender, with witnesses saying the unarmed 18-year-old had his hands up.
In December 2012, David Brown, while at Maghaberry Prison, fell seriously ill and later passed away in the hospital from a brain hemorrhage.
According to a report by the Prisoner Ombudsman, staff left Brown unattended for about five minutes when he was unresponsive and didn’t sound the alarm quickly enough.

This led the watchdog to label the Prison Service's actions as "inadequate." Tom McGonigle, the Prisoner Ombudsman, pointed out that the nurse treating Brown wasn’t informed about the emergency situation and that other prisoners weren’t confined to their cells at the time.
McGonigle emphasized that even though there were areas to improve, the investigation found no chance of a different outcome for Mr. Brown.
The Prisoner Ombudsman's office in Northern Ireland handles investigations into all in-custody deaths, including those from natural causes.
The report also noted that Brown had painkillers in his system, which were prescribed and found to be within therapeutic levels during toxicology tests.
This was important given the rumors about a white powdery substance near his nose when he died.
Although the report criticized the initial response by the prison staff when Brown was found unconscious, it did not fault the medical care he received while imprisoned.
A clinical reviewer in the investigation concluded that there couldn’t have been an earlier diagnosis and no alternative outcome was possible for Brown.
The ombudsman's report highlighted four areas needing improvement in the prison's case management, such as record-keeping and post-incident staff support.
These issues were previously brought to the attention of prison authorities and the South-Eastern Health and Social Care Trust, which treated Brown.
The Northern Ireland Prison Service (NIPS) agreed to implement the ombudsman's four recommendations, and they claim these have been enacted.

The health trust accepted their recommendation too and assured that it has been emphasized to staff and will be discussed at a "Lessons Learned" forum. Mr. McGonigle also expressed his condolences to Brown's family.
NHS Improvement was all set to reveal data about hospital deficits, but then came a snag—the government advised against it.
They were pretty let down about having to wait until after the election for the release.
Neither the Department of Health nor the Conservative Party has chimed in about this whole situation.
The hiccup seems to be the publication date, which needs a nod from the Department of Health.

With the election looming on June 8, that hasn’t been possible. "We wanted to sort out a date, but after discussions with the department, it became clear that putting the data out there would go against Cabinet Office guidelines," NHS Improvement stated.
"It's a bummer, but we've got to hold off on sharing the financial results for the provider sector until the election is over." The financial state of England's NHS often stirs up debate.
Back in the 2015-16 fiscal year, hospitals and trusts chalked up deficits hitting £2.4 billion.
The numbers from the latest fiscal year, up to the end of March, are going to confirm the 2016-17 totals.
Typically, these figures come out just ahead of NHS Improvement board meetings, the next one slated for late May.
Ideally, NHS Improvement wants to get the numbers out there within a week, but Whitehall officials are advising to hold off post-polling due to purdah rules.
The purdah convention aims to keep civil service announcements on the down-low during election campaigns, a rule that some folks think is overly restrictive.
Dr. Mark Porter, BMA council chairman, didn’t mince words, saying, "The government seems scared, dodging the looming funding crisis that’s squeezing the NHS.
Holding back the figures won't fix what's really wrong with our health service."
Dr. Mark Holland, president of the Society for Acute Medicine, added, "The election and purdah appear to stall many critical NHS decisions.
It’s fair and right that the info regarding England’s NHS should be accessible."
Shadow health secretary Jon Ashworth chipped in, "This looks like a cover-up, keeping the public from seeing the NHS's real situation.
We’re calling for full transparency, so everyone gets the true picture when casting their vote."

And to cap things off, at the start of the campaign, NHS England raised quite a few eyebrows by deciding that monthly performance figures—like A&E waiting times—scheduled for June 8 won’t be shared because it coincides with polling day.
On the day he was supposed to head to Cardiff for a Heineken Cup press event, Saracens threw a curveball.
They told him about an "important squad meeting" in Munich. He went along, only to find it was just a one-day jaunt to Oktoberfest.
The whole team, led by their captain, enjoyed the festivities so much that one of them missed the midnight flight back.
This didn't sit well with the European rugby officials, who fined Saracens £4,250 because Steve Borthwick had been sent to Oktoberfest instead of his Heineken Cup duties.
Saracens' CEO Edward Griffiths didn’t back down, saying, "We're trying to be a little bit different, which will always raise eyebrows.
Maybe others should look at what we're doing." The next weekend, during a match against Leicester, the stadium speakers blasted Bavarian drinking tunes.
By autumn 2010, Griffiths had been in charge for a bit more than 18 months and started shaking things up, bringing in South African director of rugby Brendan Venter.
Saracens had been a bit of an underdog, not really making waves on the big stage, but Griffiths and Venter brought a fresh culture.
Just eight months after the Oktoberfest trip, Saracens snagged their first Premiership title.
Fast-forward three years, and they were on the cusp of a Heineken Cup and Premiership double, set to face Toulon and Northampton on back-to-back Saturdays.
Although Toulon got the better of them, the Premiership title was still up for grabs.
Before his Saracens stint, Griffiths was at the helm of the South African Rugby Union.
He was instrumental in having the 1995 World Cup-winning Springboks learn all the verses of the national anthem, Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika, and coined the rallying cry "one team, one country."
Known for what some call the "cult of Saracens," Griffiths' distinctive approach has earned respect.
While sports administrators often juggle financial and competitive pressures, Griffiths insists he's only "interested" in the outcomes of the finals—a claim that might be a bit of a stretch.
Dyke, who stepped into his role back in 2013, originally planned to hang around for another year.
But he changed his mind after running into resistance against his reform ideas from a few FA councillors and some board members.
He took over from David Bernstein with ambitious targets in mind: get England to the Euro 2020 semi-finals and nab the 2022 World Cup trophy.
Dyke, now 68, feels football has come a long way in terms of financial health, administration, and coaching standards under his watch.
Still, he's realized convincing the FA Council to adopt "much-needed, significant reform" won't be easy.
In his announcement, Dyke said, "I'd already made up my mind—if I couldn't push through reform, I’d step down this summer, which I've mentioned to a few colleagues.
Now, even if changes go through, I might not be the right person to handle what comes next."
Before his stint at the FA, Dyke, who once served as the BBC's director general, zeroed in on modernizing the organization and boosting the number of English players in the Premier League.
He made headlines before for a throat-slitting gesture when England ended up in a tough 2014 World Cup group with Italy and Uruguay.
Just recently, Dyke, who never minced words about his criticism of Fifa under Sepp Blatter, quipped, "we should shoot ourselves" if England didn’t make it out of their group at Euro 2016 in France.
Catch the buzz around Dyke's decision on BBC Radio 5 Live's Football Daily podcast.
Bernstein, not particularly shocked by Dyke's move, admitted that neither of them managed "any substantial change," all because of how "difficult" it is to push reforms through.

"I totally get his frustration; it feels a lot like mine," Bernstein mentioned to BBC Radio 5 Live Sport, hinting that perhaps only government or regulatory "outside intervention" might shake things up.
Meanwhile, BBC Radio 5 Live's sports news correspondent Richard Conway dives into the questions that Dyke's decision stirs up.
Q: Why is Dyke frustrated? A: Back in 2014, Dyke criticized the FA Council for being largely "overwhelmingly male and overwhelmingly white."
He felt the council's members, from both professional and amateur ranks, didn’t reflect the reality of modern English football.

Despite this, they hold sway over big policy choices, and a chunk of the council’s 120 members could lose their seats if the proposed changes pass. Q: What’s the next step? Dyke's known for his political tenacity.
At 33, the former captain steps in to replace Glamorgan's Mark Wallace as PCA chairman following Wallace's retirement on February 10.
Mitchell, who handed over the captaincy to Joe Leach in 2017, becomes the 14th chairman since the PCA began in 1967.
"Over 400 fellow players voting for Daryl shows just how respected he is," said PCA chief executive David Leatherdale.
"There were strong contenders, but with his 13 to 14 years in the sport, he's well-known and trusted.
Funnily enough, I was once his boss at Worcestershire, and now he's my boss at PCA."
Mitchell, the Worcestershire opener, will serve a four-year term, aligning with the contract he inked at New Road last December.
He emerged victorious from a tight race against notable names like Graham Onions of Durham, Paul Horton from Leicestershire, Somerset's James Hildreth, and Northamptonshire's Steven Crook.
Pending the PCA AGM's approval on February 21, Mitchell will join previous Worcestershire captains Tim Curtis (1989-96) and Vikram Solanki (2009-13) in holding this post.
"I did express a desire to stay as captain," Mitchell told BBC Sport. "October was tough, but the new contract helped me move past that.
Honestly, I would've gone for the election anyway because I like to stay involved.
Maybe stepping down as captain will relieve some pressure and let me concentrate on my batting.
It's an exciting role to step into, although focus is key. It might turn out to be a hidden blessing," he reflected.

Previous PCA chairmen include Roger Prideaux (1967-68), Jack Bannister (1968-70), Mike Edwards (1970-73), Peter Walker (1973-75), David Brown (1975-80), Chris Balderstone (1980-84), Geoff Cook (1984-89), Matthew Fleming (1996-2003), Martyn Ball (2003-07), and Dougie Brown (2007-09).
Valentina Milluzzo's family claims that her doctor refused to terminate her pregnancies because he was a "conscientious objector" to abortion.
The hospital, however, strongly denies this claim. Milluzzo's funeral has been put off as the investigation continues.
She had been admitted to Cannizzaro Hospital in Catania, Sicily, on September 29 after facing complications that triggered premature labor at just 19 weeks.

This happened following fertility treatment at a different clinic. Milluzzo's condition was stable for a couple of weeks, but on October 15, things took a turn for the worse when her blood pressure and temperature dropped.

The family's lawyer says that one of the fetuses was struggling to breathe, yet the gynecologist refused to perform an abortion to save Milluzzo. Allegedly, the doctor said, "As long as it's alive, I will not intervene."
With no action taken while the fetus was still alive, both fetuses passed away hours later.
Meanwhile, Milluzzo’s health rapidly declined, and by October 16, she had developed an infection and was moved to intensive care, where she ultimately died.

Angelo Pellicano, the head of Cannizzaro Hospital, dismissed the lawyer's claims, insisting there was no question of conscientious objection because the miscarriage was due to severe circumstances beyond control.
He told Ansa, a news agency, "I rule out that a doctor could have told the family what they say he told them."
Additionally, sources informed Ansa that the doctor in question wasn't listed as a "conscientious objector."
The Catania prosecutor postponed Milluzzo's burial to conduct a post-mortem examination.
There are whispers of potential investigations into the hospital staff, but nothing's been confirmed yet.
Paolo Scollo, a senior doctor at the hospital, pointed out that while all his department's doctors are "objectors," they bring in external doctors when needed.
He added that this particular case was a spontaneous miscarriage, implying no negligence on the doctor’s part.
Earlier this year, statistics revealed that 70% of Italian gynecologists refused to carry out abortions in 2013, with even higher percentages in southern areas like Sicily, where the rate was 87.6%.
Although abortion has been legal in Italy since 1978, it's commonly allowed only during the first 12 weeks, unless the mother's life is at stake or fetal problems are significant.
Being a predominantly Catholic country, Italy sees much higher objection rates in its southern parts.
Prosecutors shared in court that Darren Byrne, 40, allegedly assaulted his wife, Maria, 35, at their home in Theydon Bois after she learned about his affair.
The jury was told that Darren poured white spirit on Maria, who was unconscious at the time, and turned on the stove before leaving the scene.
Now, at Chelmsford Crown Court, he’s facing charges of murder and arson linked to this February incident.

Prosecutor Andrew Jackson explained that the couple had a heated argument on the morning of February 13, sparked by Maria’s discovery that Darren was still involved with another woman, who was also married.
Jackson argued, "Maria Byrne's realization of his continued infidelity allegedly led to her being murdered."
The court heard that following this brutal act, Darren took the family dog for a walk, leaving the house for more than an hour—a fact recorded by CCTV.
When he returned and realized his plan hadn't worked, he allegedly tried to stage the scene.
He dialed emergency services, claiming his wife was "burned" and saying, "The stove was on and the frying pan's on the other side of the room.
She's not breathing." Darren also told paramedics that Maria had been making a bacon sandwich for him and was dead by the time he came back.
In the trial, the jury learned from a post-mortem that white spirit had saturated Maria's clothes, and a half-empty bottle was found in the garage.
Notably, the couple's two kids were not at home when their mother died. The trial, full of grim details, is still in progress.

Media playback isn't working on this device. Midweek brought new developments for O'Neill and Keane as they hashed out agreements with the Football Association of Ireland (FAI), though they haven't put their signatures on the contracts yet.
Their journey to Euro 2016 will start against Sweden this coming Monday. "We're thrilled to remain," Keane, 44, shared with a grin.
He loves the gig, working alongside the players, staff, and the folks at the FAI.

Despite having his sights set on club management again after his time at Sunderland and Ipswich, Keane has stuck to his role with the Republic of Ireland team since November 2013, even turning down chances at Celtic to stay as O'Neill's assistant.
"Club management isn’t off the table. I'm only 44, after all—I’ve got time," he reflected.
"I definitely aim to jump back into that world, thinking in terms of a few years, not weeks."

Things were pretty laid-back during the press conference at the team’s base in Versailles, with Keane only shifting gears to serious when the topic of a contract clause came up, one that could let him talk to clubs over the next couple of years.
"What my contract says is private," he shot back, a bit cheeky. "By the way, who do you work for? What's your contract like? Do you get good pay? That’s none of my business."
In a jovial tone, he even cracked a joke about the team’s tournament facilities, a nod to his dramatic exit from the World Cup training camp in Saipan back in 2002.
"The FAI has really nailed it this time. Lessons sure have been learned. The only gripe?

My bed's a touch too soft," he jested. "Honestly, the facilities are top-notch; they speak volumes for everyone's hard work here—the training pitch, the hotel, the spot itself. It's grand. We're having a blast."
Last Thursday, the mayor of London found himself in hot water for giving his barrister wife, Marina Wheeler, a lift through the city on a single-seater bike.
Riding a "backie" is actually a no-go according to the 1998 Road Traffic Act—it could land you a fine of up to £200.

The mayor apologized, claiming he didn’t realize he was bending the rules. Sam Jones from the cycling charity CTC called it "very naughty," stressing that cyclists need to stick to the law and not carry passengers like that.

A video has been making the rounds showing Mr. Johnson and his wife. They’re caught cruising around North Kensington with Marina perched on the saddle, sans helmet, clutching her handbag, while Mr. Johnson stands up and pedals along.
When some car passengers pointed out his faux pas, he hopped off the bike with a cheeky "Night, night," to them. You can hear one passenger joking, "Mate, you all right?
Saddling, that’s a good one, eh?" while another says, "You're not allowed to do that, mate."
Under Section 24 of the Road Traffic Act, only specially designed bikes can carry more than one person—it’s not really meant for classic single-seaters.
The mayor, well-known for his love of cycling and the launch of London’s "Boris bikes," had a spokesperson say, "The mayor apologizes for the short ride he gave his wife on the bike.
He didn’t know he was breaking the law. It’s not like he planned to cycle all the way home with Marina on the back!
He just wanted to get her to a main road to hail a black cab. The mayor loves his cycling and also supports the black cab trade; he was just trying to marry the two."
At 30, the cyclist from County Down etched his name into history as the first Irishman in over a century to clinch a world track title.
He pulled off this remarkable feat in the 2013 scratch race held in Belarus. That unforgettable year also saw him snatch a World Cup gold in Manchester.
He candidly shared, "Missing out on the Olympics took a toll, and I lost my passion for cycling.
The drive to train just isn’t there anymore—pushing on would be a waste of time."
Earlier, in Belarus, he had bagged silver in the individual pursuit and then topped it off by winning the scratch event at the World Championships.
It truly was a whirlwind year for him. With silver in the points race at the World Championships and a European bronze thrown in, he juggled successes and injuries.
Right after his Belarus triumph, a leg fracture at the Tour of Taiwan and some muscle injuries in Belgium tested his resilience.
Yet, by the end of 2013, he was ranked as the top scratch rider in the UCI world standings.
He went on to grab a scratch silver at the 2014 Track Cycling World Championships too.
His stellar 2013 performance earned him the BBC Northern Ireland Sports Personality of the Year.

Following a silver medal at the 2014 World Championships in Colombia, folks saw him as a strong medal contender for the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow, hoping he’d improve on the team pursuit bronze won in Delhi back in 2008.
But Glasgow didn't go as planned, with injuries limiting his comeback. Reflecting on these challenges, Irvine said that "aches and pains" led him to retire.
"I loved playing a part in making cycling more mainstream," he admitted. "I'm really proud of my world and European achievements, and it’s pretty exciting having my name in the history books."
In the footage, some Kenyan soldiers are seen with white shopping bags, while others appear to be picking up white boxes from a mobile phone store.
The attack, carried out by suspected al-Shabab militants at a Nairobi shopping center on September 21, claimed at least 67 lives.

Right now, the Kenyan military is looking into the looting allegations. Reporters say the CCTV footage was captured near the entrance of the Westgate Mall's Nakumatt supermarket, which sells everything from food to electronics.
In one part of the video, soldiers can be seen leaving the supermarket, walking past a floor stained with blood, with plastic bags in hand.
Another clip shows soldiers near a mobile phone shop; one of them reaches over the counter to grab a white item, followed by others taking similar items identified by Reuters as mobile phone boxes.
The Westgate attack sparked a four-day siege, leaving substantial damage to the shopping center.
The Kenyan military has launched an investigation into the looting allegations, which many Kenyans find deeply upsetting.
Over the weekend, The Nation, Kenya's leading newspaper, ran a story titled "Shame of soldiers looting Westgate."
This footage came to light as Kenyan authorities announced they had found a body they suspect was the fourth attacker.
"Today, Sunday, October 20, 2013, we recovered a fourth body identified from CCTV footage as a terrorist," said Kenyan Interior Minister Joseph Ole Lenku.
"DNA and other investigations will confirm their identities. We've also recovered four AK47 rifles used in the assault and 11 magazines."
Initially, officials reported 10 to 15 gunmen, but CCTV footage seems to show only four militants.
It's still unclear if some attackers got away. The Somali militant group al-Shabab claimed the attack was retaliation for Kenyan military operations in Somalia.
Last week, the BBC's Newsnight disclosed that one of the suspected attackers was Hassan Abdi Dhuhulow, a 23-year-old Somali-born Norwegian.
His family fled to Norway in the 1990s, but he went back to Somalia in 2009 and reportedly joined al-Shabab.

Sources with al-Shabab told the BBC Somali Service that Dhuhulow attended a training camp in El Bur, central Somalia, and took part in various operations in Mogadishu and Kismayo, becoming quite notorious in jihadist circles.

The media playback feature's acting up on this device, but here's the scoop: during a 0-0 draw in Dublin against the Republic of Ireland, Real Madrid's forward picked up his second yellow card this season.
That means he’ll be sitting out the match against Group D's top team, Serbia, on June 11 due to suspension.
"We need to fill that gap and aim for a good result," Gunter mentioned. Over on Aston Villa’s side, defender Neil Taylor will also be missing the Belgrade match.
He’s staring down a possible three-game suspension for a tackle that left Republic captain Seamus Coleman needing surgery on his fractured right leg.
Reading's Gunter, now tied as Wales' third-most capped player, reckons the team can still pull through without major players like Bale, the world’s second priciest player.
"We've handled things without key players before and always said we're not just a one-man team," Gunter remarked.
"For Gaz to shine, he needs the team, and that's unchanged. Sure, it's better having him around, but we're pushing to hit our targets with or without him," he added.
Bale, who's bagged four goals so far this campaign, hasn’t skipped a competitive international game since October 2013, playing in 21 straight competitive matches.
Missing him is a blow for Wales, sitting third in the group, four points back from Serbia and the Republic of Ireland, after drawing four out of five Group D encounters.
But Gunter's optimistic there’s still time to stack some victories and acknowledged the wild card nature of other match results.
"We would've liked more points, but qualifying is always a tough nut to crack. We’re still undefeated and close to turning draws into wins.
We've weathered worse. We've thrived in different places, and it's time to draw on that positivity." The match in Dublin was marred by Everton defender Coleman’s rough injury.
Although the media playback feature isn’t cooperating, Coleman did receive significant on-field medical attention, including oxygen, before being stretchered off.

When questioned about any potential provocation, given an earlier incident involving Republic midfielder Glenn Whelan and his Stoke buddy Joe Allen, Wales’ manager Chris Coleman asserted, "Our team can stand up for themselves when it’s needed."
Former Warrington full-back Richie Mathers took to Twitter to slam the "iPitch" at Stobart Stadium, showcasing photos of his grazes and dubbing the surface an "absolute joke."
Despite his team's 32-14 victory, Mathers wasn't impressed. Meanwhile, Widnes weighed in, suggesting the icy conditions during the match likely caused his injuries.

Julie Gaskell, the club's chief executive, explained: "We had four games on the pitch this weekend, and considering the extreme weather—with temperatures hitting minus seven on Friday night—we think the injuries are what you'd expect in such conditions.
Similar injuries happened in Salford's game on Saturday too. Our players have been training on a similar surface for nine months without any issues, so any problems would’ve shown up by now."
Gaskell added that in the past four weeks, there were no injury reports from five-a-side football and boys and girls tag rugby played on the iPitch.
The Rugby Football League also chimed in, confirming their match commissioner saw nothing wrong with the surface, which is the sport's first artificial pitch.
RFL spokesman John Ledger commented, "We're confident Widnes will keep using the iPitch.
It wasn't more dangerous than any other surface over the weekend, and the extreme weather might have played a part."
At a campaign rally, Trump went off on a tangent, calling the South Carolina senator an "idiot" and urging the crowd to give a call to the number he'd shared.
When a Politico reporter dialed it up the next Tuesday, who should answer but Senator Graham himself.
Graham's recent smackdown of Mr. Trump as a "jackass" came after Trump made disparaging comments about Senator John McCain.
The mix of Republicans and veterans groups are getting louder with their criticism of Trump for seeming to diminish McCain's military service, especially pointing out his time as a POW in Vietnam.
Trump's quip, "He's a war hero because he was captured. I like people who weren't captured," didn't exactly win hearts.
Despite all this uproar, Trump is still leading national polls with a hefty margin over his closest Republican rival—a lead that mostly took shape before he went off on McCain.
Trump’s dominance in the media frenzy of the Republican race is really riling up his opponents.
Since he kicked off his campaign in June, he's been in the spotlight for remarks branding undocumented Mexican immigrants as "rapists" and "criminals."
Graham wasn't holding back when he said on CNN Monday, "The world is literally falling apart, and all we're talking about is Donald Trump."
Typically, dissing a military figure like ex-POW McCain, who can't lift his arms above shoulder height due to torture, would be political suicide.
But Trump seems to flourish amid today's wild media environment and chaotic campaign styles.
His bold statements just draw more coverage and social media buzz, and oddly enough, it's boosting his polling numbers.
Somehow, for a chunk of Republican voters, causing waves equal getting votes. Trump’s really got a knack for this political demolition derby.
At a private event in Vancouver, Uber CEO Travis Kalanick revealed that Uber is burning through more than $1 billion a year in China.
This figure first popped up on Canadian tech site Betakit and was later confirmed by Uber China via Reuters.
Since starting its operations in China back in 2014, Uber has been up against the country’s top taxi app, Didi Kuaidi, and is presently active in over 40 cities across China.
Last year, the company rolled out plans to expand into 100 cities within the next year.
Kalanick highlighted, "We’re making profits in the U.S., but China’s a different story, with losses surpassing $1 billion annually."
Despite this, China remains Uber’s largest international market, although they lag behind Didi Kuaidi in market share.
"Our rival is strong and, despite not turning a profit in any of their locations, they're snapping up market share," Kalanick explained.
Yet, he’s optimistic—Uber’s share surged from a meager 1% at the beginning of 2015 to roughly 30-35%.

Didi Kuaidi, backed by Chinese tech behemoths Tencent and Alibaba, has also partnered with Lyft, a competitor of Uber in the U.S. Kalanick mentioned raising about $200 million to help Uber hold its ground in these emerging markets, as noted on Betakit.

He remarked, "I’d much prefer to build the business rather than keep hitting up investors, but if I don’t fundraise, I'm at risk of being pushed out as rivals buy up pieces of the market." Presently, according to its website, Uber operates in 380 cities worldwide.
On Sunday's Politics Scotland program, Employability Minister Jamie Hepburn talked about a report from the Fraser of Allander Institute.
The report suggested that the Scottish economy is on the brink of recession and isn't keeping pace with the rest of the UK.

Mainly, it's the slump in oil prices causing this slowdown. Mr. Hepburn mentioned that "around two-thirds of the sluggish growth stems from the oil and gas downturn," but he also acknowledged some other underlying problems.

He stressed the need to focus on what Scotland's economy is doing right, too. Dean Lockhart from the Scottish Conservatives wasn't holding back, saying the SNP should own up to the economic state of affairs, calling it quite the "indictment."
He referred to the report to claim that Scotland's been through "a lost decade under the SNP."

Over at Scottish Labour, Jackie Baillie pointed out that the growth of the economy under the SNP has been virtually stagnant, remarking, "In the past decade, the Scottish economy’s growth has hit just 1.2%, a stark contrast to the robust 17% growth we saw in the earlier seven years."
An economist on the show also pointed to the oil price crash—and some deeper issues—impacting the economy.
Prof. David Bell from the University of Stirling explained how the fall in oil prices hit the North-East hard and had ripple effects through the rest of Scotland.
He noted that other areas of the economy have been pretty sluggish over the past ten years.
He thinks Scotland should focus on long-term strategies, like boosting infrastructure investment and improving skills policies, to make the region more attractive to businesses.
David Johnstone, Managing Director of After Digital, chimed in with concerns about a skills shortage in crucial technical roles.
"Finding qualified candidates is challenging," he said. Marketing roles have applicants lining up, yet there’s a real shortage for those technical development positions.
He also mentioned how colleges and training providers struggle to keep up with industry changes.
A committee headed by Paralympic champ Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson has suggested that Wales could become the first country to make physical education (PE) a core subject in its national curriculum.

By doing this, schools could dedicate more time to sports. However, teaching unions worry that adding to the core curriculum might draw attention away from current subjects. The Welsh government says it will take this recommendation into consideration.
Education Minister Leighton Andrews is enthusiastic about exploring ways to increase physical activity among kids and teens.
BBC Wales education correspondent Arwyn Jones points out that while giving students more ways to exercise is crucial, adding PE to the core curriculum is more complicated than it appears.
Right now, the core subjects in Wales are Welsh, English, maths, and science, which receive focused attention and resources from the government.
Teaching unions are concerned that expanding the core could lessen each subject’s importance.
With over a third of young people in Wales being overweight or obese—costing the NHS over £70 million a year—boosting PE is becoming increasingly important.
Making PE a core subject would mean schools would need to invest more time, resources, and training into it.

Teachers would need to show they’re adept during their training, schools would need more qualified PE specialists, and they’d face tough assessments from education consortia and Estyn, the school inspection body.
Regular progress checks would also be necessary. Even though this proposal is bold, the group believes it’s a necessary move.

The report, which includes insights from Sports Wales chair Laura McAllister, argues that the Welsh government’s commitment to physical literacy means PE should be viewed as important as reading and writing.
But teaching unions still caution against cramming too much into the core curriculum.
Dr. Philip Dixon, director of ATL Cymru, stresses the importance of having a focused core: "We need to keep it small.
Literacy and numeracy are essential; adding PE might be a good idea, but in the end, it’s up to the government."
Sir Keir Starmer believes there’s a compelling argument for the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) to have the final say on prosecuting cases.
Right now, it's up to the police in England and Wales to decide whether a case should go to the CPS after investigating a death.
The CPS, however, thinks cases should hit a prosecutor’s desk as early as possible.
According to the Department of Transport, 113 cyclists died in the UK last year.
A BBC Newsbeat Freedom of Information request found that between 2007 and 2014, there were 276 cyclist deaths involving motor vehicles.
In those incidents, 148 drivers (54%) ended up charged, but less than half of those convicted actually went to prison.
Sir Keir, now serving as a Labour MP, told the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme that when a death warrants a criminal investigation, "it really ought to go off to the CPS for the final decision."

In Scotland, if driver fault is evident in a cyclist’s death, they submit a report to the Procurator Fiscal, though it appears this isn’t commonplace, as a 2014 Freedom of Information request to Police Scotland showed.

Cycling advocates are pushing for a shift in liability presumption in civil cases, pointing out there's currently no bias either way. My father Mick was killed last year while biking through central London.
He spent three weeks in a coma before he passed away. During the inquest, the driver claimed she only realized something happened after she heard a noise, like "something falling from the sky."

The coroner concluded it was an accidental death. Right from the start, we were skeptical about the police’s investigative efforts, feeling they didn't hunt down potential witnesses as they should have, and our concerns were basically ignored.

A year after my dad's death, we held a vigil at the site of the crash. That day, police told a journalist they’d refer the case to prosecutors, suggesting a trial could take place, which felt like a step forward.
But just four days later, the police told the same journalist the case was closed.
I’m still searching for answers about my dad’s accident, and now our last shot is a private prosecution.
Ian Toothill thinks he's the first cancer patient to stand atop the world's tallest mountain.
A die-hard Sheffield Wednesday fan, he raised eyebrows by planting a Sheffield United flag there to support charity efforts.
The 47-year-old personal trainer hit the summit on Monday, raising nearly £31,500 (around $40,600) for Macmillan in the process.
He cheekily tweeted: "Just a cancer guy and a [Sheffield Wednesday] fan at the top of Everest with a @SUFC_tweets flag.
No big deal." From Sheffield but living in Willesden Green, London now, Toothill isn't new to Himalayan climbs.
Diagnosed with bowel cancer in June 2015, he was briefly cancer-free in 2016 before getting the tough news it was back, this time with a grim prognosis—"just several months left."
But in February, chatting with BBC Radio Sheffield, he said: "I’m set on proving anything is possible."
He made it to the North Col route’s peak on May 16 and Everest’s summit on June 5.
Someone called Miss NJP tweeted: "Absolutely incredible achievement for @IanToothill.
So emotional to see this moment. Amazing job getting to the top #climbingforcancer."
The whole flag thing? That was a friend's cheeky challenge worth a £1,000 donation.
Leslie Binns from Rotherham joined Ian for part of the ascent; Binns had previously sacrificed his own summit bid to save another climber last June.
Ian's fundraising didn't just hit the target of £29,100—it smashed past, nearly hitting £31,500.
Malorie Bantala, 22, tragically gave birth to a stillborn baby boy at 32 weeks after a brutal attack in London this past June.
The assault allegedly stemmed from her decision against having an abortion, which led Kevin Wilson and a 17-year-old to assault her.

They both deny the charges of child destruction and grievous bodily harm. During proceedings at the Old Bailey, it was revealed that Mr. Wilson became enraged when Miss Bantala insisted on keeping their baby, rejecting his suggestion to terminate the pregnancy.
Though he apologized for his behavior, Wilson, a teaching assistant, claimed he was at home in Bermondsey, south-east London, napping during the incident.
He expressed shock and surprise at the news of the pregnancy, admitting he misled Miss Bantala with plans to go to Ghana, as he didn’t want to "play happy families."
Wilson stated, "I told Malorie I'm too young to have a child and to have an abortion."
Between May and June, there was no contact with Miss Bantala after a quarrel arose when she told friends he was the father, accusing her of being unfaithful.
He mentioned that before her baby was lost, he had moved on to another relationship, and his new girlfriend also became pregnant but didn't have a child.
On June 15, the day of the attack, Wilson worked at a behavioral school before heading home.
Following the assault in Peckham, Miss Bantala suffered severe internal injuries, with her stillborn son delivered via Caesarean section. The trial is still in progress.
Prince Harry got quite the reception when he arrived in Surama village, nestled in the heart of the Iwokrama rainforest.
They welcomed him with a feathered headdress, setting the stage for a lively cultural dance around a pole.
While there, he chatted with rangers to get the scoop on rainforest conservation efforts and the perks of eco-tourism.
His pit stops included a local school and the awe-inspiring Kaieteur Falls, famed for being one of the tallest waterfalls with an impressive freefall.
As his Caribbean tour neared its end, Prince Harry made his way to the Iwokrama International Centre, a place closely tied to the Prince of Wales, who's been its patron since 2000.
In Fairview village, he paid respects to the elders and took a look around the school.
An open-air community hall was the backdrop for his visit, where locals gifted him a painting of their traditional homes.
During his speech, Harry praised the secluded community, playfully reflecting on his father's fond memories of the place: "He spoke fondly of his time here when he was much younger and had more hair.
The work you're doing is remarkable, and your leadership is vital for preserving this area."
The day wrapped up with a visit to Kaieteur Falls, which drops a stunning 250 meters—far taller than Niagara Falls.
Earlier in the week, Harry was in Barbados, sharing a stage with Rihanna during a concert to celebrate World AIDS Day.
Together, they took HIV tests to raise awareness in Bridgetown. Just so you know, Guyana is the only English-speaking country in South America.
Over the years, it switched hands between the Dutch, French, and British from 1780 to 1813.

It's also known for the tragic 1978 Jonestown massacre, where over 900 followers of Jim Jones's People’s Temple died in a mass suicide. If you're curious about Guyana, dive deeper into its fascinating history.
Natural Resources Wales (NRW) recently made it clear that the proposed £1.1 billion M4 project can't fully offset its impact on sites of special scientific interest (SSSIs).
The plan would run through four SSSIs across the Gwent Levels. During the Newport inquiry, Welsh Government lawyers brought up the need to balance environmental concerns against other factors.
It came to light that roughly 105 hectares of land meant to protect water invertebrates would be lost if the project goes ahead.
The reens in the Gwent Levels, a unique network of ditches dating back to Roman times, act as homes for various rare species.

The Welsh Government has promised to create new reens to replace those lost. Dr. Jessica Poole from NRW informed the inquiry that after discussions with the Welsh Government, she's on board with the new reens' design.
However, she voiced worries about how effective they'll be, admitting it'll likely take time for them to support the aquatic life meant to be conserved.
She's well aware of the difficulties in recreating an intricate ecology that's evolved over centuries.
NRW stresses that the Welsh Government hasn't proven that the project fulfills its legal duty to foster sustainable development.
On a different note, Dr. Poole suggested that the alternative blue route, backed by transport expert Prof. Stuart Cole, could slash the motorway's impact on SSSI land.

The inquiry was updated that several issues NRW raised against the draft plans have been addressed, and they're now satisfied with concerns regarding water quality, drainage, and the protection of species such as otters and bats.
Morag Ellis QC, speaking for the Welsh Government, pointed out that it's up to Welsh ministers to weigh the motorway's potential effects on SSSI land against other public interests.
She argued that suggesting adverse effects were "fully mitigated for" sets an incorrect legal standard.
Ellis described NRW's revised position, resulting from detailed discussions with the Welsh Government, as "a major step forward."
In Nairobi and other cities, many shops are staying open. The Kenya National Commission on Human Rights reports that at least 24 people have died from the violence since the election on August 8.
Mr. Odinga argues that the election was manipulated to guarantee President Uhuru Kenyatta's win and has proclaimed a "day of mourning for the fallen patriots."
Yet, on Twitter, there's a push for returning to the usual routine under the hashtag #TurudiKaziniChallenge, which means "Let's return to work" in Swahili.
President Kenyatta has also urged for peace, saying, "At the end of the day, we are all Kenyans.
We shouldn't fight or destroy each other's property or take lives." He emphasized that the election is behind us, and most people are back to work.
In Kibera, a part of Nairobi known for supporting Mr. Odinga, some young folks have taken to burning tires, according to the BBC's Tomi Oladipo.
Still, despite agreeing with Mr. Odinga that the election results were skewed, some of his backers in Kibera have opened their shops again; they can't afford more business setbacks.
Over in Mombasa, things seem business-as-usual. Meanwhile, Kisumu, another pro-Odinga area in the west, is showing mixed responses to the strike—some stores remain open, while others are closed.
The official count handed President Kenyatta about 54% of the vote, with Mr. Odinga close behind at 45%.
On Sunday, Mr. Odinga called for a strike, telling followers, "This is a failed regime that resorts to killing rather than addressing the real issue.
The vote was stolen; there’s no secret about that." But foreign observers declared the election free and fair.

Both Federica Mogherini, the EU's foreign affairs chief, and former UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan have encouraged Mr. Odinga to pursue legal action, though the opposition claims it's not a viable option.
The proposed deal aims to ease Europe's migration troubles, but Mr. Gove isn't pleased with Turkey, accusing it of suffering from "erosion of fundamental democratic freedoms."
He argues that instead of giving Turkey "concessions," the EU should actually be protesting.
David Cameron weighed in, saying it'll take "literally decades" for Turkey to join the EU.
He pointed out that the UK can veto their entry since all EU countries and 28 national parliaments must agree for a new member to be accepted.
Despite these assurances, Mr. Gove has highlighted that the "official British government policy" backs Turkey's membership without needing a public vote on new EU entrants.
According to him, the EU referendum on June 23 is the UK's "only chance" to voice opinions on free movement from Turkey.
Earlier, in the EU referendum campaign, Turkey's membership bid and the deal for Turks to travel visa-free in exchange for Turkey accepting migrants from Greece caused quite a stir.
At Vote Leave's headquarters on Wednesday, Mr. Gove, a key figure in the Out campaign, revisited this issue, cautioning about the security risks of bringing Turkey into the EU.
He said, "With the growing terrorism threat, it's difficult to see how visa-free travel for 77 million Turkish citizens is in our security interests."

Adding, he mentioned that "creating a border-free zone from Iraq, Iran, and Syria to the English Channel seems unwise, especially when extremists might think the West is opening its borders to appease an Islamist government."
Mr. Gove also expressed concerns that Turkey's "democratic development" is backsliding under President Erdogan.
He strongly urged, "We and the European Union should protest this erosion of fundamental democratic freedoms," yet he regretted that Erdogan keeps receiving concessions.
Meanwhile, the prime minister accused Leave campaigners of spreading "very misleading claims about Turkey" and the EU.
This debate strikes at the heart of immigration and free movement issues in Europe.
Last month, Mr. Cameron commented, "It would take decades, literally decades, for this to happen, and even then, we could still say no."
He stressed, "The fact that the Leave campaign is getting something as straightforward as this wrong should call into question their judgment on the larger issue of leaving the EU."
Food Standards Scotland recently released a report showing that store promotions tend to favor salty or sugary foods more than healthier options.
The study, done by Stirling University experts, calls for a shake-up in retail to help shoppers make healthier choices.
Yet, the Scottish Grocers' Federation isn't on board, arguing the report misses all the work they've done to push healthy eating.
FSS has pointed out some alarming figures: right now, 30% of Scots are obese, and it's expected to hit 40% by 2030 if things don't change.
Professor Leigh Sparks, who led the report, chatted about this on BBC Radio Scotland's Good Morning Scotland.
He highlighted how stores mainly push less healthy items, like those oversized boxes and bags of crisps.
Sparks thinks both manufacturers and retailers need to step up—makers should tweak their recipes, and stores should rethink their marketing and give better information to shoppers.
"Retailers know it's a problem and are looking for solutions," he said but noted that voluntary measures haven't done much because unhealthy promotions are still dominant.

The report also backs the idea of a sugar tax. FSS senior dietary expert Dr. Gillian Purdon says they're in favor of extending the sugar tax beyond just sodas and encouraging changes like packing smaller portions, cutting down sugar, fat, and salt, and improving food info in stores and restaurants.
She remarked, "This report will help us create ways for retailers to offer and promote more nutritious options.
For healthier eating habits, we need to regulate promotions of high-fat, salt, and sugar foods, both in stores and places we eat."
Previous research by FSS shows that about half the purchases of less healthy foods happen through promotions, compared to about 30% for healthier ones.
The report wraps up by noting, "How stores promote and showcase food affects the health and diet of Scots.
Just relying on voluntary efforts or expecting consumers to make informed choices isn't enough."
Editing a whole game down to its highlights usually takes someone with a sharp eye to zero in on the crucial moments.
But over in Spain, scientists are working on a new approach. They're building a computer system designed to do all that heavy lifting for us.

The plan is simple: automatically edit games by picking out the key events. Researchers at the Polytechnic University of Catalonia have been at it for a while and just put out an 18-page report detailing how it all works.
Arnau Raventos, who's leading the project, told Newsbeat they're teaming up with TV folks in Spain to make life easier for those currently crafting game summaries the old-fashioned way.

Here's the gist of the tech: it works by analyzing what they call key-frames. The computer sifts through match clips to spot signs of big moments—clusters of players, close-up shots, loud crowd reactions, or the referee’s whistle.
Arnau calls these "occasions." He points out, "We're looking to pinpoint specific combinations during a match.
A goal is definitely an occasion." Say a defender trips in the penalty area—players crowd around, whistles tweet, the camera zooms in on faces, and you've got a penalty.
Ideally, this system should catch that. But it’s not perfect yet, and even the casual football fan might get ticked with its current quirks—missing the exact second a goal hits the net.
In tests from five matches, it correctly spotted about 70% of the goals. "Let’s be straight," Arnau admits.
"We're not quite able to churn out a fully automatic summary that nails every goal."
Still, the system’s pretty handy when it comes to ditching unnecessary clips, like broad stadium shots, making the editor's job easier.
For more updates, keep an eye on @BBCNewsbeat on Twitter and Radio1Newsbeat on YouTube.
Sharad Bheswakar, a top cricketer and sports icon in Nepal, finds himself in an odd situation.
Although born and raised in Nepal and a player for the national team, he’s yet to be officially recognized as a Nepali citizen.
You’d think eligibility wouldn’t be an issue given his dad’s Indian roots and his mom’s Nepali citizenship.
Still, getting the documentation hasn’t happened for him. "I’ve been trying for almost eight or nine years to get my citizenship.
I’m still running into problems. It’s incredibly frustrating at times," he says.
He does have a special travel document for international matches, but that's not the same thing.
According to the 2006 Nepali Citizenship Act, typically, folks can apply for citizenship at 16, as long as a mother or father backs the application.
Yet, cultural biases crop up here: women in Nepal often face big challenges in passing citizenship to their kids, especially if the father isn’t around or is foreign.
Without these papers, people can’t get a driver's license, open a bank account, pursue higher education, or complete legal transactions.
The United Nations points out how widespread this issue is. As Robert Piper, the UN Resident Humanitarian Coordinator, states, "From what we see, this is a significant problem.
The Election Commission’s findings reveal that over 2 million folks interviewed in rural areas couldn’t provide citizenship documents."
Usha Kala Rai, who served in the defunct Constituent Assembly, stresses that Nepal’s bureaucracy often discriminates against women.
"Many women endure violence and discrimination—especially those who worked abroad, survived rape, were abandoned, or divorced—are in danger of losing their identity," she explains.
Then there’s Bhagwati Chettri, 55, a woman deserted by her husband years back. She never got citizenship from her parents or husband, leaving her two kids, now adults, without legal status.
"I've been trying for the last eight years to get a citizenship certificate," she laments.
A heartwarming moment featuring young Bailey Matthews has taken the internet by storm—his video has racked up more than 27 million views on Facebook.
Bailey, who's from Doncaster, was honored with the Richard Whiteley Award at a Friday night event in Leeds.
Meanwhile, cricketer Joe Root snagged the Sporting Achievement Award. The Yorkshire Awards, now in their 27th year, recognize the varied achievements of folks and businesses in the region.
Back in July, Bailey took part in a kids' event at Castle Howard in North Yorkshire, where he swam 100 meters, followed by a four-kilometer bike ride, and then ran 1.3 kilometers.
In a touching display of determination, despite two stumbles near the finish, he pushed through the last 20 meters without the aid of his walking frame.
His family said they were "extremely honored" by this recognition, and emphasized how proud they are as Northerners.

Sheffield-born Joe Root, who has climbed to the top of the ICC world rankings as a batsman and helped England claim the Ashes back from Australia, expressed his gratitude for the award, saying it's a "real honor" and thanking everyone who has supported him.
At just 24, he's cemented his status as a crucial player for England with almost 3,000 Test runs to his name.
In other awards, TV chef Rosemary Shrager, who has lived in Yorkshire for years, was named Woman of the Year, while William Hague from Rotherham was declared Man of the Year.
Hague, a former MP for Richmond, said, "Whatever I have done, and wherever I have been in the world, I have never stopped being a Yorkshireman, and never will."
Sir David Wootton was recognized with the Lifetime Achievement Award, and Huddersfield-born poet Simon Armitage took home the Arts and Entertainment Award.
Armitage's accolades include BAFTA-winning Feltham Sings, which also earned him an Ivor Novello Award.
The Business Enterprise Award was claimed by Howarth Timber, a company that started as a one-man venture in Leeds back in 1840 and now boasts over 1,000 employees.
North Yorkshire farmer Gareth Barlow was given the Countryside Award, and junior football coach Stephen Shipley received the nod for Community Hero Award.
The Association of School and College Leaders (ASCL) is setting up a series of seminars in major English cities to address new laws requiring schools and colleges to combat radicalization.
Kamal Hanif, who heads Waverley School in Birmingham and is well-versed in Islam and citizenship, will lead these discussions.
According to the union, the aim is to support and guide school leaders, especially after incidents like the trip by three London schoolgirls to Syria in February.
They ended up in Raqqa, a stronghold of the Islamic State, and their families later criticized authorities for not sharing key information that might have prevented their departure.
Under the Counter Terrorism and Security Act 2015, schools must work to prevent youth from being lured into terrorism.
These sessions, scheduled for June and July, seek to give school leaders practical advice on meeting these duties.
The focus is on fostering inclusive environments and helping educators understand how social media can be used to radicalize young people.
Hanif explains that the seminars are designed to boost understanding of radicalization and extremism, helping head teachers "identify situations" and intervene without unnecessary panic.
Young people often spend a lot of time online, where they might come across extremist ideas without getting exposed to other perspectives.
The seminars aim to assist schools and parents, who might be unaware of their children's online activities, in spotting warning signs and dealing with concerns effectively.

They'll give school leaders tools to counter extremist propaganda. Hanif will be joined by Sara Khan, a campaigner against extremism and co-founder of Inspire, along with ASCL's parliamentary specialist, Anna Cole.
Khan mentions that there's a need to clarify schools' responsibilities under the law since misunderstandings are common.
Cole highlights the necessity of early intervention and risk assessments to avoid criminalizing young people, advocating for a culture where diverse views and ideas can be openly discussed.
Jeremy Corbyn is gearing up for an announcement in Birmingham this Tuesday: a Labour-led government would bump up Carer's Allowance by 17%, aiming to help around a million folks in its first year.
The plan is to lift the weekly allowance from £62.70 to £73.10. Over three years, they'll pour an extra £2 billion into social care.

Right now, about 6.5 million people in the UK rely on Carer's Allowance as they provide care for elderly, disabled, or seriously ill friends or relatives, dedicating at least 35 hours a week and earning no more than £116 after tax.
Corbyn sees this increase as vital for aiding carers—many of whom are women—who often quit their jobs to look after family members at home.
He shared with the BBC that while caregiving can be fulfilling, it shouldn't lead to financial strains or feelings of isolation.

In his upcoming speech, Corbyn's planning to point fingers at Downing Street, laying the blame for the "social care crisis" on their £4.6 billion cut to council care budgets, which left unpaid carers with more to handle.
He’ll shine a light on the fact that these carers save taxpayers a whopping £132 billion each year, and argues they deserve more than just gratitude—they need financial support too.
Labour thinks nudging up Carer's Allowance by £10 weekly is not only the right thing to do but also makes economic sense.
Corbyn proposes to fund this initiative by undoing the Conservative cut on inheritance tax, claiming it chiefly benefits Britain’s wealthiest.
He views this change as a key step in revamping the social care framework and bolstering aid for family carers.

Labour figures estimate that revamping Carer's Allowance will run about £538 million by the year 2020/21, offset by nixing the projected £650 million inheritance tax cut for estates up to £1 million passed between married couples without incurring death duties.
However, the Conservatives counter that Labour's plan to boost the allowance isn’t financially practical.

Luke Hall, a Conservative member of the Commons work and pensions select committee, admits the enormous value carers add to society but stands by the current government's efforts, which have upped Carer's Allowance by £450 annually since 2010.
Now, two years down the line, Jones has stepped into motherhood herself, and it's brought her much closer to understanding what Gemma Foster experienced.
"Being a wife and a mom has made me realize how tough it is when a family unit breaks down.
I’d head home at night, put my baby to bed, and it hit me how two people can start out in love, have a child, and then end up apart.
Managing to co-parent without adding to the child's hurt, despite your own pain, is seriously challenging,” she shares.
Jones even had her son on set from time to time, though he doesn’t appear in the show; she jokes he "looked much better than I did" on camera.
She's eagerly anticipating more downtime with him. "Juggling work and life is tough for everybody, so I try to keep them separate when I can," she says.
"I'm really thankful because I've done quite a bit of work and now I'm taking a decent break. I’m around until Christmas, just hanging out at the park in my Converse."
The second season of the BBC One drama picks up with Gemma’s estranged husband, Simon, who’s played by Bertie Carvel, coming back to the fictional town of Parminster.
He's got his new family in tow, and they're navigating the brutal aftermath of their divorce while their son Tom is caught in the middle.
Jones admits the show can be a bit “uncomfortable” at times but insists it’s got a “weird, sexy edge.” "We've all been in a room with an ex," she says.
"Everyone has relationships and old flames, and we've all faced sticky situations.
Bertie and I probably tapped into our personal experiences to bring these feelings to life.
The writing and show's tone really let us stretch things. It's fantastical yet very much grounded in realism, exploring how far someone might go when they're really pushed."

Carvel, who's also known for portraying Miss Trunchbull in the West End's Matilda, found Mike Bartlett’s writing “thrilling” and described the Doctor Foster plot as a “real page-turner.” "He crafts incredibly complex characters," the actor notes, mentioning that playing someone who evolves in the viewer’s eyes was “a blast.” "You often find yourself looking at stuff from a completely different angle," he comments.
Research on mice and pigs shows that a protein-infused patch can boost healthy cell growth and cut down on scarring, a common aftermath of heart attacks that hampers the heart's pumping power.
According to reports in *Nature*, this patch might revolutionize treatment approaches.
A heart attack blocks blood flow, causing muscle cell death. Repairing or replacing some of these cells is thought to help reduce long-term damage.

In this particular study, an international team treated animals that had heart attacks with a collagen patch soaked in Fstl1, a protein found in healthy hearts but reduced in a crucial heart layer after an attack.
Two weeks after applying the patch, the hearts began growing new muscle cells and blood vessels, showing better pumping function.

Prof. Pilar Ruiz-Lozano from Stanford University, which holds the patent for the patch, observed, "Many of the subjects were so ill before receiving the patch, they'd have been candidates for heart transplantation.
Our aim is for a similar approach to eventually help human heart attack patients facing serious heart damage."

Prof. Gordana Vunjak-Novakovic from Columbia University, writing in *Nature*, pointed out that this could pave the way for new treatments for heart infarctions, but stressed that more research is necessary to determine its effectiveness in larger animals and humans.
The Renewable Heat Incentive scandal may have lit the spark, but it wasn't the whole story behind the election.
The real push came from Sinn Féin and republicans wanting another go at the election; they've managed to energize their supporters quite effectively.
"We put on a positive campaign, and the public seemed to like it. We're heading to Stormont on Monday, ready to tackle new challenges.
I've been saying all along, when Sinn Féin wins, everybody gains," one political leader noted.
They also pointed out that ideally, folks vote based on performance. In his view, neither the DUP nor Sinn Féin warranted another term.
"I didn't get a mandate strong enough to stay, so I'm stepping down." This situation marks a win for those favoring devolution over direct rule, choosing power-sharing over other options.
It's crucial now for all political groups to ensure that control stays with our Assembly—not handed back to Theresa May or James Brokenshire.
Alliance had a pretty good day—we gained more votes even where we typically don't do so well.
This growth in vote share bodes well for rebuilding devolution. Looking ahead, the main worry is whether this place can survive as a political body without middle-ground, non-sectarian power-sharing.
The DUP and Sinn Féin don’t appear interested in sharing control. Everyone’s got a responsibility to jump in and work hard, given the tight timeline to set up a strong administration.
The UK government’s coming days with a positive attitude. Mike Nesbitt stepping down was the right move, sparing us from tricky party talks.
Future discussions will mainly involve the DUP and Sinn Féin, with the SDLP and UUP playing smaller roles.
We're facing a tight race between the two biggest parties—a situation demanding we pay attention to issues raised during the election.
Every party, ours included, has lessons to learn. High voter turnout shows Northern Ireland’s folks are still backing the Good Friday Agreement and its power-sharing government.

The pledges are part of the party's five-year plan to govern, promising more support for families with free childcare and a boost in apprenticeships, alongside projects like the M4 relief road and the South Wales Metro transport network.
Plaid Cymru has called the program "lacklustre," and the Conservatives are saying Labour's letting Wales down.
Some of the priciest commitments include giving parents of three and four-year-olds 30 hours of free childcare per week for 48 weeks, plus rolling out 100,000 apprenticeships for folks of all ages.
As the Welsh Government shares its goals, we're expecting cuts to appear in the draft budget due in October.
A government spokesperson mentioned a close review of spending because of financial uncertainties following Brexit, hinting that tough decisions are on the way.
"Salami slicing won't suffice this time," he said, suggesting some projects and services will have to face cuts.
Speaking on BBC Radio Wales, the first minister acknowledged these impending cuts, citing shrinking budget conditions that require hard decisions.
He admitted that long-standing initiatives might need a second look. The "Taking Wales Forward" program has echoes of many promises from Labour’s Welsh Assembly election manifesto back in May.
Mr. Jones stressed Labour's dedication to keeping those promises, such as building the M4 relief road and developing the South Wales Metro.
Despite Brexit's uncertainties, Labour’s goal is to boost the economy and improve public services, which are vital for daily life.
On local government reform, Mr. Jones suggested expanded service delivery without confirming council mergers.
Plaid Cymru AM Rhun ap Iorwerth argued the government's program shows the "gulf" between the parties, even with promises tied to Carwyn Jones’s re-election as first minister.
"A lacklustre manifesto has unsurprisingly led to a lacklustre government programme," Mr. ap Iorwerth quipped.
Starting from the 2019-2020 season, the Football League is eyeing a big change by adding a new division with 20 more teams.
This move will bump up the total number of teams to 100 across five divisions, compared to the current 92.
Right now, there are 24 teams each in the Championship, League One, and League Two.
The Football League sees this as a way to ease fixture congestion and boost finances for its clubs.
The Premier League and the FA are on board "in principle.” But before this can happen, they need 90% approval from the 72 Football League clubs at their annual meeting in June 2017.
Shaun Harvey, the Football League's chief executive, told BBC Sport that this plan has "clear benefits for everyone," hinting it could be a game-changer for English football.
Still, not everyone agrees. Accrington’s owner, Andrew Holt, dismissed the idea as having "no merit," while Barry Hearn, former Leyton Orient chairman, thinks there’s potential.
A few club execs are miffed they weren't clued in before the news broke on Thursday.

Even though there's worry about financial difficulties, Harvey believes the benefits are evident, especially with backing from the Premier League and FA due to its "potential benefits on an international basis."
He stressed that a collective effort is needed for the future of English football.
The FA, too, is interested in reshaping the fixture schedule "for the benefit of all" and is keen on more discussions.
Mark Lawn, Bradford City’s joint-chairman, is against altering a structure he argues suits most clubs, pointing out potential revenue losses if teams lose home games.

His team, aiming for the League One play-offs, has concerns over income. On the flip side, Mark Devlin, Brentford’s chief executive, credits the Football League for its "innovative and far-reaching approach," seeing promise in the proposals to tackle league issues.
For anything to happen, 65 clubs out of 72 (90%) must give the nod at next year’s AGM.
The Football League board isn’t pushing a specific action but is urging members to give the proposal some serious thought.
Even after giving away 64 million Microsoft shares—5% of his fortune, still standing strong at $89.9 billion—Bill Gates is the world's wealthiest person.
Since 1994, he and his wife, Melinda, have given away $35 billion in cash and stocks to various charitable causes.
Although they made the donation in June, it only came to light on Monday, thanks to a filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.
Bill Gates now holds just 1.3% of Microsoft. Back in the day, he gave out $16 billion in shares in 1999 and $5.1 billion in 2000.
Most of their donations have bolstered the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, aiming to cut down on global poverty, fight infectious diseases, and make technology accessible all over the world.
It's not clear who got this latest donation, but federal filings often suggest it's a new contribution to a foundation, according to the Chronicle of Philanthropy.
Back in 2010, Bill and Melinda Gates, alongside investor and philanthropist Warren Buffett, kicked off the Giving Pledge.
By May 2017, 158 individuals or couples had signed up to donate at least half of their wealth to charity.
This recent gift from the Gateses is the largest charitable contribution of the year worldwide.
The second largest came from Warren Buffett, who gave nearly $3.2 billion to the Gates Foundation last month.

Michael Dell, the founder of Dell Computer Corporation, and his wife Susan rounded out the top three with a donation of over $1 billion in May to their foundation, focusing on children's issues and community projects.
During her talk at the Code Conference, Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg said they would keep Peter Thiel on the board.
Thiel's been in the spotlight for trying to take on Gawker's so-called "bullying" tactics.
Critics say he's using his wealth to silence parts of the media, which could spell trouble for Facebook.
After all, Facebook's trying to collaborate with media outlets on numerous fronts—hosting articles, exclusive videos, and advertising deals.

Sandberg clarified at the California event, saying, "Peter acted independently, not as a Facebook rep." She also pointed out, "Our board members have distinct opinions, and sharing them publicly strengthens Facebook with their diverse perspectives."
Still, some experts think Thiel's board spot might not be tenable given his as one of Facebook's early backers.
Media consultant Steve Hewlett told the BBC, "Facebook typically sees itself as a tech company but now it's got publisher responsibilities.
