If you view Facebook as a publisher, it's a clear conflict of interest. Imagine a billionaire board member of The Times or the BBC suing others over their publications."
The spat with Gawker dates back to 2007, after Gawker ran a piece titled "Peter Thiel is totally gay, people."
Thiel recently told the New York Times he bankrolled a legal team to back "victims" of Gawker's reports in lawsuits against the site—something he framed as "philanthropic."
One lawsuit led to a $140 million verdict against Gawker for privacy invasion after they published Hulk Hogan’s sex tape.

Gawker’s appealing the decision, but its future hangs by a thread. Nick Denton, who founded Gawker, has pushed back against Thiel’s involvement and raised questions about his role at Facebook, even penning an open letter asking: "As a Facebook board member, have your personal political and news views influenced corporate decisions?"
The plans to ink an agreement between India and Bangladesh on sharing river water hit a snag, thanks to objections from West Bengal's chief minister.
Plus, there wasn't any deal for granting India overland access through Bangladesh to its northeastern states.
On a brighter note, a good number of "stateless border people" found a silver lining.
The two nations decided to proceed with integrating roughly 50 Bangladeshi enclaves in India with Bangladesh and about 100 Indian enclaves in Bangladesh with India.
Folks living in these areas can choose to be citizens of either country, but the finer points still need to be sorted out.

According to Sabir Mustafa, the BBC Bengali editor, the failure to seal the Teesta river water-sharing agreement is a big blow for Bangladesh's PM Sheikh Hasina, who's put a lot on the line to get this deal done.
Mustafa also mentions that, right now, India and Bangladesh have the closest ties since the 1970s when India helped Bangladesh gain independence from Pakistan.
This coziness, however, masks growing discomfort about the relationship's direction.
There are fears that India's leaders might be cosying up too much to Bangladesh's Awami League, which could spell trouble if the opposition party BNP comes to power.
Over in Bangladesh, there’s a bit of worry about Sheikh Hasina's eagerness to cater to India’s demands.

The whole visit lost its edge when India abruptly announced that the major river-sharing agreement was off the table, dampening the excitement of the Indian prime minister's first visit to Bangladesh in 12 years.

They agreed to revisit the water-sharing issue down the road. Prime Minister Singh later remarked that "substantial progress has been made on sharing water of common rivers," but more talks will be necessary.
Most folks believe the deal fell apart because West Bengal's Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee raised last-minute objections, worried that India might be giving Bangladesh too much of the water.
Kepler-452b's orbit puts it at a distance from its star similar to Earth's, but it's got a radius that's 60% bigger than our own planet's.
Scientists are pretty excited about this one because it could potentially have liquid water, which is crucial for life as we know it.
NASA's John Grunsfeld didn't hold back, dubbing the planet "Earth 2.0" and saying it's the closest companion to Earth we've found so far.
Sitting approximately 1,400 light-years away, Kepler-452b was brought to our attention by Jon Jenkins, who heads up Kepler data analysis at NASA's Ames Research Center.
He described it as a "new kid on the block," highlighting its debut among other Earth-like finds such as Kepler-186f, which made waves in 2014.
Kepler-186f, while smaller, orbits a cooler red dwarf. In contrast, Kepler-452b revolves around a star similar to our Sun, just a bit bigger and brighter, by about 4% and 10%, respectively.

With a 385-day orbit, this planet's year exceeds Earth's by just 5%. Although we can't pin down its mass exactly, it's estimated to be around five times that of Earth—if it turns out to be rocky, we might see active volcanism and gravity twice what we're used to.
This exoplanet is part of a batch of 500 potential planets spotted by the Kepler telescope, being the first to be confirmed as a planet.
Among these, twelve have diameters less than twice Earth's and are situated in the habitable zone, hinting they might support liquid water under the right conditions.
Dr. Suzanne Aigrain from the University of Oxford, though not involved in this research, noted that this planet’s traits are the most Earth-like yet confirmed.
She also pointed out the significance of finding these twelve planets within the habitable zone, noting how they bolstered the ever-growing Kepler planet catalog.
An Inverness man, James Nicol, says his old employer is just ignoring him. He worked on council houses back in the 1980s and believes he was exposed to asbestos during that time.

Now, he's asking Highland Council to recognize this exposure. But, when questioned, council reps firmly declined to discuss Mr. Nicol's issue, stating that any claims are dealt with by solicitors, not directly.

At 85 years old, Mr. Nicol remembers his time as a laborer with Highland Regional Council—now known as Highland Council—and insists he came into contact with asbestos while doing refurbishments in Inverness.
He also had a stint as a school janitor for the council. This March, he got some tough news: a diagnosis of mesothelioma, a deadly type of lung cancer that’s nearly always linked to asbestos.
The first signs of trouble showed up during a swim; he realized he couldn't keep his usual pace and decided to see his doctor.
"I could swim, just not at the same speed, so I went to my GP," he told BBC Scotland.
From there, it was on to x-rays, scans, and finally a biopsy in Aberdeen. Raigmore Hospital in Inverness confirmed what he feared: "it was all bad, no cure Mr. Nicol," he recalls being told.

While he still draws a local authority pension, Mr. Nicol insists that Highland Council hasn’t responded to letters from his solicitor about his illness. A council representative reiterated, "We cannot comment on this matter.

Solicitors handle claims against Highland Council, not us directly." Clydeside Action on Asbestos, a charity originally set up in 1984 to help shipyard workers, now extends its support to people across all sorts of jobs, including more and more women.
Phyllis Craig, a senior welfare rights officer and director there, remarked, "We're seeing a lot from construction, plus teachers, nurses, doctors, policemen, and firemen."
She also pointed out a wrong assumption that women encountered asbestos only by washing their husbands' work clothes.

Women in workplaces like hospitals and schools faced risks just like men did. Thanks to some recent legal shifts in Scotland, folks suffering from asbestos exposure, and their families, now have more rights compared to other parts of the UK.
Take Annie McGhee, for example; a former textile factory worker from Motherwell, who might be eligible for a one-time government payment.
In Northern Ireland, it’s another Tuesday, and politics are all over the headlines.
The big talk today? The ongoing political deadlock, which was supposed to be resolved by yesterday at 4 PM—still hasn’t budged an inch.

The Belfast Telegraph isn’t holding back its frustration, suggesting that MLAs should have their paychecks cut off after three months if they can’t hash out an agreement. Did you know their salaries cost taxpayers £13.5 million a year?
It’s on par with the Renewable Heating Incentive mess that threw the power-sharing executive off balance.
Former Assistant Chief Constable Alan McQuillan is sounding the alarm about public anger if the MLAs keep getting paid without actually doing anything.
He’s warning that without a working executive, jobs and public services are on shaky ground.
People aren’t going to be happy if full pay goes to MLAs who aren't getting anything done.
Political commentator Malachi O’Doherty weighs in on Secretary of State James Brokenshire's predicament.
Brokenshire has to figure out a way forward for Northern Ireland while stuck in this mess.

O'Doherty warns that a slip-up could deepen the region's divisions. Meanwhile, the Belfast Telegraph reports on the Glenn family’s painful wait to learn if the body found in the River Foyle is that of missing 23-year-old Jack Glenn, who vanished after a night out on February 2.

Over at the News Letter, the 'Morning View' editorial is taking Sinn Féin to task, accusing them of holding Northern Ireland “to ransom.” They’re wondering just how long London will ignore pressure from Dublin and recognize that it isn’t right for a party opposed by 72% of voters to call the shots.
They argue that while fears of violence loom, London can’t afford to be timid anymore.

And just to make clear, they claim their criticism isn’t sectarian, reminding folks of their independent stance during the RHI scandal. Northern Ireland, they admit, is dealing with yet another governance crisis.
The 23-year-old goalkeeper, on loan from Chelsea, delivered some incredible saves during the penalty shootout that saw the Chairboys eliminate Blackpool from the EFL Trophy back in January.
In that nail-biting match, with just four minutes to go, Blackman again showcased his talent by blocking Brad Potts' penalty to secure a draw.
Early in the game, Adebayo Akinfenwa had the first crack at scoring but sent the ball wide.
Potts kept pressing and tried a speculative shot about midway through the first half, which nicked the crossbar.
Then, right before halftime, Paris Cowan-Hall fired a low shot that was expertly saved by Blackpool's goalie, Dean Lyness.
After the break, Potts made another attempt that was dramatically cleared off the line by Blackman, even as Blackpool insisted it had crossed over.
Blackman's heroics peaked in the dying moments when he fantastically blocked Potts’ close-range effort.
So the match ended in a stalemate: Wycombe Wanderers 0, Blackpool 0. During the second half, Luke O'Nien of Wycombe earned a free kick in defense after getting fouled by Neil Danns of Blackpool.
Michael Harriman from Wycombe committed a foul too, giving Danns a free kick on the right flank.
Wycombe switched up their lineup, bringing Sam Saunders in for Sam Wood. Some more rough play followed, with a Jack Payne foul giving Joe Jacobson a free kick for Wycombe.
Then, Blackpool got a penalty when Max Müller fouled in the box, but Potts' shot was stopped in the bottom right corner.
Another twist came when Jamille Matt was fouled in Wycombe's area. Myles Weston almost shocked everyone with a header that narrowly missed.
Wycombe made another swap, putting Alex Jakubiak in for Paris Cowan-Hall. On the fouling front, Cowan-Hall won a defensive free kick thanks to Tom Aldred’s mistake.

Luke O'Nien ended up with a yellow card for a particularly nasty foul. Blackpool’s defense got a breather with a free kick won by Will Aimson, and they substituted Danns out for Jordan Flores and Matt with Mark Cullen.
Jack Payne had a shot from outside the box, but it didn't find the target. Later, Cowan-Hall won another free kick following a foul by Kelvin Mellor.

Nathan Delfouneso’s shot from the center was blocked. Wycombe decided to bring in Myles Weston for Dayle Southwell, and yellow cards were handed out to Jordan Flores from Blackpool and Wycombe’s Marcus Bean.

Matthew Daley, 35, is in the spotlight for a troubling incident. He denies murdering Donald Lock, 79, but admits to attacking him in Findon, near Worthing, last July, claiming diminished responsibility due to his mental health.
At Lewes Crown Court, surprising revelations emerged: Daley wasn't suffering from Asperger's syndrome as previously thought, but rather undiagnosed paranoid schizophrenia going way back.
Dr. Roderick Ley, a forensic psychiatrist, evaluated Daley after the incident. It turns out, Mr.
Lock, a retired solicitor, was stabbed after a minor accident. His car hit Daley's at around 16 mph after Daley made an abrupt stop on the A24 in West Sussex on July 16.
Unfortunately, Lock, who had been celebrating being cancer-free, died on the spot.
The trial shed light on Daley’s decade-long struggle with mental health, and his family had been pleading with professionals to get him the help he desperately needed.
Dr. Ley told the court, "The Asperger's diagnosis was off. It's been paranoid schizophrenia all along, lurking undiagnosed for years."
Although Daley wasn't always in a psychotic state, he tended to "downplay" what he was experiencing.
He showed traits like being "narcissistic," "histrionic," and "self-centered," which narrowed the chances of a full recovery.
But Dr. Philip Joseph, another forensic psychiatrist, believed Daley wasn't psychotic during the stabbing, judging by all the evidence he reviewed.
Matthew's father, John Daley, also took the stand, painting a picture of his son as a "nice guy" who loves his family, animals, and struggles with lying due to his "scrupulously honest" nature.
Concerns grew when Matthew started hearing voices, so John began keeping a journal of his son's treatment and his own worries for his future.
"I didn't want to be in my 80s, wondering, 'What did I do?'" John shared with the jury. The trial continues.
After a former ombudsman investigator got arrested for allegedly swiping sensitive security papers, there's a pretty big stir.
These documents supposedly contain info that the police and MI5 think could put lives at risk.
The Police Federation of Northern Ireland (PFNI) called it "astounding and very worrying."
Over the weekend, detectives from the PSNI’s Serious Crime Branch nabbed a 69-year-old man in Dartford, Kent, following a joint search with the local police.
Apparently, he retired from the ombudsman's office years ago, and the documents aren’t linked to any current probes.
Mark Lindsay, the PFNI chair, pointed out the importance of fair investigations for police officers during a chat on BBC's Good Morning Ulster.
He said, "Police officers deserve the same protections as anyone else, protections that are currently missing in the ombudsman's office."
He emphasized that while the Police Ombudsman's office is crucial, it must earn and keep police officers' trust.
Now, the police have kicked off a criminal investigation and put a hold on sharing more sensitive materials with the ombudsman’s office while they review security procedures.

Ulster Unionist MP Tom Elliott argued that the ombudsman's office has some serious explaining to do, insisting, "When there’s alleged wrongdoing, the PSNI should step in earlier for independent checks," as he told the BBC, mentioning a gap in the process.
The ombudsman's office, speaking to the BBC, said they were informed by the police about last week's theft of sensitive documents. They're hoping the pause in material sharing is just temporary.
Fans finally got the happy ending they’d been hoping for, with Miranda Hart's lead character walking down the aisle.
The New Year's Day episode pulled in 7.3 million viewers, going by overnight figures.
Meanwhile, the first part of the finale on Christmas Day attracted 6.7 million viewers.
Neela Debnath from The Independent called the ending "sweet and heart-warming," highlighting its unexpectedly moving and tender moments amidst the comedy mishaps.
This final episode saw Miranda dealing with her mother and embracing her true self.
Gerard O'Donovan of The Telegraph noted: "New Year's Day delivered all the humor and joy we could have wanted in a masterclass of romantic comedy writing and performance, wrapping up with a wedding."
Mark Lawson in The Guardian observed, "As the fans wished, Miranda had two classic falls in her comedic farewell.
Her promising career, beyond this inventive and well-acted sitcom, suggests she won't be failing, metaphorically speaking, anytime soon."
Before the final episode aired, Hart tweeted: "Happy New Year Day and farewell to my creative baby day.
8pm BBC One. No guarantees, but you MIGHT spot @GaryBarlow." The show started out on BBC Two in 2009, later moving to BBC One.
It revolves around Hart’s character, a clumsy shop owner. Patricia Hodge plays her mother, and Sarah Hadland is the assistant manager.
The series and Hart herself have won accolades from the Royal Television Society and the British Comedy Awards.
The first episode of the third series was the most-watched TV program during Christmas 2012.
Hart, now 41, is set to star alongside Jude Law and Melissa McCarthy in the American comedy "Spy," directed by Paul Feig of "Bridesmaids" fame, slated for a UK release this May.
Plus, she’ll be releasing "Peggy And Me," an autobiographical book about her life with her dog Peggy, sometime this year.
Back in the 2013/14 academic year, further education colleges were bustling with 99,293 students.
Fast forward to 2015/16, and that number fell to 82,818, as per the Department for the Economy (DfE).
During those years, enrolments in FE colleges also took a hit, dropping by 15%, largely because some students enroll in more than one course.
If we get into the specifics, there were 180,825 enrolments in 2013/14, which slid down to 153,817 by 2015/16.
Belfast Metropolitan College (BMC) was hit particularly hard, experiencing a steep drop from 36,685 enrolments in 2014/15 to just 28,514 in 2015/16—a drop of 22.3%.

When asked about this sharp decline, BMC stayed mum. Fergal McFerran, President of NUS-USI, didn't hold back, calling the trend a "staggering drop" and urging the executive to ramp up funding for tertiary education and student financial aid in the next budget.
Meanwhile, South Eastern Regional College managed to fare a bit better, seeing its enrolments decrease by a relatively modest 8.3%, moving from 35,832 in 2013/14 to 32,858 in 2015/16.

FE colleges are known for their variety of courses suited to different learners, but insiders told the BBC that tighter budgets have forced cutbacks on courses and staff, which could be pushing down enrolment numbers.
In 2015/16, more than 400 folks in staff roles were offered voluntary redundancy packages.
Leisure and non-regulated courses also took a hit, particularly affecting lifelong learners.

DfE figures show these enrolments dropping from 39,000 in 2013/14 to roughly 24,500 in 2015/16—a result of DfE's "Further Education Means Business" strategy, which focuses on courses boosting economic growth.
Gerry Campbell, who heads Colleges NI, spoke on the key role further education plays in Northern Ireland's economic future.
Despite fewer residential and leisure courses, he pointed out that colleges are pushing to provide courses with economic relevance.
This shift comes alongside a confirmed £10 million budget cut for FE colleges by the Department of the Economy for 2015/16.
Tony Bellew, the WBC cruiserweight champ at 34, pulled off a shocker last month by stopping David Haye in a heavyweight showdown.
But when folks asked him about taking on Anthony Joshua, the reigning WBA and IBF champ, Bellew didn't hesitate: "Absolutely not.
I don't need that kind of fight. He's far too good for me." His promoter, Eddie Hearn, tossed out the idea of Bellew squaring off next with WBO champ Joseph Parker.
Parker, a 25-year-old from New Zealand, is gearing up to defend his title against Romanian Razvan Cojanu in Auckland next weekend.
Bellew reflected on Joshua's thrilling 11th-round win over Wladimir Klitschko with a touch of longing, "I still dream about winning a heavyweight world title, but a different one than AJ has."
After his unexpected triumph over Haye—a rather sensational heavyweight debut for the Liverpudlian—Bellew’s thoughts have wandered towards retirement.
Yet, when banter turned to facing Parker, Bellew remarked, "I trust Eddie knows what he's doing."
Hearn confirmed there's no Bellew-Joshua clash on the horizon, casually noting on BBC Radio 5 live's Sportsweek that "Tony and Joshua are good friends."
Now, Bellew, who used to roll in the cruiserweight category, isn't quite a natural at heavyweight.
He moved up just to tackle David Haye in March and clocked in at 96.6 kg for that bout.
Meanwhile, Joshua bulked up to a career-high 113 kg against Klitschko—a solid 20 kg heavier.
Bellew's gaze partly rests on WBC heavyweight champ Deontay Wilder. Wilder's itching for a unification fight with Joshua if he snags the WBO belt from Parker.
"I plan to secure the WBO belt, and after dealing with any mandatory challengers, aim for a major fight early in 2018," Wilder declared with determination.
After Jahangir, an Afghan father, shared his ordeal with the BBC, he got an unexpected call from President Ashraf Ghani.
The president promised arrests would be made. Jahangir’s story began eight years ago when his wife was reportedly raped in Badakhshan province.
He’s been struggling to have those accused brought to justice because they've got some serious political connections.

His wife recalled the horrible experience to BBC Persian, saying, "I pleaded with them, ‘For God's sake, I've just given birth; I’m like a child to you, even your daughter is older than me.’ They beat me badly, and I still carry their bite marks even after all these years."
Inayatulhaq Yasini, from BBC Pashto, explains the significance of their choice to speak out, addressing a taboo in Afghanistan where victims of sexual abuse often remain silent.
President Ghani, following the media coverage, promised Jahangir the case would be thoroughly investigated.
Jahangir's wife told the BBC, "I want justice, so other women don’t suffer like I did."
This added spotlight is pushing the Afghan government to take action and sort things out.
The courage shown by Jahangir and his wife might inspire other victims to share their stories and change how such cases are dealt with.
Jahangir, who works as a policeman, mentioned to the BBC that although eight men were arrested initially, six walked free thanks to their political influence.

His family, now in Kabul for safety, faces a tough situation. Jahangir even threatened suicide if things don’t improve: "If they’re not put on trial, I’ll have to end my life to escape this suffering."
He made this threat publicly on Afghan TV and later met with officials from the interior ministry, pleading for justice.
During a BBC interview, he got another call from President Ghani, which moved him to tears.
Sworn in as president in September, Ghani has promised to tackle corruption head-on.
Though corruption and violence against women are rampant, they usually don’t get much attention.
But there was a turning point last October when the nation was outraged after five men, convicted of gang-raping four women, were executed.
Sterling managed to claw back some of its earlier losses, but there's widespread speculation that the currency could falter if Britain opts to leave the EU.
Many analysts foresee a significant plunge in sterling's value with a Brexit vote.
This worry comes from the general belief among economists—though opinions vary—that leaving the EU would hurt the UK's economy.
Membership in the EU plays a vital role in shaping trade and the broader economic landscape in the UK.
With new deals on the table, uncertainty looms over whether British exporters will retain easy access to EU markets, possibly throwing a wrench in selling goods there.

On top of that, foreign investment might take a hit due to this uncertainty, worsening matters given the UK's sizeable current account deficit, which covers trade in goods and services, plus some financial transactions internationally.
This deficit gets funded via loans and foreign investments in financial assets, and jittery investors might prefer lower sterling prices to fund it.
Of course, there's a counter-argument from groups like Economists for Brexit, who suggest the UK could flourish outside the EU.
But for now, the short-term buzz in markets, particularly concerning sterling, seems rooted in what's considered the mainstream view.
When we talk about currency market reports, the focus is often on spot rates—those immediate exchange rates where currency buys happen.
Investors have another tool: options, which allow them to buy or sell currency (or other financial assets) later on at a set price.
So, come what may, options work like insurance against currency rate swings. If rates don't move as predicted, the option goes unused, which means insurance costs without action.
Smart money in this segment of the market indicates investors expect a leave vote would weaken sterling.
Neil Trotter admitted to sneaking photos of women at Edinburgh's Waverley Station and Glasgow's Buchanan Galleries between June and September 2014.
The 54-year-old from Falkirk got quite the earful from the sheriff, who reminded him that "women should be able to walk without fear" in public spaces.
As a consequence, Trotter's name will remain on the sex offenders register for 10 years.
During a previous hearing at Edinburgh Sheriff Court, it was revealed that Trotter commuted daily to Edinburgh for work by train.
On September 29, a fellow passenger noticed him acting in "a curious, a sinister manner" at Waverley Station, getting unusually close to a woman ahead of him on the escalator.
Prosecutor Aidan Higgins described how Trotter was caught using his phone to discreetly snap photos up the woman's skirt.
This suspicious behavior was reported to British Transport Police, who identified Trotter thanks to CCTV footage.

He was arrested the following day as he exited the station. A thorough examination of Trotter's phone and computer uncovered 22 videos taken from June 11 to September 29, all capturing images under women's skirts.
Defense solicitor Neil Hay said that Trotter was "most ashamed of his actions" and realized how unacceptable his behavior was.
Hay added that Trotter had "lost his career, nearly bankrupted his family, and brought shame upon himself and those close to him."
Sheriff Peter Braid sentenced him to 18 months in prison, saying, "You've pleaded guilty to taking images of women secretly, driven by voyeuristic impulses for sexual gratification.
The fact that this continued for over three months, in public places where women should feel safe, involved significant planning.
The societal outrage against such offenses calls for no other solution but a custodial sentence, as both punishment and deterrence."

Media playback isn’t supported on this device. Mark Cavendish, famed for winning 30 stage victories in the Tour de France, began his pursuit with a sixth-place finish in the scratch race, the first of six events.
He clocked the second-fastest time in the individual pursuit and snagged seventh in the elimination race, with three more challenges lined up for Monday.
Becky James made waves by breaking the women's sprint Olympic record during the qualifiers.
Scheduled for Monday’s quarter-finals, she’ll be joined by fellow Brit Katy Marchant.

At 31, Cavendish opened his campaign with a tough sixth in the scratch race. Denmark’s Lasse Norman Hansen, the Olympic champ from London 2012, and Roger Kluge grabbed the top two spots by gaining a lap advantage over everyone else.
Cavendish's pursuit time of 4:16.878 initially put him ahead of Colombian Fernando Gaviria Rendon, the reigning world champ.
Yet Hansen went on to set a jaw-dropping new Olympic record with 4:14.982, topping Sir Bradley Wiggins' record from 2008.
Although Hansen claimed victory in consecutive events, he slid to sixth overall after being the first to go out in the elimination race, a format where the last rider every second lap is cut.
Cavendish held steady while others dropped out but was hit with a disqualification for overtaking outside the track lane, finishing seventh as a result.
France's Thomas Boudat, the 2014 world champ, leads with 106 points, just edging out Italy’s Elia Viviani by two points, who won the elimination round.
Cavendish finds himself in third place with 96 points. Monday’s events kick off with the time trial at 14:21 BST, followed by the flying lap and points race.
Wales’ Becky James, fresh off a silver in Saturday's keirin, continued her stellar form by setting a new Olympic record during the sprint qualifiers.
Her time of 10.721 seconds edged out Victoria Pendleton's 2012 London record of 10.724, making her the top qualifier.
She swiftly outpaced Azerbaijan's Olga Ismayilova by 0.165 seconds to roll into Monday’s quarter-finals, starting at 14:00 BST.
Marchant also moved ahead by defeating Canada’s Monique Sullivan after securing the second-fastest qualifying time.
Australia’s reigning champ, Anna Meares, was beaten by Lithuania’s Simona Krupeckaite but fought back to earn a spot in the final eight via a repechage race.
Media playback is not supported on this device. For the latest scoop, subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter for a roundup of news, features, and videos delivered straight to your inbox.
At the core of the media’s irritation is the tightly controlled, almost choreographed nature of today's political campaigns.

They're packed with perfectly staged photo ops from all major parties. This election season feels like it should be called the "hi-vis, hard hat campaign," especially with folks like David Cameron and George Osborne steering clear of unscripted interactions with the public to dodge any curveballs voters might throw their way.
But hey, there’s a silver lining—a chance to glimpse some real, unvarnished politics: the election hustings.

These events have been a big hit this general election season. The term 'hustings' might stir some curiosity, and it turns out, a Christian charity’s research shows a record number of these have taken place in churches.
I’ve been to a few hustings myself, and their strength lies in the raw, straightforward nature of the debates.
You’ve got voters directly grilling politicians, slicing right through the usual campaign rhetoric to confront issues often left in the shadows.
This was crystal clear at a hustings held at All Nations for Christ Church in Normanton, part of the Derby South constituency.

The audience was predominantly from the African Caribbean community. Politicians from various parties, including Dame Margaret Beckett, there to defend her Labour majority of 6,000 votes, faced questions on pressing topics like immigration, Europe, and education.
One particular question that really hit home was: Why are African Caribbean graduates three times more likely to be unemployed six months after graduating?

Research conducted by the Bow Group think-tank and Elevation Networks, a charity focused on youth employment, studied 2,500 students over two years and uncovered glaring differences in job opportunities for black students compared to their white peers.
An audience member, clearly angry, declared, "That's outrageous and disgraceful," which got a nod of approval from the Green Party.
Green candidate John Devine, who’s running in Derbyshire's Amber Valley, chimed in, "That shows there’s discrimination in the job market."
There were calls for legislation to make sure employers audit their hiring practices.

This complicated issue needed a thoughtful approach, but Evonne Williams, the Conservative candidate for Derby South, hesitated to offer a solid plan, saying, "It's something we haven't considered, but I'm happy to take it back to the party."
As for Labour’s Dame Margaret, she pledged to look over the Equalities Act to see if it needs a makeover.
David Cameron said that building a stadium could "inspire young people and bring jobs and wealth" to the county.
Labour, however, slammed this as a "cynical" move to sway voters, while the Liberal Democrats questioned how it would be funded, and Mebyon Kernow was skeptical about the Conservatives' promise.

A tangle of planning issues has thrown the stadium's future into uncertainty. Back in March, Cornwall council members delayed their decision on approving the construction of a supermarket meant to fund the stadium, putting the whole plan at risk, according to supporters.
Now, revised plans for the stadium at West Langarth are expected to go before the council in May.
Cameron said he plans to get the Department of Culture, Media and Sport to team up with Sport England, Cornwall Council, and local sports teams to push this project forward.
"The stadium proposal is exciting. If we need extra funding, I'll make sure we get it," he said. Stuart Roden, the Labour candidate for Truro and Falmouth, wasn't buying it.
He dismissed Cameron's announcement as "a cynical empty promise that will lead nowhere.
It’s just smoke and mirrors, and voters won't fall for this unfunded diversion."
Simon Rix, the Lib Dem candidate for the area, told BBC News: "I’d love to see a stadium in the right place if we can lock down the funding.
But just like their promises on the NHS, Conservatives aren’t saying where the money will come from."
Stephen Richardson, Mebyon Kernow's candidate for Truro and Falmouth, voiced his doubts too, saying, "Forgive me if I don't believe a word of any David Cameron promise during the election campaign."
For more details on the constituency and a full list of candidates, click here.
Calls are mounting for Douglas Ross to step down as the party's justice spokesperson after he skipped a justice committee meeting in the Scottish Parliament.
Instead, he was busy officiating a football match between Sporting Lisbon and Real Madrid as an assistant referee on that Tuesday.
According to his register of interests, Ross pulls in up to £40,000 annually as a self-employed assistant football referee.
On top of that, he's also a councillor for Moray Council. His trip to Portugal meant he missed a policy and resources committee meeting the same day.
SNP MSP Ben Macpherson wasn’t quiet about it, pointing out that this isn't the first time Ross's refereeing has disrupted his parliamentary work.
Apparently, he even missed a crucial vote because he was in Switzerland for World Cup referee training.
Macpherson didn’t mince words: "The arrogance and blatant disregard of 'three jobs' Tory Douglas Ross is astounding.
Previously, when he skipped responsibilities for refereeing commitments, it was dismissed as a 'one-off' by the Tories.
Now it merits a straight red card. He clearly values his £40k-a-year weekend job and trips to European cities more than his legislative and council duties, showing contempt for his constituents.
If Douglas Ross can't commit to his roles, he should either step back from refereeing or immediately resign from Holyrood's justice committee.

Ruth Davidson should remove him from the frontbench team." Meanwhile, a spokesperson for the Scottish Conservatives fired back: "Earlier this year, Ben Macpherson invited Douglas to discuss refereeing with clubs in his constituency—presumably, that invitation has been withdrawn." As for Ross, he opted not to comment on the situation.
Jamie Robinson, a medical researcher, shared a troubling experience on BBC's World Have Your Say programme.
He talked about how train staff locked themselves in a service room, leaving passengers to fend for themselves.
This unsettling account aligns with what French actor Jean-Hugues Anglade described — being pinned against a metal door, pleading for help that never came.
The incident unfolded on a Friday aboard a high-speed train going from Amsterdam to Paris.

Trouble seemed to begin right after the Thalys train zipped through Brussels. Robinson saw three train crew members rush through his coach, carriage 11, which was next to carriage 12 where the gunman showed up.

"They didn’t say a word. There was a man chased by two women," he recalls. "They looked scared, didn’t warn us, just hurried to the end of my carriage, got inside a service door, and locked it tight."
Carriage 11 was at the train's front, leading to a restricted area. Chaos erupted as folks fled carriage 12, some hurt, others warning the gunman was shooting.
"We were stuck, roughly 20 to 30 of us, including Jean-Hugues Anglade and his family.

We were in the dark about what was happening," Robinson says. Anglade, whose hand got injured trying to trigger the train’s alarm, shared how staff hid in a private cabin when they might have steered passengers to a safer spot near the luggage.
He told Paris Match (in French), "We shouted for the staff to let us in, we begged 'open!'
but silence was all we got." Agnes Ogier, the CEO of Thalys, stated there’d be an internal investigation, and the staff would need to explain their actions during this dramatic event.
Robinson recalls after 10 tense minutes, a man came into their carriage telling them the attacker was subdued, a massive relief.
This man, it turns out, was Anthony Sadler, one of the heroic Americans who helped tackle the gunman.
Robinson describes the wave of relief that swept through, leaving passengers in shock and disbelief.
They stayed quiet and still until reaching Arras station, where Ayoub El-Khazzani, a 25-year-old Moroccan suspect, was detained.
Mr. Abe recounted his 90-minute meeting at Trump Tower, describing it as "candid" and taking place in a "warm atmosphere."
During Trump's campaign, some of his comments put longstanding U.S. alliances, including the one with Japan, under the spotlight.
This was Trump's first in-person meeting with a world leader since clinching the election.
The relationship between the U.S. and Japan has been a key alliance since World War II, with the U.S. playing a pivotal role in Japan's economic recovery.
Trump plans to scrap the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, a move at odds with Mr. Abe, who backs the TPP as a way to counter China's growing economic power.
Though the deal is likely off the table once Trump takes office, it had already cleared Japan's parliament.

Trump has also floated the idea that Japan should foot more of the bill for the U.S. military presence there and suggested Japan and South Korea might need to develop their own nuclear arsenals to manage North Korea's missile threats.
The meeting came together after Mr. Abe called the president-elect to congratulate him, mentioning his upcoming stop in New York on the way to an Asia-Pacific trade summit in Peru.
Afterward, Mr. Abe remarked, "We had a very candid discussion over a significant period and in a very warm atmosphere.
I believe that without mutual confidence, the alliance cannot function in the future.
Following today's discussion, I'm convinced Mr. Trump is a leader in whom I can place great trust."
Although Mr. Abe was sparse with details, he did mention they planned to meet again for deeper talks on various issues.
Also attending the meeting were Trump's daughter Ivanka and her husband Jared Kushner, who have become key advisers.
There’s some buzz in the media about Ivanka possibly becoming ambassador to Japan.
Since his election, Trump has been busy at his Manhattan offices, meeting with world leaders and potential cabinet members.
Meanwhile, Vice President-elect Mike Pence, leading the transition team, expressed a desire to work with Democrats.
After meetings with Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer and House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, Pence spoke of his eagerness to find common ground to move the country forward.
At the same time, President Barack Obama advised his successor to stand firm against Russia if it veers away from U.S. "values and international norms."

Albania grabbed a solid win, kicking off with a Kamo Hovhannisyan own goal. Then, Ledian Memushaj curled in a sublime free-kick to double the score before Armando Sadiku clinched the third with a simple finish.
This victory bumps Albania ahead of Denmark in Group I, nabbing second place. Meanwhile, Portugal cruised past Serbia 2-1.
Serbia faced drama, having two players sent off: Aleksandar Kolarov, from Manchester City, picked up two yellows, and Nemanja Matic of Chelsea saw red for a clash with Portugal’s Andre Andre.
Portugal, already settled as group champions, opted to rest Cristiano Ronaldo in their Serbia game.
Instead, Luis Nani, once Ronaldo’s teammate at Manchester United, quickly netted one with his left foot.

Serbia fought back, as Zoran Tosic smashed in an equalizer in the second half. But it was Joao Moutinho who stepped up from the bench to ensure Portugal's victory, striking one home from the edge of the box just 12 minutes shy of full-time.
With Denmark now stuck in third, they're headed for a play-off to try for France next summer.
The match wrapped with Armenia 0, Albania 3. In the second half, Armenia’s Aras Özbiliz drew a foul from Burim Kukeli and earned a free kick.
Armando Sadiku had his chance following Varazdat Haroyan's foul. After a brief halt because Odise Roshi got hurt, things picked up again.
Shkelzen Gashi was denied by the keeper, and Özbiliz’s free-kick attempt went astray.
Albania swapped Migjen Basha for Amir Abrashi. Armenia's Karlen Mkrtchyan snagged a free kick after Sadiku fouled.
A through ball from Varazdat Haroyan aimed for Vardan Pogosyan found him offside.
Gael Andonian got a booking for a nasty tackle, while Migjen Basha also saw yellow for a foul on Gevorg Ghazaryan.
Artur Sarkisov took a free kick on the right wing post-foul from Taulant Xhaka. Goal!
On the surface of the Khumbu Glacier, nestled in the mighty Himalayas, ponds have been spreading out and combining to form larger water bodies.
Climbers tackling the daunting task of ascending this imposing peak have to navigate this glacier, including the treacherous Khumbu Icefall.
The glaciers in the region are melting quickly, sparking concern as global temperatures climb.
Scientists have pointed out that Khumbu's situation is relatively unique, though it's not alone—other Himalayan glaciers are also experiencing a rise in new lake formation.
These lakes are dangerous; they can overflow unexpectedly, resulting in downstream floods, destruction, and even loss of life.
This marks the first scientific expedition to the area since last April's devastating earthquake.

"About ten years back, the Khumbu Glacier had only scattered ponds, but over the last five years, they’ve started to grow and connect," explained Ann Rowan, who led research from the universities of Sheffield and Leeds.
Dr. Rowan’s team dives into studying glaciers hidden under debris, with particular attention on Khumbu.
"Interestingly, on the left side of the glacier’s lower bit, there are around seven or eight big ponds now joining up and forming a sort of chain," she revealed to the BBC.
"Water from the glacier’s upper regions is passing through these ponds, nudging them to link up.
Right now, the glacier seems like it's breaking apart and might end up with some pretty big and risky lakes on its surface."
Dr. Rowan’s crew pored over 15 years' worth of satellite images of Khumbu and completed three ground surveys since 2009.
Their findings brought to light that sections of the lower debris-covered part are dwindling because of ice loss beneath, helping these water bodies form and spread.
The study shows Khumbu's surface has been sinking at roughly two meters a year over the past 15 years.
Unlike the typically sleek glaciers found elsewhere, many in the Himalayas wear blankets of sand, gravel, and rocks.
Researchers mention that climbing temperatures are causing ice loss in many Himalayan glaciers' upper areas, reducing ice flow to the lower sections and causing them to shrink.
At Sheffield Crown Court, a woman recounted a harrowing experience from when she was just 12 years old.
She described how Basharat Hussain and two other men picked her up from a children's home and subjected her to abuse.
Her testimony included an account of being taken to Blackpool, where several men raped her.
Hussain, denying these claims, is one of seven individuals on trial for suspected child abuse in Rotherham.
Given the case's sensitive nature, the woman's identity remains confidential. She shared how the initial abuse began after Hussain and a group of Asian men took her and a friend out to dinner.
"I felt really grown-up," she admitted. "They treated us to a meal, and I didn't even think to say no."
She also revealed that when she was 16, she was taken to Blackpool to work at a restaurant, an arrangement prosecutors say Hussain orchestrated.
She claimed she was held there for months, forced to have sex nearly every day, and eventually returned to Rotherham with several sexually transmitted infections.

The defendants in this case face serious charges: Arshid Hussain, 40, from High Street, East Cowick, Goole, faces 30 charges, including five counts of rape; Qurban Ali, 53, of Clough Road, Rotherham, faces four charges, including rape and conspiracy to rape; Majid Bostan, 37, from Ledsham Road, Rotherham, is charged with indecent assault; Sajid Bostan, 38, of Broom Avenue, Rotherham, faces seven charges, including four counts of rape; Basharat Hussain, 39, with no fixed address, faces 15 charges, including two counts of rape; Karen MacGregor, 58, of Barnsley Road, Wath, South Yorkshire, faces four charges, including conspiracy to rape; and Shelley Davies, 40, of Wainwright Road, Kimberworth Park, Rotherham, faces three charges, including conspiracy to rape.
During cross-examination, Gillian Batts, defending Mr. Hussain, challenged the witness, asking, "The truth is you've never met Basharat Hussain, have you?"

The witness firmly replied, "Yes, I have." The allegations suggest Mr. Hussain was part of a group engaged in the sexual exploitation of children from 1987 to 2003, reportedly targeting, grooming, and subjecting them to degrading and violent acts. The trial is still in progress.
The Home Office put the brakes on the Detained Fast Track (DFT) system due to concerns it wasn't offering enough protection, especially for "vulnerable applicants."
Immigration Minister James Brokenshire mentioned he was hopeful the system would be back on track in a few weeks.
This halt affects about 800 people, allowing them to apply for bail, with approximately 100 possibly needing to be released from detention.
Since its start in 2000, the DFT system was supposed to speed up the legal proceedings for straightforward cases while keeping the applicants in detention.
However, the Court of Appeal ordered its immediate suspension last month after a High Court ruling pointed out "structural unfairness."

On June 12, Mr. Justice Nicol had initially placed a "legal stay" (a temporary pause) on this ruling after a challenge from the campaign group Detention Action, allowing the system to keep running while appeals were pursued.
BBC's home affairs correspondent, Danny Shaw, mentioned there were worries among officials about how solid their procedures really were.
Speaking in the House of Commons, Mr. Brokenshire admitted the system was battling "significant legal challenge."

He noted risks in protecting vulnerable applicants and decided to pause the policy temporarily, hoping it wouldn't last more than a few weeks. The idea is to have better safeguards set up to avoid unfairness.
During this pause, detained asylum seekers waiting for hearings will be reassessed at a higher level to decide if they should be released to continue their applications normally.

Mr. Brokenshire pointed out that those who meet general detention criteria wouldn't be directly affected by this suspension, as they're often held for reasons like the risk of running off or soon-to-happen deportation. Only those for whom detention can't be justified without DFT will be released.

He also mentioned that people up for removal to a safe third country or those who pose a public risk, including foreign offenders, will still remain detained. Back in 2013, the DFT system fast-tracked about 4,300 asylum cases.

The president-elect recently shared that Mrs. Trump and their son Barron are planning to move to Washington "very soon, after he's finished with school," though they haven't pinned down an exact date yet.

Transition spokesman Jason Miller stressed the family's excitement about their future roles but explained the move was postponed to avoid pulling Barron out of school mid-year. Still, social media users didn't hold back with criticism.
One tweet from Pamela Benbow read, "The First Family living in the White House is symbolic for us and for the world.

Melania Trump's decision is shocking." Some folks made light of the situation, teasing that maybe Mrs. Trump's taste in decor had something to do with it, while others speculated about the impact on the Trumps' marriage.

It's not too surprising that people had strong opinions; only two First Ladies before her never lived in the White House: Martha Washington, because it wasn't built, and Anna Harrison, whose husband died before her move.
Yet, Mrs. Trump does have supporters. One Twitter user remarked, "Good, that's what most responsible parents do with a child Barron's age."
This aligns well with Mrs. Trump's history of prioritizing Barron, as she stayed at Trump Tower throughout the campaign to be there for him.
Their situation isn't unheard of; many mothers and kids have adjusted to life in the White House.

William Seale, a White House historian and author, mentioned that Frances Folsom Cleveland, Grover Cleveland's wife, only lived in the White House during the social season, spending most of her time at a private residence dubbed "Oak View" or "Red Top" because of its red roof.
This was the home for the young bride who was the first and only First Lady married in the White House at age 21, while the president was 49.
Seale noted, "It's totally normal for kids to finish their school year first. Honestly, I don't find it surprising at all."
He also pointed out that when President John Tyler took over after President William Henry Harrison's death, his children didn't make the immediate move to the White House either.
Gordon Strachan's squad faced another setback, losing their second match in four games, which has folks wondering about Strachan's future at the helm.
Former Scotland striker Steven Thompson gave his take, rating their performance, but it's not looking good.
The goalie? Not much he could do about the goals, spent most of his time getting the ball from the net.
The Derby winger, unexpectedly picked, held his ground on defense even while out of position.
Back in action after quite the hiatus, Scotland's standout player was a real menace up front and put in an all-out effort.
He looked sharper than he did in Slovakia, though he had some hard luck with the first goal despite a solid block.
Blew a great chance to level the score, missing a free header that really should've been on target.
One of the players, starting rarer than usual, kept England's threats at bay for a good stretch.
The captain? Full of grit and hustle, though he had a habit of losing the ball.

He’d just come out of retirement—how many more games can he commit to? The Celtic captain added the usual energy and aggression to the middle of the park, but he didn’t see enough of the ball to change much.
Surprisingly chosen despite limited appearances at West Brom, he botched a clear shot early in the second half, sending it wide.
Another player—a bit too fond of giving the ball away—managed to deliver some dangerous set-pieces.
He should have scored after Forrest's miss with a wide-open chance. In the first half, one player led with energy but then made a poor call by not passing to Snodgrass in a promising counter-attack.
As the game wore on, he tired out, and Scotland fell apart. Subbed in during the dying moments, another had no real chance to sway the result.
The one who replaced Anya after his injury couldn’t do much; England hogged the ball and dulled any threats. He came on too late to really get involved.
The government shutdown, the first one we've seen in 17 years, has left over 700,000 employees on unpaid leave since October 1.
National parks, tourist sites, and even government websites and office buildings have shut down.
Despite all this, the country's 1.4 million active-duty military members continue to fulfill their duties.
However, almost half of the Defense Department's 800,000 civilian workers had to stop working when the shutdown kicked off—unless they're involved in "national security" work.
By October 5, though, the department announced it would bring back most of these employees.
According to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, this move was based on the Pay Our Military Act, which Congress passed just before the shutdown hit.
The law allows employees supporting the "morale, well-being, capabilities, and readiness" of service members to dodge furloughs.
Hagel mentioned, "I expect us to significantly reduce—but not eliminate—civilian furloughs under this process."
Meanwhile, the Department of Energy can keep its operations going for a bit without sending everybody home, but they've got plans in place just in case the shutdown drags on.
If that happens, some facilities will close down, and only a small slice of staff—about 1,113 out of 13,814—will stick around.
Those excused from furlough include folks overseeing the safety of our nuclear arsenal and running power infrastructure.
Over at the National Nuclear Security Administration, which handles nuclear weapons and naval reactors, 343 employees will focus on safety and property protection.

More than 400 people will stay at the Southwestern and Western Area Power Administrations to manage hydroelectric power and power lines across the southern and western parts of the U.S. A few employees from other departments are also sticking around to safeguard "human life and property."

Even with most department staff furloughed, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is still operational, offering critical public safety services like weather forecasts and shipping updates.
Some workers at the Bureau of Industry and Security are staying on the job to review exports.
Essential transportation roles are still active, including air traffic control and inspections at airports and for hazardous materials—with 36,987 out of 55,468 personnel working.

Staff involved with commercial space launches are also pressing on. Meanwhile, they're putting a hold on things like facility security inspections, routine security background checks, and employee drug testing programs.
Pre-tax profit took a pretty big hit, dropping 49.7% to £27.7 million for the first half of the year ending June 30th.
The company focused on boosting its operations during this time, which means the financial numbers aren't exactly shining at the moment.
According to Ladbrokes CEO Richard Glynn, though, the firm is poised for growth and showing notable progress.
"We've got the products, platforms, people, and brand lined up for success," he said.
Last year, Ladbrokes joined forces with software developer Playtech to shift its gaming products onto a new system.

This change was more disruptive than they had hoped, but now it's all sorted. They've also upgraded 9,000 gaming machines to better models and closed 46 shops that weren't performing well, almost hitting their target of 50 closures for the year.
Ladbrokes mentioned there will be more closures, but they're not sure exactly when or where just yet.
In the UK, the firm faced setbacks due to “industry-wide, customer-friendly results” from January's football matches and June's horse racing events.

On top of that, following the Association of British Bookmakers' (ABB) voluntary industry code aimed at promoting responsible gambling dented revenues, since it allows players to set personal limits on spending and time on the gaming machines.
Still, they had a strong showing during the World Cup, with mobile bets soaring 1,100%.
"The board is confident about the business's future and aims to meet their performance expectations for the year," the statement wrapped up, and Ladbrokes shares saw a 3% bump in early trading.
Nick Batram, an analyst at Peel Hunt, pointed out that the profit dip wasn't really a surprise.
"The results might not be stellar, but they fit within what's expected. It's good to see Ladbrokes tackling key issues," he added.
The new £5 polymer note, slightly downsized from the old paper version, is starting to roll out in branches across Scotland before hitting a wider release.
It still proudly features Sir Walter Scott and The Mound on one side and keeps the bridge motif on the flip side.
While the old paper £5 notes from the Bank of Scotland are being phased out, they’re still good at shops, banks, and ATMs for now.

Looking ahead, the Bank plans to introduce a polymer £10 note next year. The new plastic notes are touted to be cleaner and tougher, handling crumples and spills much better than their paper counterparts.
Back in September, the Bank of England launched its first £5 polymer note with Winston Churchill, although other parts of the UK have already made the switch to plastic.
These polymer notes are made from a thin, transparent film printed with special ink layers, featuring see-through areas like tiny windows.
Over 20 countries, including Scotland, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada, are already on board with polymer currency.

Just last year, the Clydesdale Bank made waves with the UK’s first fully plastic note—a limited edition £5 commemorative piece that just entered full circulation and is here to replace the paper ones.
This note celebrates Scottish engineering legend Sir William Arrol, showcasing the Forth Bridge and the Titan Crane, with more images of the Forth Bridge on the back.
Meanwhile, the Royal Bank of Scotland is gearing up to release its own £5 polymer note on October 27, featuring Scottish writer Nan Shepherd.
Next year, they're introducing a £10 polymer note with scientist Mary Somerville, marking their debut as the first women to grace the main issue notes.
Shasta County Sheriff Tom Bosenko highlighted that the injuries Sherri Papini suffered carried more than just physical pain—they sent a message.
Sherri, a 34-year-old mom of two, went through "repeated beatings," according to her husband, Keith Papini.
On Wednesday, authorities announced they're looking for two Hispanic women who were last seen driving a dark SUV.
Early last Thursday, Sherri was discovered on a highway about 140 miles from her home in northern California, with a bag over her head, and chained at the waist and wrists.
She had been abducted while jogging near her place in Redding, California, on November 2.
Sheriff Bosenko mentioned that there was a message branded onto her skin. While the message wasn't specified, it seemed to be about power and control, or conveying something deeper.
Her blonde hair had been cut, which Bosenko believed was done by "a very sick person" trying to change her looks and degrade her.

Speaking to ABC News, Keith Papini said Sherri was "covered in bruises, ranging from yellow to black," and added, "My Sherri suffered tremendously, and any mental image you might have of how she looked isn't as shocking as the truth."
Her nose had been broken, and at just 87 pounds, her body was covered in bruises of various colors, severe burns, rashes, and marks from chains.
Authorities have cleared Keith of any suspicion after he passed a polygraph test.
In a written statement, he talked about being worn out by "rumors, assumptions, lies, and hate," calling them both exhausting and disgusting.
He acknowledged public interest but insisted he wouldn't respond to every false claim, stressing there was no hoax or made-up racial conflict involved.
Since being released on November 24, Sherri has already spoken with investigators three times.
Police are preparing to release sketches of the suspects, who are believed to be armed with a handgun.
Should Scotland break away and become independent? For some folks, those words on millions of ballot papers were crystal clear.

To the die-hard believers, Scotland was a nation, plain and simple. They ignored debates on oil prices and government bonds, drawing power instead from age-old stories of freedom fighters like William Wallace, Robert the Bruce, and Andrew de Moray in the 13th and 14th centuries.
Some took inspiration from the Jacobite uprisings in the 18th century, aiming to bring back the House of Stuart to the British throne.
Others thought of the brief 1820 rebellion, led by Lanarkshire weaver James Wilson and his radical comrades who ended up facing execution for pushing for parliamentary reform.

This deep-rooted nationalism, though, was mainly personal. Wilson once declared, "Scotland Free, or a Desert," and back in the '80s it was scrawled on motorway bridges—but come 2014, it seemed to have faded into history.
As Mario Cuomo, a former New York governor, once said, "You campaign in poetry.
You govern in prose." In Scotland, though, the 2014 independence campaign sounded more practical than poetic.
The late Professor Sir Neil McCormick dubbed it "utilitarian nationalism," framing independence as the path to prosperity for Scotland.
This wasn’t about commemorating battles like Stirling Bridge or Bannockburn, or avenging Flodden or Culloden—it was all economics.

In the end, the "Yes" crowd didn't win. It was a wet, drizzly autumn morning when Scotland woke up to a clear, though not landslide, choice to stick with the Union: 44.7% said yes to independence, but 55.3% said no.
Why? Among "the 45"—how the losing side referred to themselves—there were feelings of betrayal.
They believed a powerful mix of business interests, the media, and even British security forces had swayed voters against independence.
The message from the establishment, bolstered by largely critical press coverage, skewed negative even as many "No" voters upheld a positive, sometimes sentimental, view on staying united.
Those supporting the UK often voiced sadness and reluctance, troubled by the idea of leaving behind a 300-year-old partnership.
The Republican Party is in a bit of a mess right now, with lots of infighting and fiery rhetoric flying around.
Sure, some folks might go as far as to call Republican voters "idiots," but most people are a tad more discerning than that.
What's really tricky for Republicans is the US electoral map. Winning key, high-population swing states is crucial, and it's not easy.
Here's a thought: a recent poll from three swing states—Florida, Ohio, and Pennsylvania—shows the two leading nominees are neck and neck.
These three states, boasting a total of 67 electoral votes, backed Democrat Barack Obama in 2008 and 2012.
Now, if you add them to the states Mitt Romney bagged in 2012, you get 273 electoral votes, which is three more than the magic number to land the presidency.
In the national scene, a tracking poll released on Wednesday has Donald Trump narrowing the gap with Hillary Clinton, which is making Democrats a bit jittery.
Yet, cooler heads note that the Reuters/Ipsos poll, with Clinton at 41% and Trump at 40% and 19% undecided, was done online.
Then there’s the Quinnipiac swing-state poll, which had a bigger sample of white voters who generally favor Republicans.

This implies that Trump's apparent surge might not be quite what it seems. Nate Silver, the well-known election analyst, warns us not to leap to big conclusions from these polls, reminding everyone about the rollercoaster nature of elections where anything can happen.
While political junkies are glued to every poll, the fact that Trump is giving Clinton a run for her money raises doubts about those early forecasts of a Democratic landslide.
Trump does have a shot at the presidency. It might be a long shot, but it's there.
His potential success hinges largely on the Rust Belt—states like Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, and Wisconsin.
Even if Florida, with its booming Hispanic population, leans towards Clinton, Trump can still clinch victory by flipping those Rust Belt states.
And he knows it. "We’ll win places many say you can’t win, like Michigan," Trump confidently proclaimed at a rally in Indiana back in April.
To give an example, someone on Twitter pointed to The Times's front page and remarked, "He's white, so let's emphasize that he's unemployed, a lone wolf, and has mental health issues."
The Times certainly wasn’t alone in facing such backlash. Just this past Thursday, the Daily Mail devoted a whole page to criticizing a Guardian cartoon.
That cartoon implied the Finsbury Park mosque attacker was driven by reading their paper and The Sun.

I chimed in on Twitter about the issue too. Yet, what really grabs my attention is the criticism leveled at Facebook and Google for their lackluster efforts in removing online far-right content that glorifies such attacks.
Recently, there's been a surge in political pressure on these tech giants, along with smaller companies, to make sure the internet doesn't become a "safe haven" for terrorists.

The political urge that Something Must Be Done has really picked up steam. At a recent press conference, Theresa May and Emmanuel Macron not only promised to work together but also to levy fines on companies that drag their feet in taking down hateful content.
This pressure has intensified in response to a white man's attack on Muslims, indicating a wider range of web content could come under fire.
If an anti-Semitic attack occurs, will there be demands for Facebook and Google to tackle anti-Semitism?
Could growing sectarian strife in India bring about calls to remove Hindu nationalist content?
Maybe. It’s essential to untangle the complexity here and mull over what it means to push these powerful companies into action.
First, we need to separate encryption issues from the broader matter of hateful content—something some British politicians have blurred.
Apps like WhatsApp are attractive to terrorists due to their end-to-end encryption, which makes it tough for security services to break in.
Weakening this protection by adding a backdoor could open the door to misuse by hostile nations and cybercriminals.
When it comes to dealing with hateful material, the hurdles are both practical and philosophical.
On the practical side, coping with the sheer volume of content is nearly unmanageable, even with Artificial Intelligence on board.
In November 2015, the IAAF decided to suspend Russia because of state-sponsored doping activities.

On Monday, this ban was extended, affecting the 2017 World Championships. Mutko, facing criticism from the IAAF, admitted there were "many abuses and breaches," yet he stressed that "colossal work has been done" over the last year.
Russia aims to be reinstated by November, which hinges on their ability to restore their drug-testing agency, currently sidelined due to allegations of a cover-up.
Since stepping into his role in October, Mutko has been outspoken, especially after the McLaren report exposed a state-backed Russian doping scheme.
In January, he stirred up controversy by suggesting that women's doping results might be influenced by sexual activity shortly before tests.
Yet, on Monday he conceded, "Athletes broke the rules, and many coaches just don't get how to train without doping; they should retire."
While Russia will miss the World Championships starting on August 4 in London, some athletes may compete under a neutral banner.
The IAAF is reviewing 35 athletes who can demonstrate they've been tested independently, apart from the suspended Russian agency.
Although Andrei Silnov, the vice president of the Russian track federation, opposes the idea of neutral athletes, he’s skeptical if the situation is as dire as the IAAF suggests.
"We're solving it, step by step. We're doing what's necessary," Silnov said. "They talk about a doping culture. What culture of doping?"
Francois Bayrou, a fellow centrist and devout Roman Catholic, reached out with an alliance offer, which was accepted.
Meanwhile, the buzz is that support for Emmanuel Macron, who's been favored to take the election, has dipped a bit according to recent polls.
Things are heating up on the far-right front: two of Marine Le Pen’s staff were detained over a financial probe.
There's a formal investigation into her chief of staff for allegedly misusing EU funds to pay parliamentary assistants, said French media.
Her bodyguard was questioned too. Le Pen, leader of the National Front, is adamant that she's done nothing wrong, brushing the inquiry off as a "political dirty trick."
While she's ahead in opinion polls for the first round in April, the second round doesn’t look as promising for her.
Mr. Bayrou, who's had his presidential runs, pulling in over 18% of the vote in the 2007 race, announced he’s stepping back this year and instead threw his support behind Macron.
He’s worried about "the failure of France" and sees Le Pen as a "major and immediate threat" to both the country and Europe.
Macron, who's all about free-market and unity, was pleased with Bayrou's offer.
He mentioned to Reuters how it aligns with his vision for renewal and unity. Analysts are thinking Bayrou voters will now split between Macron and the conservative Francois Fillon.
A fresh poll has Macron and Fillon neck-and-neck for that crucial second-place spot in the first round, each at about 19%.
Before Bayrou’s announcement, he was looking at about 5.5%, while Le Pen seemed to command 26%.
In the hypothetical second round, Macron is forecasted to beat Le Pen 61% to 39%, with Fillon also beating her, but with a narrower 57% to 43%.
Initially, Fillon looked like he'd glide into the runoff with Le Pen and win it all.
But then January hit, and a scandal involving payments to his family put a dent in his reputation.
He caught up with former PM Alain Juppe, whom he bested in the Republican primaries, as per Le Figaro newspaper.
Le Pen faces accusations from the European Parliament, saying she misused about 340,000 euros (£289,000; $359,000), reports AFP.

The claims suggest her bodyguard, Thierry Legier, was paid for a job that didn’t exist and her chief of staff, Catherine Griset, was compensated as her EU assistant in Brussels but was actually working for the party. Both Legier and Griset were questioned on Wednesday.
Media playback isn't supported on this device. The match was as physical and gritty as head coach Eddie Jones wanted for England’s big comeback.
Jones set the mood at Murrayfield and left quite satisfied with the win. We’re likely to see more from England's game in the next few matches.
Their strategy relied on direct play, heavily using the forwards. Yet, Jonathan Joseph didn’t get the ball much, and the wingers seemed mainly engaged during kick returns.
This points to England needing to polish up their backline plans. Stat-wise, England nailed their set-pieces.
Captain Dylan Hartley was almost flawless with his line-outs, missing just one out of 15.
Jones’s vision of a strong set-piece approach and a tough pack played out well against Scotland.
They also made the most of their clean opportunities to score tries, which is encouraging, though Joseph probably wants more action.
Media playback isn't supported on this device. Owen Farrell, Joseph’s center partner, wasn’t making headlines either, and full-back Mike Brown didn't have his best game.
Improvement will take some time. I'm still not fully sold on the Owen Farrell and George Ford combo at fly-half and inside center.
When two typical number 10s try to split game organization duties, they don’t always have enough direct impact; Farrell only carried the ball three times and Joseph just four against Scotland.
This shows the midfield isn’t firing on all cylinders, although their combined efforts did help Jack Nowell score a try.
Ideally, an inside center who can create plays and also pose a solo threat would fit better than temporarily using a fly-half there.
Someone like Henry Slade—once he’s back from injury—could be perfect. But for now, England is adapting as well as they can with the resources they've got.
The 35-year-old winger, Shane Williams, has signed a one-year deal with the Mitsubishi Dynaboars, competing in Japan’s Division Two.
Williams made a splash in his final game for the Ospreys, scoring twice. On Twitter, he revealed, "It was a last-minute offer, and I had to decide quickly.
I'm really excited about this new adventure." Back in February, he announced he wouldn't be accepting the Ospreys’ offer to continue playing in Wales for a tenth season.

For a bit of nostalgia, let's remember: Williams was named International Rugby Board Player of the Year in December 2008 after racking up 58 tries in 87 international games, and two tries in four Tests with the British and Irish Lions.
He wrapped up his international career with flair, nailing a last-minute try in Cardiff on December 3rd.
A double-Grand Slam winner, he's the Ospreys' all-time top try-scorer, with 57 tries over 141 matches.
His last run in Europe was actually with the Barbarians in Cardiff on June 2nd.
Though it seemed like he'd stick around with the Ospreys at Liberty Stadium next season, the club has allowed him to seize this rare chance.
The Ospreys said, "Given Shane's exceptional service, we understand this unique opportunity for him and his family to explore a new culture.
We won't stand in his way. We wish them the best in Japan and look forward to welcoming Shane back to Ospreylia after his stint, continuing to represent us off the field."
Williams stands second on the all-time international try-scoring leaderboard, just behind Australia’s David Campese.

Taking a page out of the playbook of former Ospreys pals Jerry Collins and Filo Tiatia, who ventured off to Japan with Yamaha Jubilo and Toyota Verblitz in 2011, Shane’s journey abroad feels like the next exciting chapter.
In a surprising twist of events, Pembrokeshire council nearly allowed Michael Smith to become a foster carer, all because of sheer luck.
The Western Telegraph got its hands on a confidential report from 2015, which spilled the beans on a pretty big oversight.
Apparently, the head of service failed to mention some major child protection issues concerning Smith.
The council wasn't too happy about this report getting out; they called it an unfortunate leak, since someone inside shared it despite being told not to.
Smith was in Haverfordwest, working with the council's youth department from May 2001 until January 2012.

During that time, he had three disciplinary hearings. The allegations were quite serious: he let a kid drive his Land Rover, allowed one without a seatbelt, and even let a youth reported missing stay at his house.
The independent social worker's report pointed out that Smith showed several grooming behaviors, although formal abuse charges weren't filed back then.
His stint with the council ended with a dismissal for gross misconduct. Things escalated in September 2013 when the police started investigating him on accusations of sexually abusing a boy.
Fast forward to July 2014, Smith found himself facing a six-year prison sentence.
He pleaded guilty to sexually assaulting a child under 13, encouraging sexual activity, and taking indecent photographs. He also confessed to having 1,136 indecent images of children.
Back in 2010, he put in an application to become a respite foster carer with the council.
The fostering team reached out to the Head of Youth Service for feedback on Smith.
Oddly, the head’s response was "very positive," even skipping over some important parts.
When asked to list any concerns, including past disciplinary actions, he left it blank. Thank goodness one of the foster panel members had a good memory.
When the application came up, they recalled Smith's previous investigation in 2005 for inappropriate behavior.

That memory jog led them to turn down his foster carer application. The report highlighted that without this coincidental recollection, the panel might have wrongly assumed Smith had a clean record. This stroke of luck prevented a risky approval.
At 33, Jung snagged his third win after topping the charts at Burghley and Kentucky, wrapping things up with a flawless showjumping act on Sunday.
Andreas Ostholt from Germany nabbed second on So Is Et, while Britain's Gemma Tattersall took third riding Arctic Soul.
Jung's Grand Slam victory brings back memories of Pippa Funnell's similar feat in 2003. "We're going to need some time to really soak in this big moment.
It’s quite an achievement," Jung commented. Zara Tindall managed a 23rd-place finish on High Kingdom, the very horse she won a team silver with at London 2012, securing her Olympic qualification.

The selection for Team GB won’t be finalized until July, but Tattersall, Tindall, Kristina Cook (seventh on Star Witness), Izzy Taylor (eighth on Allercombe Ellie), and Ben Way (12th on Galley Light) have all met qualifying standards.
Jung consistently outperformed in dressage, cross-country, and showjumping, ending up with a record low of 34.4 penalty points at Badminton Park.
Ostholt finished his run with 43.4 points, and Tattersall, just behind, with 44.6.
Tattersall really made her Olympic ambitions clear by flawlessly clearing all thirteen jumps in the showjumping finale, keeping pace with Ostholt and Jung after Saturday's cross-country.
Despite having room for two poles to fall in his last run, Jung finished unblemished, earning a standing ovation from the sell-out crowd.
Jung is now seen as a prime candidate to hold onto his Olympic individual eventing title and can likely lead Germany to a team victory in Rio.
He cannot help but sing praises for La Biosthetique’s trio, calling them "the best in the world" after they snagged the Olympic, world, and European titles back in 2012.
Jung seems set on giving Great Britain a run for their money; they came second in team eventing at London 2012.
He didn’t just break a Badminton points record set in 2006—he’s the first to lead all the way from dressage through to the finish since 2007.
It’s the Grand Slam victory that'll make Badminton 2016 unforgettable in the eventing world, though.

Out of the 77 pairs of horses and riders, 46 made it through the entire week. And New Zealand’s Sir Mark Todd, who clocked in fourth, might very well compete in his seventh Olympic Games at age 60—fingers crossed!
Sports Direct recently revealed a sharp drop in their half-year profits, with the weak pound playing a notable role in the downturn.
The company, previously under fire for its working conditions, reported a 25% dip in pre-tax profits, landing at £140.2 million.
Interestingly, despite these challenges, they announced they're spending £40 million on a corporate jet.
CEO Mike Ashley opened up about the last six months, calling them "tough for our people and performance."

In going over the numbers, Ashley emphasized that while their UK sports retail business is still central to Sports Direct’s success, they’ve been hit by unfavorable exchange rates and have had to reassess risks tied to stock levels and their European stores' performance.

Under scrutiny, particularly during his stint as chairman, Mr. Hellawell used the results announcement to take a swipe at how the company has been treated, remarking, "I strongly believe that the aggressive political, union, and media campaign against us has not only tarnished our reputation but also swayed our customers and hurt our employees’ morale."
He expressed doubt about the ethical intent of the scrutiny, pointing out how these actions harmed the very people meant to be protected.
"The board admits our shortcomings but insists on the disproportionate, inaccurate, and misleading narrative," Hellawell continued.
"Our staff, who are the backbone of our organization, are not to blame here. They're increasingly frustrated and angered by the negative response they find unjustified."
It’s been a rocky period for Sports Direct, riddled with scandals. An HMRC probe looked into whether workers at their Derbyshire warehouse were paid below the legal minimum wage.
