A damning report by the Business, Innovation, and Skills Committee accused the company of treating employees inhumanely.
Things got more heated when MPs said someone tried to record their private conversation at the Shirebrook warehouse visit.
More trouble brewed with a new inquiry into the company’s finances and a wave of senior staff resignations.
Dave Forsey stepped down as CEO, with Mr. Ashley taking over. Interim Finance Director Matt Pearson was succeeded by temporary appointee Herbert Monteith in October.
The interim results quietly noted a shift in priorities; tucked away under "corporate assets and facilities," they mentioned the upcoming arrival of a corporate plane.
"I wouldn't say I'm tough... just lucky," Reg Foggerdy remarked after disappearing last month during a hunt for a wild camel in Western Australia.
On October 12, police trackers found him sitting under a tree about 15 kilometers (9 miles) from the spot where he went missing.
Reg, a diabetic who recently had a heart attack, confessed he'd lost hope. "I've heard you can die after three days without water; why I lasted six, I can't explain," he shared with 7News.
"At one point, I considered just lying down and giving up. I imagined my family finding me like that."
Wearing only a t-shirt, shorts, a cap, and flip-flops, Mr. Foggerdy got turned around in the desert's scorching heat while chasing the camel.
To survive, he stirred up an ants' nest with a stick and ate the insects for nourishment—following a tip from British survival expert Bear Grylls. "They tasted alright.
On the first day, I had about 12, and on the second day, about 18. If anyone wants to call me 'Ant Man,' I don't mind," he chuckled.
Though he spotted police search helicopters a number of times, they didn’t see him despite his efforts to wave his hat for attention.
In the end, a local Aboriginal man helped the police by identifying Mr. Foggerdy’s footprint left by his slipper.
After nearly facing death, he feels revived. But when questioned if he'd revisit the scene of his adventure, he replied with a grin, "I might go back and look for my gun."
Australia, on the hunt for their fourth straight World T20 title, opted to bat first and ended with a total of 148-5.
Elyse Villani took center stage, smashing her way to the first half-century ever seen in a final—clocking 52 runs off a mere 34 balls.
But the real buzz came from Hayley Matthews, the 18-year-old sensation from the Windies, who lit up the game with her extraordinary 66 off 45 balls, hammering three sixes in a crucial 120-run stand.
The West Indies pulled off the win with three balls to spare, and their men’s side later celebrated their own T20 victory.
Despite being winless in their previous eight encounters against Australia in T20 internationals, the Windies braved the pressure bowling at Eden Gardens.
Villani didn’t waste the chance on some wayward full tosses, speeding her way to fifty, while Meg Lanning belted three back-to-back fours in her own 52-run outing.
Ellyse Perry showed her class with two impressive sixes in a quick 28-run cameo.
Australia's defense tightened up at the close, allowing just one run from the last over.
The Windies chase, though, was slow out of the gate—only three runs in the first couple of overs.
Things warmed up when Matthews and captain Stafanie Taylor cranked up the fifth over against Perry, collecting 16 runs, hitting their century partnership by the 14th over.
With Matthews out and 29 needed from 26 balls, Taylor wrapped up her 59-run stint—a mere five runs from eight deliveries remained.
The Windies clinched victory in the final over, thanks to an errant throw that led to jubilant celebrations.

The men's team joined in as they prepared for their clash against England. The win revived West Indies cricket, adding to their Under-19 squad's victory over India in the 50-over World Cup back in February.
West Indies captain Stafanie Taylor shared her relief and excitement: "I've waited forever for this moment, and it's just perfect timing.
Our batting really got us through, and having the men's team cheering us was fantastic."
Darren Sammy, the men’s captain, had texted Taylor with a boost: "Staf, you’re gonna do it; you gals are gonna do it."

Australian captain Meg Lanning tipped her hat to the Windies: “Full credit to them—they played superbly, even though we didn't quite meet our own expectations. A target of 160 would’ve been ideal, but we stood by our defense.”

Negotiations have been underway for several weeks about the Northern Ireland international, but Manchester City has already faced two rejections from West Brom for a player they insist isn't on the market.

Jonny Evans, who spent nine years at Manchester United before his 2015 move to Albion, still has two years left on his current contract. West Brom also turned down a £10m offer from Leicester for the 29-year-old.
Evans, who joined United as a youngster, won three Premier League titles and two League Cups while making 198 appearances.
His move to West Brom came after Louis van Gaal left him out of his plans at United.
Arsenal showed interest in Evans last year, but West Brom wasn't swayed by their approach for their captain.
City manager Pep Guardiola mentioned last month that he's still on the hunt for another central defender before the transfer window shuts.
Right now, Eliaquim Mangala is fourth choice for that spot, but his long-term future at City seems uncertain.
On BBC Radio 5 live, former Everton winger Pat Nevin noted that City's weakness at center-back is no secret.
While Virgil van Dijk would be the perfect fit, Jonny Evans, at 29, might be at the peak of his powers.
Evans is comfortable with both two or three at the back and is solid on the ball.

Honestly, it's tough to see any drawbacks here. In the current Premier League climate, many might say he's overpriced, but considering how hard it is to find quality center-backs these days, he'd be worth every penny.
The folks at Project Loon, part of the X research lab, have just announced they’ve taken a big step forward with machine learning, helping them predict weather patterns.
This is a game-changer because it lets them steer their balloons more accurately, focusing on specific areas rather than wandering all over the globe.

With fewer balloons needed, the whole thing becomes much more cost-effective. Astro Teller, Google's guru for ambitious projects, shared that now they can test services in targeted regions with just ten, twenty, or thirty balloons, instead of needing hundreds.
He hinted that “real users” might start trying out the system soon, though he kept mum about exactly where they’ll kick things off.
Google's big goal here is to reach nearly four billion people without internet, especially in those tricky remote rural spots.

Instead of laying down lots of infrastructure like in developed countries, they’re betting on delivering internet from these giant balloons, about the size of a tennis court, floating 11 miles up in the stratosphere.
By tweaking their altitude, these balloons catch different weather streams to stay put.
Thanks to machine-learning algorithms, they’ve gotten good at predicting weather conditions to keep the balloons almost stationary for a long time.
Just last year, they managed to keep a cluster over Peru for three months. Over the past year, Google’s been feeling the heat from shareholders to cut back on its big-ticket projects.
They spun off their self-driving cars into Waymo and have been hustling to make it commercially viable amid grumbles about profits.
Teller pointed out that Project Loon is one of their more “mature” ventures. Even as they work on deals with telecom companies, Google isn't hurrying to break Project Loon into its own entity.
"We're seeing way more potential for profit, and that’s exciting," he mentioned.

"Things have worked out better than we expected, boosting Loon's future." Still, there’s a major roadblock: the balloons' longevity. Right now, the longest uninterrupted flight they've done is 190 days.
Germany's dull showing in Tbilisi raised some eyebrows, and the follow-up in Frankfurt after their narrow 1-0 win over Georgia didn't exactly soothe the nerves about Monday's match.
Mats Hummels told BBC Scotland that Germany hasn't quite hit their stride yet, though their game against Poland came close to showing their true capabilities.
They were particularly strong in attack, pushing forward at every opportunity and exploiting holes in Poland's defense with quick, incisive passes.
By the 20-minute mark at the Commerzbank Arena, it looked like Germany had Poland on the ropes, with a 2-0 advantage that could’ve easily ballooned to five or six goals before the match wrapped up.
Thomas Muller, who kicked things off by netting the first goal, was in top form.
His seemingly casual style conceals a sharp instinct that puts him in the perfect spots in the penalty box.
With Karim Bellarabi, the speedy Bayer Leverkusen winger, Germany's attack gained another gear.
Despite his first appearance for the national team ending in a loss to Poland last year, he's since become a staple under Joachim Low, proving his worth this past Friday.
On the left flank, he paired with Jonas Hector, the talented Cologne full-back, and together they outsmarted Lukasz Piszczek, the seasoned Borussia Dortmund defender.
The duo's teamwork contributed to Muller’s goal and stirred up plenty of trouble on the field.
This suggests whoever Gordon Strachan installs at right back—maybe Alan Hutton—will need some help to fend off Germany's relentless attack.
There was chatter about some of Scotland’s players missing club minutes, but Germany's Bastian Schweinsteiger and Mario Gotze didn’t let similar issues hold them back.
Schweinsteiger has only started two of Manchester United’s six competitive matches so far, while Gotze has had just one start in the Bundesliga for Bayern Munich.
Still, they were pivotal in Germany's victory over Poland. Gotze, sometimes playing up front, maneuvered into open spaces, creating chances for Muller.

Scoring twice—once with a brilliant play from the edge of the box—and hitting the post, Gotze showed why Joachim Low continues to back him, despite Pep Guardiola’s ongoing uncertainty about his role at Bayern.
The idea that Ukraine is entirely free from far-right influence is pretty off the mark.
Sure, far-right parties didn't cross the 5% mark needed for parliamentary seats, but their votes could've been more impactful if they weren't so spread out.
Right now, there's just one minister with ties to nationalist parties, and he isn't a neo-Nazi or a fascist.
Plus, you've got Volodymyr Groysman, a Jewish guy leading the parliament as the third highest-ranking official.
Yet, Ukrainian officials and much of the media often assert that Ukraine's politics are untouched by fascism—another misconception.
The whole topic is sensitive, which is why many shy away from it, fearing it'll fuel Russian propaganda.
That said, sweeping the issue under the rug might backfire, letting ultra-nationalists fly under the radar and leaving many Ukrainians in the dark about neo-Nazi or fascist ideologies.
This sensitivity hit home when President Petro Poroshenko granted citizenship to someone labeled a "Belarusian neo-Nazi" by human rights advocates.

On December 5, Poroshenko honored defenders of the Donetsk airport against Russian-backed forces, among them Serhiy Korotkykh, who he commended for "courageous and selfless service." A snapshot captured Poroshenko alongside Korotkykh, in full military gear.

Experts on the far right criticized the move, pointing to Korotkykh's links with groups like the Russian National Unity party and the neo-Nazi National Socialist Society (NSS), aiming to spark a race war, as noted by academic Anton Shekhovtsov.

Though Korotkykh once faced charges for a 2007 bombing in Moscow and a 2013 stabbing in Minsk, he was released due to lack of evidence, though activist Halya Coynash underscored the severity of these allegations if true.

Ukrainian officials, including Valentyn Nalyvaychenko, the head of security services, brushed off claims about Korotkykh's neo-Nazi ties as defamation, insisting there was no counterintelligence data blocking his citizenship.
Healthcare workers are clearly at their breaking point, and the way this outbreak is being handled has been slammed as "lethally inadequate."

It's a situation that's going from bad to worse. While the outbreak has been dragging on all year, some shocking new numbers show that 40% of the deaths have happened just in the last three weeks. So, what are we looking at in the months, or even years, ahead?
It's tough to say—the future's always a gamble, especially in these unprecedented times.
Unlike past outbreaks, which were quickly tamped down, affecting only a handful of people, this one's already hit more than 3,900.

We get our first insights from what's happening now. Dr. Christopher Dye, who's in charge of strategy at the World Health Organization, has the tough job of trying to predict how the outbreak will unfold.
He shared with the BBC, "We're really worried about the latest numbers we've gathered."
Up until now, Liberia was bearing the brunt, especially around the epicenter in Lofa County and the capital, Monrovia.
Meanwhile, new case numbers in Sierra Leone and Guinea—the other two hardest-hit countries—had been holding steady.
But that's shifted recently, with cases rising everywhere except a few rural spots in Sierra Leone's Kenema and Kailahun districts.
"In most other areas, both cases and deaths seem to be increasing. That surprised me," said Dr. Dye.
Stories about healthcare workers stretched beyond their limits are everywhere. There are widespread reports of lacking essentials like gloves.
In Monrovia, Médecins Sans Frontières runs an isolation center with 160 beds, but the lines are getting longer, and they're saying they need 800 more beds just to take care of the sick.

This isn't how you stop an epidemic; it's how you make it worse. Dr. Dye's initial projections paint a grim picture: "We're seeing about 500 new cases each week right now, and those numbers are climbing.
I've looked ahead five weeks, and if current trends hold, we could be dealing with not hundreds but thousands of new cases weekly, and that’s incredibly worrying.

Things look dire, and we need to brace for them getting worse." The World Health Organization is planning its response based on the possibility of the outbreak hitting 20,000 cases before it’s contained.
Often viewed as the least corrupt nation in Africa, Botswana not only boasts the continent's longest-running multiparty democracy but also one of the fastest-growing economies anywhere.
Yet, things started to wobble a bit after the 2008 global economic hit and the rollercoaster ride of commodity prices.

Folks began to worry about the country's heavy reliance on diamonds. For the first time, Botswana's facing financial squeezes, negative growth, and is even knocking on the doors of international donors for a hand.
To counteract these issues, Botswana is trying to shake things up economically.
They're looking to spruce up sectors like tourism and cattle farming while also eyeing fresh opportunities in technology and entrepreneurship.
Still, diamonds are the big player—making up a third of the GDP, 70% of export earnings, and another third of government revenue.
But, here's the catch: diamond production has peaked, and some experts reckon the reserves might run dry by 2030.
Unemployment is creeping up, with official figures nearing 20%. About 45% of the population teeters below the poverty line.
In 2009, the economy shrank, and the industrial sector took a massive 30% hit. Signs of unrest are bubbling, especially after some recent public sector strikes.
Linah Mohohlo, who led the Bank of Botswana for 15 years, raised some red flags in a BBC Africa Business Report chat.
She pointed out that the government has been attempting to steer away from just mining for years.
The policies that focused on diamonds made it hard for other industries to bloom.
State intervention and red tape scare off investors since most of the contracts are government-backed—putting a damper on entrepreneurial spirits.
While Botswana sits in a relatively stable part of southern Africa, it's not without its hurdles.
The electricity woes in South Africa and Zimbabwe's political turmoil add to the mix.
Mohohlo is especially worried about their neighbors luring away foreign direct investment and thinks Botswana needs to up its game to stay competitive.
Manufacturing hasn’t taken off as they'd hoped, only contributing around 5% to the GDP, though it does employ more people than mining.
Compounding the struggle, Botswana's trying to juggle a small domestic market of just two million while competing with South Africa.
Conservative MP Fiona Bruce pushed for clarity on how the law handles sex-selective abortion, but her proposal didn't pass, losing 292 to 201.
What did come about was a decision to review how common these kinds of abortions are.

The government stands firm that sex-selective abortion is already outlawed. Health Minister Jane Ellison noted that the Department of Health rolled out new guidance last May that independent sectors need to adhere to.

Before things got heated in the debate, Bruce had the backing of over 100 MPs. Her amendment wasn't trying to change the law but aimed to tweak the 1967 legislation, which was crafted way before we knew how to pinpoint a fetus's sex.
Another amendment, suggesting a review of gender-selective abortion across England, Wales, and Northern Ireland, got massive approval, with votes landing at 491 to 2.
Bruce argued her amendment would clearly spell out in law that sex-selective abortion isn't allowed in the UK and enable the government to set new best practice guidelines.
She pointed out that the existing law didn't specifically address gender-selective abortion because the technology just wasn't there back in 1967.
Bruce assured her proposal wouldn’t penalize pregnant women but rather hold doctors responsible for authorizing such abortions.
She shot down claims that her proposal would block abortions tied to gender-linked disabilities.
Conservative David Burrowes backed her, saying UK law doesn't explicitly ban gender-selective abortions.
Jim Shannon from the DUP supported it too, agreeing accountability should rest with doctors, not women.
But there was pushback. Dr. Sarah Wollaston, who chairs the Health Select Committee, wasn't on board, saying it was unnecessary and worried about "unintended consequences."
She was concerned it might scare women from speaking up about feeling pressured to abort due to gender concerns, which could lead to them being criminalized.
Wollaston pointed out there's no solid proof of widespread gender-selective abortion in the UK, cautioning against stigmatizing communities.
Plus, she warned how the new clause might tangle with existing abortion laws by "conferring personhood on the fetus."
The 31-year-old cricketer has just inked a two-year deal to play limited-overs cricket with Glamorgan.
Ingram was celebrated back in 2016 as Glamorgan's player of the year in one-day formats, but he’s not really chasing the Indian Premier League dream for now.
"The IPL isn't high on my agenda right now, but who knows what might happen in the future," he noted.
"For now, having a secure spot with Glamorgan for the next few years gives me peace of mind."
After knee surgery sidelined him in August 2016, he missed out on the four-day Championship cricket that summer.

He made a comeback to the longer format in 2017 with Glamorgan, but he’s been weighing the balance between family time and fitness, leading him to dial down his packed schedule, including games with South Africa's Warriors.
"Playing year-round while living in South Africa has its challenges, so I'll be there more often.
Plus, my injury history plays into my decision," he told BBC Wales Sport. "I need to focus on what suits me best—50-over and T20 cricket—so I'm thankful to the club and excited to stick with them.

But hey, exploring international options is still on the table." The IPL and Australia’s Big Bash are hailed as top cricket tournaments globally, drawing huge crowds, and they've even inspired the England and Wales Cricket Board to create a major city competition for 2020.
"Everyone talks about the IPL, but when you're committed to UK cricket, it doesn't become a priority.
I've always dreamt of playing county cricket," Ingram shared. "The IPL is an incredible event with top players from around the world and unmatched promotions.
But money isn’t my main driver. I just wanna make good choices, earn decent pay, and truly enjoy playing."

Ingram was chattering away after hitting his career-best limited-overs score of 142, as Glamorgan squeezed past Essex in the One-Day Cup by just one run. He aims to keep playing Championship cricket for the rest of the 2017 season.
Back in May, Qatar made promises to boost the rights of migrant workers in response to growing worries about their treatment.
However, Amnesty International is saying they haven’t seen much improvement when it comes to stopping worker exploitation.
They pointed out that Qatar still hasn’t reformed those controversial laws tying migrants to a single employer.
And let's not forget the exit permit rule: workers still need their employer's permission to leave the country.

Amnesty's Sherif Elsayed-Ali put it plainly: “Time’s running out fast.” Qatar won the World Cup bid four years ago, drawing global attention, but since then, most actions have merely been promises and draft proposals.
He highlighted the urgent need for Qatar to act decisively to avoid the World Cup being linked to forced labor and exploitation.
With the influx of foreign workers pouring in ahead of the event, migrants now make up the majority of the workforce.
Back in November, Qatar’s Sports Minister, Salah bin Ghanem bin Nasser al-Ali, chatted with The Associated Press, revealing some labor reforms were on the horizon "in the next few months."
But Amnesty argues these plans aren't enough. While there’s a growing acknowledgment among Qatari officials about the need for reform, real changes need to happen, and soon.
According to Amnesty, if significant reforms aren’t implemented, it really puts a damper on how serious the Qatari authorities are about improving conditions.
Last year, Qatar saw the tragic deaths of over 180 migrant workers, with countless others likely hurt from dangerous work environments.
Despite this, Qatar is pushing forward with its massive $200 billion investment in infrastructure, touting the World Cup as a springboard for national development.

After weeks of speculation about whether Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, would stick around longer because of the referendum results, he threw a curveball that caught folks in the City and the government off guard.
People at the Bank figured he had two main options: stay until 2021 or wrap it up as planned in 2018.
But Carney threw in a third option: a one-year extension. It seemed like a bit of a clunky middle ground.
Was political pressure keeping him from staying until 2021? Or maybe he saw the gloomy UK economic forecasts post-Brexit and thought it was a good time to leave?
On top of that, his family wasn’t keen on hanging on in the UK for three more years while he was jetting off to global summits.
That family factor could've tipped the scales. When Carney came on board in 2013, who could've guessed the UK would soon be wrangling its way out of the EU?
Pascal Lamy, who used to head the WTO, once likened it to "taking an egg out of an omelette."
Then June 23 happened, making Carney's gig even more complicated. Leaving in 2018 would have him exiting right in the heat of Brexit talks.
So, should he extend to the usual eight-year stretch governors generally serve to help steady the jittery markets?
Carney was aware of how the job's challenges were shifting, and he even told friends he "wanted to serve" longer.
This led many to think he'd stay the full course. But in quiet conversations a few weeks ago, he started entertaining a "third way"—a shorter extension.
The reasons? Personal. In 2018, one of his daughters finishes her A-levels, and another completes her GCSEs.
Like anyone else, he's got family responsibilities to juggle. But this job needs full dedication, and he's all in for as long as it feels right.
After last week's 3-0 defeat to England, Strachan wasn't spilling anything about his future plans.
Scotland, sitting second to last in the World Cup qualifying group with just four points from four matches, is in a tough spot.
Motherwell manager McGhee is optimistic, though. When asked about Strachan's continuation, he said, "I'd be amazed if he doesn't.
Honestly, with the way the team's played, he's getting the most out of the players.
So, it's only fair for him to move forward to the next games and go for better outcomes."
Looking ahead, Scotland's got a home match against Slovenia in March and a home rematch with England at Hampden in June.
The qualification wraps up with double-headers later in 2017 against Lithuania and Malta, followed by Slovakia and Slovenia.
To qualify for the 2018 finals in Russia, the group winners get a direct pass, and the eight top runners-up out of the nine European groups face off in playoffs for four additional spots.
Scotland started off Group F strong with a big 5-1 win in Malta, but could only salvage a late draw at home against Lithuania.
Things went downhill with a 3-0 loss to Slovakia in Bratislava, followed by the same scoreline against England at Wembley.
"Everyone can have their say," McGhee commented. "No matter what others think, we'll keep pushing until we're told otherwise.
If folks really look at it, they'll see the players are giving their all, even if they're coming up short due to skill gaps or sheer bad luck.
We're justified in continuing because we're still squeezing the best out of them."
Back in 2014, Nigel Farage appointed Mr. Gill, and he feels confident that most UKIP members are still in his corner.
He’s now trying to convince those in North Wales to rank him high on their list for May's assembly election.
UKIP will rank candidates through a ballot conducted among party members for each of the five regions.
Mr. Gill says it was actually his idea to have this ballot, trying to address concerns about candidates being imposed from outside Wales, like former Tory MPs Mark Reckless and Neil Hamilton.
Though he won’t name names, he firmly believes it’s up to the members to decide.
But there are voices saying he hasn’t done enough, claiming the selection should've been handled entirely in Wales and calling for him to step down.
"I’ve been working with UKIP in Wales for 11 years, canvassing all over, so I know most of our members," he explains.
"I understand their quality, passion, and ability, and I've always stood up for them."
Sure, critics from other parties might call UKIP anti-Welsh, but the real challenge comes from within.
Since the NEC made its decisions behind closed doors, those not in the meetings have to rely on Mr. Gill's word.
"Of course, not everyone likes me, but I’m sure my supporters outnumber my critics," he says.
He believes some of the criticism is driven by personal reasons, like people changing their mind about running.
He scoffs at claims that he's out of touch with the grassroots as "nonsense." The selection process might look chaotic compared to other parties, but Mr. Gill sees UKIP as a unique option.
Despite being an MEP, he doesn’t see himself as part of the political elite—hardly surprising with the current distrust in politicians.

And really, who does claim that label these days? Catching up with Mr. Gill at his home—a cozy bed and breakfast on Anglesey where he and his wife, Jana, raise their five kids—I ask if he wishes he could dodge the critics telling him to quit. "Of course," he admits. "I’m human, after all."
Back in 2016, Zimbabwean MP Joseph Chinotimba, a staunch supporter of President Robert Mugabe, kicked off the year with quite the romantic gesture.
At 66, this war veteran and his wife Vimbai made headlines by snagging a spot in the Book of African Records.
How? By winning a Valentine's Day contest. Their achievement? Clinching victory in "The Longest Kiss in Africa Challenge" with a smooch lasting 10 minutes and 17 seconds.

They beat the previous African record by over five minutes! Unfortunately, this wasn’t quite enough to challenge the world record, held by a Thai couple who managed to kiss for an epic 58 hours, 35 minutes, and 58 seconds.
Later in 2016, Nigerian MP Dino Melaye found himself in hot water for his comments on gender equality and the harsh treatment women face.

During a fiery Senate session in July, he allegedly threatened violence against fellow senator Oluremi Tinubu, reportedly saying he’d "impregnate" her and then backtracking with the dubious excuse that biologically, it couldn't happen as Tinubu had reached menopause.
This claim was picked up by Nigeria's Punch newspaper, but despite all, Tinubu decided to forgive him.
Her stance was clear: she wouldn’t back down. She pointed out, "I am not advocating just for women; I am asserting my place.
If someone invades my space, I must respond. Rosa Parks wasn't seeking activism; she just refused to give up her seat, which spoke volumes."
Women across Africa grapple with various rights issues, yet they possess the vote.
In Zambia, there was a peculiar rule in past elections barring women with nail varnish from voting unless they removed it, claiming it interfered with the indelible ink process.
Thankfully, things shifted during the elections in August when President Edgar Lungu won another term.
The electoral commission took to social media to announce that women with "painted nails and/or false nails" were free to vote, ensuring they could exercise their democratic rights.
Meanwhile, Cameroon took a step towards gender equality with some eyebrow-raising legislation.

In June, there was a lively debate in parliament over a proposed law that would bring consequences for men caught committing adultery, similar to what women already faced—two to six months in jail for having extramarital affairs.
On Friday, an article stirred up quite the controversy when MacKenzie drew a troubling comparison between Everton midfielder Ross Barkley, whose grandfather is from Nigeria, and a "gorilla."
He went on to claim that men with similar earnings in Liverpool often turn out to be "drug dealers."
Merseyside Police have jumped in, looking into whether these comments cross the line into "racial hate crime" territory.
The Sun, trying to smooth things over, apologized for the offense caused, saying they weren’t aware of Barkley's background.

MacKenzie echoed this, dismissing the racism accusations as "beyond parody." Initially, the article even featured photos of Barkley next to a gorilla, a move that didn’t sit well with anyone, prompting a quick removal.
At 23, Barkley recently faced an "unprovoked attack" in a Liverpool bar, per his lawyer, which has also spurred a police investigation into that incident.

Joe Anderson, the Liverpool Mayor, wasn’t having any of MacKenzie's remarks. He took the issue to the police, calling the piece a "racial slur," chatting with BBC Sport, and pointing out that it perpetuates nasty racial stereotypes, especially given Barkley's mixed-race identity.

Anderson hit up Twitter to explain that he contacted Merseyside Police and the Independent Press Standards Organisation about the article, insisting that "ignorance is no excuse" and labeling the Sun's apology "simply inadequate."
Anderson also took a jab at Everton for staying quiet on the matter, urging them to block Sun journalists from Goodison Park—saying their silence was "a slap in the face to our city."
As a call to arms, he asked fans at the weekend's Premier League match against Burnley to turn their backs on the game at 15:06 BST in protest.

MacKenzie, it's worth noting, was at the helm of the Sun during its notorious 'Hillsborough: The Truth' front-page debacle, which wrongfully accused Liverpool fans of causing the 1989 tragedy at Sheffield Wednesday's stadium that claimed 96 lives.
Though MacKenzie apologized in 2012, the Hillsborough inquests last year confirmed those fans were unlawfully killed and not at fault.

This Saturday marks 28 years since that tragic event unfolded. Joey Barton, a former Everton player now at Burnley, didn’t hold back on social media, calling MacKenzie's words about Barkley, "a young working-class lad," downright appalling, emphasizing how out of line they were, given his mixed-race heritage.
Saracens pulled off a solid 28-17 win against Clermont Auvergne at Murrayfield on Saturday, keeping their hopes of a historic 'double-double' in both European and English championships alive.
Now, they're gearing up for another challenge next Saturday with a trip to Exeter for their first Premiership semi-final.
McCall remarked, "If we stay hungry and humble, there's no reason we can't get better.
Our team’s pretty young, and that win was promising." Should Saracens defeat Exeter, they'll square off against either Wasps or Leicester in the Premiership final at Twickenham on May 27.

Chris Ashton got Saracens off to a great start by scoring in the 13th minute. It marked his 37th European try—setting a new record—thanks to a perfect grubber kick from Alex Goode. Ashton quickly acknowledged his teammates, saying, "I won't lie, I'm thrilled.
But it's largely because of the group I’ve played with over the past five years.
Seeing my name up there is nice, but this club deserves a lot of the credit." Ashton, who will leave Saracens this summer for Toulon in the French Top 14, spoke about his mixed feelings on moving on.
"I'll miss it. These last five years have been amazing," he admitted. "I’ve seen some real highs and definite lows.
The support from everyone here has been wonderful, so leaving is going to be tough."
Meanwhile, Alex Goode, who played a key role in securing Saracens’ second European title, has shined this season, despite not being picked for England since his last appearance against Fiji in 2016.
Last year's Premiership player of the year, he continues to thrive in club rugby.
"We’ve got a young squad hungry to improve," Goode noted. "Playing with this team is a joy.
Our biggest strength is that we're always chasing progress, never feeling like we’ve peaked."
Ahmet Davutoglu pointed out how the airstrikes on IS spots around the Syria-Turkey border, along with hits on Kurdish PKK fighters in Iraq, are shaking things up in the conflict.
Turkey's actions are a reaction to recent violence, like the deadly bombing in Suruc that took 32 lives.
NATO's holding an emergency meeting on Tuesday to talk it over. Meanwhile, the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) have asked Turkey to stop attacking Kurdish fighters in Syria.
In a chat with local newspaper editors, Davutoglu mentioned that the military moves have set up "new conditions" in the regional struggle.
"With Turkey's strong use of its military, there's potential for change in Syria, Iraq, and the wider region," he told Hurriyet Daily News.
Turkey, being a NATO member, has called on Article 4 of NATO's treaty, requesting consultations when security is at risk.
"This meeting is spot-on, given the mess and unrest in Syria, Iraq, and along Turkey's NATO borders," NATO's Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg told the BBC.
Davutoglu added that Turkey might work with the Syrian Kurdish PYD, which is affiliated with the PKK, under the condition they aren't a threat to Turkey and break ties with Bashar al-Assad.
However, the attacks on the PKK in northern Iraq have shattered the two-year ceasefire.
Recently, Turkey's arrested many suspected supporters of IS or the PKK. Police raids in Istanbul led to three days of riots in the Gazi district, ending with a policeman and an activist dead.
The US has called for calm between Turkey and the PKK, supporting Turkey's right to defend against Kurdish attacks.
On Monday, the YPG claimed Turkish tanks shelled Zormikhar, a Kurdish-controlled village in Syria, and later, a Kurdish vehicle was "heavily fired upon" near Kobane in Til Findire village.
They criticized, "Instead of targeting IS spots, Turkish forces are hitting our units. This isn’t the right approach."
Oliver Burke breaks the mold when it comes to wingers, blending lightning speed with an imposing physical presence.
At just 19, he's already making a name for himself as an extraordinary football talent.
This season, he's established himself as a regular starter with Nottingham Forest, thanks to the new head coach, Philippe Montanier.

Burke has rewarded Montanier's faith by netting four goals. Now, just as he's about to earn his third cap with Scotland, lining up for Gordon Strachan's squad in their World Cup qualifier against Malta, Burke has made a big leap to the Bundesliga.
RB Leipzig snapped him up for a tidy £13 million. So, what do we know about this rising star who might just be the player Scotland has been dreaming of?
Burke was born in Kirkcaldy on April 7, 1997, but he grew up in England. He joined Nottingham Forest's youth academy when he was just eight, and before long, he was signing a professional contract.
His first taste of first-team action came as a late sub under Stuart Pearce in a 3-1 Capital One Cup defeat to Tottenham on September 24, 2014.
A short loan stint to Bradford City added some early experience, even though it was a couple of losses in League One.
Once back with Forest, he steadily solidified his spot in the squad, helped along by fellow Scot Dougie Freedman last season.
With a 6'2" muscular frame, you might mistake him for a rugby player at first glance.
By December, he found the back of the net against Cardiff City, marking his first goal for Forest and nudging out his namesake, Chris Burke, at City Ground.
The elder Burke, once with Rangers, had trials at Kilmarnock before heading to Rotherham United on loan, eventually getting released.
Despite often coming off the bench—18 times in 31 appearances—Strachan saw something special in Oliver.
He got his first Scotland call-up in March, after impressing when Strachan was actually scouting another player, Tony Watt.
When it comes to wingers, some rely on speed, others on skill, and some on sheer power. Burke seems to have a little bit of it all.
Medics in their white gowns and surgical caps are pushing hard for the government to keep a promise from 2013 to bump up their salaries.
As the strike unfolded, dozens of mental health patients reportedly walked out of a Nairobi hospital.

The authorities say the strike's premature—they want talks to continue. They also say the doctors are ignoring a court order that temporarily halts the strike until the month’s end to give room for more negotiation.
But the Kenya Medical Practitioners, Pharmacists, and Dentists' Union (KMPDU) has hit its breaking point, frustrated with the government’s unfulfilled vows.
"We’ve tried everything—lots of diplomacy and dialogue—but enough is enough," said union chair Samuel Oroko.
Around 5,000 medical staff from over 2,000 public hospitals stopped working at midnight on Sunday, leaving hospitals unable to provide emergency services, according to the union.
A BBC correspondent remarked that this puts thousands of lives at risk since many Kenyans can't afford private healthcare.
At a hospital in western Kenya, a Daily Nation reporter overheard a nurse telling a laboring woman to ask the county governor for help.
In Kenya, counties handle some medical staff payments. Amid the strike chaos, at least 50 mental health patients reportedly left Mathare hospital in Nairobi.
Footage from the Standard newspaper showed them scaling the hospital walls and leaving the premises.
Medical staff are demanding the implementation of a 2013 deal between their union and the government, which promised a 300% salary increase for doctors.
The union is also calling for more doctors to be hired to improve the doctor-to-patient ratio, which currently stands at one doctor for every 16,000 Kenyans.
"We’re dealing with a severe doctor shortage, yet our counties say they can't hire more," union representative Gitau Kagona told the Daily Nation.

"These hurdles stop us from delivering quality service in hospitals." During the strike kickoff event, some medical staff symbolically held up empty sacks, pointing to money from a disputed government tender that a businesswoman allegedly carried off in a sack.
They've also started a social media campaign, #LipaKamaTender, meaning "pay like the tenders," suggesting salaries should be paid as swiftly as government contracts.
While there have been scattered protests and strikes over delayed salaries, this is the first strike of such magnitude on this issue nationwide.

Pae Jun-ho, known as Kenneth Bae in the United States, faced accusations from North Korea for allegedly smuggling anti-government materials and plotting against the state, according to KCNA, the North Korean state news agency.
A spokesperson for the Supreme Court denied that Bae was being used as a "political bargaining chip" against the US. Last year, Bae was detained after entering North Korea as a tourist.
In recent history, North Korea has nabbed several American citizens, including journalists and Christians accused of spreading their faith.
These individuals usually found release after interventions by notable Americans like former Presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter, who both made visits to Pyongyang.

The official told KCNA that Bae had been "sent to China as a missionary" and allegedly set up "plot-breeding bases" meant to infiltrate around 250 students into North Korea's Rason port city, aiming to undermine the government.
The spokesperson claimed Bae rallied overseas North Koreans and foreigners to engage in hostile acts to overthrow the government while carrying out a smear campaign.
Bae's complete confession reportedly helped him avoid a death sentence, with officials stating his actions damaged the prestige of North Korea's supreme leadership.
They also pushed back against any claims that Bae’s trial wasn’t transparent or that it served as political leverage.
Bae, 44, was taken into custody in November after arriving in Rason, a special economic zone near the China-North Korea border.
Some South Korean activists suspect he was detained for taking photos of malnourished children, while other stories highlight his devout Christianity.
He was convicted on April 30, amid a period of escalating tension between the US and North Korea after Pyongyang conducted its third nuclear test.
In response to North Korea's nuclear activities in February and a long-range rocket launch in December, the UN had broadened sanctions against Pyongyang in March.
North Korea lashed out at both the sanctions and the joint US-South Korea military drills, threatening US military bases and cutting key communications with South Korea.
This piece covers the pardon of Alan Turing, who was convicted of gross indecency in 1952 and forced to undergo chemical castration.
His arrest came after an affair with a 19-year-old man in Manchester, which led to him losing his security clearance and halting his critical codebreaking work for the Allies in World War II.
The pardon was issued through the Royal Prerogative of Mercy, thanks to Justice Minister Chris Grayling, who wanted to honor Turing's extraordinary achievements.
Grayling pointed out that Turing’s work at Bletchley Park significantly shortened the war and saved countless lives.

In 2012, Turing's legacy was celebrated on the 100th anniversary of his birth. His work allowed the Allies to crack German Naval codes encrypted with the Enigma machine, and it was a game-changer in codebreaking.

This was publicly acknowledged in April 2012. Grayling emphasized Turing’s conviction for homosexual acts as unjust and discriminatory, highlighting the importance of recognizing his wartime contributions and scientific achievements.
The Queen’s pardon, which took effect on December 24, is seen as a fitting tribute.
Turing died in June 1954 from cyanide poisoning, ruled a suicide, though some biographers and friends suggest it might have been accidental.
Many have long campaigned for Turing’s pardon, including Dr. Sue Black, who has also advocated for the pardon of all men convicted under anti-homosexuality laws.
She expressed a desire for broader societal change, condemning the mistreatment they endured.

However, some critics view the pardon as inadequate and merely symbolic. British home computing pioneer Sir Clive Sinclair called it “silly nonsense,” although he recognized the wrongful treatment of such an extraordinary individual.
Prince William wrapped up his last shift on Tuesday, and word is he could be heading back to London to rejoin his regiment, the Blues and Royals of the Household Cavalry.
This move might give him more opportunities to step up his royal duties alongside The Queen.
Reflecting on his time on Anglesey, he called it a "special place," as he concluded a three-year stint there.
Back in August, speaking at the Anglesey Show, he praised the locals for their warm hospitality.
"For both me and Catherine, Anglesey is unmatched in beauty and friendliness," he remarked.
"When my search and rescue role ends next month and we move, we'll miss it dearly.

Huge thanks for welcoming us as you do countless visitors each year." He cherished the island as their first home together, promising it would always remain close to their hearts. "We plan to come back many times with our family," he assured.
Prince William became a qualified search and rescue pilot in September 2010, commencing his training at Valley from January that same year.
His first rescue mission was in October 2010 during his debut full operational shift.
The BBC's royal correspondent, Peter Hunt, tweeted on Tuesday about Prince William's last day at RAF Valley, noting that his future plans haven't been publicly announced yet.
Colin Green, who's got a knack for water economics, says Thames Water could rake in at least £100 million every year with their new project.
The company's pushing for a tunnel as the best way to keep sewage out of the River Thames.
A Thames Water spokesperson stressed that this tunnel is the cheapest fix for the problem, though they're still figuring out who's footing the bill.
Prof. Green from Middlesex University pointed out that current rules let Thames Water get a 4.5% annual return on their investment in the so-called super sewer.
However, he thinks they could borrow the money at just about 2% per year. "We need to shake up the price incentives to change this," he remarked.
Green didn't mince words about the regulatory system, run by Ofwat, which he says encourages spending on infrastructure rather than dialing up efficiency.

According to a Thames Water rep, "Independent experts have done tons of studies, and the Thames Tunnel came out as the cheapest way to handle the 39 million tonnes of sewage flooding into the Thames annually.
But who's paying and building the tunnel? That's still up in the air, and Thames Water might not be the ones to do it.

Ofwat will set the investor's rate of return independently." Green went on to claim that Thames Water's returns will shoot up once they pay off the tunnel's construction loan, although that could take 30 to 40 years.
He added, "Even after those loans are sorted, consumers will keep covering the whole asset's capital value, giving Thames Water a nice 14% return just on the tunnel."

An Ofwat spokesperson threw in, "We're working with Thames Water, Defra, and other folks to back the Thames Tunnel's development and financing, making sure costs stay under control and benefit customers."
Meanwhile, Hammersmith and Fulham Council prefer a cheaper fix for London's sewage woes, like a shorter tunnel.
Councillor Harry Phibbs commented, "The way things are, they can charge customers way more for borrowed money than what they actually pay."
Back in 2014, South Africa's public protector released a report that found Mr. Zuma "benefited unduly" from the fancy renovations at his home.
They recommended that the country's auditor-general and finance minister figure out how much he should cough up to settle the score.
Interesting timing, though—it was just a week before the constitutional court was set to take up the matter.
BBC Africa Live was buzzing with updates about the scandal surrounding President Zuma's Nkandla residence in KwaZulu-Natal.
It's become a political whirlpool. Who'd have thought an amphitheater, swimming pool, and even a cattle enclosure could stir such a mess?
Despite Zuma's proposal to pay back the money, both the opposition Democratic Alliance (DA) and Julius Malema's Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) aren't backing down.
They want a full-on corruption investigation and are pressing forward with their court case.
Post-announcement, the hashtag #PayBackTheMoney began trending in South Africa—courtesy of the EFF MPs who famously echoed those words in parliament last year.
The skepticism persists, though. Milton Nkosi from BBC News weighs in with some analysis.
Zuma's offer to reimburse the funds seems like a strategic attempt to dodge embarrassment at the looming Constitutional Court hearing.

Could it also be tied to the approaching local government elections? The Nkandla fiasco has certainly been a headache for the ruling African National Congress (ANC), troubling them just as they're hustling for votes.
Professor Somadoda Fikeni, a political analyst, hints at Zuma's fragility as his time in office winds down, exacerbated by last year's contentious shuffle of finance ministers.

Maybe Zuma's just trying to avoid another parliament meltdown like last year's opener, where EFF members interrupted his speech by shouting "pay back the money." The interruption got so out of hand that security had to step in.

It was quite the spectacle at the South African Parliament. And speaking of spectacle, why on earth did Zuma ditch two finance ministers in one week? All figures in 2013 financial terms, according to the Public Protector Report.
Students noticed a mistake in the multiple-choice questions that led to two possible correct answers.
As a result, officials decided to validate both answers, and the head of the national exam board offered to resign.
This annual test is a big deal—it's a key factor in determining high school students' academic paths.
South Korean media says about 3,600 to 4,000 students could have their scores affected by the error.
Education Minister Hwang Woo-Yea appeared on TV to express regret and emphasize the need to improve how questions are crafted.

"We're digging into the root cause," he said. The nine-hour College Scholastic Ability Test, taken by about 640,000 students on November 13 at 1,216 sites nationwide, is reported by South Korea's Yonhap news agency.
Students often spend years prepping for this exam, driven by the intense competition and substantial parental pressure, because a great score opens doors to top universities.
The snafu in the biology and English sections fired up complaints from parents and students on the Korea Institute for Curriculum and Evaluation (KICE) website, which oversees the test.
Last year's exam wasn't without its own drama—a world geology question error sparked legal battles, ending with the Seoul High Court ruling in favor of four students challenging it.
"Though we gave it our all to sidestep mistakes this year, yet again we've got questions that have thrown students, parents, and teachers into chaos," said Kim Sung-Hoon, head of KICE.
NATO's Secretary-General, Jens Stoltenberg, recently pointed out that Russia and NATO are at odds over facts, narratives, and who's to blame when it comes to Ukraine.
Since Russia's annexation of Crimea back in 2014, tensions with the West have been simmering.
Recently, a Russian envoy took a swipe at NATO for its military exercise in the Baltic region.
Talks in Brussels, initially scheduled for a certain time, stretched over 90 minutes longer than expected.
At a press briefing, Stoltenberg mentioned that many NATO allies take issue with how Russia frames the Ukraine conflict, arguing it’s not just a civil war.

“This is Russia meddling in eastern Ukraine,” he stressed, “backing separatists with weapons, money, gear, and even oversight.” Stoltenberg admitted that deep-seated differences remain between NATO and Russia after the meeting.
He stressed the need for open lines of communication to sort out disagreements and hopefully reduce the risk of military flare-ups.
Nevertheless, both sides acknowledged the need to uphold the Minsk peace agreement, which, though shaky, has brought about a ceasefire in eastern Ukraine.

Meanwhile, Russia's NATO envoy, Alexander Grushko, accused the U.S. of military intimidation after an American guided-missile destroyer was spotted near Kaliningrad last week. “We intend to counter these threats with all necessary moves,” he warned.
In a related incident last week, two Russian warplanes made close passes over the U.S. ship in the Baltic's international waters—something U.S. officials have labeled as "aggressive."
The NATO-Russia Council, which began in 2002, hasn’t convened at the ambassador level since June 2014, though some political talks have occurred.
Ukraine, along with Western nations, believes Russia is secretly aiding the rebels who've taken control of much of eastern Ukraine, a charge Russia denies flat out.
As a countermeasure, NATO has boosted its military footprint in Eastern Europe, aiming to respond to what it sees as a Russian military build-up.
However, Russia perceives NATO’s growing reach in Eastern Europe as a direct threat to its security.
In a rare sit-down, General Petraeus dove into the tough job of dealing with extremist groups on an "industrial-strength" scale, stressing how military force alone just won't cut it.
Known widely for his involvement in the Iraq war, he was the mind behind the troop "surge" that upped US forces and enlisted Sunni tribesmen to stand with them against al-Qaeda.
These days, Iraq’s army, backed by the US, is fighting tooth and nail to reclaim land seized by IS.
Petraeus doesn't mince words, calling IS "a formidable enemy"—a force that acts like a full-fledged army but still holds a mix of insurgents and terrorists.
Drawing a comparison to al-Qaeda in Iraq, which he played a pivotal role in defeating, Petraeus pointed out al-Qaeda's deeper entrenchment and bigger numbers in Iraq back then than IS has now.
He described IS’s recent capture of Ramadi, the main city in Anbar province, as "a strategic loss" that challenges the idea that IS is on the back foot.
Despite this, he’s confident Ramadi will be back under control in weeks, maybe even less.
Petraeus mentioned this setback calls for a strategic rethink and improvements, which are already in progress.

A quick run through his career highlights: he graduated from West Point in 1974 and joined the army; he led the US troop surge during the Iraq war in 2007; took charge of US Central Command in 2008; became NATO commander in Afghanistan in 2010; jumped ship to the CIA in mid-2011; and resigned in November 2012 due to an affair.
After leading forces in Iraq and Afghanistan, Petraeus moved on to head the CIA, stepping down in 2012 after it came out he had an extramarital affair.
He was accused of sharing classified information with his mistress, which led to a misdemeanor guilty plea.
Despite these personal hurdles, Petraeus remains a significant player in America's military narrative.
He masterminded the "surge," shifting troops from bases out to local areas to boost security.
He also expanded the Anbar Awakening by rallying Sunni tribesmen against al-Qaeda.

Given the hurdles Iraq is facing now, folks from the White House, the Pentagon, and Capitol Hill are tapping into his expertise. Petraeus pushes for syncing political and military game plans together.
The Senate came up short on the vote for the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, with a result of 61-38.
It needed a two-thirds majority to pass. Former Senator Bob Dole, who uses a wheelchair, made an appearance on the Senate floor to show his support.
Dole isn't just any supporter; he's a former Republican presidential candidate and a World War II veteran who was disabled due to his service.
The treaty itself is pretty significant, signed by 155 countries and ratified by 126, including big names like the UK, France, Germany, China, and Russia.
It's all about making sure disabled folks have equal rights and freedoms worldwide.
Senator John McCain from Arizona, Senator Richard Lugar from Indiana, and former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh also backed it, but unfortunately, only eight Republican senators voted in favor.
Some, like Senator Jim Inhofe from Oklahoma, opposed it, worrying about potential increased regulation and bias from international bodies.

The White House didn't hide its disappointment at the majority opposition, pointing out that ratifying the treaty would extend rights that Americans with disabilities already enjoy to those living or traveling abroad.

Senator John Kerry from Massachusetts argued that the treaty is straightforward, saying it simply combats discrimination against the disabled, and reassuring that it wouldn't require any changes to U.S. law.
The treaty builds on the 1990 Americans with Disabilities Act, a cornerstone for the UN treaty developed during George W. Bush's presidency and signed by President Obama in 2009.
The UN claims that around 10% of people globally, roughly 650 million, are living with disabilities.
The Cambridge student, caught up in all the chaos, apparently got the "significance" of the monument but had no clue he was swinging from a war memorial.
Gilmour, from Billingshurst, West Sussex, found himself with a hefty 16-month prison sentence for violent disorder back in July.
He's now trying to get that sentence reduced. The judges heard he had indulged in LSD and Valium before diving into the central London protests against tuition fee hikes last December.
He was spotted clinging to a Union flag on the Cenotaph and leaping onto the hood of a Jaguar that was part of a royal convoy.
The previous judgment from a Kingston-upon-Thames Crown Court judge stated he lobbed a rubbish bin at the vehicle—a point his lawyers are battling in the appeal.

That same crown court judge admitted the Cenotaph incident wasn't part of the violent disorder but blasted it as "outrageous and deeply offensive behavior.” During his antics, Gilmour also kicked a window at Topshop's Oxford Street store and wrapped up his day with a mannequin's leg.
Representing Gilmour, David Spens QC claimed his client didn't recognize the Cenotaph, due to not owning a TV for a decade, making the slip-up "not actually as surprising as might have been thought."
The court heard that Gilmour turned to alcohol and drugs after being rejected by his biological dad, writer Heathcote Williams.
Mr. Spens assured the court that Gilmour has “successfully reformed and rehabilitated himself,” tackling his "underlying drug and alcohol problems."

He argued, “My submission is that this sentence was unduly harsh, unnecessarily so.” The court's decision is on hold while they await other appeals linked to last August's riots, which might influence the outcome of Gilmour's case.
Recently, some folks have seen their tax bills skyrocket by as much as 900%, and they're calling it "ridiculous."
Because of this hike, a good chunk of profits from certain energy projects are ending up with councils, and some projects are even operating at a loss, say reports from BBC Wales.

The Welsh Government has picked up on the issue and is thinking about offering assistance, but the British Hydropower Association hasn't held back its criticism over the lack of action from ministers.
Community Energy Wales also chimed in, stating these changes are really hurting projects.
Now, most community energy initiatives are small and run by volunteers, bringing in money for their local areas.
But the way business rates are being calculated is hitting hydro schemes really hard.
These rates are set by the Valuation Office Agency in England and Wales, though it's the Welsh Government that's in charge of implementing them in Wales.
The British Hydropower Association has reached out to Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford for help.
According to Simon Hamlyn, their CEO, community hydro schemes are teetering on the edge, and might even be abandoned due to these unaffordable rates—something they definitely want to avoid.
Meanwhile, Keith Jones from Community Energy Wales mentioned a typical hike of about 300% that no one saw coming in their financial plans.
Elsewhere, the Scottish government has stepped up with complete business rates relief for community energy projects, while England has topped the increase at £600.
In Abergwyngregyn, Gwynedd, Gavin Gatehouse, involved with the Ynni Anafon hydro project there, shared that their monthly rates have shot up from about £900 to over £2,000.
This project, which took years to get off the ground, has the potential to bring in up to £40,000 a year for local causes.
They even set up a charity to give out grants, but the increase in rates is squeezing what's available.
Over in Bethesda, another community hydro project is bracing for losses. "It's really frustrating, and I'm quite angry," Mr. Gatehouse said.
"Our profits are being slashed because of inadequate government support for local councils."
Mr. Drakeford pointed out that over £210 million in rate relief was set aside for 2017-18 to support businesses, including community energy projects.
He also mentioned there's a plan to roll out a new small business rate relief scheme starting in 2018.
After giving birth to her first son, Dylan, she was met not with cheers, but with the stark news: "We're sorry, but your son has Down’s syndrome."
Despite her nursing expertise and her husband's background in medicine, the negative information they received was overwhelming.

"When your child has a disability like Down’s, they hit you with stats—average life expectancy around 50, that they won't go to mainstream school, all the things they supposedly can't do," she shared.
Fast forward fourteen years, and Dylan is proving them wrong. Now in Year 9 at a regular school, he's part of the Down’s Syndrome GB swimming squad.
This lack of initial support pushed his mom and a couple of others to take action.
When Dylan was little, a health visitor introduced his mom to Katharina Barker and Nicky Williams, both of whom also had children with Down’s syndrome.
They quickly discovered they shared the same frustrations over inadequate support.
Though Katharina had a smoother experience when her daughter Amelie was born, specialist help was still elusive.
"Honestly, it’s frustrating," she confessed, "because without someone showing you, you'll struggle to find the services."
To tackle this, they hosted a coffee morning for parents to connect and share their journeys.
The success of this gathering led to the founding of a charity that offers speech and language therapy, educational resources, and holds annual conferences.
Even though Nicky has stepped away from the Monmouth-based 21 Plus charity, celebrating its 10th birthday, Victoria and Katharina are devoted to expanding its impact.
Their efforts earned them a spot as finalists in the national St David Awards citizenship category.
They aim to assist children with Down’s syndrome in "achieving their potential and accessing more opportunities."
Victoria noted, "One mom told me she loves being able to ask us anything, even those questions she’d feel silly asking elsewhere. That’s why I do it."
On Monday night in Bridport, Dorset, she unveiled her new role during a charity screening of the show's final episode, hosted by Dorset Rape Crisis.
Hesmondhalgh couldn't hide her pride in having "given a voice" to rape victims through the eight-part crime series.

The charity organization was "excited" about her stepping into the role. The third and final series of Broadchurch, which was partly filmed in West Bay, tackled the story of Trish Winterman's rape—a character brought to life by ex-Coronation Street star Hesmondhalgh.
A standout part of the series is the bond between Trish and her rape counselor, Beth Latimer, played by Jodie Whittaker.

Tracy Parsons from Dorset Rape Crisis shared that they worked closely with the show's writer and producer, Chris Chibnall, and commented on how the series's portrayal of support was significant for those touched by rape.
"We're thrilled that Julie has taken on the patron role; it's a massive boost for our trustees, staff, and clients to have her on board," Parsons said.
Hesmondhalgh added, "It's a relief to have offered a voice—even in a small way—to survivors of rape."
Speaking about her new role with Dorset Rape Crisis, she mentioned, "I'm honored to help raise awareness of the essential, life-changing work being done."
She stressed the urgency of discussing rape, highlighting the importance of conversations about consent, respect, and healthy relationships within the family.
Albert Newman ended up driving 30 miles in the wrong direction along the M42, A42, and M1 before crashing into a van.
During the inquest, it was found that one police force didn’t have motorway patrols on duty at the time, and another had earlier missed that Newman’s license had been revoked.
The coroner decided to delay the hearing so more questions could be posed to officers.

Newman, who suffers from dementia and is from Nottingham, collided his Mazda Premacy with a Transit van near Kegworth, Leicestershire, last October, killing passenger Michael Luciw and injuring driver Andy Harrington.
During the inquest, it emerged that Warwickshire police were first alerted about the car going the wrong way on the M42, but they initially recorded the incorrect direction.
They corrected it later, but by then, Newman had moved into Leicestershire on the A42, where the roads policing unit had finished its shift, leaving the area without specialized motorway patrols.
Pamela Oxlade, traveling to Birmingham Airport alongside her husband, shared with the inquest: "We had just overtaken a lorry when suddenly these two balls of light appeared.
It happened so fast and was surreal because the car was just a shadow in the dark.
I called 999 to report it, and they said they were already informed. We mentioned being about half an hour from the M1 heading towards Birmingham.
It was a relief to know they knew." The inquest also revealed that 20 minutes later, Mrs. Oxlade noticed signs advising drivers to slow down due to a car going the wrong way.
Coroner Trevor Kirkman criticized Leicestershire police, saying, "It seems the procedure is poorly executed.

This car traveled a considerable distance without intervention." At the hearing in Loughborough, it came to light that months before the accident, Nottinghamshire Police spoke with Newman about reports of him driving with dementia symptoms.
However, an officer failed to check his paperwork, which would've shown his license was revoked for medical reasons two years earlier.
Mr. Kirkman adjourned the hearing until December to explore if the force could've taken the car at that time.
In closing, a senior Nottinghamshire police officer expressed remorse to the families, admitting the force might have been able to prevent the tragedy.
These days, we tend to picture new inventions popping out of unknown labs, backed by tons of grant money.
But believe it or not, the spirit of the home-grown inventor is alive and kicking.
Just ask David Williams and John Dingley, consultant anesthetists at Morriston Hospital in Swansea.
They had their "Aha!" moment while fiddling in their garages, armed with glue guns and car-body filler.
Inspired by Trevor Baylis’s wind-up radio, they tossed around the idea of creating something similarly affordable and straightforward for the medical field.
With Dr. Williams's stint in remote areas, he saw first-hand how critical it was to have equipment that doesn't rely on a constant power source.
In Zambia, whole operating theaters were just sitting unused, all because they lacked spare bulbs or had unreliable power.

This fired them up to build essential medical tools without breaking the bank. After a week of tweaking standard medical gear with some power tools, they rolled out a prototype called the ShakerScope.
This nifty light source can be used to examine eyes, ears, and throats without the need for batteries.
Dr. Patrick Finlay from the Institution of Mechanical Engineers noted, "According to the World Health Organization, 95% of medical devices fail in developing countries.
Designers in the West often don't account for global conditions. This kind of invention is a game changer.
Typically, you’d need three separate battery-powered instruments for these examinations.
It's just not feasible for low-income countries." The ShakerScope works thanks to a movable magnet surrounded by a wire coil—something Michael Faraday figured out back in 1831.
You shake it for about 30 seconds, and that's enough to light it up for three minutes.
"It might sound short," Dr. Williams commented, "but it’s usually plenty for most ear and eye exams or even placing tracheal tubes."
Once charged, the device holds its power for weeks, and its LED bulb lasts up to 10,000 hours.
Plus, they've designed it with interchangeable heads, so it can morph into multiple devices.
Carl Baker, formerly with MK Dons, made quite the entrance on his debut for Portsmouth, snagging a goal that evened things up against Carlisle after Reggie Lambe had put them ahead.
Carlisle had to soldier on with a player short since Jamie Devitt got a red card just before the break.
Portsmouth came out swinging, their new recruit Milan Lalkovic pushed Carlisle's keeper, Mark Gillespie, to make a terrific save within minutes.
But soon after, Mike Jones threaded a perfect pass to Lambe, who coolly slotted it past David Forde, giving the visitors the early lead.
Not long after, Devitt exited the game, seeing red for tugging on Gary Roberts.
Baker stepped up before halftime, driving a low shot past Gillespie to even the score.
The second half kicked off with Michael Smith narrowly missing a sitter for Portsmouth, while Roberts and sub Kyle Bennett couldn't capitalize on their late chances.
The match wrapped up in a 1-1 draw, according to the Press Association. Baker, aiming for more glory, saw his shot veer right of the goal, and Carlisle swapped David Atkinson in for Jason Kennedy.
After a foul by Luke Joyce, Baker won a free kick in the attacking half. Bennett tried his luck from outside the box but got blocked, then sent another one too high.
A corner conceded by Gillespie led to Michael Doyle’s shot getting saved down low.
Bennett's next attempt missed to the left, Baker followed with a save in the bottom corner.
Noel Hunt came on for Danny Rose, and Baker nabbed a defensive free kick when Danny Grainger fouled him.
Nicky Adams took advantage of a free kick after Doyle's foul. Bennett's strike was saved low; Rose hit the post with a left footer.
Gillespie picked up a yellow, with Rose nearly striking it right. Carlisle shuffled Mark Ellis in for Shaun Miller.
Bennett's last right-footed shot went wide. Portsmouth swapped Conor Chaplin for Smith, with Bennett stepping in for Lalkovic.
At Detroit Metro Airport, an American Airlines plane and a Southwest Airlines plane got too close for comfort while taxiing, resulting in the American plane's wing hitting the Southwest plane's tail.
This happened Wednesday morning around 6:05 local time (11:05 GMT). Thankfully, nobody was injured, and there weren't any fuel leaks.
The Federal Aviation Administration is on the case, planning to investigate what went wrong.
Passengers stayed onboard, and one of them, Fletcher Sharpe, chatted with the BBC about what he experienced as he waited for a replacement flight.
He mentioned that a few folks had remarked on the two planes being unusually close, but he never thought they’d actually collide.
"Suddenly, we heard this loud crunch and scraping sound," he recalled. "I thought something must've been run over.
When I looked, the American plane’s right wing was messed up and the Southwest plane’s tail was busted.
It felt frustrating. Even when driving a car, you gotta make sure there's enough room."
Another passenger, Jim Bishop, shared with Fox 2 News Detroit that they were stuck waiting for about two and a half hours with barely any initial information.

"There was silence for ten minutes," he said. "Then, finally, an announcement came acknowledging the accident and asking folks to stay calm. A steward mentioned that in his whole 35-year career, this was a first."
The temperature was freezing, and they were de-icing the Southwest plane when the mishap occurred.
Both planes were Boeing 737s. After the collision, Southwest Airlines said the plane would need maintenance and was supposed to head to Dallas, with 95 passengers to be rebooked.
The airline appreciated everyone’s patience while working to get them where they needed to be.
American Airlines also apologized for the hassle, rebooking their 150 Dallas-bound passengers onto other flights.
Phil Collins, who’s 66, took a nasty fall on his way to the bathroom and injured himself near his eye.
This happened after his recent back surgery, which makes walking pretty hard for him these days.
He ended up at the hospital where they gave him stitches and he’ll be monitored for the next 24 hours.

Because of this, his concerts on June 8 and 9 have been pushed to November. Unfortunately, the postponement came right before he was supposed to hit the stage, leaving some fans already en route to London.
One fan posted on Facebook: "Sorry to hear that... but we are on a train heading to see him.
#gutted... no idea what to do now ðŸ˜¢." Another said after Wednesday’s show: "Amazing night last night!!!
What a fantastic fan base you have. Get well very soon xxxxxxxx." Collins’ team updated on Facebook that he hit his head on a chair during the fall, but assured everyone he's "recovering well."
He shared his "sincere apologies and thanks to fans," noting that although he’s dealing with "drop foot," he’s had a "fantastic week at his first shows in 10 years."
He really appreciates the warm welcome and can't wait to get back on stage. If you’ve got tickets for the June 8 gig, they’ll be good on November 26, and June 9 tickets are valid for November 27.
Next up for Collins is a stop in Cologne this Sunday, then Paris, before leading BST Hyde Park in London on June 30.

Phil, famous from Genesis, is a powerhouse songwriter and performer. He’s one of only three artists—alongside Paul McCartney and Michael Jackson—to sell over 100 million albums worldwide as both a solo act and band member.
His big hits include "A Groovy Kind of Love" and "Against All Odds." On top of that, he’s snagged seven Grammys, six Brits, an Oscar, and two Golden Globes.
Stay connected with us on Facebook, Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, or Instagram at bbcnewsents. Got a story idea? Shoot an email to entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.
Margaret Thatcher peacefully left this world at 87 on a quiet Monday, April 8, 2013.
Just over a week later, on April 17, a ceremonial funeral was held for her, complete with military honors.

Thatcher definitely stirred the pot from the get-go. When she became prime minister back in '79, she was ready for big changes in the way the country was governed, sparking a transformation across Britain.
She pushed for privatizing government-owned entities like British Gas and BT (British Telecom), convinced private companies could run these services better.
Her policies also opened up opportunities for thousands to buy their council homes, giving them a stake in the community.
Under her leadership, the City of London rose as a global hub for banking and business.

Thatcher's reputation skyrocketed when she made the bold move to send British troops to the Falklands Islands in 1982 after Argentina's invasion, a the tiny group of islands some 8,000 miles away in the South Atlantic.
Though the conflict was costly, resulting in hundreds of lives lost, the victory was widely celebrated back home.
Yet, not all of her policies were met with open arms—some sparked serious controversy and led to public outcry.
In 1984, thousands of miners were up in arms, protesting her plan to shutter numerous coal mines, which would mean losing countless jobs.
And in 1990, the poll tax she introduced ignited clashes in London because critics felt it unfairly burdened the poor rather than the wealthy.
Dubbed the "Iron Lady" for her no-nonsense, steadfast leadership, Thatcher was known for getting by on a mere four hours of sleep each night.
Her legendary life was even given the Hollywood treatment in the 2012 movie, "The Iron Lady."
Holding the title of longest-serving prime minister in the 20th century, she won three elections during her 11 years in power.
Eventually, even her own party thought it was time for her to step aside, leading to her emotional exit from Downing Street.
More than two decades later, she’s still remembered as the prime minister who profoundly reshaped Britain, marking her as one of the most significant figures in modern British history.
The Care Quality Commission (CQC) inspection gave the University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust an "inadequate" rating.
Both the Royal Lancaster Infirmary and Furness General Hospital in Barrow were flagged for needing improvements in patient care.
The trust mentioned that they’re "part-way through a process of significant improvement."

Just last year, the North Cumbria University Hospitals Trust, located in the northern part of the county, was among 11 trusts put under special measures after the Keogh review highlighted higher than average mortality rates.
The CQC’s February inspection did spot some progress in areas such as maternity and A&E, but plenty of issues are still lingering.
One specific concern was the quality of medical care in a part of the Royal Lancaster.
Recruiting nurses and doctors remains a "fundamental" problem, with the trust "relying too much" on temporary staff.

Professor Sir Mike Richards, the chief inspector of hospitals, expressed his disappointment, saying, "The trust has a long history of quality issues, so it is disappointing that many issues are still unresolved.
I do not believe the trust will overcome its challenges without external support."
Inspectors also went to Westmorland General Hospital near Kendal, where they found mostly good service overall.
The trust’s chief executive, Jackie Daniel, admitted, "The reports show we are in the midst of significant improvement, which will take several years to complete.
Changing the culture of a large, complex organization is not an overnight task." You can find the detailed inspection reports on the CQC website.

She sounded pretty sure the Games would bring "honor and pride" to the country. Ms. Rousseff, who's been losing popularity thanks to a tough economic slump, said Brazil would rise to the occasion, pulling off a safe and successful Olympics.
She mentioned that 12,000 people would be chosen to carry the Olympic torch through roughly 300 cities across Brazil next year.
