"We're just 399 days away from the opening of the Olympic Games, and on August 5, the world will turn its eyes on us and witness the lighting of the Olympic flame," Ms. Rousseff announced at a ceremony in Brasilia.
Starting in the capital in May, the torch relay will wrap up at Rio's Maracana stadium during the opening event of the Olympics in August.
The organizing committee, along with sponsors, will be picking torchbearers in the coming months, and each person will carry the torch for a stretch of 300 meters.
The relay's route includes the Federal District, home to Brasilia, and winds through 26 states over about 90 to 100 days.
Security, she highlighted, would be top priority. She urged the thousands of fans who came to Brazil for the World Cup to return for the Rio Games.
Meanwhile, the International Olympic Committee has raised concerns about delays in preparation and pollution in Guanabara Bay, where the sailing and windsurfing events are scheduled.
Authorities say they're aware of athletes' concerns but insist that water pollution won't pose significant health risks during the Games in August 2016.
"We believe we can overcome the challenges ahead," Ms. Rousseff stated confidently.
"We aim to deliver a historic Olympics." This event marks the first time a South American city hosts the Olympics—Rio de Janeiro.
Back in 1943, the fleet's chief medical officer put together a book as a special ninth birthday present for his son.
It’s a fascinating collection, and one of the standout autographs belongs to Flight Commander Henry Melvin "Dinghy" Young.
He was the second-in-command during that daring raid and tragically, he didn’t make it back, shot down on his return flight.
The book eventually found its way to Newark, Nottinghamshire, sold by someone whose dad had gathered these signatures at Scampton’s RAF base in Lincolnshire.
That’s where Squadron 617, famously known as the Dambusters, got its start in March 1943.
In May of the same year, they used Barnes Wallis' innovative bouncing bomb to strike key dams in Germany's Ruhr Valley.

The mission came at a steep cost, with eight out of 19 aircraft lost. Henry Young—known as "Dinghy" because he’d survived two crashes at sea by using a dinghy—was at the controls of an Avro Lancaster dubbed A-Apple during the first wave assault on the Möhne Dam.
The album doesn’t stop with Young’s signature; it includes autographs from other notable crews at Scampton.

There’s Group Captain Robert McFarlane, who later headed a Lancaster squadron in the Battle of Berlin, and Flying Officer Chas Walker, an Australian cricketer turned pilot who died in combat in December 1942.
Some signatures are jazzed up with illustrations: a finely drawn Lancaster soaring, a kangaroo sketched by an Aussie airman, and two cartoon airmen with a cheeky "Jolly good show, what?!"

as a caption. James Brown, the seller of this collection, also had other treasures up for grabs—a silk map retrieved from the charred remains of a Lancaster bomber and his dad’s official flying officer commission.

Chapman's Ice Cream recently made an offer to buy Beavercrest Community School in Markdale for about CA$1 million ($741,000; £596,000), acknowledging the community's significant role in their business journey.

Ashley Chapman, the company's vice-president, shared with the BBC that despite hurdles like regulations and asbestos, they're eager to work with the school board and help fund solutions. "Somebody needs to step up to fix the situation," he pointed out.
He suggested purchasing the building and leasing it back to the school board at a reasonable rate to keep it open.
However, the old building might need millions for repairs, and legal issues complicate private purchase of public assets.
"Our proposal is more of a temporary fix to delay the closure," Chapman explained.
Beavercrest is just one of roughly 600 schools the province plans to close to save money, mainly affecting rural areas.
If Beavercrest shuts its doors, local kids might have to endure up to 90-minute bus rides to reach other schools.
Right now, the school hosts 195 students but can fit 319, according to a recent report from the school board.
Chapman stressed that any changes should focus on what's best for students. Being a Beavercrest alumnus himself, he feels that helping out is both the right thing to do and smart business.
Chapman's Ice Cream, founded by his parents in 1973, is one of Canada's largest producers and has doubled its workforce in the last six years, with more growth on the horizon.
The company faces challenges attracting talent to Markdale, a small town of 1,325, even with boosted wages.
"How can we get new folks to come here if there’s no elementary school?" Chapman wondered aloud.
Last October's surprise appearance of a 33-foot deep sinkhole at Fontmell Close in St Albans, where there once was a clay pit, left quite a mess.
Some folks are still dealing with basic service outages, and the street's still shut down while experts puzzle over what exactly went wrong.
Hertfordshire County Council is pushing to get everything sorted out by Christmas, though.
The sinkhole popped up in the dead of night, and over 50 families found themselves suddenly without power, water, or sanitation.
They've since gotten temporary fixes, but residents are making do with a detour through a nearby heath for now.
The deep dive investigation—using detailed microgravity surveys and drill explorations—pointed a finger at old mine workings as the culprits.
Fortunately, the ground subsidence report indicated there aren't any more major voids lurking around.
Councillor Terry Douris remarked, "We had to figure out why this happened before jumping into repairs.
It's been a tough time for everyone living nearby, and hopefully they can settle back home by Christmas."
As if things weren't hectic enough, resident Ben Bagshawe, who had to evacuate with his very pregnant wife, welcomed their baby boy just a week later.
They've been renting an apartment, thankfully covered by insurance. "It's annoying but not the end of the world," he shared.
Then there's Rosemary and Derek Broom, right next to the sinkhole, who never left.
They declared their road as "the safest place to live in the country" after all the surveying.
Mrs. Broom casually mentioned, "They've checked everything—roads, fields, even the playgrounds. We're not worried a bit."
In a string of tweets on Tuesday morning, the president framed the release of intelligence information as a cunning move to boost U.S. national security priorities.
Later that day, National Security Adviser HR McMaster jumped in, calling Mr. Trump’s actions “wholly appropriate” at a press briefing.
It was probably the smartest approach, given the president's broad powers to declassify info whenever he sees fit.
As Richard Nixon famously said, “When the president does it, that means it is not illegal.” But saying it's justified doesn't make the problem vanish, and a tweet isn't going to put out the fire.

Let’s dive into why that is. First up, the whole impeachment talk. Following a report by The Washington Post, some of Mr. Trump’s harshest critics pounced, accusing him of "treason" and calling for his swift removal.

While carelessly revealing top-secret intel out of sheer ignorance or bragging might not be illegal, it could ignite a political storm that, worst-case scenario for the president, could lead to impeachment proceedings.
This process in the U.S. Constitution is about "high crimes and misdemeanors,” making it more about politics than strict law.
In the House, a simple majority is enough to impeach, kicking off a Senate trial that demands a two-thirds vote to actually remove a president.

As the folks at Lawfare Blog point out, critics might argue Mr. Trump’s actions breached his oath to "preserve, protect, and defend" the Constitution—a broad argument raised in the three serious presidential impeachment attempts in U.S. history.

While it’s possible, it’s certainly not a given, especially since the outcome depends heavily on political dynamics and how the narrative unfolds. Meanwhile, some in Trump's circle might feel like grumbling, "Russians.
Why'd it have to be the Russians?" Allegations of cozying up to America’s geopolitical adversary have shadowed Mr. Trump since he hit the campaign trail.

He’s been under the microscope for his compliments to President Vladimir Putin; several aides remain entangled in investigations into Russian meddling in the 2016 election; his attorney general stepped back from his role due to a nondisclosed meeting with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak; and his first national security adviser was shown the door for fibbing about his Russian ties—and now faces an FBI probe.
Scientists and charities are strongly advocating for the HPV vaccine as a measure to prevent head and neck cancers.
Because HPV is spread through sexual contact, girls aged 12 and 13 are already vaccinated to protect against cervical cancer.
The Welsh government, however, is waiting on guidance from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any changes.

Organizations like Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team are gearing up to send a letter to the Welsh government on Monday, urging them to expand the vaccination program.
They mentioned on the BBC Radio Wales' Eye on Wales show that there’s a growing number of head and neck cancer cases.
Dr. Mererid Evans, an oncologist at Velindre Hospital in Cardiff, pointed out, "In the last decade, I've noticed a shift.
The ones affected are often younger men with families—the average age being 55—and most don’t even smoke."
Jon Antoniazzi from Tenovus Cancer Care added, "HPV is responsible for 5% of cancers worldwide.
The Welsh government needs to take action against these cancers and show they're committed to public health.
It's time to think outside the box and start vaccinating boys now." Since 2008, a school vaccination program has managed to vaccinate 85% of Welsh girls.
The Welsh government has said, "We plan to await the committee's recommendations and will consider any changes suggested for the HPV vaccination program in Wales."
Mrs. Morgan is shaking things up with a plan to revamp what she calls an "outdated, inefficient, and unfair" system.
Her proposal? Cut out the middlemen—the local authorities—and send funds directly to school heads.
Meanwhile, Labour isn't too thrilled, accusing the government of dodging tough questions about potential funding losers.
Mrs. Morgan insists schools need money that "truly reflects their needs," aiming to get those dollars "straight to the frontline," and further diminish the local authorities' role.
This past Monday, the education secretary rolled forward with a plan to implement a new school funding formula for 2017-18, responding to gripes about local funding disparities.
For a bit of perspective, students in Rotherham are getting £500 more each year than their counterparts in Plymouth, even though both face similar disadvantages.

Back in December, a group of MPs, led by Graham Stuart, the former Education Select Committee chairman, pushed for change, pointing out that some areas receive up to £6,300 per student yearly, while others manage with just £4,200.
The government pledges to establish a more uniform method of dishing out the over £40bn core schools budget, aiming to do away with these "historical anomalies."
Thanks to the Chancellor's Autumn Statement, we've got more details, including a national per pupil rate with extra funds for students with additional needs.

Russell Hobby, who leads the National Association of Head Teachers, agrees that shaking up the system for fairer funding is a good call and is rooting for a "significant shift" towards more direct school funding.
But, as always, there's a flip side: Hobby warns of "winners and losers" under the new system, as there's still a lack of clarity on how funds will be divvied up.
Concerns are mounting, particularly for schools in inner London that might face cuts.

Christine Blower, over at the National Union of Teachers, has sounded the alarm that without additional money, these proposals could lead to "significant cuts" for many schools already feeling the squeeze from real-term per-pupil funding reductions.

Malcolm Trobe, interim head of the ASCL head teachers' union, is backing the change-up of the funding mechanism but insists, "Simply redistributing the current funds won't cut it against the substantial real-term cuts school budgets are facing.

We need more investment," he emphasizes. The Department for Education argues the current setup just doesn't match up with real needs anymore, noting big demographic shifts over the last decade, like the doubling of kids eligible for free school meals in Lincolnshire and a near half-drop in Southwark.
Five years back, the Criminal Justice Psychoactive Substances Act hit the scene, bringing with it a sweeping ban across the board.
Before this law was in place, about 100 "headshops" dotted the state, selling legal highs like hotcakes.
But now? They've vanished completely. Det Supt Tony Howard from the Garda Drugs Unit summed it up: "The headshop industry is gone."
He talked about concerns at the time, seeing a wave of young folks trying out these new psychoactive substances—many who wouldn't normally touch drugs.

"They thought they were safe; after all, they were 'legal highs'," he noted. With the ban, selling, marketing, importing, or exporting these substances became off-limits in Ireland, though tobacco, alcohol, caffeine, and meds got a free pass.

Selling legal highs was quite the money-maker back then; there was a shocking incident where firefighters stumbled upon a stash of 450,000 euros (£330,000) locked away in a safe, at a Dublin headshop that was torched.
Since legal highs weren't breaking any laws at the time, the cops handed the cash back to the owner—a situation that would be unlikely now due to the strict ban.
Howard pointed out how swiftly shop owners played ball when the law changed. "The industry saw how tough the legislation was and worked with us by turning over any leftover products," he said.
Should the UK think about following Ireland's lead and put a stop to legal highs?
Now that headshops aren't a thing on the high street, some doubt it's the best way to keep users safe.
Tony Duffin, director of the Ana Liffey Drug Project in Dublin, shared that significant harm still lingers from those substances once sold by these shops.
Many casual users now hop online for psychoactive substances, while regular users are dealing with drug dealers instead.
He added, "New Zealand is working on setting up laws to regulate headshop drugs, so the UK should weigh all the options it has for drug policy," offering food for thought on what's next.
Police issued an alert after getting complaints about two men acting suspiciously near schools in Carrickfergus.
Rumors have spread online with pictures of a clown and his sidekick in a balaclava, causing a stir in the town.
While some folks on social media are saying the police are taking the fun away, officers launched an investigation because parents were worried about their kids being scared by the clown.
On the PSNI Newtownabbey and Carrickfergus Facebook page, a police officer chimed in with, "Fun is fun, but scaring school pupils is another matter."
The clown, who likes to call himself the Carrick "Killer Clown," reached out to the police to say sorry for any upset he caused.
He clarified it was all meant to be a prank, not to frighten anyone or make a big mess.
As another officer mentioned, "He is fully aware of the sensitive nature surrounding schools and photos."
On BBC Radio Ulster's Evening Extra, the clown admitted he'd gotten worried messages from parents.
"That wasn’t the aim. It was meant to be just fun. As a parent myself, I realized there was a problem when someone voiced concern," he explained.
"I talked to the officer in charge about maybe apologizing personally to school heads, but in civilian clothes.
The officer passed along my apology, which was accepted, so hopefully parents will be informed."
Earlier, a post on the Carrick Killer Clowns' Facebook page noted: "Due to mixed reactions to the school photos, they have been removed.
This event was meant to be a laugh, but some parents found it offensive and not humorous."
Not long after, another photo popped up showing them standing outside the Carrickfergus police station.
To save the 1733 portrait of Gambian Ayuba Suleiman Diallo by William Hoare, a whopping £100,000 still needs to be raised.
The entire cost to secure the artwork is £555,000. Contributions are already lined up from the Heritage Lottery Fund, The Art Fund, and the National Portrait Gallery (NPG).
Remarkably, this piece, never shown to the public before, is currently on display at the London gallery.
Diallo came from a wealthy family of religious scholars but was captured at 29 and sent into slavery on an American plantation.
His failed escape attempt led to imprisonment, where he crossed paths with lawyer Thomas Bluett.
Bluett was struck by Diallo's sharp mind and education and helped him move to England.

There, Diallo found a warm welcome among the British aristocracy and scholars. The NPG has noted this painting by Hoare as the first British artwork to depict an African as both an individual and equal.
A spokesperson from the gallery shared with BBC News that the portrait, once privately owned, was auctioned at Christie's in London last December for £554,937.50.
After the sale, Culture Minister Margaret Hodge put a temporary export bar in place—offering a window for UK museums and galleries to gather enough funds to match the purchase price.
Generous grants of £333,000 and £100,000 have come in from the Heritage Lottery Fund and The Art Fund, with the NPG also chipping in.
The Lottery Fund's grant covers the costs for acquiring, conserving, displaying, and touring the portrait to other museums across the UK.
Broadcast journalist and National Portrait Gallery trustee Zeinab Badawi noted, "This portrait is a rare glimpse of 18th-century African presence in Britain.
It would make a powerful addition to the National Portrait Gallery's collection, echoing Britain's diverse cultural heritage."
The strike revolves around last year's decision to offer midwives in England, Scotland, and Wales a 1% pay raise.
During this stoppage, the Department of Health made sure services weren't interrupted.
They claimed that midwives in Northern Ireland got the same deal as those in England.
"While we would've liked to have done more in the 2014/15 period, it's worth noting that midwives and other non-medical staff received at least a 1% pay bump.
On average, taking incremental progression into account, the rise was 3.7%, with some seeing raises as high as 6.7%," a spokesperson explained.

In Northern Ireland, the most senior midwives got this raise as a one-off payment last March, while those in lower pay bands didn't benefit in the same way—most only saw an annual increase of about £1,500.
The Royal College of Midwives (RCM) argues that all midwives should get the 1% raise like their peers across the UK, plus their usual salary progression.
Talks between the Department of Health and various health unions resumed on Tuesday and were described as promising, though more strikes, including plans to claim overtime, are on the horizon.
Amy Leversidge from the RCM criticized the department for "acting cheekily" by suggesting Northern Irish midwives received the same raise as their English counterparts.
She pointed out that those in higher pay bands got a temporary 1% boost in February, which was then rolled back to 2013 levels by April.
According to the union's employment relations adviser, the NHS system's incremental progression based on experience and performance isn't the same as a true pay raise.
"We don't want to wait until February 2016 to see the results; we want to negotiate a solution now," she stated.
Midwife Hazel McAllister told the BBC, "We're just as passionate, caring, and hard-working as our colleagues in other UK regions who got the 1% pay raise.
We feel very undervalued by those refusing to pay up. I've loved being a midwife for 37 years—it's a wonderful profession, but I'm worried about its future."
Liberty Global, Virgin Media's parent company, recently revealed a mix-up in how many new premises Virgin claimed it hooked up in the UK and Ireland back in 2016.
Originally, they said 465,000 places were connected, but after a thorough check, it turns out the real number was 314,000.
Liberty discovered Virgin had been a bit hasty in stating how quickly it could complete these connections.
According to Liberty's regulatory filing, the reported figures included premises where installation was "essentially complete" but not actually finished.
This included around 142,000 sites they expected to connect by early 2017. However, by late February of that year, Liberty realized a bunch of these places hadn’t progressed as they'd thought.
This sparked a review, and they found some connections were "misrepresented" as completed when they really weren’t.

Another 9,000 were accidentally marked done when they weren't. Dan Howdle, a telecoms analyst from Cable.co.uk, told the BBC: "The reporting methods let them jump the gun a bit, but there's no sign of intentional wrongdoing."
He added: "Virgin Media looks to be tackling the issue head-on, but these mistakes can tarnish a brand's reputation."
As a result of Liberty's investigation, four Virgin Media employees have been suspended and could face disciplinary action, maybe even getting fired.
Virgin Media acknowledged this mess-up will affect connection numbers for the first half of 2017.
They’ve also taken steps to speed up Project Lightning, appointing Robert Evans as the new managing director.
From now on, they won't count unfinished connections in their reports. Launched in 2015, Project Lightning plans to connect about four million UK homes and businesses to internet speeds of 300Mbps.
By December's end, Virgin reached 567,000 premises—quite a drop from the initially claimed 718,000.
Her support for menstrual leave and the idea that women should have access to it kicked off quite the debate.

We've gathered some of your thoughts and experiences on the matter. While we push for equality in pay and jobs, some argue taking an extra "day off" every month for being a woman doesn’t really promote equality.
It hints that women might not work as effectively as men, undercutting the call for equal treatment.
I'm a woman, and I manage to work just as well as any man, periods and all. If some women have more severe issues, maybe they should check with their doctors—it's their personal matter!
—Charlotte Rachael, Halifax, UK For me, the pain can last for up to two weeks straight.
I've even fainted at work due to temporary anemia and sometimes have to pause and lean against a wall on my way to the office.
Still, I don’t feel the need to take sick leave or think we should have additional leave.
Women experiencing severe symptoms should continue seeking help from their GP. Offering extra leave could lead to misuse by women who aren't suffering but just want more time off.
—Lyndsey Victoria Corp, Barnsley, UK Unfortunately, issues like these can also contribute to lower salaries in male-dominated fields.

If we're aiming for equality, maybe we need to toughen up. —Valerie Richardson, Oregon, US The idea of menstrual leave makes some sense, but if it’s unpaid, it could actually widen the wage gap because fewer hours mean lower pay, which concerns many.
If it were paid, those taking leave would need to work harder to make up for it, or else an earnings gap might form.
And hey, time off for pain isn’t a vacation, but it doesn’t contribute to a company's bottom line either.
Maybe government support could be an answer, though I’m not really a fan of too much intervention.

—Alex, Dundee, UK I truly feel for women who genuinely struggle. As a woman and head chef, there have been times when I've had to steal a minute in the walk-in fridge just to cool down and avoid passing out. I face the same challenges and pains.

Which event surprised us more: the first positive steroids test in Scottish rugby’s history, or the backlash against Scottish, Welsh, and Irish teams making it into the Heineken Cup from a league without relegation?
It’s a tough call. But for now, let’s delve into the steroids issue, and save the Heineken Cup chatter for later.
So, Sam Chalmers—who happens to be the son of the well-regarded player Craig Chalmers—came forward to apologize, saying he got the steroids online.
Sounds like he’s painting himself as a “lone wolf,” doesn’t it? But was he really alone in using them?
Did he confide in anyone? According to some youth rugby coaches, the connection between weight training and supplement use can't be ignored.

No doubt, players feel the push to bulk up—while the rugby field has stayed the same size for 150 years, people certainly haven’t. Nowadays, brute force often takes precedence over nimbleness on the field.
What I can't accept? The idea that players feel they’ve got no choice but to turn to steroids.
That’s flat-out cheating. Buying steroids? It’s about breaking the rules, hoping to slip under the radar of drug testers.

Sure, some guys might think about steroids and ultimately decide against it. And hey, if you’re not innately big enough, maybe rugby isn’t your thing. It’s not really a sport for any and every body type anymore.
Young players often go heavy on supplements—before, during, and after their training—possibly thinking they can't hit their targets with regular food alone.
This mentality could push them toward the risky conclusion that unnatural aids, like steroids, are a 'must.'

Now, can size be gained from a purely natural diet? Let’s turn to the IRB’s 2012 stats—there were 1,542 tests inside and outside of competition spanning IRB tournaments like the HSBC Sevens World Series, Rugby World Cup 2015 qualifiers, Test matches, and Age Grade Rugby.
After the attacks, files turned up on a computer that someone had tossed into a trash bin, according to a well-informed source.
This computer had a final message from Ibrahim el-Bakraoui, one of the airport bombers.
The Belgian authorities have now identified all 32 victims who died on March 22.
Among them, 17 were Belgian nationals, with the other 15 coming from various countries. There are still 94 people in the hospital, many in serious condition.
The first funeral was for Raghavendran Ganeshan, and his remains were returned to Chennai, India, on Tuesday.
The computer was discovered the day after the Brussels attacks, in a bin on Max Roos Street in Schaerbeek.
The three suspects captured on airport CCTV had left their hideout on this street, taking a taxi, and it was their driver who led police to the spot where explosive materials were later found.

According to De Tijd newspaper, the files on this computer included information and images of the prime minister's building and office at 16 Rue de la Loi (or Wetstraat in Dutch), as well as details about his official residence on Lambermont Street.
It's unclear if the bombers took these images themselves or just pulled them from the internet.
A spokesperson for Mr. Michel said security at these sites had already been stepped up before the attacks due to existing vulnerabilities.
The chancellery is next to the US embassy and is on the same street as Maelbeek metro station, where Ibrahim el-Bakraoui's brother set off a bomb a little over an hour after the airport attack.

This computer has now become a key piece of evidence for Belgian authorities as they try to find the third airport suspect, who ran off when his suitcase didn't detonate. In his final message, Ibrahim el-Bakraoui expressed feeling hunted and unsafe.
It's been reported that the FBI has copies of hard drives linked to the Brussels attack suspects.
Meanwhile, Brussels airport remained closed for flights on Wednesday after a test involving hundreds of staff members.
The airport announced that flights wouldn't resume until at least Thursday afternoon as they were still assessing trial results. They've set up a temporary check-in area and increased security.

Flights will only start again at 20% capacity, and CEO Arnaud Feist mentioned that a full reopening could take months, requiring a thorough overhaul of the departures hall, including everything from air conditioning to check-in desks.
Several airlines have rerouted flights to Liege, Antwerp, Ostend, and Charleroi.
On Wednesday, Kevin McGuigan Sr was tragically shot at his Comber Court home in the Short Strand.
The police figure two men pulled the trigger, hitting him multiple times in the head and chest from close quarters.
They made a quick getaway afterward. The BBC mentioned the 53-year-old was one of several suspects in the murder of Gerard 'Jock' Davison last May.
Sinn Féin denies any Provisional IRA involvement in McGuigan's death, while the DUP has warned there'll be "repercussions" if these claims ring true.
A father of nine, McGuigan was rushed to the Royal Victoria Hospital but didn’t make it.
Vincent Kearney, BBC Northern Ireland's home affairs correspondent, described the killing as a "professional, execution-style" hit by two masked fellas wielding semi-automatic weapons.
Detective Chief Inspector John McVea, heading up the investigation, noted the gunmen were on foot, decked out in dark gear and had their faces covered.
He issued a call for anyone who might know what these guys were up to before and after the shooting to speak up.
Before this, McGuigan was questioned by officers about the murder of 47-year-old Jock Davison in Belfast's Markets area three months back.
Davison, who used to be an IRA commander and McGuigan's friend, grew embroiled in a feud with him.
Together, they started the paramilitary group Direct Action Against Drugs (DAAD), known for going after and killing more than a dozen alleged drug dealers.
The feud got nasty, with McGuigan reportedly surviving a "punishment attack" supposedly ordered by Davison.
Det Ch Insp McVea acknowledged there’s been a lot of chatter about what sparked McGuigan's murder but emphasized that McGuigan wasn’t seen as a suspect in Davison’s murder, just a possible witness.
He cautioned that speculation can be risky, urging everyone to let the investigation run its course and to share any useful info.
McVea did leave a bit of room about McGuigan being a suspect, stating at a press conference that Davison’s murder case is still open to all leads.
He also called on community leaders to help lower tensions and encourage calm and restraint during these tough times.

Britain's choice to leave the EU has definitely stirred the pot. Some folks think it's a smart move for the nation, but others have their doubts, worrying that Russia might end up being the big winner here.
There's been a fair share of criticism aimed at David Cameron. People across Europe are saying he put his party's interests above the country's by calling for the referendum.
Take Jevgeny Ossinovski, Estonia's Health and Labour Minister—he took to Facebook to accuse Cameron of gambling with Europe's future.

Eiki Nestor, the Speaker of the Estonian Parliament, questioned Cameron's ability as a leader, pointing out that while he wasn't misleading the Brits into voting, he seemed more concerned with election results than with the fate of the UK and Europe.
Vaira Vike-Freiberga, the former President of Latvia, tweeted that Cameron will go down in history as a less-than-stellar British prime minister.
Audronius Azubalis, a Lithuanian conservative figure, saw the referendum as a showcase of "political irresponsibility."

And, in another corner of social media, Lithuanian journalist Algis Ramanauskas didn't hold back, saying, "Despite my affection for Britain, it’s easy to see there are plenty of fools there too.” That post got over 1,000 likes, showing he's not alone in his skepticism.
Yet, despite the criticisms, Brexit supporters are alive and kicking, especially among Baltic Eurosceptics online.
Estonian MEP Martin Helme embraced the Brexit outcome, declaring it a "joyous day for freedom and national independence" and even likened 'Land of Hope and Glory' to a kind of second anthem.
Lithuanian journalist Andrius Uzkalnis saw the vote as a stand against "European integration zealots," reflecting the Brits' frustration with the constant lecturing.
And just to make things even more interesting, he added, "No worries, Trump will also get elected."
Even Estonian analyst Ahto Lobjakas weighed in, criticizing the intense calls for tough EU-UK negotiations post-Brexit.
He tweeted, "Why assume the EU's sole option post-Brexit is the UK's honor killing?"
Meanwhile, in Latvia, pro-Russian activist Aleksandr Gaponenko saw Brexit as a golden opportunity for Latvia to follow suit, announcing plans to collect petition signatures.
He's expecting a crackdown on signatories, which he believes would lead to widespread European condemnation—and possibly even Latvia's expulsion from the EU.
In Latvia, in particular, there's a sense among some that Russia stands to gain the most from Brexit.
Swiss curator Hans Ulrich Obrist has snagged the top spot on ArtReview's Power 100 list once again, repeating his 2009 feat.
This year, Adam Szymczyk from Poland has made quite the leap, moving from 14th place to second.
Meanwhile, art dealers Iwan and Manuela Wirth, who were at the top back in 2015, have now settled into third.
Oliver Basciano, who serves as Deputy Editor at ArtReview, shared with BBC News that "Hans Ulrich Obrist is everywhere.
He's got this far-reaching network that ties together artists, thinkers, scientists, curators, and more, which lets him propel ideas.
Nowadays, contemporary art is more about ideas than physical objects." Over in the US, art dealer David Zwirner has slipped to fourth.
Sir Nicholas Serota, after announcing he's leaving Tate after 30 years to head the Arts Council, stays in the fifth spot alongside Frances Morris, the newly-minted director of Tate Modern.
Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, now ranked 10th, has taken quite a dive, losing nine spots.
Notable newcomers include feminist theorist Donna Haraway at 43, UK artist Ed Atkins at 50, and the Indian art group Raqs Media Collective at 86.
This ranking is shaped by a panel of 16 judges—writers, artists, curators, and critics—who assess power and influence over the year.
You can check out the full list on ArtReview's website. Keep up with us on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, follow us on Instagram, or send your story ideas to entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.
The beach where Seifeddine Rezgui unleashed Tunisia's deadliest terror attack, pulling a Kalashnikov from his parasol on that fateful Friday, has already reopened.
Camera crews hover around, capturing the scene, while passersby pause, lost in thought.

The deep emotional scars left by the tragedy will linger for a generation. For Sabi, who's 57 and looks after the boat club mainly frequented by Hotel Imperial guests—the attack's target—the wounds are far from healed.
He points to the very spot where Rezgui first showed up, made a call, then tossed his phone into the sea before starting his deadly rampage.
"People were falling all around me," he recalls, "and I just grabbed as many customers as I could and ran."
They made their escape through a staff gate into a hotel basement, yet Sabi went back to save more. "I lost six of our loyal guests, folks who came here regularly.
They were like family. This beach should be bustling, but it's deserted now." Looking at the lined-up, vacant sunbeds, Sabi's voice wavers, and tears well up.
"We'll keep fighting," he says. "At least we can still smile." Tunisia is in shock, with its vital tourism sector hit hard.
Thousands of vacationers have already left on emergency flights arranged by tour operators.
I watched another busload leave the Hotel Imperial and head to Enfidha airport on Saturday night, destined for Manchester.
Among them was a man whose fiancée had died right in front of him. Most were too traumatized to talk.
Yet, at nearby hotels, many guests are staying put. "I wanted to leave early," says Isabelle Campbell from Gateshead, "but my husband said: if we leave, they win.
I'm still nervous about the beach though." Her husband, Bob Taylor, chimes in about a moment earlier on, when they noticed a speedboat in the water, its engine revving toward them.
"For a second, we thought: Oh God, something's happening again. We switched from Egypt to Tunisia because of security concerns back there," he shares.
"Now, who knows what's next for this place?" With one in ten Tunisians employed in tourism, the industry, already reeling from the Bardo museum attack in March, faces a downward spiral.
This only adds to the anxiety over the frightening rise in Islamist attacks across Tunisia.
In the US, the film raked in an impressive $204.6 million (£132 million), based on initial estimates.
This makes it the second-biggest opening weekend ever, right behind 2012's Marvel's The Avengers, which pulled in $207.4 million (£133.8 million).
So, what made this film such a hit? Well, Chris Pratt seems to be a big factor.
After years of playing supporting roles and gaining recognition for his comedic work on Parks and Recreation, Pratt's become one of Hollywood's most bankable stars over the last year.
Back in 2014, he starred in two of the top five highest-grossing films at the US box office: The Lego Movie and Guardians of the Galaxy.
Pratt has a knack for mixing charm, vulnerability, and humor, injecting humanity into even the most CGI-heavy blockbusters.
This was clear in Guardians, a movie that featured a talking raccoon and a giant animated tree, yet still managed to earn a whopping $774 million (£499 million) globally.
It was the third highest-grossing movie of that year. Pratt's looks certainly don't hurt his appeal either.
Let's talk China—Hollywood's second-largest film market after the US, known for its tight restrictions, allowing just 34 foreign films each year.
So snagging a spot on that list is crucial for boosting box office numbers. Unlike most Hollywood flicks that hit China later than the US, Jurassic World launched simultaneously in both regions.
Released across 66 international markets, it pulled in $307.2 million (£198 million) worldwide, with a hefty $100.8 million (£65 million) from China alone—that's almost 20% of the global take.
Back when the original Jurassic Park came out, IMAX screens were mostly reserved for short films and documentaries.
Fast forward to today, and there are about 800 IMAX screens worldwide, giving audiences the chance to see dinosaurs in larger-than-life detail.
Watching a T-Rex in 3D has enticed viewers to buy those pricier tickets for a more immersive experience, significantly boosting box office sales.
In fact, Rentrak, a box office analysis firm, reports that nearly half of Jurassic World's US earnings came from 3D showings.
Finally, Steven Spielberg's 1993 blockbuster, Jurassic Park, holds a special place in the hearts of many.
It was a game-changer for CGI and one of the defining films of the '90s, capturing the imaginations of an entire generation.
Bryce Dallas Howard, from Jurassic World, told the BBC, "I was 12 when Jurassic Park came out, and it blew me away.
Watching it felt like seeing real dinosaurs." Her co-star Chris Pratt chimed in, "I was 13 and felt the same way."
The US recently slammed what it called the "extra-judicial release" of certain detainees, labeling it "a major step backwards."
These individuals are part of a group of 88 prisoners who were originally in US custody but got handed over to Afghan control back in 2013.
While the US insists these folks are "dangerous individuals," Afghanistan contends there just isn't enough evidence against them.

Earlier this month, the Afghan government moved to release 72 of these prisoners, prompting the US to quickly voice its disapproval, asserting there was "strong evidence" tying them to "terror-related crimes."
Since Afghanistan took over Bagram jail in March last year, hundreds of detainees have walked free.

However, letting these 88 go has stirred up a lot of controversy. For 45 out of the impending 72 releases, the Afghan authorities say there's zero evidence, and for the other 27, what they have isn't enough to bring to trial.
The US claims that setting any of these men free violates the agreement made when Bagram was handed over to Afghanistan.
"The ARB [Afghan Review Board] is sending back into society dangerous insurgents who've spilled Afghan blood," the US military stated, reacting to the news that 37 detainees were cleared for release.
Among these 37, the US noted, 17 are linked to bombings, while others either had knowledge of or took part in attacks that harmed or killed Afghan and coalition troops.

There's also been a broader disagreement between the two nations due to President Hamid Karzai's reluctance to sign a security agreement with Washington, which is crucial for outlining how the US will wrap up its presence in Afghanistan.
As per the UN Security Council's mandate, the US-led international forces are set to pass all security duties to Afghan forces before pulling out entirely by the end of 2014.
If a "Security and Defence Cooperation Agreement" gets signed, it could allow around 10,000 US troops to stay in Afghanistan for up to 10 more years.
Batsman Joe Root seems to be the prime candidate to take over from Alastair Cook, who stepped down on Monday after a record-setting stint of leading England through 59 Tests.
Since May 2015, Root has been right there alongside Cook as the Test vice-captain.

Root's Yorkshire roots have shaped a younger, energetic player. "He may come off as quiet, but don't let that fool you—he's got a fiery spirit and is quite impressive," Anderson shared on The Tuffers and Vaughan Cricket Show.
If Root gets the nod at 26, he'd actually be stepping in a year earlier than Cook did back in August 2012.
Root's been on a roll since his debut on December 13, 2012, racking up a remarkable 4,594 Test runs.
Only India's captain Virat Kohli edges him out with international runs, having nabbed 8,536 across all formats compared to Root's 8,469.

Anderson, who tops England's Test wicket-takers, knows a thing or two about captaincy changes, having seen five full-timers since May 2003—Nasser Hussain, Michael Vaughan, Kevin Pietersen, Andrew Strauss, and Cook—with Andrew Flintoff pinch-hitting for a time in 2006 and 2007.
Anderson muses, "Root's wise beyond his years; he excels at one-on-one talks." It's a big deal, really, since Root is their star player, and you want to ensure his game stays strong.
Though England's next Test isn’t until July, it's going to be a packed summer with seven home Tests against South Africa and the West Indies, culminating in the Ashes down in Australia come November.
Root had a stellar 2016, smashing 1,477 Test runs, with centuries against South Africa, Pakistan, and India, and adding 796 in ODIs and 297 in T20s.
Anderson admires his passion: "His love for the game is something special, especially for someone who's achieved so much."
Root's been stepping in whenever Cook needed a breather, making key strategic decisions.

He's definitely shown leadership chops. Root's experience captaining Yorkshire is notable too, having led them four times in the County Championship, including snatching the 2014 title when regular captain, Andrew Gale, was suspended.
Plus, he captained Yorkshire again when Middlesex, under Australian Chris Rogers, broke records with a score of 472-3 and secured a win by seven wickets that very year.
So, you've savored a fiery chicken wing in Angola or a zesty "yassa poulet" in Senegal recently?
Well, that chicken might have quite the travel story, probably coming from places like Brazil, Germany, or other EU countries, frozen for the journey.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture reports that chicken imports to sub-Saharan Africa have skyrocketed—tripled, in fact, between 2004 and 2014.
But why's this happening, and what can be done to boost local poultry production?
Let's dive into four key reasons behind this trend and some ideas on how to beef up (or rather, "chicken up") Africa's poultry industry: 1) So, Why Chicken Over Beef?
There's a massive demographic shift coming; Africa's population is on track to double to 2.5 billion by 2050, which means meat demand is going through the roof, with chicken leading the race.
"Chicken reigns supreme for most Africans," says Kevin Lovell from the South Africa Poultry Association.
Beef prices can be pretty steep, and pork is off the menu in certain areas due to religious practices.
With more folks living in cities, there's a growing appetite for local fast-food joints and global franchises.
Kentucky Fried Chicken, for example, is making its mark with over 700 outlets spread across 13 African nations.
"Meat production can't keep up with this insane demand growth," explains Calestous Juma, a Harvard professor specializing in International Development.
It's eye-opening! The World Bank paints a picture where by 2030, half of Africa's population—over half a billion people—will be city dwellers, up from 36% in 2010.
2) Feeding the Birds: Remember the good ol' "road runner" chicken wandering freely in backyards?
Known for their toughness and taste, these birds mostly survive by their own wit, offering nutrition or a little extra cash with minimal fuss.

But scaling up farming involves feed supplies, mainly maize and soy. Due to weak agricultural systems in Africa, feed sometimes needs importing, raising costs and stalling farmers' plans to increase grain output.

So, here's the scoop: Mobile operators, Culture Secretary Maria Miller, and communications regulator Ofcom are gearing up to chat about speeding up the spectrum allocation to get faster mobile download speeds rolling.
Ofcom reckons they can fast-track this process, possibly kicking off 4G networks around May or June, rather than waiting till the end of the year as initially thought.
Even before the meeting, O2’s been pretty upbeat about launching their 4G services by summer 2013.

O2's chief exec, Ronan Dunne, sounded pretty positive when he said, "It's been a very good process, and it feels like we've made significant progress, so I'm hopeful we'll have a basis for moving forward."
Yet, he couldn’t hide his impatience, adding, "We're pleased with the progress but frustrated by the time it has taken."
An Ofcom spokesperson cleared the air, blaming litigation—both real and threatened—for the long wait.
O2 and Vodafone especially weren't thrilled when the rival network EE, previously known as Everything Everywhere, got the green light to use its existing 1,800MHz spectrum for 4G ahead of the others.
O2 even considered hitting the legal route to block EE's edge. Now, there's a possible deal in sight that might see EE announcing its 4G launch date by the month’s end.
O2 and Vodafone, on the other hand, have to hang tight until the older radio spectrum bits, which were for analog TV and air traffic control, are cleared and sold.
The UK's fourth-largest network, Three, isn’t in the running for EE’s 4G spectrum until September 2013.

Ofcom hinted at possibly nudging its airwave auction forward by two weeks from the January schedule, aiming to speed up the frequency transfer and effectively cut EE's head start to around half a year.
But if any legal spanners get thrown in the works, delays could crop up. "Ofcom made a clever move by letting EE launch early," commented Matthew Howett, a telecoms analyst with Ovum.

"It's really set things in motion and will push others to act." Meanwhile, a major network source told the BBC they're seeking assurance from EE not to obstruct Mitco, a group tasked with sorting out potential 4G interference with other signals, like digital TV.
Back in the early '90s, a woman, who was just 14 at the time, told detectives she believed Robert Howard had tried to assault her in his Castlederg apartment.
Fast forward to August 1994, and Arlene, only 15, disappeared without a trace. Her body was never found, but Howard, who died in prison last year, was the prime suspect all along.
After the incident, this woman, who remains unnamed for legal reasons, had warned Arlene to stay away from Howard.
Describing him, she mentioned his unnerving stare, saying, "He’d glare at me in a way that was really unsettling."
Most of the visits to Howard’s place were uneventful until one terrifying day. Recalling that day, she said, "I thought we were just playing hide and seek," but things quickly took a dark turn.
"I was scared Bob Howard would attack me, and luckily, I got away," she shared.
She yelled for Donna Quinn, Howard’s girlfriend’s teenage daughter, who was in another room.
Fearing the worst, she thought, "He might assault me, and I had to act." She managed to knee Howard and escape.
Finding Donna sitting in another room, she left and cut ties with both Howard and Donna.
She kept quiet about what happened for years, only opening up to detectives in 2002.
Describing that time, she admitted, "It was a living nightmare I had to block out."
Howard was later found guilty of assaulting another teenager and murdering Hannah Williams in London.
Meanwhile, back in Castlederg, Arlene vanished after a night out at a disco in County Donegal in 1994.
A social worker at the inquest noted the difficulties Arlene faced, especially after losing her mom in 1990. It was Michelle McKernan who reported Arlene missing in August 1994.
Kell Brook, the IBF welterweight champ hailing from Sheffield, is taking a bold step up two weight classes to go toe-to-toe with Gennady Golovkin, the undisputed world middleweight champion.
The clash is set for September 10 in London, and it's shaping up to be one heck of a showdown.
At 30, Brook is one of 14 world champs from Britain. He told BBC Sport, "Beating Golovkin would make me the top pound-for-pound fighter in the world.
Back in the day, winning a world title was a national sensation. Nowadays, it feels a bit routine, like, 'Oh look, another British world champion.'

To really make waves, you’ve got to pull off something extraordinary." Brook’s record is spotless—36 wins, no losses—and he has defended his IBF welterweight title three times since snatching it from Shawn Porter, an American, back in 2014.
Critics, though, have mentioned the caliber of opponents he's faced hasn't been top-notch until now.
Golovkin, the 34-year-old knockout artist from Kazakhstan, also stands unbeaten in 35 fights, bagging 32 wins through knockouts.
With a jaw-dropping 91% knockout rate, he's etched his name in world middleweight championship history.
Brook is pumped: "The buzz is incredible—this is a mega-fight. It's not your regular champ-versus-champ deal; it's the biggest showdown in boxing right now. Two undefeated heavy hitters facing off?
You don’t see that every day. And I'm moving up two classes, taking on a guy others shy away from.
You really don’t wanna miss this." Brook is aiming to pull off what compatriot Amir Khan couldn’t.
Khan took the leap up two weight divisions to face Saul Alvarez, the WBC titleholder at the time, but was KO’d after six rounds.
As for Golovkin, with WBA, WBC, and IBF titles in his belt, he's among the most avoided opponents in the ring. Saul Alvarez even opted to vacate his WBC title rather than fight him.
Mr. Blair stressed that the party he once led should focus on governing rather than acting like a "fringe protest movement."
He's been quite outspoken in his criticism of Jeremy Corbyn, warning beforehand that under Corbyn's leadership, the party could face "annihilation."
When Blair's remarks appeared in the Spectator, Corbyn's office chose not to comment.
Blair wrote: "All parts of the Labour Party that still aim to govern, as opposed to protesting from the sidelines, see the tragedy in the party's current state."
While Blair didn't name Corbyn directly in his article, his comments underscore the inner conflict about the party's future.
Despite most Labour MPs being against Corbyn's leadership bid, he secured a strong victory with over half the membership's votes.
Tensions flared especially after a Commons vote on air strikes in Syria, which led to some MPs experiencing online abuse for supporting military action.

Corbyn has made it clear that "abuse and intimidation" are unacceptable. There's also a worry that moderate Labour MPs could be ousted due to the grassroots Momentum group's influence, though the group has denied this.
Blair defended the party's legacy during his leadership, saying it "effectively discarded" socialism's strict ideological ties.

However, he admitted the party "fell short" on certain tough decisions, with significant parts of the membership unhappy with the "compromise" and "pragmatism" demanded for governing, seeing it as a betrayal of Labour's mission.
Looking ahead, Blair argued for "more modernizing and less ideological thinking" to tackle issues like housing shortages and social exclusion.
"We risk not even asking the right questions," he warned, "much less finding the right answers."
Many current Labour members feel the party "lost its way" while in power, but Blair concluded, "I believe we found it."

He acknowledged, "Despite our efforts, we didn't persuade enough people that true progressives are always modernizers—not because they give up principles, but because they bravely uphold them in the face of reality."
Kicking off the season’s lineup is "All My Sons," brought to life by Talawa, a black-led theater company.
This gripping play zeroes in on Joe and Kate Keller, an all-American couple dealing with the heart-wrenching loss of their son after World War II.
Michael Buffong, the director, recently chatted with arts correspondent Tim Masters about why this drama has earned the status of a 20th-century classic.
Buffong points out that touring "All My Sons" during Arthur Miller’s centenary adds a special layer of attention to an already remarkable work.
Although the timing wasn’t planned, it's certainly one of those delightful surprises.
So, what makes "All My Sons" resonate as an American classic? Well, its themes strike a universal chord, examining the American dream’s allure and its steep costs.
The narrative plunges into issues of loyalty, trust, betrayal, family secrets, and what happens when illusions crumble under harsh truths.
Joe Keller’s blind spot is obvious—his intense family loyalty leads him to justify actions solely for familial benefit, forgetting about wider societal responsibilities.
That's where he trips up. Reflecting on the five-star reviews from the 2013 production, is there a sense of pressure this time around?
Buffong confesses he hasn't let it weigh him down—overthinking could keep him up at night. In theater, you're guaranteed to encounter reviews, good or bad.
So, what's different for this tour? Tackling a classic anew always uncovers fresh insights.
With half the cast being newcomers, there's a natural infusion of fresh energy, showcasing the play’s lasting richness.

Does a black cast bring something unique to the table? Certainly—it adds layers, especially when portraying a black family chasing the American dream, raising the stakes given the backdrop of black history in the U.S.
Still, at its core, it remains a story about an all-American family. Since Buffong took over Talawa in 2012, he feels he's still just getting started on this exciting journey.

Even if the two governments see eye to eye on some matters, like free trade within the single market, Carwyn Jones wasn’t thrilled when he realized he never got a peek at that letter before it went public on Wednesday.
He wasn’t the only one caught off guard—most of Mrs. May’s cabinet felt the same.
Chatting with AMs, the first minister mentioned, “I talked over the Article 50 letter with the prime minister generally during our Swansea meeting last week.
But, to be frank, today’s the first time I’ve actually seen it, and we didn’t get a chance to help draft it.
That’s just not okay. It’s been a pretty infuriating process where devolved administrations have repeatedly been brushed aside.

Especially seeing that the UK government claims it wants to negotiate in a way that includes the entire UK.” Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns had his own take, saying, “That reaction's a bit disappointing.
The prime minister’s been to Wales three times just in the last six weeks. We’ve been talking about the letter’s content for ages.

Everyone’s chipped in, but the UK government’s gotta think about the whole UK, including Wales.” And while Mrs. May did remember to mention Wales in her note to Donald Tusk, she noted, "Once powers return to the UK, we’ll consult thoroughly to decide which should stick around in Westminster and which should go to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.
The government expects this will greatly boost decision-making power for each devolved administration."
While Scotland might've been the focus, there are some pressing questions: Which powers are getting redistributed?
Does this cover farming or economic aid? And, maybe most crucially, will these powers come with funding?
Alun Cairns didn’t dive into these, but Carwyn Jones flagged worries that no extra funding would accompany the powers after 2020.
This hints that Mr. Jones doesn’t see Jeremy Corbyn snagging power that year, despite Labour's vow to keep EU funding levels for regional aid post-2020.

Some folks in Whitehall think the way EU funds were managed in Wales—as shown in Nick Clegg’s film about Ebbw Vale—gives reason to move powers back to Westminster, but politically, that seems off the table now.
The Board of Community Health Councils (CHCs) in Wales isn’t saying much about why Tony Rucinski, their chief executive, got suspended.
Before his suspension, emails show Rucinski expressing worries that the board's chair, Mutale Merrill, might’ve been swayed by a government minister to stop him from doing media interviews.
Merrill has denied these claims, calling the emails not "factually correct," and Rucinski's been told to keep quiet.
The organization, which likes to call itself the "independent voice of patients" in Wales and oversees seven CHCs, had a budget of £3.8 million for 2015-16.
Rucinski took on the new role of chief executive in July 2015, telling BBC Wales back then that he aimed to "make things happen" and turn CHCs into a "more proactive and effective patient voice."
But just four months later, the Welsh Government appointed Merrill as the new chair, and by February 2016, Rucinski was suspended.
Sources told BBC Wales there was already tension brewing between Rucinski and Merrill.

According to emails obtained by BBC Wales, Rucinski was worried about being blocked from doing interviews about a Welsh Government digital health initiative in December 2015 and an OECD report comparing UK health services in February 2016.
Rucinski mentioned that media interviews were part of his job and suggested that Merrill's orders might’ve come after she met with a Welsh Government minister.
He wrote, "I am genuinely concerned about the comments you have relayed from your meeting with the minister."
After Rucinski's suspension, there was a board meeting where Merrill aimed to straighten out the media coverage mess with him.
The meeting notes state that Merrill mentioned the "media embargo" applied just to him about the OECD report and hinted there was more to the decision than could be shared.
She wanted him to give a briefing before speaking publicly to ensure a solid media strategy.

The notes also touched on their talks about establishing a media protocol and said he shared one of Merrill's text messages with staff "without her knowledge and without context of previous discussions."
Mr. Netanyahu's comments have ruffled feathers at the White House, even though he's tried to tone things down afterwards.

The US and Israel have been at odds lately over several issues. Despite this, Mr. Obama described his relationship with Mr. Netanyahu as "businesslike," and pointed out, "I've met with him more than any other world leader." According to him, personal ties aren't what's fueling their disputes.
"He’s acting in his country's interest as he sees it, and I’m doing the same," he said.
"It's not about personal bonds, but a clear, substantive challenge," Mr. Obama insisted, adding, "This isn't just about everyone joining hands and singing 'Kumbaya'."
Earlier on Tuesday, Israeli officials dismissed claims that Israel was snooping on US-led negotiations.
Mr. Netanyahu has slammed the US's role in the nuclear talks, considering them a potential security threat to Israel.
Meanwhile, Mr. Obama has been critical of Mr. Netanyahu's pre-election remarks opposing the creation of a Palestinian state.
At a Tuesday press conference, initially focused on Afghanistan, President Obama sidestepped questions about the spying allegations from the Wall Street Journal.
Nevertheless, he assured that Israel and other regional allies have been kept in the loop about the talks.
Mr. Obama also expressed doubt that Mr. Netanyahu's attempts to clarify his pre-election stance would help support a two-state solution.
"Based on the prime minister's statements, it's tough to see how that would happen," he said.
"I've said before, and I'll say it again: during the election, Prime Minister Netanyahu mentioned a Palestinian state wouldn’t be realized while he's in charge.
I took him at his word," the president noted. In a US TV interview, Mr. Netanyahu voiced support for a two-state solution but emphasized that "circumstances have to change."
Mr. Obama admitted that Mr. Netanyahu didn't outright say a Palestinian state would "never" come to be.
Joe Robinson, a 24-year-old from Leeds, was nabbed in the seaside town of Didim, along with his fiancée, Mira Rojkan, and her mom.
The word is that he’s being accused of posting stuff on social media about his time in Syria with Kurdish militia.
His lawyer, Kaya Sertkaya, said, "We’re still uncertain when he'll appear in court."
Joe, a former British soldier who had been to Afghanistan, went to Syria in 2015 to hang out with the YPG, a Kurdish group that’s been fighting IS.

He’s been quite vocal about his experiences in the media. Now, Turkey sees the YPG as linked with the PKK, a Kurdish militant group that’s been around in Turkey since 1984, although the YPG isn't banned in the UK and is even a key US ally against IS.
His dad, Andrew Robinson, reached out for diplomatic support, telling the BBC, "Hearing he was arrested on terrorism charges was a gut punch. I had no idea about the situation in Turkey.
We're just hoping that maybe the government or Foreign Office will pitch in and help us get some clarity."
Sharon Robinson, Joe's mom, called the whole arrest "the most ridiculous thing I have ever heard in my life."
Sertkaya mentioned Joe is currently locked up in Aydin, western Turkey, on charges of "being a member of a terrorist organization."
He added, "I saw him yesterday; he seemed okay and in good spirits, but the legal process is in limbo.
With the state of emergency, these terror-related arrests really delay getting to court."
He also noted, "It's likely he'll be waiting at least three months for a court date."
The Foreign and Commonwealth Office put out a statement saying they're supporting the family and keeping in touch with Turkish authorities.

According to Guney Yildiz, a Turkish affairs analyst at the European Council on Foreign Relations, it's "not a surprise" that Joe might face legal troubles in Turkey, considering his past connections with a group regarded by Turkey as a security threat.

Sandwell Councillor Mahboob Hussain is in hot water, with accusations of breaching the council's code of conduct, and it’s not just one or two counts—six of them, according to Gowling WLG, the solicitors who’ve been digging into this mess.
More than a year ago, the law firm set out to uncover any funny business tied to the sale of old council properties.
Despite being suspended by Labour, Mr. Hussain insists he’s done nothing wrong.
Gowling's scrutiny focused on transactions between 2011 and 2013, zeroing in on sales that included three dilapidated public toilets and a rundown coroner's office in Smethwick.
Meanwhile, a police probe wrapped up in March, and they decided not to pursue any charges.
Legal challenges held up Gowling's report for a while, but finally, it got published on Friday "in the public interest," the council said.
Some details had slipped out to the BBC beforehand, spilling the beans on its findings.
Council Chief Executive Jan Britton mentioned the next move is referring these allegations to the internal standards committee for some serious reviewing.
A thorough audit will dive into land sale policies and consider potential disciplinary measures for staff.
The report lays out the claims that triggered the resignation of former economy chief councillor Mr. Jones, alongside Mr. Hussain, from their cabinet roles once the investigations kicked off.
Both of them managed to get their party suspensions lifted before the May elections, but Mr. Hussain is back on suspension, the party confirms.
Tipton Green ward councillor Mr. Jones, who’s been cleared, feels pretty good about the report’s release and its conclusions.
In his words, "I've consistently asserted my innocence and fully cooperated with all investigations."
Oldbury ward councillor Mr. Hussain claims he didn’t know who bought those toilets, as the purchases came via a company name instead of his buddy’s name.
He said he was clueless about the details and pricing of the deals. As for Mr. Hafeez, arrested last year but didn’t supply any evidence, he hasn't gotten back to the BBC’s further inquiries.
Police told him back in November 2015 that they wouldn't act against him. Mr. Hafeez noted that his arrest wasn’t linked to any Sandwell Council property sales and considered suing various parties.

It's quite the ironic twist: the council originally put an asset management plan in play to cut costs and streamline operations, hoping to save by shrinking into fewer buildings and making some cash from unloading surplus properties to balance out those pesky government cuts.
Over the last three years, police in England and Wales have talked to nearly 400 kids under 12.
The BBC found that since 2013, there have been over 4,000 cases where children made and shared explicit photos of themselves.
It’s illegal for anyone under 18 to have, create, or share sexual images, including if they’re of themselves.

In a pretty surprising case, a five-year-old from County Durham was interviewed by Durham Constabulary last year, making him the youngest involved in what the police term a sexting investigation, as per a query from BBC Newcastle.
Detective Chief Inspector Steve Thubron explained that these cases get dealt with individually, with a strong focus on child safety.
He reassured that while such incidents are logged following national crime recording standards, they don't result in the kids being criminalized.
"We team up with other organizations to guide teachers and young people," he said.
“We encourage any worried children to talk to a trusted adult or reach out to 101.” Usually, those caught up in sexting are around 13 or 14.
Interestingly, a 10-year-old boy was given a caution by Northumbria Police after he sent a sexual image of himself to an 11-year-old through Oovoo, a social media app for video and picture sharing.
Greater Manchester Police reported the most cases, with 695, including some involving four seven-year-olds and four eight-year-olds.
Even if there's no prosecution, after an indecent image is sent, it’s out of the sender's hands.
If it gets onto a public social media site, friends, family, or even potential employers might see it.
Many kids have talked about how a photo shared with someone in confidence ended up being spread far and wide.

Kerry Smith from Plan International UK, which advocates for children's rights, spoke on the BBC’s Victoria Derbyshire show about the gendered nature of sexting pressures. "Girls are more pressured to share images," she pointed out.
"And when they do, they get shamed, not the boys asking for or holding onto the images."
She stressed the need for education, saying that while awareness is there, it's vital to get this knowledge across to kids.
"Parents want this information shared with their children, and it’s critical for schools to make sure that happens," she added.
Joseph Rowbottom, 27, from Wrawby in North Lincolnshire, and Albert Venus, 22, from Hull, both lost their lives on May 24, 1915, during the Second Battle of Ypres.
Their bodies were unexpectedly discovered some 98 years later while construction crews were busy erecting a new housing development.
At their reburial in Ypres Town Cemetery, family members gathered to honor them, their coffins respectfully draped with the Union Jack.
In April 2013, along with their remains, the excavators unearthed shoulder titles from the North and East Riding Batteries of the RFA.
Thanks to the diligent work of the Ministry of Defence researchers, Rowbottom and Venus were identified from among the six sets of remains discovered.
John Howden, the 73-year-old great-nephew of Gunner Venus from Roos, East Yorkshire, received the folded flag from the coffin.
He shared, "When they gave me the flag, I felt a lump in my throat and had tears in my eyes.
I hadn't expected to be so affected. You feel distant, but suddenly you're involved, and it's emotional."
Howden learned about his great-uncle only after he received a letter from the MoD, and he spoke of his gratitude at the DNA confirmation.
On behalf of Gunner Rowbottom's family, Caroline Rowbottom, the granddaughter of his cousin, accepted the Union Jack.
Living in Brigg, North Lincolnshire, she expressed surprise upon getting the MoD's letter: "Until then, we were unaware of his existence; he wasn't in our family tree, which is very sad.
The ceremony was very moving and well-organized." Due to heightened security concerns following recent attacks in Brussels, the traditional five-gun salute was not carried out.
Before the war, local newspapers nicknamed Gunner Rowbottom "Milky Joe" for his job as a milkman.
As for Gunner Venus, he enlisted with the 2nd Northumbrian Brigade in December 1914, later moving to the Hull Batteries to complete his gunner training.
Joe Hart, 29, hasn't stepped onto the field for Manchester City this season, and the club's told him he can move on if he wants.
"It's a big concern," Sam Allardyce admitted during his chat on BBC Radio 5 Live, where he also mentioned he'd reveal his choice for captain this month.
Yet, the ex-Sunderland coach assured fans that Hart will still make the cut for the squad in next month's World Cup qualifier against Slovakia; the lineup is expected this Sunday.
Hart, who boasts 63 England caps, struggled in Euro 2016, with blunders against Wales and Iceland hastening England's departure in the last 16.
He's fallen out of favor with City's new boss, Pep Guardiola, while Argentine keeper Willy Caballero has been the regular starter so far.
Everton's interested in Hart, but he's not keen on moving to Sevilla or Borussia Dortmund, despite their interest in him.
Meanwhile, Barcelona just announced they're nearing a deal with City for goalkeeper Claudio Bravo.
"We want to see as many of our players getting regular starts for their clubs, which would then benefit them when playing for England," Allardyce explained.
"It's not as common now as it was 20 or 25 years ago, as the number of English players in the Premier League has dropped."

The first World Cup qualifier in Group F for England will be held in Trnava on September 4, marking Allardyce's debut match as England's manager following Roy Hodgson's resignation post-Iceland defeat.
Allardyce still ponders whether Manchester United's Wayne Rooney will retain his role as captain.
"I'll announce who's captain by Wednesday at the latest; everyone's asking," he said.
For more stories and updates, sign up for the BBC Sport newsletter delivered straight to your inbox.
Just winning Taiwan's presidential election, she's firm in believing that Taiwan's future is for its people to decide.
This stands as a direct challenge to China, which sees Taiwan as a breakaway province, and doesn’t shy away from using force to bring it back into the fold.
Beijing's trying to decode Ms. Tsai’s stance on Taiwan's sovereignty and her potential moves.
She's kept things pretty ambiguous, and not just with China—many in Taiwan view her as a quiet yet unpredictable force.
She describes herself as someone who prefers to stay out of the spotlight, calling her rapid political ascent an "accidental life."
But what's the big deal about this election? Is it all about the economy? And why is the China-Taiwan divide such a big thing?
Ms. Tsai is Taiwan's first female leader, but unlike other famous Asian women, she didn’t inherit a political legacy.
As the youngest of 11 from her dad's fourth wife, she had a comfortable upbringing.
Her father owned a thriving car repair shop and made good off land deals, but insisted she go to public schools to get a broader view of society.
She spent 30 years in academia, snagging a law degree from National Taiwan University, a master’s from Cornell, and a Ph.D. from the London School of Economics, eventually becoming a law professor.
Her law expertise and fluency in English caught attention in the 1990s when she served as a legal consultant for Taiwan's WTO entry negotiations, marking her entry into public service.

As a national security advisor to former President Lee Teng-hui, she helped shape his special state-to-state relations doctrine—portraying Beijing and Taipei as two separate countries, much to China's displeasure.
Under President Chen Shui-bian, during tense cross-strait relations, she led the Mainland Affairs Council, finding ways to interact with China despite the hostility.
She launched the groundbreaking "Small Mini Links" program in 2001, allowing direct ferries and trade between Taiwan’s outlying islands and mainland China.

Later, she pushed for the first chartered flights between the two. By 2003, even amid worries about opening up too fast to China, Ms. Tsai convinced Mr. Chen and lawmakers to amend Taiwan's law on relations with China to legalize Taiwanese business investments on the mainland.
Germany's Muller is snapping up the dairies operation responsible for milk processing and distribution for £80 million.
This comes after a steep plunge—a staggering 95% drop—in the UK's biggest dairy food company's profits, which dwindled down to £900,000 for the six-month period ending in September.
Dairy Crest churns through and delivers around 1.3 billion liters of milk each year, serving both retailers and homes.
In their statement, Dairy Crest mentioned the sale brings benefits to consumers, customers, and dairy farmers alike.
The dairies business makes up about 70% of the company's revenue, which ticked up 1% to hit £682.1 million over the same six months.
Once the sale gets the green light from shareholders, which could take a few months, Dairy Crest plans to zero in on its more lucrative cheese and spreads divisions.
In the UK, some 14,000 dairy farmers pump out 3.3 million liters of milk daily, though there's a heated debate about the industry's financial health thanks to falling milk prices.
Investors seemed to like Dairy Crest's game plan to step away from a struggling sector, pushing shares up by 10% during morning trades on Thursday.
Muller has high hopes that the acquisition will help slash costs and ramp up exports of UK dairy products.
Ronald Kers, Muller's CEO for the UK & Ireland, remarked: "We find the current conditions in the UK fresh milk market unsustainable for dairy processors over the medium to long term.
This acquisition gives us a chance to cut costs, improve efficiencies, and secure future investments."

As part of the deal, Muller Wiseman Dairies, Muller's UK unit, will take over factories in Foston (Derbyshire), Chadwell Heath (Essex), Severnside (near Gloucester), and the Hanworth glass bottling site in Middlesex, where Dairy Crest is currently consulting with staff about its future, along with 72 depots. Muller had earlier scooped up Robert Wiseman back in 2012.
The headmaster at Beaulieu Convent School in Jersey is raising eyebrows over how extravagant and pricey the school prom has become for parents.
He’s also worried about alcohol and drug use during the event for Year 11 students, who are 15 to 16 years old.
A former student thinks the school is overreacting, stressing how significant the prom is as a rite of passage.
Headmaster Chris Beirne argues that the prom is distracting from the school’s values.
In a letter to parents, he quoted a colleague who was critical of the event, calling the preparations neither positive nor worthwhile.
This colleague noted the financial strain and competitive atmosphere that many parents find overwhelming and pointed out concerns over substance use at after-parties.
The pressure to look slim, trendy, and have flawless skin is also said to be quite stressful. Mr. Beirne concluded he can't handle the risks tied to the prom.
So, instead, the school will hold a celebratory mass for Year 13 students and their families, followed by drinks.
Beaulieu Convent, where tuition runs £5,400 a year, has about 760 students from ages 4 to 18.
Hannah Hosegood, a 20-year-old alum, called the prom "a first taste of maturity" and suggested tackling issues like drugs or alcohol if they occur rather than scrapping the event entirely.
She’s disappointed that current students won’t get to experience something that's been anticipated and cherished for ages.
The former health minister is stirring the pot with a bold suggestion: NHS funding should come from a specific tax clearly marked on every payslip.
The idea, pitched by Mr. Lamb, wouldn’t hike up overall taxes since it’d be offset by cutting income tax or national insurance.
He’s sounding the alarm that the NHS seriously needs cash now to avoid sinking.
Just to be clear, this isn't official party policy yet and won’t be discussed at this year’s Bournemouth conference.
But Mr. Lamb, the health spokesperson, is genuinely intrigued by the thought of a unique NHS and care tax, separate and crystal clear on payslips.
He’s all for local areas having the option to boost funding for NHS and social care as well.
The Lib Dems are keen to roll out these concepts across the UK, though, with health and social care being devolved matters, exactly how this gets enforced is a big question mark.
Mr. Lamb, who lost to Tim Farron in the leadership race back in July, thinks a cross-party commission could really dig into these ideas.
He’s planning on chatting with everyone from health pros and patients to trade unions and academics.
While ministers have promised £2 billion for the NHS this year and another £8 billion by 2020, Mr. Lamb told the BBC that’s just not cutting it.
Unless more funds are funneled in, we could be staring at a £30 billion gap by 2020, thanks to the pressure from an aging population.
And let’s not forget social care, which he says is "on its knees," needing a £5 billion cash boost pronto.
Having seen the figures up close, Mr. Lamb is really worried. He's adamant that brushing off these challenges could spell disaster for the system.
Right now, taxpayers get a yearly breakdown of their tax contributions, including what goes to healthcare.
