A previous effort to create a cross-party social care commission before the 2010 election, in which Mr. Lamb played a role, ended up going nowhere.

At the upcoming charity event, he's set to dive into a Q&A with the audience. The dinner, taking place in Edinburgh on May 26, is shaping up to be one of his most notable speeches since leaving the White House.

Held at the EICC, it's being put together by The Hunter Foundation, which was founded by the well-known businessman and philanthropist, Sir Tom Hunter. A table for ten at this dinner is looking to fetch about £5,000.
In the past, The Hunter Foundation has brought big names like Bill Clinton, Leonardo DiCaprio, and George Clooney over to Scotland.

Just last year, DiCaprio made his way to Edinburgh, speaking at the Scottish Business Awards at the EICC and visiting Home, a restaurant on Queensferry Street that donates its profits to homeless services. Fans waited for hours in the pouring rain just to catch a glimpse of him.
The year before, George Clooney stopped by Social Bite on Rose Street, where he left $1,000 (about £650) for charity and met with a crowd of nearly 200 people.

The money raised from this event will go towards supporting children’s charities in Scotland and the Obama Foundation, which was founded by the former president and his wife, Michelle. Sir Tom plans to set aside some seats for local young people.
He remarked, "From the South Side of Chicago to the White House has been an epic, historic journey, and it's a true honor to hear that story from the man who made it.
We are both proud and delighted to host the 44th president of the United States in Scotland."
Speaking to the Press Association, Sir Tom expressed, "We're always seeking inspiring speakers for Scotland, and having President Obama is truly thrilling."
He hinted at a special surprise, saying, "President Obama loves music, so we have some exciting guests lined up."
During her five-day visit to the US, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon shared her enthusiasm with BBC Scotland from New York, saying she was "really excited" about the event.
"Many people in Scotland are eager to welcome President Obama and hear his insights," she added.
About a thousand people gathered outside the Senedd for a minute of silence and to light candles in remembrance.
Among them, over 2,000 French nationals living in South Wales were accounted for by the French consulate in London.
Marie Brousseau-Navarro, the Honorary Consul of France in Cardiff, shared how deeply touching the messages of support have been.
"We are united in shock and sorrow, alongside everyone marching globally," she said.
Saleem Kidwai, chairman of the Muslim Council of Wales, received warm applause when he encouraged everyone to "stand together, shoulder to shoulder."
He added, "My condemnation is absolute. Ultimately, truth will triumph over falsehood, and light will overcome darkness."
First Minister Carwyn Jones joined the crowd, holding a candle during the silence, while some participants held up pencils as a tribute.
The silence ended with applause. Earlier, Jones had noted, "Tonight's vigil in Cardiff Bay is a chance for the people of Wales to pay respects to the victims of the terrible Paris attack.
It's also a moment to show solidarity with the French and everyone who stands for our democratic values and freedoms, in the face of such senseless acts of terror."
Meanwhile, Welsh Secretary Stephen Crabb tweeted, "Standing with the French community in Wales and in support of freedom of speech everywhere.
6pm this eve. Senedd, Cardiff. #CharlieHebdo." As a show of unity, landmarks in London were lit up in the colors of the French flag.
World leaders also gathered in Paris for a massive unity march, which drew over a million people and overshadowed the marches of 700,000 the day before.
On Saturday, Swansea City striker Bafetimbi Gomis dedicated a goal in their team's 1-1 draw with West Ham to the Paris attack victims.
Police and media in Wales also observed a minute's silence for those affected by the Charlie Hebdo attack in Paris on Wednesday.
In the events that followed, a police officer lost their life on Thursday, and French forces stormed two hostage sites around Paris on Friday, ending the standoffs by killing three hostage takers.
Reflecting on the outpour of sympathy, Ms. Brousseau-Navarro said, "We have been truly moved by the hundreds of messages of support and condolences."
James Vaughan put Bury ahead in the 61st minute and quickly added a second goal six minutes later.
But the game took a sour turn for Bury when Niall Maher was sent off after giving away a penalty in the 70th minute, which Millwall’s Shaun Williams converted with ease.
As the clock ticked down to 86 minutes, Callum Butcher brought Millwall level with a headed goal.
In a dramatic twist, substitute Aiden O’Brien then scored the winner in stoppage time, marking Bury’s 10th consecutive loss—a grim record for them this season.
Earlier, Millwall found themselves initially awarded a penalty, only for referee Chris Sarginson to change his mind.
Vaughan had a near miss with a header, and Neil Danns saw his shot deflected wide.
Millwall pressed with chances from Harry Smith and Fred Onyedinma, and Joe Martin’s free-kick forced a sharp save.
Bury’s edge came from Danny Mayor’s cross that allowed Vaughan to score off the bar, and his second came from a precise Scott Burgess pass.
Maher’s handball blocked an Onyedinma shot, leading to the penalty Williams converted.
Bury’s keeper, Ben Williams, made a great save from an Onyedinma header, but eventually, Millwall equalized through Butcher’s header from a Shane Ferguson free-kick.

O’Brien sealed the win with a shot from a Mahlon Romeo cross in stoppage time. In the game's dying moments, Kelvin Etuhu saw yellow for a foul, Onyedinma secured a free kick for Millwall, and Danny Mayor struggled to convert chances for Bury.
Aiden O'Brien was cautioned as well for over-celebrating his winning goal, assisted by Onyedinma's play.
Antony Kay came close with a header for Bury, and Tom Pope gained a late free-kick due to a foul by O'Brien.
Another chance for Mayor was blocked, while Smith missed with a header for Millwall.
Towards the end, Alfie Pavey came on for Joe Martin in a Millwall substitution, and Ben Williams conceded a corner.
Shaun Williams’ header was saved at the lower left, making Millwall's victory a wrap. Final Score: Bury 2, Millwall 3.
Mark Bellamy, who heads the Intensive Care Society, told the BBC that without new and effective treatments, antibiotic resistance will just keep getting worse.
Sepsis, a serious condition arising from infections, results in about 37,000 deaths annually in the UK.
That's a staggering number, and NHS England is urging hospitals to band together to tackle this problem.
Sepsis often stems from blood poisoning, causing a fierce immune response that can quickly lead to organ failure or even death if not treated promptly.
Some early warning signs are fever and a racing heartbeat. To prevent more deaths, the Intensive Care Society recently launched a campaign to boost awareness about sepsis.
In the UK, those 37,000 annual sepsis deaths outnumber fatalities from both lung cancer and bowel cancer, with the former claiming just over 35,000 lives and the latter around 16,000.
The society, along with the UK Sepsis Trust, argues that hospitals don’t record sepsis cases diligently or have adequate knowledge on spotting and treating sepsis in its early stages.
Take the case of Julie Bignone, who nearly lost her life to sepsis. She spent seven weeks in the hospital, some of it in intensive care.

At first, she thought she had a bad flu and stayed in bed all weekend. It was only after visiting her GP and being told to come back if things got worse that her family, growing worried, called an ambulance. Turns out, she had pneumonia and sepsis, and her life hung in the balance.
It was intensive care and heavy doses of antibiotics that pulled her through. Julie says she should've trusted her gut when she felt something was seriously wrong.
“Because sepsis symptoms are vague, it’s easy to make mistakes. We need a system where doctors really listen to their patients' concerns,” she insists.

Professor Bellamy, from the Leeds Institute of Biomedical and Clinical Sciences, has recently encountered patients for whom antibiotics just didn’t work—a scenario he once thought was only theoretical.
He emphasizes the crucial role of raising sepsis awareness and ensuring quick intervention to improve survival odds.
He also warns about an unsettling "specter," hinting we're moving into a post-antibiotic era as these treatments lose their punch.
Ann Maguire, 61 years old, met a tragic end at Corpus Christi Catholic College in Leeds back in April 2014.
A student, Will Cornick, just 16, was handed a minimum 20-year prison sentence after admitting to her murder.
Mrs. Maguire's family has voiced worries that Cornick's guilty plea meant the details were never fully explored in court.
After dedicating 40 years to the school, Mrs. Maguire was on the verge of retirement.
Cornick, who was 15 at the time, attacked her cruelly from behind, stabbing her seven times in the neck and back while she was attending to another student.
Her husband, Don Maguire, has stressed the urgent need to understand if her death could have been prevented.
"With the guilty plea last year, there wasn't a full trial to really dig into all the evidence," he remarked.
"We believe an independent statutory review of all the facts is crucial so that lessons can be learned from this terrible event.

It left pupils and staff deeply shaken and shattered our family. An inquiry won't bring Ann back, but it will give us some peace, knowing if measures could have been taken to avoid this tragedy, sparing other families from such heartache."
The Department for Education (DfE) recognized the family's call for an inquiry into "the tragic events," noting that the Secretary of State is attentive to their concerns.
"We are aware that the Leeds Safeguarding Children Board has started a two-stage review to learn lessons, which we hope will be open and thorough," their statement read.
The DfE also mentioned that no decisions will be made until this review wraps up.
In the Premier League clash at St James' Park on Wednesday, it looked like Jonny Evans and Papiss Cisse were involved in a spitting incident.
Referee Anthony Taylor had a chat with both players after what happened in the first half, but didn't hand out any yellow cards.
The Football Association is waiting for Taylor's match report before deciding if they need to take action.
Just to put it into perspective, George Boyd was hit with a three-match ban in the past for spitting at Manchester City's Joe Hart.
But under the current regulations, such offenses now face a stiffer penalty of six matches.
Cisse might be in for a tougher time since he already saw red in December for elbowing Everton’s Seamus Coleman, potentially adding an extra match to his suspension as per FA rules.

The incident's stirred quite a bit of commentary from past players. Dietmar Hamann, who used to play in Newcastle's midfield, slammed the behavior as "unacceptable" and "disgusting," while Phil Neville, a former Manchester United defender, pointed out that both should be ashamed.
On BBC’s Match of the Day, Hamann warned of the negative impact on young viewers and said player conduct towards each other and officials is getting worse by the week.
Jermaine Jenas, another player who wore the Newcastle jersey, expressed his own disgust on BBC Radio 5 live, saying the game can do without such antics.
TV footage shows Evans spitting at Cisse while Cisse was down on the pitch, and Cisse seems to have reacted similarly.
Neither Newcastle manager John Carver nor Manchester United’s Louis van Gaal caught the event live.
Carver, whose team took a 1-0 loss, mentioned, "I can't comment on it. I just know there was a fracas on the halfway line."
As for van Gaal, he commented, "I don’t think Jonny Evans is a spitter. Maybe spitting on the floor, but from the bench, it’s impossible to see."

Media playback isn’t supported on this device At 32, the Welsh triathlete celebrated her first World Series win since 2012, breaking Gwen Jorgensen's 13-race winning streak and outpacing British rival Jodie Stimpson.
"Helen's truly made her mark," Stanford said, who, along with Vicky Holland, has already punched her ticket to Rio.

With the official announcement expected in June, two-time world champ Jenkins and Commonwealth champ Stimpson are in a tight race for a spot on Britain's women's triathlon team for the Rio Games this summer.
"Helen's shown what she's capable of," added Stanford, Jenkins' fellow Welsh athlete.
"British Triathlon really stressed the importance of demonstrating medal potential for Rio, and Helen's done just that.
She didn’t just win the race; she took down Gwen Jorgensen, the top pick for Rio’s gold.
Beating her definitely signals Helen’s medal potential, so it'd be quite the shock if she doesn't get selected."
Stimpson kicked off the season with a bang, winning the World Series opener in Abu Dhabi and the sprint World Cup in Australia.
But at the Gold Coast, she lagged, finishing 12th, over three minutes behind the race winner.
"Jodie started off brilliantly," said Stanford, the 2013 world champion. "That Gold Coast race was crucial, and unfortunately, she didn’t shine like we'd hoped.
She’d made a strong impression earlier in the year, though, so the selectors have a tough call to make."
After her Australian victory, Jenkins reflected: "The team's not been announced yet, but I feel I did what was needed today.
We've got an incredibly strong team, and it’s a bit of a sting knowing Jodie might miss out on the Games."
Back in March, Scotland's first minister inked an MOU with SinoFortone and another Chinese company, but it hit a snag.
The Scottish government blamed "hostility" from opposition parties for the deal's collapse, which was supposed to be worth a hefty £10bn.
It all went down at Nicola Sturgeon's official crib, Bute House, with SinoFortone Group and China Railway No.
3 Engineering Group (CR3). Critics were quick to jump on it, calling for a detailed response about this "regrettable episode."

The backlash wasn’t just about the deal's failure, though. Folks were uneasy because the parent company, China Railway Group, had been called out for human rights issues in an Amnesty International report and had even been blacklisted by Norway's oil fund.
Sturgeon tried to calm the waters, saying that any real concerns would halt specific deals, and promised that investments would be vetted by the Scottish Parliament.
In August, The Sunday Times broke the news that the deal had crumbled, calling it the "Scottish shambles" over in China.
Despite this, Economy Secretary Keith Brown's spokesperson played it down. He acknowledged the concerns but said they hadn’t believed the deal was entirely off.
He threw some shade at opposition parties for risking investments, stressing: "We didn’t think the MOU was completely canceled.
SinoFortone still sees a future here, even amid the political friction. We're open to future collaborations with China, which can boost Scotland's infrastructure.
The MOU was about building relationships, and we're keen to keep that door open."
Opposition parties weren't letting this slide, though. Labour's Jackie Baillie pushed for transparency, saying the government needed to clear the air urgently.
She remarked, "Scotland deserves clarity on this hush-hush deal. This whole affair casts doubt on the SNP ministers' transparency and skill.
This was a mess from the start, branded a 'shambles' for keeping it under wraps till it all collapsed, leaving Scots in the dark yet again."
Scottish Conservative economy spokesman Dean Lockhart chimed in, adding, "This episode proves the SNP isn’t reliable when it comes to handling the economy."
Cynthia Cheroitich, a 19-year-old student, found herself in a desperate situation, resorting to drinking body lotion to fight off hunger and thirst.
Her ordeal came to an end on Saturday morning when security forces, with the aid of a familiar teacher, convinced her that it was safe to come out.
Cynthia's nightmare began early Thursday morning around 5:30 (2:30 GMT), as she and her classmates were gearing up for exams.
"Out of nowhere, gunshots rang out, and everyone was wondering, 'What's going on?'"
Cynthia recounted to the Associated Press. In a panic, they dashed to their rooms, but the attackers pursued them.
Once inside, she hid beneath a bed, with others in the room. The attackers commanded them to emerge, but Cynthia chose a wardrobe to conceal herself, burying under clothes.
Her narrative echoes those of many survivors: her roommates were taken by the gunmen, separated based on their ability to recite Koran verses.
Their fate remains unclear. To survive, Cynthia discovered bottles of body lotion and drank them, despite the fear that kept her frozen in place.
"It was nice and lovely," she described, reflecting on the strange experience. All she could do was pray.
It wasn't until 10:00 on Saturday, after the chaos subsided, that the rescuers managed to convince her to leave her hiding spot.
Initially skeptical, worried they might be al-Shabab, she asked, "How do I know you're the Kenyan police?" Ultimately, a college staff member's reassurance was what led her to step out.
Norman Rimmington, or as everyone fondly called him, "Rimmo," first signed up with Barnsley back in 1945 as their goalkeeper, making a modest £3 a week.
His journey with the club was more than just playing—it was a lifelong commitment.
Over the years, he wore many hats: coach, assistant manager, groundskeeper, physio, and kit manager.
When his funeral procession passed by Oakwell Stadium, fans gathered to say their goodbyes, a testament to his impact.
Born in Staincross, Rimmo was known at Barnsley as a “fearless” goalkeeper. He played 27 matches before moving to Hartlepool United in 1947.

Aside from football, he worked hard as a pit fitter and mechanic. Rimmo made his way back to Barnsley in 1952 and stayed there, dedicating his life to the club until he passed away in late December at 93.
His funeral was held at All Saints Church in Darton, with a follow-up ceremony at Barnsley Crematorium, where family, friends, colleagues, and old teammates came together to remember him.
In a chat with BBC Sport, Rimmo fondly recalled the rough-and-tumble days as a keeper.
"You'd get a fair bit of stick," he chuckled. "They'd knock you into the back of the net, and it counted as a goal.
It’s a different game now—they go down like they've been shot, but there's nothing wrong with them."
Before he passed away, Rimmo was honored with the British Empire Medal for his outstanding contributions to football.
Reflecting on his deep connection to Barnsley, he said, "I was born here, raised here, and I've played here.
I love the club and everything I've done." Barnsley FC hailed him as “a true club legend,” someone who embodied pride and dedication throughout his life.

Here's a snapshot of his illustrious career: - Born on November 29, 1923, in Staincross, near Barnsley - Worked as a pit fitter and mechanic alongside his football endeavors - Played for Barnsley FC in 1946-47 with 27 appearances - Moved to Hartlepool United from 1947-52, making 127 appearances - Later years saw him return to Barnsley as an ‘A’ team coach from 1952-61 - Served as head coach and physio from 1961-72 - Took on the roles of groundsman and physio from 1972-78 - Became assistant manager and physio from 1978-80 - Continued as physio until 1985 - Finished his long tenure as kitman and laundry from 1985-2016.
Jono Gibbes, once a New Zealand player and now 40 years old, is stepping into the role of forwards coach at Clermont Auvergne.
He has a similar background from his time at Leinster. He’ll be reporting to Les Kiss, the director of rugby, yet the status of Neil Doak, the current head coach, isn't clear.
Gibbes mentioned, "My admiration for Les, both as a coach and a person, was a big reason for my choice."
Ulster is currently sitting in the sixth spot in the Pro12 and had a rough go, being knocked out of the European Champions Cup.
Gibbes elaborated, "Les talked to me about his vision for Ulster, and it was a big influence.
I've played against Ulster quite a bit. Recent games between Clermont and Ulster gave me a good look at their strong points, and I'm keen to dive into their setup next season."
Starting at Leinster in 2008, where he clinched three Heineken Cups, Gibbes noted, "Spending six years at Leinster and three at Clermont, I've worked with top-notch coaches and players.
I’m thrilled to bring what I've learned to Ulster, and my family is excited to settle into the lively Belfast community."
He moved to France in 2014 and helped push Clermont to the Top 14 and Champions Cup finals in his debut season.
Kiss, who’s 52, spoke highly of Gibbes: "Jono’s track record is outstanding, and he’s eager to join Ulster.
Since he hung up his boots, he’s been a crucial part of coaching at two leading European clubs.
He’s brilliant as a forwards coach, and his broad knowledge of the game will be a huge asset to us."
Kiss added, "We’re reworking our coaching plan for next season, and bringing Jono on board as head coach is the first step.
We’ll have more updates about our coaching lineup soon to make sure we get the balance just right."
Ms. Yellen mentioned that market valuations are currently "quite high," yet she doesn't see any bubbles forming on the horizon.
Over in the regional markets, it was Chinese stocks that took the hardest hit. The Shanghai Composite dropped 2.8% to finish at 4,112.21, notching its third day of losses in a row.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng didn't fare much better, falling 1.3% to 27,289.97 and keeping up a six-day losing streak.
This slide came after some companies on the mainland decided to offer shares, leading investors to pull money from other stocks.
Plus, there are worries about new regulatory moves in China, like capping margin financing and tightening what stocks can be bought with borrowed funds.
Meanwhile in Japan, the Nikkei 225 went down 1.23% to settle at 19,291.99, following a week's break for the holidays.
The Australian S&P/ASX 200 index also dipped, losing 0.82% to close at 5,645.70.
On Wednesday, Aussie stocks had their worst single-day drop in over two years, thanks to lackluster results from major banks.
There's some nervousness about what lies ahead for Australia's top four banks. National Australia Bank (NAB) reported a cash profit increase of 5.4% for the six months up to March.
Plus, NAB is gearing up for a colossal capital-raising move worth 5.5 billion Australian dollars ($4.4 billion; £2.8 billion), involving new shares.
They plan to spin off and list their troubled British bank, Clydesdale, to bolster their balance sheet.
This capital drive might just be the biggest in Australia's corporate history, according to the media.
In addition, investor mood took a hit from recent unemployment numbers, which rose slightly to 6.2% in April.
Over in South Korea, the Kospi index saw a 0.65% drop to 2,091.00 by the end of the day.
Whether people agree or disagree about Mr. Aamer, his return to the UK was a sigh of relief for many in Whitehall.
His 5,017 days in detention had really put a strain on the transatlantic relationship and made it tough for the government to connect with the most isolated Muslim communities.
Now back in the UK, he will get top-notch medical care, including a psychiatric evaluation, and finally meet the son born on the day he was taken to Guantanamo Bay.
But there's a flipside. Davis Lewin, representing the Henry Jackson Society—a think tank focused on security and foreign relations—warns that Mr. Aamer's return needs careful handling.
His legal team insists he’ll cooperate with monitoring, although they argue it's unnecessary since the allegations against him came from torture.
If MI5 decides to keep tabs on him, Mr. Aamer might not even realize it, given how discreet these operations usually are.
The bigger picture for the UK involves grappling with its legacy and lessons learned.
Critics have noted that the US wasn't the only country to falter on legal and moral fronts after 9/11.
London didn't advise Washington against the use of Guantanamo nor push for the return of British detainees from Afghanistan—a move critics say undermined Britain's core justice principles.
"Human rights, justice, and the rule of law are universal," says Andrew Mitchell, a former Conservative cabinet minister involved in the push for Mr. Aamer’s release.
"He's been deprived of these rights. It's awful for him, and we must uphold these principles to effectively fight terror.

We need to stick to the rule of law and recognize human rights for everyone." Moreover, some American interrogations relied on intelligence from Britain, which may point to British involvement in torture.
This has led many MPs to seek answers about the UK's actions right after 9/11. "An essential step is for [Shaker Aamer] to share his experiences here in Britain on camera," says Mr. Mitchell.
A father's decision to post a video inviting "everyone" to his daughter's party on Facebook certainly sparked some buzz.
Crescencio Ibarra, aiming to gather just neighbors and friends for the occasion, ended up extending the invitation to all.
The planned event, featuring local bands, food, and a horse race, became inadvertently open thanks to his vow not to turn anyone away.
In the video, Mr. Ibarra stands next to his daughter, Rubi, dressed in a tiara, with his wife Anaelda Garcia.
He addresses the camera, "Hello, how are you? We invite you to our daughter Rubi Ibarra Garcia's 15th birthday party on December 26th," with Rubi smiling beside him.
He mentions three bands set to play and promises a 10,000 pesos ($490; £390) prize for the winning horse racer, wrapping up with a heartfelt invite to all.
In Mexico, a girl's 15th birthday is a big deal, marking her step into adulthood.
It's common to see lavish ceremonies with live music, and the girls often dress up lavishly, enjoying their "queen for the day" status.
Why this particular video spread like wildfire—over 800,000 shares, tons of memes—is a bit of a mystery.
Mr. Ibarra, in a TV chat, confessed he couldn't tell what caught people's eye. "We just wanted to invite the locals," he explained, dismissing any rumors of a scaled-back guest list.
Although initially upset by the unexpected, occasionally mocking reactions toward their rural way of life, the family rolled with it and planned the bash outside La Joya, in San Luis Potosi.

Ms. Garcia lovingly referred to Rubi as her "queen" and chuckled about a meme showing Donald Trump and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto allowing undocumented Mexican migrants to return to Mexico just for Rubi's bash.
Meanwhile, local official Roberto Alejandro Segovia Hernandez promised that police would secure La Joya and nearby roads for crowd safety, a pledge that bred even more memes.
Rubi's older sister shared that Rubi is "very excited" and can't wait for the big party.
The proposal to introduce half an hour of free parking was shot down recently. Four DUP members of the Assembly had put forward the idea, but Infrastructure Minister Chris Hazzard wasn’t impressed.
He called their motion "seriously misguided," saying that administering a free parking system would swallow up a lot of resources.
Even with that shot down, the assembly did okay a Sinn Féin amendment to take a fresh look at how on-street parking is handled.
Hazzard chimed in to BBC News NI, saying, "I'm all for a review—a strategic dig into on-street car parking policy and where it's headed."
What he couldn’t back was the DUP’s plan, as it seemed to suggest slashing penalty fines right off the bat, without any review.

"That's just not the right way to go about it," he explained. The DUP motion was signed by former minister Edwin Poots and his colleagues William Humphrey, George Robinson, and Alex Easton, who were pushing for more wiggle room in parking policies to help businesses in towns and villages.
Looking back, parking enforcement in Northern Ireland was privatized back in 2006, with fines starting at £60.
Folks could get a 50% discount if they paid up in two weeks. Fast-forward to 2012, and Stormont MLAs decided to up those fines to £90—or £45 if you paid within 14 days.
Former Roads Minister Danny Kennedy thought that hiking the fines would be more effective in curbing dodgy parking.
The current minister pointed out that "at least two-thirds" of those fined do pay up quickly, grabbing that £45 rate.

"In many areas, this fine seems quite appropriate," Hazzard noted. Meanwhile, a Belfast City Council committee recently made the call to scrap the usual free parking during the Christmas season in the city center.
Barclays recently announced a 10% fall in pre-tax profits for the July-to-September quarter, bringing them down to £1.43 billion, apart from settlement costs.
This update came just a day after the bank revealed Jes Staley as the incoming CEO, starting in December.

Their non-core units, currently up for sale, aren't showing much progress. Losses ballooned to £337 million from these sectors, which include some investment bank assets and parts of the European retail banking division.
Barclays earmarked £270 million to settle claims over U.S. mortgage bonds and another £290 million to make up for unfavorable foreign exchange rates that affected some clients.
Meanwhile, the businesses Barclays plans to hold onto, like its UK High Street branches and Barclaycard, saw a slight profit increase of 1%, reaching £1.76 billion.
Factoring in a £560 million hit from one-offs and other costs and gains, pre-tax profits for the third quarter dipped to £861 million compared to £1.22 billion the year before.
Revenue also took a hit, dropping from £6.4 billion to £6.1 billion from June to September.

Staley, whose current role is with US hedge fund Blue Mountain Capital Management and who previously worked at JP Morgan, is set to replace Antony Jenkins, who was let go in July following disagreements with board members.
Staley's pay package consists of a £1.2 million salary, £396,000 in pension contributions, and potential bonuses up to £5.5 million, mostly in shares.
Additionally, he’ll receive an annual £1.15 million in shares that he has to hold onto for five years.
His total potential compensation could hit £8.2 million if he bags the full bonus.
Furthermore, he's set to receive Barclays shares worth roughly £1.93 million to replace what he lost from JP Morgan when leaving.
In his message to the team, Mr. Staley mentioned a focus on less capital-intensive areas in investment banking, like advising on mergers and facilitating stock trades—ideas analysts had floated.
Harrison Ford is gearing up to return as Indiana Jones in the series’ fifth installment, which is set to hit theaters in 2019.
During an interview with the BBC, Ford shared, "I've always felt we could make another one.

My condition was having Steven [Spielberg] and a solid script involved." Fortunately, both pieces are falling into place—Spielberg is penning a script that should meet everyone's expectations as he takes on the director's mantle once more.
Spielberg helmed the earlier four Indiana Jones adventures, all brought to life with production from George Lucas of Star Wars fame.
Ford first stepped into the iconic role in 1981 with Raiders of the Lost Ark, and continued in three more films, the last being 2008's Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull.
In a separate chat with the BBC coinciding with the Star Wars: The Force Awakens DVD release, Ford discussed his stint as Han Solo.
Even though Solo's character met his end in the film, Ford didn't rule out a return, saying, "Anything is possible in space."
He shared his desire for Han Solo's demise to mean something pivotal for the storyline, stating, "I wanted there to be some weight to the narrative."

Reflecting on his experience, Ford expressed, "Getting to work with talented actors, with a script I had confidence in, under a director who led with assurance and generosity—that was a true pleasure."
Still, he admitted he doesn't personally relate to the characters he plays: "I strive to give the characters an emotional depth that resonates with audiences.
I want them absorbed in the unfolding journey instead of feeling they truly know the character," Ford clarified.
Star Wars: The Force Awakens skyrocketed to become the UK's biggest hit of 2015, raking in an impressive £94.06m in just 16 days after its release.

The Electoral Commission's results are in, and Mr. Akufo-Addo from the New Patriotic Party (NPP) has clinched victory by securing over the essential 50% plus one vote, beating out his main rival, President John Dramani Mahama of the National Democratic Congress.
The inauguration of the president-elect is set for January 7, following a one-month transition.
Mr. Akufo-Addo, who faced losses in 2008 and 2012, earned respect for handling those defeats with grace.
Notably, in 2012, despite losing by 300,000 votes to President Mahama, he chose not to stir up mass protests or violence.
Instead, he took the matter to court and accepted the Supreme Court's verdict. At 72, he's got quite a history—his father, Edward Akufo-Addo, was once Ghana's Chief Justice and ceremonial President.
A promise he made back in 2012, for free high-school education, has been realized.
But the cornerstone of his campaign this time around was the "one district, one factory" initiative, a big push to industrialize the nation by setting up factories in each of the 216 districts.
During a rally in eastern Ghana, he stated, "The time has come for us to advance our industrial development.
We need jobs; the current government's lack of them threatens our country’s future stability."
Up north, he promised a functioning dam "in every village" to support agriculture.
Though critics from the NDC have shrugged these promises off as overly ambitious, Akufo-Addo remains unwavering, assuring they're grounded in reality.
His wife, Rebecca Akufo-Addo, played an active role in his campaign, painting a picture of him as a "very loving" family man during a TV interview.
"He is also deeply passionate about politics and has always cared about Ghana, wanting to contribute to the nation," she said.
Akufo-Addo has been a force in strengthening the NPP, which first contested elections in 1992 as Ghana transitioned back to multiparty democracy from military rule.
His political journey stretches over 40 years, beginning in his early 30s when he opposed the military government.
Educated in Ghana and the UK, he practiced law in France and served as an MP for the Abuakwa South constituency in eastern Ghana from 1996 to 2008.
In a chat with Andrew Marr on the BBC, Gen. Sir Nicholas Houghton voiced his concerns that not using nuclear weapons could really weaken Britain's deterrent strategy.
He also worried about this idea gaining traction politically. Following this, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn called on the defense secretary to address Sir Nicholas's remarks.
Corbyn argued that it's troubling when top military personnel step into political debates, stressing that they need to stay neutral in our democracy.

He accused Sir Nicholas of stepping outside the constitutional line by publicly engaging in political dialogue and said he'd officially ask the defense secretary to ensure the armed forces remain impartial.

Corbyn, who's been a key player in the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, stirred the pot at a party conference, clashing with his shadow cabinet when he declared he'd never authorize the use of nuclear weapons.

He later backed Scottish Labour's stand against Trident. As Labour leader, Corbyn has pushed against renewing Trident and champions an international nuclear weapons treaty aimed at a world free of such arms.
Sir Nicholas weighed in on Corbyn's stance, voicing worry that his refusal to use nuclear weapons might influence political authority.

He explained that deterrence hinges on the credible possibility of deploying them; the idea is that their mere presence prevents conflict, and if a prime minister publicly commits to never using them, "the deterrent is then completely undermined."
According to Sir Nicholas, many politicians only grasp this nuance when they're actually in power.
After attending a wreath-laying event in his Islington North constituency following Remembrance Sunday services at the Cenotaph, Corbyn commented that Sir Nicholas's remarks were less than helpful.
On Channel 4 News, Corbyn pointed out that in a democracy, it's the elected officials who are supposed to make political choices.
He invited Sir Nicholas to discuss any concerns with him directly, suggesting, "If he's worried, he ought to come and talk to me about it."
Four men—John Collins, 74, Terry Perkins, 67, Brian Reader, 76, and Daniel Jones, 58—admitted their involvement in the notorious Hatton Garden heist during a hearing at Woolwich Crown Court.

This daring raid targeted the Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Company in London’s famed jewelry district, leading to the theft of goods worth over £10 million as more than 70 safety deposit boxes were cleared out.

Arrested back in May, Perkins from Heene Road in Enfield, Collins from Bletsoe Walk in Islington, Jones from Park Avenue in Enfield, and Reader from Dartford Road in Dartford fessed up to conspiring to burgle, having planned to loot the deposit company between January 1 and April 7.

Interestingly, although they faced additional charges of conspiring to transfer or conceal stolen property, the prosecution opted not to pursue these after securing their admissions for the burglary conspiracy.
Hatton Garden Safe Deposit’s fate took another turn as a law firm recently revealed that the company’s insolvency has led to liquidation, unable to pay off debts owed to several creditors.
These four are yet to be sentenced. The Met Police was left in hot water post-burglary due to a lack of response when an intruder alarm triggered at the scene.
They’ve since expressed regret for not following protocol, vowing to dig deeper into why the alarm was deemed not urgent.
There’s more to come, as five others are awaiting their day in court, pleading not guilty to burglary conspiracy.

Hugh Doyle, 48, from Riverside Gardens, Enfield, William Lincoln, 60, from Winkley Street, Bethnal Green, and John Harbinson, 42, from Beresford Gardens, Benfleet, Essex, will stand trial in November, denying involvement in laundering charges too.
Meanwhile, Paul Reader, 50, of Dartford Road, and Carl Wood, 58, of Elderbeck Close, Cheshunt, Hertfordshire, haven’t yet entered their pleas.
It’s not just these men facing charges; Perkins’ daughters and their husbands appeared in court over similar accusations related to the ill-gotten gains from January 1 to May 19.

Brenn Walters, known as Ben Perkins, 43, Laura Perkins, 40, from Manor Court, Enfield, along with Terri Robinson, 35, and Steven Robinson, 46, from Sterling Road, Enfield, found themselves charged last month for their alleged roles in the heist.
